column2: One’s seat, bed, vehicle, wife, children and watervessel are pure for one’s self.

column1: ātmanaḥ śuciretāni pareṣāṃ na śucirbhavet /
column2: But they are not pure for others.

column1: bhārākrāntasya gurviṇyāḥ panthā deyo guruṣvapi //
column2: Even preceptors should leave way for pregnant women afflicted by the weight.

column1: na paśyeccārkamudyantannāstaṃ yāntaṃ na cāmbhasi / nekṣennagnāṃ striyaṃ kūpaṃ śūnāsthānamaghaughinaṃ //
column2: One should not look at the rising or setting Sun or in the waters. One should not look at naked woman. One should not peep into the well and look at a dog, or drinking house and a sinner.

column1: antaḥpuraṃ vittigṛhaṃ paradautyaṃ brajenna hi // nārohedviṣamānnāvanna vṛkṣaṃ na ca parvataṃ /
column2: One should not enter the apartments of women or treasury. One should not go as an emissary of another person. One should not board an uneven boat, or climb a tree or a mountain.

column1: arthāyatanaśāstreṣu tathaiva syāt kutūhalī //
column2: One should then be interested in sciences relating to acquisition of wealth.

column1: loṣṭamardo tṛṇacchedī nakhakhādī vinaśyati /
column2: One who tramples on clod of earth, one who cuts the grass and one who eats the nail would perish.

column1: mukhādivādanaṃ nehed vinā dīpaṃ na rātrigaḥ // nādvāreṇa viśedveśma na ca vaktraṃ virāgayet /
column2: One should not desire to raise sounds with the mouth. One should not stir out in the night without a lamp. One should not enter a house not having a door.

column1: kathābhaṅgaṃ na kurvīta na ca vāsoviparyayaṃ // bhadraṃ bhadramiti brūyānnāniṣṭaṃ kīrtayet kvacit /
column2: One should not interrupt in the midst of a conversation. One should not wear other’s garments. One should always say good. One should never utter that which does not please others.

column1: pālāśamāsanaṃ varjyaṃ devādicchāyayā vrajet //
column2: Seat made of palāśa wood is prohibited. One should move in the shade of gods etc.

column1: na madhye pūjyayoryāyāt nocchiṣṭastārakādidṛk /
column2: One should not go in between revered people. One should not look at the broken and falling asterism.

column1: nadyānnānyāṃ nadīṃ brūyānna kaṇḍūyed dvihastakaṃ //
column2: One should not utter the name of another river while standing in one river. One should not gargle with two hands.

column1: asantarpya pitṝn devānnadīpārañca na vrajet /
column2: One should not cross the river without propitiating the forefathers and gods.

column1: malādiprakṣipennāpsu na nagnaḥ snānamācaret //
column2: One should not throw impurities like feces in the waters. One should not bathe remaining naked.

column1: tataḥ samabhigaccheta yogakṣemārthamīśvaraṃ /
column2: Then one should worship lord Īśvara Śiva for the sake of welfare and prosperity, One should not remove one’s garland oneself.

column1: srajannātmanāppanayet kharādikarajastyajet //
column2: One should avoid the dust of an ass and other animals. One should not ridicule mean people.

column1: hīnānnāvahaset gacchennādeśe niyasecca taiḥ /
column2: One should not go with them and live with them.

column1: vaidyarājanadīhīne mlecchastrībahunāyake // rajasvalādipatitair na bhāṣeta keśavaṃ smaret /
column2: One should not also reside at a place devoid of a physician, a king and a river, a place ruled by other races, women and many men. One should not converse with women in their monthly menstrual courses or otherwise fallen.

column1: nāsaṃvṛtamukhaḥ kuryāddhāsaṃ jṛmbhāṃ tathā kṣutaṃ // prabhorapyavamanaṃ khadgopayedvacanaṃ budhaḥ /
column2: One should not laugh, yawn and sneeze without covering the mouth. A wiseman should avoid disrespect shown to his master and his own self. One should guard the words of one’s self and his master.

column1: indriyāṇāṃ nānukūlī vedarodhaṃ na kārayet //
column2: One should not yield to the dictates of his organs. One should not control the natural impulses of the body.

column1: nopekṣitavyo vyādhiḥ syādripuralpo 'pi bhārgava / rathyātigaḥ sadācāmet vibhṛyānnāgnivāriṇī //
column2: O Bhārgava! One should not ignore a disease like an insignificant enemy. One should always sip waters for purification whenever one goes in the street.

column1: na huṅkuryācchivaṃ pūjyaṃ pādaṃ pādena nākramet /
column2: One should not carry water and fire. One should not utter huṃ to a good and venerable person.

column1: pratyakṣaṃ vā parokṣaṃ vā kasya cinnāpriyaṃ vadet //
column2: One should not speak something unpleasant to someone either in his presence or his absence.

column1: vedaśāstranarendrarṣidevanindāṃ vivarjayet /
column2: One should refrain from abusing the scriptures, king, sages and gods.

column1: strīṇāmīrṣā na kartavyā triśvāsantāsu varjayet //
column2: One should not envy women and one should avoid having faith in them.

column1: dharmaśrutiṃ devaratiṃ kuryāddharmādi nityaśaḥ /
column2: One should hear righteous things, have devotion to gods and adhere to righteous path.

column1: somasya pūjāṃ janmarkṣe vipradevādipūjanaṃ //
column2: One should worship Soma moon as well as gods and brahmins in the natal star.

column1: ṣaṣṭhīcaturdaśyaṣṭamyāmabhyaṅgaṃ varjayettathā /
column2: One should avoid bathing with the application of oil on the sixth, eighth and fourteenth days of the fortnight.

column1: dūrādgṛhān mūtraviṣṭhe nottamaivairamācaret //
column2: One should pass urine and stools far away from the house. One should not have enmity with great men.

column1: dravyaśuddhiṃ pravakṣyāmi punaḥpākena mṛṇmayaṃ /
column2: shall describe the mode of purification of things .

column1: śuddhyen mūtrapurīṣādyaiḥ spṛṣṭāmraṃ suvarṇakaṃ // āvartitañcānyathā tu vāriṇāmllena tāmrakaṃ / kṣāreṇa kāṃsyalohānāṃ muktādeḥ kṣālanena tu //
column2: Earthen vessel made impure by contact with urine or feces would become pure by heating again. A copper and gold vessel similarly made impure may be made pure by melting or the copper one by water or acid. The vessels made of bellmetal and copper may be purified with acid.

column1: śākarajjumūlaphalavaidalānāṃ tathaiva ca //
column2: Lotuses, vessels made of iron, vegetables, ropes, roots, fruits and cane could be made pure by washing.

column1: mārjanādyajñapātrāṇāṃ pāṇinā yajñakarmaṇi /
column2: The sacrificial vessels are made pure by sprinkling water with hand at the sacrificial work.

column1: uṣṇāmbunā sasnehānāṃ śuddhiḥ sammārjanādgṛhe //
column2: Those made of oily things such as wax could be purified with hot water being sprinkled in the house.

column1: bahuvastre prokṣaṇācca dāravāṇāñca takṣaṇāt //
column2: Muddy water may be purified by straining it through a cloth, or by sprinkling on many cloth.

column1: prokṣaṇāt saṃhatānāntu dravāṇāñca tathotplavāt /
column2: Wooden things get purified that moment by sprinkling with water.

column1: śayanāsanayānānāṃ śūrpasya śakaṭasya ca // śuddhiḥ samprokṣaṇāj jñeyā palālendhanayos tathā / śuddhārthakānāṅkalkena śṛṅgadantamayasya ca //
column2: Liquid materials which have become solidified would become pure by sprinkling or by leaping up. A bed, seat, vehicle, winnowing basket and cart would become purified by sprinkling water, as also in the case of straw and fuel. Things made of the horn and tusk may be purified by a paste of white mustard.

column1: gobālaiḥ palapātrāṇāmasthnāṃ syācchṛṅgavattathā / niryāsānāṃ guḍānāñca lavaṇānāṃ ca śoṣaṇāt //
column2: A vessel containing flesh may be purified with cow’s tail. Bones have to be purified as in the case of horns. Molasses of jaggery and solution of salt may be purified by drying.

column1: kuśumbhakusumānāñca ūrṇākārpāsayos tathā /
column2: Safflower, flowers, wool and cotton may be purified in the same manner.

column1: śuddhannadīgataṃ toyaṃ puṇyantadvat prasāritaṃ //
column2: The flowing water of a river is pure. So also the water that remains spreads out.

column1: mukhavarjañca gauḥ śuddhā śuddhamaśvājayormukhaṃ / nārīṇāñcaiva vatsānāṃ śakunīnāṃ śuno mukhaṃ //
column2: A cow is pure except in its mouth. The mouths of a horse and goat are impure. The mouths of women, calves of cows, birds and of dogs are pure.

column1: mukhaiḥ prasravaṇe vṛtte mṛgayāyāṃ sadā śuci /
column2: While hunting a dog dripping water from its mouth is always pure.

column1: bhuktvā kṣutvā tathā suptvā pītvā cāmbho vigāhya ca // rathyāmākramya cācāmedvāso viparidhāya ca /
column2: One should sip water thrice for purification after eating, sneezing, sleeping, drinking water, having had a dip in the water, walking on the street and having changed the dress worn.

column1: mārjāraś caṅkramācchuddhaś caturythe 'hni rajasvalā //
column2: A women in her menstrual courses becomes pure after bathing on the fourth day.

column1: snātā strī pañcame yogyā daive pitrye ca karmaṇi / pañcāpāne daśaikasminnubhayoḥ sapta mṛttikāḥ //
column2: She becomes eligible to take part in rites relating to gods and manes. In impurity due to the apāna one of the airs in the body five parts of mud should be used, fifteen parts in purification after urine and seventeen parts in impurity due to feces.

column1: ekāṃ liṅge mṛdaṃ dadyāt karayostridvimṛttikāḥ /
column2: One should apply one part of mud to the penis and three times two parts of mud on both hands.

column1: brahmacārivanasthānāṃ yatīnāñca caturguṇaṃ //
column2: For the brahmacārins students, the foresters and ascetics it is laid as four times.

column1: śrīphalair aṃśupaṭṭānāṃ kṣaumāṇāṅgaurasarṣapaiḥ /
column2: Silken cloth are purified with śrīphala emblic myrabolan, white cloth with white mustard.

column1: śuddhiḥ paryukṣya toyena mṛgalomnāṃ prakīrtitā //
column2: It is said that the hairs of animals would be purified by sprinkling water.

column1: puṣpāṇāñca phalānāñca prokṣaṇājjalato 'khilaṃ /
column2: Flowers, fruits etc. would get purified by sprinkling water.

column1: pretaśuddhiṃ pravakṣyāmi sūtikāśudhhimeva ca /
column2: shall describe purification after death and after the birth of a child.

column1: daśāhaṃ śāvamāśaucaṃ sapiṇdeṣu vidhīyate //
column2: The pollution due to the death of a sapiṇḍa is prescribed for ten days.

column1: janane ca tathā śuddhirbrāhmaṇānāṃ bhṛgūttama / dvādaśāhena rājanyaḥ pakṣādvaiśyo 'tha māsataḥ //
column2: O Excellent among Bhṛgus descendants of Bhṛgu! So also purification from pollution is after birth in the case of brahmins, after twelve days for the warrior class, after fifteen days for the tradesmen, and after a month for śūdra fourth class.

column1: śūdro 'nulomato dāse svāmitulyantvaśaucakaṃ /
column2: If the dead belongs to the higher class, the pollution for the servant of the lower class would be as for the master.

column1: ṣaṭbhistribhirathaikena kṣatraviṭśūdrayoniṣu // brāhmaṇaḥ śuddhimāpnoti kṣatriyastu tathaiva ca /
column2: A brahmin or a person of the warrior class who had his birth through the warrior, tradesman or śūdra gets purified after six or three or one day in order.

column1: viṭśūdrayoneḥ śuddhiḥ syāt kramāt paraśurāmaka // ṣaḍrātreṇa trirātreṇa ṣaḍbhiḥ śūdre tathā viśaḥ /
column2: O Paraśurāma! if born of a tradesman and śūdra purification would be after six or three nights respectively and if born of a śūdra and tradesman purification would be after six nights.

column1: ādantajananāt sadya ācūḍānnaiśikī śrutiḥ // trirātramāvratādeśāddaśarātramataḥ paraṃ /
column2: If one’s child dies before the formation of teeth, one become pure at once, if it dies before tonsure, the parent has pollution for a night, if before the vratabandha vow relating to investiture of thread pollution lasts for three nights, and ten nights if afterwards.

column1: ūnatraivārṣike śūdre pañcāhācchuddhiriṣyate //
column2: If a śūdra dies at less than three years of age, the purification should be after five days.

column1: dvādaśāhene śuddhiḥ syādatīte vatsaratraye / gataiḥ saṃvatsaraiḥ ṣaḍbhiḥ śuddhirmāsena kīrtitā //
column2: If aged more than three, purification would be after twelve days, if aged six years, the purification would be after a month.

column1: strīṇāmakṛtacūḍānāṃ viśuddhir naiśikī smṛtā /
column2: If a female child dies before tonsure, the purification would be after a night.

column1: tathā ca kṛtacuḍānāṃ tryahācchuddhyanti bāndhavāḥ //
column2: Similarly, the relatives of female children dying after tonsure get purified in three days.

column1: vivāhitāsu nāśaucaṃ pitṛpakṣe vidhīyate / piturgṛhe prasūtānāṃ viśuddhir naiśikī smṛtā //
column2: No pollution is laid down for the parental side if a female dies after marriage. If a woman delivers a child in her parent’s house, the relatives get purified after a night.

column1: sūtikā daśarātreṇa śuddhimāpnoti nānyathā /
column2: A woman after childbirth gets purified after ten days and not otherwise.

column1: vivāhitā hi cet kanyā mriyate pitṛveśmani // tasyāstrirātrācchuddhyanti bāndhavā nātra saṃśayaḥ /
column2: There is no doubt that if a married girl dies in her father’s house, the relatives get purified after three nights.

column1: samānaṃ labdhaśaucantu prathamena samāpayet // asamānaṃ dvitīyena dharmarājavaco yathā /
column2: If two pollutions take place and the second one is equal or inferior to the first one, the pollution ends with the first one, and ends with the second one if the second is not equal. These are the words of Dharmarāja.

column1: deśāntarasthaḥ śrutvā tu kulyāṇāṃ maraṇodbhavau // yaccheṣaṃ daśarātrasya tāvadevaśucirbhavet /
column2: One who lives abroad happening to hear the news about the death of his kinsmen would be impure only for the remaining part of the ten days of impurity.

column1: atīte daśarātre tu trirātramaśucirbhavet //
column2: If it is known after ten days, impurity would last for three days.

column1: tathā saṃvatsare 'tīte snāta eva viśuddhyati /
column2: Then if one year had elapsed, one would become pure after bathing.

column1: mātāmahe tathātīte ācārye ca tathā mṛte //
column2: One has to do as before if either the maternal grandfather or the preceptor dies.

column1: rātribhirmāsatulyābhirgarbhasrāve viśodhanaṃ /
column2: One gets purified after abortion after the same number of nights proportionate to the months period of pregnancy.

column1: sapiṇde brāhmaṇe varṇāḥ sarva evāviśeṣataḥ // daśarātreṇa śuddhyanti dvādaśāhena bhūmipaḥ / vaiśyāḥ pañcadaśāhena śūdrā māsena bhārgava //
column2: O Bhargava son of Bhṛgu whoever of a sapiṇḍa of a brahmin caste may die the pollution ends after ten days for all without any distinction. So also for a warrior class it would end after twelve days, the tradesmen after fifteen days and the śūdras after a month.

column1: ucchiṣṭasannidhāvekaṃ tathā piṇḍaṃ nivedayet / kīrtayecca tathā tasya namagotre samāhitaḥ //
column2: A ball should be made and offered from the remnants of the ceremony and placed in front. One who does the deed should then declare the name and clan of that person dead.

column1: bhuktavatsu dvijendreṣu pūjiteṣu dhanena ca / visṛṣṭākṣatatoyeṣu gotranāmānukīrtanaiḥ // caturaṅgulavistāraṃ tatkhātantāvadantaraṃ /
column2: After the excellent brahmins had partaken food, were well honoured with gifts and had blessed with unbroken rice and water with the recitation of the name and clan of the doer, one should dug up three pits of four cubits breadth and depth and of twelve cubits length.

column1: vitastidīrghaṃ kartavyaṃ vikarṣūṇāṃ tathā trayaṃ //
column2: Near the pits one should kindle three fires.

column1: somāya vahnaye rāma yamāya ca samāsataḥ // juhuyādāhutīḥ samyak sarvatraiva catustrayaḥ /
column2: O Rāma Paraśurāma one should offer oblations to Soma, Agni Fire god and Yama four handfuls three times each.

column1: piṇḍanirvapaṇaṃ kuryāt prāgvadeva pṛthak pṛthak // annena dadhnā madhunā tathā māṃsena pūrayet /
column2: Balls of rice should be offered separately in each one of theseas before. One should fill pits with cooked rice, curd, honey and flesh.

column1: madhye cedadhimāsaḥ syāt kuryādabhyadhikantu tat //
column2: If an intercalary month occurs this should be done in addition.

column1: athavā dvādaśāhena sarvametat samāpayet /
column2: Or this ceremony should be completed in twelve days.

column1: saṃvatsarasya madhye ca yadi syādadhimāsakaḥ // tadā dvādaśake śrāddhe kāryaṃ tadadhikaṃ bhavet /
column2: If an intercalary month occurs in the middle of the year, then there would be extra rites at the time of doing the twelfth ceremony.

column1: saṃvatsare samāpte tu śrāddhaṃ śrāddhavadācaret //
column2: After the completion of one year the ceremony should be done as the annual ceremony.

column1: pretāya tata ūrdhavaṃ ca tasyaiva puruṣatraye /
column2: If one dies balls of rice should be offered to the ancestors of the three past generations.

column1: piṇḍān vinirvapettadvaccaturastu samāhitaḥ // sampūjya datvā pṛthivī samānā iti cāpyatha / yojayet pretapiṇḍaṃ tu piṇḍeṣvanyeṣu bhārgava //
column2: O Bhārgava! After having worshipped and offering ball of rice with the recitation of syllables pṛthvī samānā, the ball of rice intended for the dead should be united with those intended for the other ancestors.

column1: pretapātraṃ ca pātreṣu tathaiva viniyojayet /
column2: So also the vessel for the dead should be united with the vessels for the ancestors.

column1: pṛthak pṛthak prakartavyaṃ karmaitat karmapātrake //
column2: This rite of uniting the vessels should be done one by one.

column1: mantravarjamidaṃ karma śūdrasya tu vidhīyate /
column2: This rite is laid down without the recitation of syllables for the śūdra.

column1: sapiṇḍīkaraṇaṃ strīṇāṃ kāryamevaṃ tadā bhavet //
column2: The rite of sapiṇḍīkaraṇa should be done in the same way for women.

column1: gaṅgāyāḥ sikatā dhārā yathā varṣati vāsave //
column2: One may be able to count the sand particles in the Ganges or the rain drops as Indra rains.

column1: śakyā gaṇayituṃ loke natvatītāḥ pitāmahāḥ /
column2: But one may not be able to count in this world the past ancestors.

column1: kāle satatage sthairyaṃ nāsti tasmāt kriyāṃ caret //
column2: In the evermoving time there is no permanence. Hence, one should do the deeds.

column1: devatve yātanāsthāne pretaḥ śrāddhaṃ kṛtaṃ labhet /
column2: The dead would get the results of ceremony whether they are in heaven or in hell.

column1: nopakuryānnaraḥ śocan pretasyātmana eva vā // bhṛgvagnipāśakāmbhobhirmṛtānāmātmaghātināṃ / patitānāṃ ca nāśaucaṃ vidyucchastrahatāś ca ye //
column2: There is no pollution due to the death of a person by falling from a cliff, burnt by fire, in a trap, by drowning in the water or by suicide. There is no pollution on account of the death of those fallen from their caste and those killed by lightning and weapons.

column1: yatibratibrahmacārinṛpakārukadīkṣitāḥ / rājājñākāriṇo ye ca snāyādvai pretagāmyapi //
column2: Ascetics, those who have undertaken vows, studentcelibates, kings, sculptors and those initiated for religious ceremonies and those under the command of the king should bathe, if they had followed the dead body.

column1: maithune kaṭadhūme ca sadyaḥ snānaṃ vidhīyate /
column2: Immediate bathing is laid down after copulation and coming across smoke from a burning dead body.

column1: dvijaṃ na nirharet pretaṃ śūdreṇa tu kathañcana // na ca śūdraṃ dvijenāpi tayordoṣo hi jāyate /
column2: A śūdra should never carry the dead body of a brahmin. So also a brahmin should not carry the dead body of a śūdra. There would arise sin from these.

column1: anāthaviprapretasya vahanāt svaragalokabhāk //
column2: One would reach heaven by carrying the dead body of a destitute brahmin.

column1: saṅgrāme jayamāpnoti prete 'nāthe ca kāṣṭhadaḥ / saṅkalpya bāndhavaṃ pretamapasavyena tāṃ citiṃ //
column2: One who gifts fuel for burning the dead body of a destitute person would get victory in battle. One who performs the cremation of the dead should solemnly vow that he is a relative and then circumambulate the funeral pyre in the anticlock direction.

column1: parikramya tataḥ snānaṃ kuryuḥ sarve savāsasaḥ /
column2: After the completion of cremation rite all should get out and bathe with their clothes.

column1: pretāya ca tathā dadyustrīṃstrīṃś caivodakāñjalīn //
column2: Then handful of water should be offered thrice for the dead.

column1: dvāryaśmani padaṃ datvā praviśeyus tathā gṛhaṃ / akṣatānnikṣipedvahnau nimbapatraṃ vidaśya ca //
column2: After that one should enter the house after placing the foot on a stone at the entrance to the house. Unbroken rice should be offered to the fire and margosa leaves should be eaten.

column1: pṛthak śayīran bhūmau ca krītalabdhāśano bhavet /
column2: All should sleep separately on the floor. One should eat light food that has been bought.

column1: ekaḥ piṇdo daśāhe tu śmaśrukarmakaraḥ śuciḥ // siddhārthakaistilair vidvān majjedvāsoparaṃ dadhat /
column2: The learned one who offered the ball of rice becomes pure after shaving, bathing with white mustard and sesamum and wearing different clothes on the tenth day.

column1: ajātadante tanaye śiśau garbhasrute tathā // kāryo naivāgnisaṃskāro naiva cāsyodakakriyā /
column2: Neither cremation with fire, nor the rites of offering waters should be done in the case of the death of children who had not grown teeth and in the case of abortion.

column1: caturthe ca dinekāryas tathāsthnāṃ caiva sañcayaḥ //
column2: The gathering of the bones of the cremated should be done on the fourth day.

column1: asthisañcayanādūrdhvamaṅgasparśo vidhīyate //42//
column2: Denotes Paraśurāma. See . fn . cf.

column1: srāvāśaucaṃ pravakṣyāmi manvādimunisammataṃ /
column2: shall describe the pollution due to abortion accepted. by Manu and others.

column1: rātribhirmāsatulyābhirgarbhasrāve tryaheṇa yā //
column2: In the case of abortion pollution lasts so many nights proportionate to the period of pregnancy for the mother.

column1: cāturmāsikapātānte daśāhaṃ pañcamāsataḥ /
column2: the pollution lasts for three days, after five months for ten days.

column1: rājanye ca catūrātraṃ vaiśye pañcāhameva ca //
column2: It lasts for four nights in the case of royal people, and for five days in the case of tradesmen.

column1: aṣṭāhena tu śūdrasya dvādaśāhādataḥ paraṃ /
column2: It lasts for eight days in the case of śūdra and for twelve days in the case of others.

column1: strīṇāṃ viśuddhiruditā snānamātreṇa vai pituḥ //
column2: Purification hasbeen prescribed for women. But the father of the abortive becomes pure by bathing alone.

column1: na snānaṃ hi sapiṇḍe syāttrirātraṃ saptamāṣṭayoḥ /
column2: No bathing has been laid down for those who are sapiṇḍas. If the abortion occurs in the seventh or eighth month, pollution lasts for three nights.

column1: sadyaḥ śaucaṃ sapiṇḍānāmādantajananāttathā //
column2: In the case of the death of a child after the appearance of the teeth, the sapiṇḍas become purified immediately.

column1: ācūḍādekarātraṃ syādāvratācca trirātrakaṃ /
column2: If the death of a child occurs before the tonsure, the pollution is for a night, and before the undertaking of the vow for the investiture of sacred thread it lasts for three nights for sapiṇḍas.

column1: daśarātraṃ bhavedasmānmātāpitrostrirātrakaṃ //
column2: For the mother and father the pollution lasts for ten nights.

column1: ajātadante tu mṛte kṛtacūḍe 'rbhake tathā / prete nyūne tribhirvarṣair mṛte śuddhistu naiśilkī //
column2: For those who are not sapiṇḍas, if the child dies before the appearance of the teeth, or after the tonsure, the pollution lasts for three nights. If the child dies before it is three years old, one becomes pure after a night.

column1: dvyaheṇa kṣatriye śuddhistribhirvaiśye mṛte tathā /
column2: In the case of a warrior class purity is after two days, and three days in that of the tradesman.

column1: śuddhiḥ śūdre pañcabhiḥ syāt prāgvivāhad dviṣaṭtvahaḥ //
column2: A śūdra becomes pure after five days. If the death occurs before marriage, the pollution lasts for twelve days.

column1: yatra trirātraṃ viprāṇāmaśaucaṃ sampradṛśyate / tatra śūdre dvādaśāhaḥ ṣaṇṇava kṣatravaiśayyoḥ //
column2: In the circumstances in which the pollution for brahmins is noted as three nights, in such cases a śūdra would have for twelve days and the warrior class and tradesmen would have for six and nine days respectively.

column1: dvyabde naivāgnisaṃskāro mṛte tannikhaned bhuvi /
column2: If a child dies when two years old no cremation be done. It should be buried in the ground.

column1: na codakakriyā tasya nāmni cāpi kṛte sati //
column2: No water of libation need be given even if it had been named.

column1: jātadantasya vā kāryā syādupanayanāddaśa /
column2: Or it should be done if the child had grown teeth. If death occurs after the investiture of sacred thread one has pollution for ten days.

column1: ekāhācchuddhyate vipro yo 'gnivedasamanvitaḥ //
column2: A brahmin who propitiates the fire and is well versed in the scriptures becomes pure after a day.

column1: hīne hīnatare caiva tryahaś caturahas tathā /
column2: The pollution lasts for three or four days if one is inferior or still less inferior in his learning.

column1: pañcāhenāgnihīnastu daśāhādbrāhmaṇavruvaḥ //
column2: One who has neglected the worship of fire would become pure after five days.

column2: of a brahmin would become pure after ten days. A warrior gets pure after nine days and a brahmin possessing qualities after seven days. A tradesman possessing qualities becomes pure after ten days.

column2: A śūdra gets pure after twenty days. The normal period of pollution would be ten days for a brahmin, twelve days for the warrior class, fifteen days for the tradesman and one month for the śūdra.

column1: guṇotkarṣe daśāhāptau tryahamekāhakaṃ tryahe / ekāhāptau sadyaḥ śaucaṃ sarvatraivaṃ samūhayet //
column2: If there be excellent qualities the normal pollution for ten days would become three days, for three days would become a day, for one day would become immediate purity.

column1: dāsāntevāsibhṛtakāḥ śiṣyāś caivātra vāsinaḥ / svāmitulyamaśaucaṃ syānmṛte pṛthak pṛthagbhavet //
column2: The pollution for the servant, pupil, hired servant and disciple, residents of same place will be as that of their masters. But the pollution for the death would be separate.

column1: maraṇādeva kartavyaṃ saṃyogo yasya nāgnibhiḥ / dāhādūrdhvamaśaucaṃ syādyasya vaitāniko vidhiḥ //
column2: In the case of pollution due to the death of a person who performs sacrifices etc., the obsequial rites should be commenced after doing purification before the cremation is done.

column1: sarveṣāmeva varṇānāntribhāgāt sparśanambhavet /
column2: One may touch a person polluted after onethird of the period of pollution is over in the case of all the castes.

column1: tricatuḥpañcadaśabhiḥ spṛśyavarṇāḥ krameṇa tu //
column2: The period after which one may touch the polluted is three, four, five and ten days for the four castes respectively.

column1: caturthe pañcame caiva saptame navame tathā / asthisañcayanaṃ kāryaṃ varṇānāmanupūrvaśaḥ //
column2: The gathering and immersion of the bones should be done on the fourth, fifth, seventh and ninth day after the death for the four castes in the successive order.

column1: ahastvadattakanyāsu pradattāsu tryahaṃ bhavet /
column2: Pollution would be for a day in the death of girls not given in marriage and three days in the death of girls after marriage.

column1: pakṣiṇī saṃskṛtāsveva svasrādiṣu vidhīyate //
column2: A night and two days enclosing it has been laid down as the period of pollution in the death of married sisters and others.

column1: pitṛgotraṃ kumārīṇāṃ vyūḍhānāṃ bhartṛgotratā /
column2: The gotra for the unmarried girls would be that of the father, and for the married girls that of their husbands.

column1: jalapradānaṃ pitre ca udvāhe cobhayatra tu //
column2: The water of libation should be offered to the father on both sides in the case of the married.

column1: daśāhopari pitroś ca duhiturmaraṇe tryahaṃ /
column2: The pollution for the parents would be for three days after ten days in the case of the death of the daughter.

column1: sadyaḥ śaucaṃ sapiṇḍānāṃ pūrvaṃ cūḍākṛterdvija //
column2: O Brahmin! the sapiṇḍas would become pure immediately in the death of the boy before the tonsure is done..

column1: ekāhato hy āvivihādūrdhvaṃ hastodakāt tryahaṃ /
column2: The pollution would be for one day in the death of a girl before the marriage had been done and three days after the girl had been given in marriage.

column1: pakṣiṇī bhrātṛputrasya sapiṇḍānāṃ ca sadyataḥ //
column2: The pollution lasts for a night and two days enclosing it in the death of the brother’s son and immediately for the sapiṇḍas.

column1: daśāhācchuddhyate vipro janmahānau svayoniṣu /
column2: A brahmin becomes pure after ten days in the death or birth through the brahmin woman.

column1: ṣadbhistribhirahaikena kṣatraviṭśūdrayoniṣu //
column2: So also a brahmin becomes pure in the death or birth through the warrior, tradesman and śūdra respectively after six or three days or one day.

column1: etajjñeyaṃ sapiṇḍānāṃ vakṣye cānaurasādiṣu /
column2: This should be known as applicable to the sapiṇḍas.

column1: anauraseṣu putreṣu bhāryāsvanyagatāsu ca //
column2: shall describe the pollution in the case of the death of illegitimate children.

column1: parapūrvāsu ca strīṣu trirātrācchuddhiriṣyate / vṛthāsaṅkarajātānāṃ pravrajyāsu ca tiṣṭhatāṃ //
column2: It is said that there would be purity after three days in the case of the death of the illegitimate •children adulterous wives and women who had former husbands.

column1: ātmanastyāgināñcaiva nivartetodakakriyā /
column2: No water of libation need be given for those born in the mixed castes and, those gone abroad and those committing suicide.

column1: mātraikayā dvipitarau bhratarāvanyagāminau // ekāhaḥ sūtake tatra mṛtake tu dvyaho bhavet /
column2: Pollution for those having one mother and two fathers and brothers having illegitimate wives, would be one day for birth and two days in the case of death.

column1: sapiṇḍānāmaśaucaṃ hi samānodakatāṃ vade //
column2: have described the pollution for sapiṇḍas. shall describe the pollution for those having relationship by the libation of waters.

column1: bāle deśāntarasthe ca pṛthakpiṇḍe ca saṃsthite / savāsā jalamāplutya sadya eva viśuddhyati //
column2: One becomes pure after bathing with the dress worn at the death of a person who is not a sapiṇḍa, whether the dead be a boy or has died abroad.

column1: daśāhena sapiṇḍāstu śuddhyanti pretasūtake /
column2: But sapiṇḍas would become pure only after ten days in the case of both birth and death.

column1: trirātreṇa sukulyāstu snānāt śuddhyanti gotriṇaḥ //
column2: The members of the same family distant relatives would become pure after three nights. Those belonging to the same clan would become pure after bath.

column1: sapiṇḍatā tu puruṣe saptame vinivartate /
column2: The relationship of sapiṇḍa would cease after the seventh generation in the case of males.

column1: samānodakabhāvastu nivartetācaturdaśāt //
column2: The status of being eligible for waters of libation would cease after the fourteenth generation.

column1: janmanāmasmṛte vaitat tatparaṃ gotramucyate /
column2: If details about one’s birth are not remembered he is said to belong to another clan.

column1: vigatantu videśasthaṃ śṛṇuyādyo hy anirdaśaṃ // yaccheṣaṃ daśarātrasya tāvadevāśucirbhavet /
column2: One who hears about the death of a person abroad within ten days after the death, pollution would last only for the remaining period of the days.

column1: atikrānte daśāhe tu trirātramaśucirbhavet //
column2: If it is heard ten days after the death pollution would be for three days.

column1: saṃvatsare vyatīte tu spṛṣṭvaivāpo viśuddhyati /
column2: If one hears after one year had elapsed, one becomes pure after touching waters.

column1: mātule pakṣiṇo rātriḥ śiṣyatvigbāndhaveṣu ca // mṛṭe jāmātari prete daihitre bhaginīsute /
column2: The pollution lasts for a night enclosed by two days in case of death of the maternal uncle,. a night in case of death of the pupil, priest and relatives.

column1: śyālake tatsute caiva snānamātraṃ vidhīyate // mātāmahyāṃ tathācārye mṛte mātāmahe tryahaṃ / durbhikṣe rāṣṭrasampāte āgatāyāṃ tathāpadi //
column2: Only bathing is laid down in case of the death of soninlaw, daughter’s son, nephew sister’s son, brotherinlaw and the son of the latter. The pollution would last for three days in case of the death of maternal grandmother, preceptor and maternal grandfather.

column1: upasargamṛtānāñca dāhe brahmavidāntathā / satrivrati brahmattārisaṅgrāme deśaviplave // dāne yajñe vivāhe ca sadyaḥ śaucaṃ vidhīyate / vipragonṛpahantṝṇāmanuktaṃ cātmaghātināṃ //
column2: It is laid down that one becomes pure in the following cases Death at the time of a famine, the decadence of kingdom, a calamity has befallen, in case of death due to misfortune or at the time of eclipse, in the death of knower of brahman by means of fire, in case of the death of one who constantly performs sacrifice, one who observes a vow, a celibate, in case of death at battle and national calamity, while gift is being made, a sacrifice is being performed and the marriage is being conducted.

column1: asādhyavyādhiyuktasya svādhyāye cākṣamasya ca / prāyaścittamanujñātamagnitoyapraveśanaṃ // apamānāttathā krodhāt snehātparibhavādbhayāt /

column1: udbadhya mriyate nārī puruṣo vā kathañcana // ātmaghātī caikalakṣaṃ vasetsa narake śucau /

column1: vṛddhaḥ śrautasmṛterluptaḥ parityajati yastvasūn //

column1: trirātraṃ tatra śāśaucaṃ dvitīye cāsthisañcayaṃ /

column2: The śrāddha annual ceremony for the dead should be done on the fourth day.

column1: vidyudagnihatānāñca tryahaṃ śuddhiḥ sapiṇḍike /

column1: pitṛmātrādipāte tu ārdravāsā hy upoṣitaḥ /

column2: After one year had gone, the obsequies should be done as laid down.

column2: If one, who is an asapiṇḍa, carried the dead body, he becomes pure after bathing with the dress, touching the fire and taking ghee.

column1: yadyannamatti teṣāntu daśāhenaiva śuddhyati /
column2: If one eats food from them, he becomes pure only after ten days.

column1: anadannannamahnyeva na vai tasmin gṛhe vaset //
column2: If not eaten food there, he becomes pure that day itsel£ Then one should not stay in that house.

column2: The brahmins who carry the dead body of a destitute brahmin, get the benefits of a sacrifice at their each step and would become pure after bathing alone.

column1: pretībhūtaṃ dvijaḥ śūdramanugacchaṃstryahācchuciḥ /
column2: A brahmin who accompanies the dead body of a śūdra becomes pure after three days.

column1: mṛtasya bāndhavaiḥ sārdhaṃ kṛtvā ca paridevanaṃ // varjayettadahorātraṃ dānaśrāddhādi kāmataḥ /
column2: After having mourned the death of a person along with the relatives, one should avoid making any gifts or doing śrāddha etc. willfully for a day.

column1: śūdrāyāḥ prasavo gehe śūdrasya maraṇaṃ tathā // bhāṇḍāni tu parityajya tryahādbhūlepataḥ śuciḥ /
column2: If a śūdra woman delivers a child or dies in one’s house, the vessels should be discarded and one becomes pure after three days by sweeping the floor of the house with water.

column1: na vipraṃ sveṣu tiṣṭhatsu mṛtaṃ śūdreṇa nāyayet //
column2: The dead brahmin should not be made to be carried by a śūdra when the same caste men are available.

column1: nayet pretaṃ snāpitañca pūjitaṃ kusumair dahet /
column2: After bathing the dead body, it should be cremated after being worshipped with flowers.

column1: nagnadehaṃ dahen naiva kiñciddehaṃ parityajet //
column2: Never should the dead body be cremated naked. A part of the body should be left uncovered.

column1: gotrajastu gṛhītvā tu citāṃ cāropayettadā /
column2: One who is born in the same clan should lift and place the dead bodyon the funeral pyre.

column1: āhitāgniryathānyāyaṃ dagdhavyastibhiragnibhiḥ // anāhitāgnirekena laukikenāparas tathā /
column2: One who has not consecrated the sacred fire should be cremated with one among these three fires. The others should be cremated with the ordinary fire.

column1: asmāt tvamabhijāto 'si tvadayaṃ jāyatāṃ punaḥ //
column2: The son should place the fire at the face with the words, “You were born from this. May this be born from you again.

column1: asau svargāya lokāya sukhāgniṃ pradadetsutaḥ /
column2: This is for the heaven”.

column1: sakṛtprasiñcantyudakaṃ nāmagotreṇa bāndhavāḥ //
column2: The relatives should utter the name and clan of the dead and sprinkle water once.

column2: The water of libation should be done in this way in the death of the maternal grandfather, and the preceptor. The water of libation is optional in the case of the death of the girl friend, sister’s son, fatherinlaw and priest.

column1: apo naḥ śośucidayaṃ daśāhañca suto 'rpayet /
column2: The son should offer the water of libation for ten days with the syllable apo naḥ śośucad.

column1: brāhmaṇe daśapiṇḍāḥ syuḥ kṣatriye dvādaśa smṛtāḥ //
column2: Ten balls of rice should be offered at the death of a brahmin. Twelve balls of rice are remembered to be offered for a warrior.

column1: vaiśye pañcadaśa proktāḥ śūdre triṃśat prakīrtitā /
column2: Fifteen balls are spoken to be for a tradesman. It is said that thirty balls should be offered for a śūdra.

column1: putro vā putrikānyo vā piṇḍaṃ dadyācca putravat //
column2: A son or daughter or anybody else may offer the balls of rice like the son.

column1: vidiśya nimbapatrāṇi niyato dvāri veśmanaḥ / ācamya cāgnimudakaṃ gomayaṃ gaurasarṣapān // praviśeyuḥ samālabhya kṛtvāśmani padaṃ śanaiḥ /
column2: After biting the margosa leaves, becoming selfcontrolled and sipping water at the entrance to the house, all should touch fire, water, cowdung, white mustard and place foot slowly on a stone and enter the house.

column1: akṣaralavaṇānnaḥ syur nirmāṃsā bhūmiśāyinaḥ //
column2: Till the pollution goes pungeant and saline food should not be taken.

column1: abhāve brahmacārī tu kuryātpiṇḍodakādikaṃ //
column2: In the absence of that person, a brahmacāri may offer the balls of rice and waters of libation

column2: Just as the pollution for the sapiṇḍas at the death of their relatives has been laid down, so also it would be in regard to birth for those who desire for purification.

column1: sarveṣāṃ śāvamāśaucaṃ mātāpitroś ca sūtakaṃ /
column2: The pollution due to death is applicable to all. But the pollution due to birth is only for the father and mother.

column1: sūtakaṃ mātureva syādupaspṛśya pitā śuciḥ //
column2: Pollution would be for the mother only and the father would become pure after touching water.

column1: putrajanmadine śrāddhaṃ kartavyamiti niścitaṃ / tadahastatpradānārthaṃ gohiraṇyādivāsasāṃ //
column2: If it had been decided that śrāddha should be done on the day of birth of the dead son, cow, gold and dress should be given as gift on that day.

column1: maraṇaṃ maraṇenaiva sūtakaṃ sūtakena tu /
column2: The pollution due to death goes with another pollution. The pollution due to birth goes with another pollution.

column1: ubhayorapi yat pūrvaṃ tenāśaucena śuddhyati //
column2: Even between them one gets pure with that which occurs first.

column1: sūtake mṛtakaṃ cetsyān mṛtake tvatha sūtakaṃ / tatrādhikṛtya mṛtakaṃ śaucaṃ kuryānna sūtakaṃ //
column2: If a pollution due to death occurs while there is pollution due to birth and viceversa, the pollution is based on that of death only and not on that of birth.

column1: samānaṃ laghvaśaucantu prathamena samāpayet /
column2: If one pollution occurs when there is already another pollution, if the two are equal or the latter is less equal then the pollution should be completed with the former.

column1: asamānaṃ dvitīyena dharmarājavaco yathā //
column2: If the two are unequal, it should be completed with the second according to the words of Dharmarāja.

column1: śāvāntaḥ śāva āyāte pūrvāśaucena śuddhyati /
column2: If death occurs at the end of another death, there is purification after the end of first pollution.

column1: guruṇā laghu bādhyeta laghunā naiva tadguru //
column2: The greater one always affects the lighter one. But the lighter one never affects the greater one.

column1: mṛtake sūtake vāpi rātrimadhye 'nyadāpatet / taccheṣeṇaiva suddhyeran rātriśeṣe dvyahādhikāt //

column1: prabhāte yadyaśaucaṃ syācchuddheraṃś ca tribhirdinaiḥ /
column2: If the pollution occurs in the morning, one becomes pure after three days.

column1: ubhayatra daśāhāni kulasyānnaṃ na bhujyate //
column2: In both cases one should not eat food from that family.

column1: dānādi ninivarteta kulasyānnaṃ na bhujyate / ajñāte pātakaṃ nādye bhokturekamaho 'nyathā //
column2: One should refrain from making any gifts. If one happened to die, he should do rites of atonement. There is no sin if it is done unknowingly in the former. Otherwise, it would be for a day for the one who dines.

column1: saṃskṛtasyāsaṃskṛtasya svargo mokṣo harimmṛteḥ / asthnāṅgaṅgāmbhasi kṣepāt pretasyābhyudayo bhavet //
column2: ṚV. ..a. One would reach heaven whether the cremation is done or not done if Lord Viṣṇu is remembered. The dead gets redemption if the bones are immersed in the waters of the Ganges.

column1: gaṅgātoye narasyāsthi yāvattāvaddivi sthatiḥ /
column2: One remains in heaven till the period his bones remain in the waters of the Ganges.

column1: ātmanastyāgināṃ nāsti patitānāṃ tathā kriyā //
column2: No cremation is laid down for those committing suicide and those fallen from righteous living.

column1: teṣāmapi tathā gāṅge toye 'sthnāṃ patanaṃ hitaṃ / teṣāṃ dattaṃ jalaṃ cānnaṃ gagane tat pralīyate //
column2: Even for them it is beneficial to drop their bones in the waters of the Ganges. The waters and food offered for them would be absorbed in the sky.

column1: anugraheṇa mahatā pretasya patitasya ca / nārāyaṇabaliḥ kāryastenānugrahamaśnute //
column2: The rite of Nārāyaṇabali should be done with great compassion for the dead fallen from righteousness. Hence, that person would enjoy favour.

column1: akṣayaḥ puṇḍarīkākṣastatra dattaṃ na naśyati /
column2: The lotuseyed Viṣṇu is without decay. That which is offered there will not perish.

column1: patanātrāyate yasmāt tasmāt pātraṃ janārdanaḥ //
column2: Lord Janārdana Viṣṇu is the vessel because that protects from falling.

column1: patatāṃ bhuktimuktyādiprada eko harirdhruvaṃ /
column2: It is certain that Lord Hari Viṣṇu is the only god who confers enjoyment, emancipation etc.

column1: dṛṣṭvā lokān mriyamāṇān sahāyaṃ dharmamācaret //

column1: yonirvibhāvasornityamataḥ śāntiṃ prayaccha me // gavāmaṅgeṣu tiṣṭhanti bhuvanāni caturdaśa / yasmāttasmācchivaṃ me syādiha loke paratra ca //
column2: On account of the fact that you are always the origin of fire and remain as a constituent of all sacrifices, you get me tranquillity. Because the fourteen worlds remain in the limbs of the cow, let me have good in this world as well as in the next.

column1: yasmādaśūnyaṃ śayanaṃ keśavasya śivasya ca / śayyā mamāpyaśūnyāstu dattā janmani janmani //
column2: On account of the fact that the beds of Keśava and Śiva are not empty let my bed also be not empty in every birth being given now.

column1: yathā ratneṣu sarveṣu sarve devāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ / tathā śāntiṃ prayacchantu ratnadānena me surāḥ //
column2: Just as the celestials are established in all gems so also let the celestials get me tranquillity by my gift of gems.

column1: yathā bhūmipradānasya kalāṃ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīṃ / dānānyanyāni me śāntirbhūmidānādbhavatviha //
column2: Just as the other gifts are not equal to onesixteenth of the merit of making a gift of land, may have peace by the gift of the land.

column1: grahayajño 'yutahomo dakṣiṇābhī raṇe jitiḥ /
column2: The performance of sacrifice to appease the planets with ten thousand oblations with the payment of the fee secures victory in battle.

column1: vivāhotsavayajñeṣu pratiṣṭhādiṣu karmaṣu // sarvakāmāptaye lakṣakoṭihomadvayaṃ mataṃ /
column2: At the time of marriage, festivities, sacrifices, rites for the installation and for the fulfilment of desires, it is said that one should do the twothe oblations a lakh times and crore times.

column1: gṛhadeśe maṇḍape 'tha ayute hastamātrakaṃ // mekhalāyonisaṃyuktaṃ kuṇḍañcatvāra ṛtvijaḥ /
column2: In the oblation ten thousand times a pit of one cubit length and another pit having a girdle and hole should be made ready at the exact spot for building the house and pavilion.

column1: svayameko 'pi vā lakṣe sarvaṃ daśaguṇaṃ hi tat //
column2: In the oblation for a lakh times there may be the self alone. These are ten times meritorious.

column1: caturhastaṃ dvihastaṃ vā tārkṣañcātrādhikaṃ yajet /
column2: The pit may be a square of four cubits or two cubits long.

column1: sāmadhvaniśīrastvaṃ vāhanaṃ pameṣṭhinaḥ //
column2: He should be addressed as “You are the vehicle of highly adorable god and your body is composed of the sound of Sāman melodies.

column1: viṣayāpaharo nityamataḥ śāntiṃ prayaccha me /
column2: You are always the remover of things. Hence you get me tranquillity.

column1: pūrvavat kuṇḍamāmantrya lakṣahomaṃ samācaret //
column2: As before the sacrificial pit should be sanctified and the oblation lakh times performed.

column1: vasordhārāṃ tato dadyācchayyābhūṣādikaṃ dadet /
column2: The vasordhārā should be given then. Then bed, ornaments and other things should be offered as gift.

column1: tatrāpi daśa cāṣṭau ca lakṣahome tathartvijaḥ //
column2: There may be ten or eight sacrificial priests in the performance of oblations lakh times.

column1: putrānnarājyavijayabhuktimuktyādi cāpnuyāt /
column2: By the performance of this one would get sons, food, kingdom, conquest, enjoyment and liberation.

column1: dakṣiṇābhiḥ phalenāsmācchatrughnaḥ koṭihomakaḥ //
column2: One who performs oblation a crore times after making different gifts, would kill his enemy as a result of it.

column1: caturhastaṃ cāṣṭahastaṃ kuṇḍandvādaśa ca dvijāḥ /
column2: The sacrificial pit may be a square of four or eight cubits and there may be twelve sacrificial priests.

column1: pañcaviṃśaṃ ṣoḍaśaṃ vā paṭe dvāre catuṣṭayaṃ //
column2: There may be twentyfive or sixteen priests and four ? on a cloth at the entrance.

column1: koṭihomī sarvakāmī viṣṇulokaṃ sa gacchati /
column2: One who does oblation crore times gets the desired things and reaches the world of lord Viṣṇu.

column1: homastu grahamantrair vā gāyatryā vaiṣṇavair api // jātavedomukhaiḥ śaivaiḥ vaidikaiḥ prathitair api /
column2: The oblation may be done with the sacred syllables of planets, or the gāyatrī or those of Viṣṇu, or those addressed to the fire god or those of Śiva or the wellknown vedic hymns.

column1: tilair yavair ghṛtair aśvamedhaphalādibhāk //
column2: One gets the benefit of doing aśvamedha sacrifice by making oblations with sesamum, barley, ghee and grains.

column1: vidveṣaṇābhicāreṣu trikoṇaṃ kuṇḍamiṣyate /
column2: In the oblations intended to cause enmity or sorcery the sacrificial pit should be a triangular one.

column1: samidho vāmahastena śyenāsthyanalasaṃyutāḥ // raktabhūṣair muktakeśair dhyāyadbhiraśivaṃ ripoḥ /
column2: The twigs should be offered with the left hand together with bones of the eagle and fire by those who contemplate evil for their enemy and who have red dress and untied hair.

column1: durmitriyāstasmai santu yo dveṣṭi huṃ phaḍiti ca //
column2: “Let the person who hates have enemies. Huṃ phaṭ”.

column1: chindyāt kṣureṇa pratimāṃ piṣṭarūpaṃ ripuṃ hanet /
column2: The image of the enemy made of flour should be cut with a knife and the enemy should be killed.

column1: yajedekaṃ pīḍakaṃ vā yaḥ sa kṛtvā divaṃ vrajet //
column2: Or one ball of rice should be offered. One who does so would go to heaven.

column1: daṇḍaṃ kuryānnṛpo nṝṇāṃ prāyaścittamakurvatāṃ /
column2: The king should punish the men who do not perform atonement for their own misdeeds.

column1: kāmato 'kāmato vāpi prāyaścittaṃ kṛtaṃ caret //
column2: One should perform atonement irrespective of the fact that the misdeed was done with one’s wilful desire or not.

column1: mattakruddhāturāṇāṃ ca na bhuñjīta kadācana /
column2: One should never eat food from intoxicated, angry and sick men.

column1: mahāpātakināṃ spṛṣṭaṃ yacca spṛṣṭamudakyayā //
column2: One should not eat food touched by great sinners and that touched by a woman in her courses.

column1: rajakasya nṛśaṃsasya vandinaḥ kitavasya ca / mithyātapasvinaś caiva cauradaṇḍikayos tathā // kuṇḍagolastrījitānāṃ vedavikrayiṇas tathā / śailūṣatantravāyānnaṃ kṛtaghnasyānnameva ca // karmārasya niṣādasya celanirṇejakasya ca /
column2: One should also not take food prepared for a group of persons, food from the courtezan, an usurer, a singer, a cursed person, an eunuch, a woman having a paramour in the house, a washerman, a noxious person, a panegyrist, a cheat, a false ascetic, a thief, one who has undergone a punishment, one who is born to an adulterine, one who is born to a widow, one who is controlled by a woman, one who sells scriptures, an actor, a weaver, and food from an ungrateful person.

column1: mithyāpravrajitasyānnampuṃś calyāstailikasya ca // ārūḍhapatitasyānnaṃ vidviṣṭānnaṃ ca varjayet /
column2: One should avoid food from the blacksmith, hunter, washerman of sarees, falsely renounced person, a harlot, an oilman, one who had ridden on a horse etc. and fallen and one’s enemies.

column1: tathaiva brāhmaṇasyānnaṃ brāhmaṇenānimantritaḥ //
column2: So also one should not eat food from a brahmin, being not invited by that brahmin.

column1: brāhmaṇānnañca śūdreṇa nādyāccaiva nimantritaḥ /
column2: So also a śūdra should not eat food from a brahmin even if invited.

column1: eṣāmanyatamasyānnamamatyā vā tryahaṃ kṣapet //
column2: If one happens to eat unknowingly from the other among these, one has to fast for three days.

column1: matyā bhuktvā caret kṛcchraṃ retoviṇmūtrameva ca / caṇḍālaśvapacānnantu bhuktvā cāndrāyaṇaṃ caret //
column2: After having eaten knowingly one should observe the kṛcchra. One who had eaten food from a Caṇḍāla and Śvapaca and the semen, feces and urine, should observe the cāndrāyaṇa.

column1: anirdiśaṃ ca pretānnaṃ gavāghrātaṃ tathaiva ca / śūdrocchiṣṭaṃ śunocchiṣṭaṃ patitānnaṃ tathaiva ca //
column2: One should observe taptakṛcchra after having eaten food within ten days of pollution, food intended for the dead or that is smelt by a cow or the remnant of that eaten by a śūdra or a dog and the food from a fallen person.

column1: taptakṛcchraṃ prakurvīta aśauce kṛcchramācaret /
column2: When the food has been taken at the time of pollution one should observe kṛcchra.

column1: aśauce yasya yo bhuṅkte sopyaśuddhas tathā bhavet //
column2: Whoever eats food from a person having pollution also becomes impure.

column1: mṛtapañcanakhāt kūpādamedhyena sakṛdyutāt / apaḥ pītvā tryahaṃ tiṣṭhet sopavāso dvijottamaḥ //
column2: excellent brahmin who had drunk water from a well into which a fivenailed dead animal had fallen or containing feces, should observe fast for three days.

column1: sarvatra śūdre pādaḥ syād dvitrayaṃ vaiśyabhūpayoḥ / viḍvarāhakharoṣṭrāṇāṃ gomāyoḥ kapikākayoḥ // prāśya mūtrapurīṣāṇi dvijaścāndrāyaṇaṃ caret /
column2: In all the cases the śūdra, vaiśya and bhūmipa the ruling class would have fasting one fourth, half and threefourth of days prescribed for the brahmins. A brahmin who has partaken the urine and excreta of a bird, boar, mule, camel, jackal, monkey and crow should observe cāndrāyaṇa.

column1: kravyādaśūkaroṣṭrāṇāṃ gomāyoḥ kapikākayoḥ / gonarāśvakharoṣṭrāṇāṃ chatrākaṃ grāmakukkuṭaṃ // māṃsaṃ jagdhvā kuñjarasya taptakṛcchreṇa śuddhyati /
column2: One gets purified by observing taptakṛcchra after having eaten flesh, food intended for the dead, flesh of karaka a species of bird and also after eating the flesh of a carnivorous animal, boar, camel, jackal, monkey, crow, cow, man, horse and camel and after having eaten mushroom, the village cock as well as the flesh of an elephant.

column1: āmaśrāddhe tathā bhuktvā brahmacārī madhu tvadan //
column2: So also a brahmacārī having eaten at the āmaśrāddha and consumed honey or garlic or onion etc.

column1: laśunaṃ guñjanaṃ cādyāt prājāpatyādinā śuciḥ /
column2: get purified by doing prājāpatya etc.

column1: bhuktvā cāndrāyaṇaṃ kuryān māṃsañcātmakṛtantathā //
column2: So also one should do cāndrāyaṇa after having eaten flesh made ready cooked by ṃmself.

column1: pelugavyañca peyūṣaṃ tathā śleṣmātakaṃ mṛdaṃ / vṛthākṛśarasaṃyāvapāyasāpūpaśaṣkulīḥ // anupākṛṭamāṃsāni devānnāni havīṃṣi ca / gavāñca mahiṣīṇāṃ ca varjayitvā tathāpyajāṃ //
column2: So also pelugavya and peyūṣa which cause excess of phlegm and vṛtākṛsarasaṃyāva, pāyasa, cakes, fried eatables made of flour, flesh of animal not prepared for a sacrifice, food intended for the gods, oblations and all kinds of milks except those of cows, shebuffaloes and goats are prohibited as well as their waters ten days old.

column1: śaśakaḥ śalyakī godhā khaḍgaḥ kūrmastathaiva ca // bhakṣyāḥ pañcanakhāḥ proktāḥ pariśeṣāś ca varjitāḥ /
column2: The hare, porcupine, godhā a kind of an alligator, rhinoceros and tortoise are those among the animals having five nails whose flesh could be eaten. The remaining ones are prohibited.

column1: pāṭhīnarohitānmatsyān siṃhatuṇḍāṃś ca bhakṣayet //
column2: One may eat fish such as the pāṭhīna a kind of sheatfish, rohita and lionfaced fish.

column1: yavagodhūmajaṃ sarvaṃ payasaś caiva vikriyāḥ / vāgaṣāḍgavacakrādīn sasnehamuṣitaṃ tathā // agnihotraparīddhāgnirbrāhmaṇaḥ kāmacārataḥ /
column2: Having eaten all eatables made of barley and wheat and all transformations of milk, vāgaṣādgavacakra ? and others, that which is oily and the food kept overnight, a brahmin should do the agnihotra, kindle the fire and as desired observe cāndrāyaṇa for a month.

column1: cāndrāyaṇaṃ carenmāsaṃ vīravadhvāsanaṃ hitaṃ //
column2: The posture of vīrāsana is said to be conducive.

column1: brahmahatyā surāpānaṃ steyaṃ gurvaṅganāgamaḥ / mahānti pātakānyāhuḥ saṃyogaś caiva taiḥ saha //
column2: The killing of a brahmin, drinking of wine, stealing and copulating with preceptor’s wife are said to be great sins.

column1: anṛte ca samutkarṣo rājagāmi ca paiśunaṃ / guroścālīkanirbandhaḥ samānaṃ brahmahatyayā //
column2: The association with them, pleasure in untruth, miserliness in a king, speaking ill of the preceptor are equivalent to the killing of a brahmin.

column1: brahmojjhyavedanindā ca kauṭasākṣyaṃ suhṛdbadhaḥ / garhitānnājyayorjagdhiḥ surāpānasamāni ṣaṭ //
column2: Neglecting the Vedas, censuring the Vedas, bearing false witness, killing of a friend, eating forbidden food and clarified butter are the six equivalents to the drinking of wine.

column1: nikṣepasyāpaharaṇaṃ narāśvarajatasya ca / bhūmivajramaṇīnāñca rukmasteyasamaṃ smṛtaṃ //
column2: The stealing of the entrusted such as a man, horse, silver, land, gems like diamond are remembered to be equivalent to the stealing of gold.

column1: retaḥsekaḥ svayonyāṣu kumārīṣvantyajāsu ca /
column2: Cohabiting with consaṅguineous girls, women of low caste, wife etc.

column1: sakhyuḥ putrasya ca strīṣu gurutalpasamaṃ viduḥ //
column2: of the son of a friend are known to be equivalent to cohabiting with the wife of the preceptor.

column1: gobadho 'yājya saṃyājyaṃ pāradāryātmavikriyaḥ / gurumātṛpitṛtyāgaḥ svādhyayāgnyoḥ sutasya ca // parivittitānujena parivedanameva ca / tayordānañca kanyāyāstayoreva ca yājanaṃ //
column2: Killing of a cow, doing a sacrifice for an outcaste, adultery, selling oneself, forsaking the preceptor, mother, and father as well as one’s vedic study, the fireworship and the son, marrying before the marriage of one’s elder brother, getting one’s daughter married to a person whose elder brother is unmarried, conducting a sacrifice for them,seducing a girl, practising usury, breaking of a vow, selling a tank, garden, wife and son, becoming an outcaste by the nonperformance of the religious rites, forsaking the relatives, teaching the servant taking instruction.

column1: kanyāyā dūṣaṇañcaiva vārdhuṣyaṃ vratalopanaṃ / taḍāgārāmadārāṇāmapatyasya ca vikriyaḥ // vrātyatā bāndhavatyāgo bhṛtādhyāpanameva ca / bhṛtāccādhyayanādānamavikreyasya vikrayaḥ // sarvākāreṣvadhīkāro mahāyantrapravartanaṃ /
column2: from a servant, selling of things prohibited for sale, exercising control over all the mines, instituting a potent amulet, destroying herbs, living by means of a woman, disregarding one’s work, felling ofunwithered trees for fuel, taking many wives, associating with those who despise women, commencing some action for the benefit of one’s own self, eating of censured food, not invoking the sacrificial fires, indulging in stealing, not discharging the debts, studying of false scriptures, bad conduct, doing deeds harmful to others, stealing grains, metal and cow, cohabiting woman fond of drinking, killing a woman, a śūdra, a vaiśya, or a kṣatriya and atheism are all minor sins.

column1: hiṃsauṣadhīnāṃ stryājīvaḥ kriyālaṅganameva ca // indhanārthamaśuṣkāṇāṃ dumāṇāñcaiva pātanaṃ / yoṣitāṃ grahaṇañcaiva strīnindakasamāgamaḥ //
column2: Causing injury to a brahmin, the act of smelling something that should not be smelt or the wine, deceitfulness, and cohabiting with men are known to be the acts to make one an outcaste. The killing of a dog, mule, camel, lion, goat, ewe, fish, snake and mongoose are known to be saṅkīrṇakaraṇa mixed acts.

column1: ātmārthañca kriyārambho ninditānnadanantathā / anāhitāgnitāsteyamṛṇānāñcānapakriyā //
column2: Getting money from the defamed, doing trade, serving a śūdra, and speaking untruth are known to be apātrīkaraṇa doing unworthy acts.

column1: dhānyakupyapaśusteyaṃ madyapastrīniṣevaṇaṃ // strīśūdraviṭkṣatrabadho nāstikyañcopapātakaṃ /
column2: The killing of insects, worms and birds, taking food followed by drinking wine, stealing fruits, fuel and flowers and cowardice are also defiling acts. A simple expiation of fasting etc.

column1: brāhmaṇasya rujaḥ kṛtyaṃ ghrātiraghreyamadyayoḥ //
column2: Fast regulated according to the phases of the moon.

column1: jaiṃbhaṃ puṃsi ca maithunyaṃ jātibhraṃśakaraṃ smṛtaṃ /
column2: See note on p. .

column1: śvakharoṣṭramṛgendrāṇāmajāvyoś caiva māraṇaṃ // saṅkīrṇakaraṇaṃ jñeyaṃ mīnāhinakulasya ca / ninditebhyo dhanādānaṃ bāṇijyaṃ śūdrasevanaṃ //
column2: Drinking water with milk and ghee once in three days for twelve days. An ancestral rite in which uncooked food is offered. A kind of fast for days, eating food in the morning for the first three days, in the evening for the next three days, only if given as alms the next three days and a plenary fast the rest of the days.

column1: apātrīkaraṇaṃ jñeyamasatyasya ca bhāṣaṇaṃ /
column2: See note on p. above. The exact meaning is not known.

column1: kṛmikīṭavayohatyā madyānugatabhojanaṃ // phalaidhaḥkusumasteyamadhair yañca malāvahaṃ //41//
column2: Food consisting of wheat flour, rice and sesamum not prepared for any religious purpose. Rice boiled with milk or sugar. A daily oblation to the fire.

column1: etatprabhṛtipāpānāṃ prāyaścittaṃ vadāmi te /
column2: shall describe the atonements for the sins described so far.

column1: brahmahā dvādaśābdāni kuṭīṅkṛtvā vane vaset //
column2: A killer of a brahmin should live in a forest for twelve years in a hut.

column1: bhikṣetātmaviśuddhyarthaṃ kṛtvā śavaśirodhvajaṃ /
column2: For the sake of one’s purity one should seek alms carrying the skull of the dead person on a staff.

column1: prāsyedātmānamagnau vā samiddhe triravākśirāḥ //
column2: Or one should throw oneself in the kindled fire thrice with head downwards.

column1: yajeta vāśvamedhena svarjitā gosavena vā /
column2: Otherwise one should do the aśvamedha, svarjit or gosava.

column1: japanvānyatamaṃ vedaṃ yojanānāṃ śataṃ brajet //
column2: Or one should recite one of the Vedas and walk one hundred yojanas.

column1: sarvasvaṃ vā vedavide brāhmaṇāyopapādayet /
column2: Otherwise one should give away all his wealth to a brahmin, learned in the Vedas.

column1: vratair etair vyapohanti mahāpātakino malaṃ //
column2: The impurity due to the great sins gets destroyed by these observances.

column1: upapātakasaṃyukto goghno māsaṃ yavān pivet / kṛtavāpo vasedgoṣṭhe carmaṇā tena saṃvṛtaḥ //
column2: One who is possessed of minor sins such as killer of the cow should drink only water along with barley. After having had a shave he should live in the cowshed covering himself with the hide of that cow killed by him.

column1: caturthakālamaśrīyādakṣāralavaṇaṃ mitaṃ /
column2: He should eat a little without alkaline things and salt in the fourth part of the day.

column1: gomūtreṇa caret snānaṃ dvau māsau niyatendriyaḥ //
column2: He should bathe in cow’s urine for two months controlling his senses.

column1: divānugacchedgāś caiva tiṣṭhannūrdhvaṃ rajaḥ pivet / vṛṣabhaikādaśā gāstu dadyādvicāritavrataḥ //
column2: He should follow the cows during the day and consume the dust rising from their feet standing with raised face. After having taken and observing a vow, he should make a gift of eleven bulls and a cow.

column1: avidyamāne sarvasvaṃ vedavidbhyo nivedayet /
column2: In the absence of these one should make a gift of all his possessions to those learned in the scriptures.

column1: pādamekañcaredrodhe dvau pādau bandhane caret // yojane pādahīnaṃ syāccaret sarvaṃ nipātane /
column2: Having caused obstruction to the movement of a cow one should do a fourth of the above atonements and twofourth if he had kept the animal bound.

column1: kāntāreṣvatha durgeṣu viṣameṣu bhayeṣu ca // yadi tatra vipattiḥ syādekapādo vidhīyate /
column2: If some mishap has occurred to the cow in the forests, mountains, inaccessible terrain and due to sickness, one fourth of the atonement is laid.

column1: ghaṇṭābharaṇadoṣeṇa tathaivardhaṃ vinirdiśat //
column2: If it dies on account of the tying of the bell or ornament, half the above atonement should be prescribed.

column1: damane damane rodhe śakaṭasya niyojane / stambhaśṛṅkhalapāśeṣu mṛte pādonamācaret // śṛṅgabhaṅge 'sthibhaṅge ca lāṅgūlacchedane tathā / yāvakantu pivettāvadyāvat susthā tu gaurbhavet //
column2: A quarter less of the above expiation should be observed if the cow or ox dies on account of taming goading or chaining or confining or yoking to a cart or while being tied to the pillar, chain or rope. When the horn or the bone of a cow has been broken or the tail been cut off, one has to drink barley water till the cow becomes healthy.

column1: gomatīñca japedvidyāṃ gostutiṃ gomatīṃ smaret /
column2: One should repeat the gomatīvidyā and the hymn on the cow and contemplate on the gomatī vidyā.

column1: ekā cedbahubhirdaivād yatra vyāpāditā bhavet // pādaṃ pādantu hatyāyāś careyuste pṛthak pṛthak /
column2: If a herd of cows has been killed accidently, one fourth atonement should be practised separately for every killing.

column1: upakāre kriyamāṇe vipattau nāsti pātakaṃ //
column2: There will not be any sin if any mishap occurs when some help is rendered with good intention.

column1: avakīrṇavarjaṃ śuddhyarthañcāndrāyaṇamathāpi vā //
column2: Those subject to minor sins except those who have violated the vow of continence should observe this vow or the cāndrāyaṇa.

column1: avakīrṇī tu kālena gardhabhena catuṣpathe / pākayajñavidhānena yajeta nirṛtiṃ niśi //
