column1: trayodaśyāṃ site caitre ratiprītiyutaṃ smaran / aśokākhyaṃ nagaṃ likhya sindūrarajanīmukhaiḥ //
column2: One should contemplate on lord Śiva causing delight to Rati wife of God of love on the thirteenth day in the bright fortnight in the month of caitra AprilMay and should draw aśoka tree with redlead and turmeric.

column1: avdhaṃ yajettu kāmārthī kāmatrayodaśīvratam /
column2: One who seeks pleasure should worship for a year and practice the vow of Kāmatrayodaśī.

column1: vrataṃ vakṣye caturdaśyāṃ bhuktimuktipradāyakaṃ /
column2: shall describe the vow to be practised on the fourteenth lunar day that would confer enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: kārttike tu caturdaśyāṃ nirāhāro yajecchivam //
column2: One should fast on the fourteenth day in the month of kārttika NovemberDecember and worship lord Śiva.

column1: varṣabhogadhanāyuṣmān kurvan śivacaturdaśīm /
column2: One who performs the worship of Śiva on the fourteenth day would get all pleasures through the year, wealth and long life.

column1: mārgaśīrṣe site 'ṣṭābhyāṃ tṛtīyāyāṃ munivrataḥ // dvādaśyāṃ vā caturdaśyāṃ phalāhāro yajet suraṃ /
column2: One should take the vow of an ascetic on the eighth or third or twelfth or fourteenth day in the bright fortnight in the month of mārgaśīrṣa DecemberJanuary, eat fruit only and worship the lord.

column1: tyaktvā phalāni dadyāttu kurvan phalacaturdaśīṃ //
column2: Then one should leave taking fruits and give fruits as gifts practising the vow of Phalacaturdaśī.

column1: caturdaśyāṃ mathāṣṭamyāṃ pakṣayoḥ śuklakṛṣṇayoḥ / anaśnan pūjayecchambhuṃ svargyubhayacaturdaśīṃ //
column2: One should worship lord Śambhu Śiva on the eighth and fourteenth days in both the dark and bright fortnights without eating. One who practises the vow on both the fortnights would reach heaven.

column1: kṛṣṇāṣṭamyāntu naktena tathā kṛṣṇacaturdaśīṃ / iha bhogānavāpnoti paratra ca śubhāṅgatiṃ //
column2: One who eats food only in the night on the eighth and fourteenth days of the dark fortnight would get all pleasures in this world and good position in the other world.

column1: kārtike ca caturdaśyāṃ kṛṣṇāyāṃ snānakṛt sukhī / ārādhite mahendre tu dhvajākārāsu yaṣṭiṣu // tataḥ śuklacaturdaśyāmanantaṃ pūjayeddhariṃ /
column2: One who bathes on the fourteenth day in the dark fortnight in the month of kārttika NovemberDecember would be happy, when he worships Mahendra in flagstaffs in the form of the banner. One should worship Ananta endless, a form of Hari on fourteenth day of the bright fortnight.

column1: kṛtvādarbhamayaṃ caiva vāridhānī samanvitaṃ // śāliprasthasya piṣṭasya pūpanāmnaḥ kṛtasya ca /
column2: After having made a watervessel out of darbha, one should prepare cakes from the flour of a prastha a measure of rice.

column1: ardhaṃ viprāya dātavyamardhamātmani yojayet // kartavyaṃ saritāṃ cānte kathāṃ kṛtvā hareriti /
column2: He should give one half of that to a brahmin and enjoy the other half himself. This vow should be done near the river and after the narration of the anecdotes of lord Hari.

column1: anantasaṃsāramahāsamudre magnān samabhyuddhara vāsudeva // anantarūpe viniyojayasva anantarūpāya namo namaste /
column2: “O lord Vāsudeva! Lift us drowned in the great ocean of endless mundane existence and put in the limitless form. Obeisance to you of the limitless form”.

column1: anena pūjayitvātha sūtraṃ baddhā tu mantritaṃ // svake kare vā kaṇṭhe vā tvanantavratakṛt sukhī //11//
column2: After having worshipped with these words and bound the consecrated thread on his own hand or the neck, the performer of the Anantavrata becomes happy.

column1: śivarātrivrataṃ vakṣye bhuktimuktipradaṃ śṛṇu /
column2: Listen! shall describe the vow of Śiva’s night that confers enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: māghaphālgunayormadhye kṛṣṇā yā tu caturdaśī // kāmayuktā tu sopoṣyā kurvan jāgaraṇaṃ vratī /
column2: The fourteenth day in the dark fortnight in between the months of māgha FebruaryMarch and phālguna MarchApril is endowed with kāma pleasure.

column1: śivarātrivrataṃ kurve caturdaśyāmabhojanaṃ // rātrijāgaraṇenaiva pūjayāmi śivaṃ vratī /
column2: One who practises the vow should fast, keep awake and resolve “ shall do Śivarātrivrata fasting on the fourteenth day and worship lord Śiva after remaining awake and undertaking the vow.

column1: āvāhayāmyahaṃ śambhuṃ bhuktimuktipradāyakaṃ // narakārṇavakottāranāvaṃ śiva namo 'stu te /
column2: invoke lord Śambhu Śiva, the conferer of enjoyment and emancipation and the boat that rescues from the ocean of hell. Obeisance to you.

column1: namaḥ śivāya śāntāya prajārājyādidāyine // saubhāgyārogyavidyārthasvargamārgapradāyine /
column2: Obeisance to lord Śiva, the tranquil person, the bestower of progeny and kingdom, the giver of fortune, health, knowledge, material prosperity and the pathway to heaven.

column1: dharmandehi dhanandehi kāmabhogādi dehi me //
column2: Give me righteousness. Give me riches. Give me fulfilment of desires and enjoyment.

column1: guṇakīrtisukhaṃ dehi svargaṃ mokṣaṃ ca dehi me /
column2: Give me the happiness of good quality and fame. Get me also heaven and emancipation.

column1: lubdhakaḥ prāptavān puṇyaṃ pāpī sundarasenakaḥ //
column2: By the practice of this vow the greedy sinner Sundarasena acquired merit.

column1: aśokapūrṇimāṃ vakṣye bhūdharaṃ ca bhuvaṃ yajet / phālgunyāṃ sitapakṣāyāṃ varṣaṃ syādbhuktimuktibhāk //
column2: shall describe the vow of Aśokapūrṇimā. One should worship Bhūdhara the supporter of the universe and the earth on the bright fortnight in the month of phālguna MarchApril.

column1: kārttikyāntu vṛṣotsargaṃ kṛtvā naktaṃ samācaret /
column2: After having set free a bull in the month of kārttika NovemberDecember one should do the nakta vrata eating food only in the night.

column1: śaivaṃ padamavāpnoti vṛṣavratamidaṃ paraṃ //
column2: One would reach the place of lord Śiva. This Vṛṣa vrata vow of letting lose the bull is an excellent one.

column1: pitryā yāmāvasī tasyāṃ pitṝṇāṃ dattamakṣyaṃ / upoṣyābdaṃ pitṝniṣṭvā niṣpāpaḥ svargamāpnuyāt //
column2: The offering made to the forefathers on the newmoon day relating to the forefathers has undiminishing benefits. After fasting the whole year and worshipping the forefathers one becomes free from sin and reaches heaven.

column1: pañcadaśyāṃ ca māghasya pūjyājaṃ sarvamāpnuyāt /
column2: One who worships the birthless deity Brahmā on the fifteenth lunar day new moon in the month of māgha FebruaryMarch, would get all things.

column1: vakṣye sāvitryamāvāsyāmbhuktimuktikarīṃ śubhāṃ //
column2: shall describe the newmoon day known as the Sāvitrī, that is auspicious and bestows enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: pañcadaśyāṃ vratī jyaiṣṭhe vaṭamūle mahāsatīṃ / trirātropoṣitā nārī saptadhānyaiḥ prapūjayet //
column2: A woman should practise vow on the fifteenth day new moon in the month of jyeṣṭha JuneJuly and worship the great chaste woman Sāvitrī at the foot of the banyan tree with seven kinds of grains after fasting three nights.

column1: prarūḍhaiḥ kaṇṭhasūtraiś ca rajanyāṃ kuṅkumādibhiḥ /
column2: Women should deeply embrace the banyan tree besmearing with saffron etc.

column1: vaṭāvalambanaṃ kṛtvā nṛtyagītaiḥ prabhātake // namaḥ sāvitryai satyavate naivedyaṃ cārpayed dvije /
column2: doing dancing and singing in the night and worship Satyavān and Sāvitrī in the morning saying “Obeisance to Sāvitrī and Satyavān”. The offering should be gifted to a brahmin.

column1: veśma gatvā dvijān bhojya svayaṃ bhuktvā visarjayet // sāvitrī prīyatāṃ devī saubhāgyādikamāpnuyāt //8//
column2: After reaching the house one should feed brahmins and eat oneself and request them to go saying “May the goddess Sāvitrī be pleased and let me get fortune etc.”

column1: vāravratāni vakṣyāmi bhuktimuktipradāni hi /
column2: shall describe vows relating to the weekdays that would confer enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: karaṃ punarvasuḥ sūrye snāne sarvauṣadhī śubhā //
column2: The asterism punarvasu on the Sunday is the hand of Sun. Bathing with all herbs is auspicious on that day.

column1: śrādhhau cādityavāre tu saptajanmasvarogabhāk /
column2: One who performs the ancestral rite on a Sunday would be free from disease for seven births.

column1: saṅkrāntau sūryavāro yaḥ so 'rkasya hṛdayaḥ śubhaḥ //
column2: A Sunday occurring on the saṅkrānti Sun’s entry from one constellation into another is the auspicious heart of the Sun.

column1: kṛtvā haste sūryavāraṃ naktenābdaṃ sa sarvabhāk /
column2: One who eats in the night on a Sunday occurring in the asterism hasta for a year would get everything.

column1: citrābhasomavārāṇi sapta kṛtvā sukhī bhavet //
column2: One who practises a vow on Mondays occurring in the asterism citrā seven times would be happy.

column1: svātyāṃ gṛhītvā cāṅgāraṃ saptanaktyārtivarjitaḥ /
column2: One who undertakes to do the vow of eating only in the night on a Tuesday occurring in the asterism svātī seven times would be free from difficulties.

column1: viśākhāyāṃ budhaṃ gṛhya saptanaktī grahārtinut // anurādhe devaguruṃ saptanaktī grahārtinut / śukraṃ jyeṣṭhāsu saṅgṛhya saptanaktī grahārtinut //
column2: One who eats only in the night on Thursday in the asterism anurādhā seven times would destroy all afflictions due to planets. One who undertakes to practise eating only on Friday in the asterism jyeṣṭhā for seven nights would get rid of all afflictions due to planets.

column1: mūle śanaiś caraṃ gṛhya saptanaktī grahārtinut //6 //
column2: One who resolves to practise eating only seven nights on Saturday in the asterism mūla would destroy all afflictions due to planets.

column1: nakṣatravratakaṃ vakṣye bhe hariḥ pūjito 'rthadaḥ / nakṣatrapuruṣaṃ cādau caitramāse hariṃ yajet //
column2: shall describe the practice of vows in different asterisms , Lord Hari worshipped in the asterism gives material prosperity. Lord Hari in the form of asterisms should be first worshipped in the month of caitra AprilMay.

column1: mūle pādau yajejjaṅghe rohiṇīsvarcayeddhariṃ / jānunī cāśvinīyoge āṣāḍhāsūrusañjñake // meḍhraṃ pūrvottarāsveva kaṭiṃ vai kṛttikāsu ca / pārśve bhādrapadābhyāntu kukṣiṃ vai revatīṣu ca //
column2: The legs should be worshipped in the asterism mūla. The shanks of lord Hari should be worshipped in the asterism rohiṇī, the knee in the combination of aśvini, the two thighs in the āṣāḍha, the male organ in the pūrva and uttara, the hip in the kṛttikā, the two sides in the bhādrapada, the belly in the revatī, breasts in the anurādhā, the backside in the dhaniṣṭhā.

column1: bhujau pūjyau viśākhāsu punarvasvaṅgulīryajet //
column2: The arms should be worshipped in the viśākhā, the fingers in the punarvasu.

column1: aśleṣāsu nakhān pūjya kaṇṭhaṃ jyeṣṭhāsu pūjayet /
column2: Having worshipped nails in the āśleṣā, the neck should be worshipped in the jyeṣṭhā.

column1: śrotre viṣṇoś ca śravaṇe mukhaṃ puṣye hareryajet //
column2: The two ears of lord Viṣṇu should be worshipped in the śravaṇa and the face in the puṣya.

column1: yajet svātiṣu dantāgramāsyaṃ vāruṇato 'rcayet / maghāsu nasāṃ nayane mṛgaśīrṣe lalāṭakaṃ // citrāsu cārdrāsu kacānabdānte svarṇakaṃ hariṃ / guḍapūrṇe ghaṭe 'bhyarcya śayyāgorthādi dakṣiṇā //
column2: The tip of the tooth should be worshipped in the svāti, the face in the śatabhṣak, the nose in the maghā, the eyes in the mṛgaśīrṣa, the forehead in the citrā and the hair in the Ārdrā. A golden image of lord Hari should be worshipped in a pot filled with molasses at the end of a year and bed, cow and materials should be given as fees.

column1: nakṣatrapuruṣo viṣṇuḥ pūjanīyaḥ śivātmakaḥ /
column2: Lord Viṣṇu should be worshipped in the form of the asterisms and in the form of lord Śiva.

column1: śāmbhavāyanīyavratakṛnmāsabhe pūjayeddhariṃ // kārttike kṛttikāyāṃ ca mṛgaśīrṣe mṛgāsyake /
column2: One who practises the vow known as, Sāmbhavāyanīya should worship lord Hari in the asterisms of every month, in the kṛttikās in the month of kārttika, in the mṛgaśīrṣa in the mṛgāsyaka māgha, with the names, such as Keśava etc.

column1: nāmabhiḥ keśavādyaistu acyutāya namo 'pi vā //
column2: or with the words “Obeisance to Acyuta one without a loss”.

column1: kārttike kṛttikābhe 'hni māsanakṣatragaṃ hariṃ /
column2: One should worship lord Hari of the form of the asterisms on the day of the asterism kṛttikā in the month of kārttika.

column1: śāmbhavāyanīyavratakaṃ kariṣye bhuktimuktidaṃ //
column2: One should resolve that “ shall do the vow known as the Sāmbhavāyanīya , that confers enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: keśavādi mahāmūrtimacyutaṃ sarvadāyakaṃ / āvāhayāmyahandevamāyurārogyavṛddhidaṃ //
column2: invoking the lord of great forms such as Keśava etc., that bestows everything and furthers longevity and health”.

column1: kārttikādau sakāsāramannaṃ māsacatuṣṭayaṃ /
column2: Food together with a pool should be offered for four months commencing with kārttika.

column1: phālgunādau ca kuśaramāṣāḍhādau ca pāyasaṃ //
column2: Rice and pulse boiled with spices should be offered for four months beginning with phālguna and sweet gruel from āṣāḍha.

column1: devāya brāhmaṇebhyaś ca naktannaivedyamāśayet /
column2: Offering should be made to the lord and brahmins in the night.

column1: pañcagavyajalesnātastasyaiva prāśanācchuciḥ //
column2: One becomes pure after bathing in water mixed with the five things got from a cow and drinking the same.

column1: arvāgvisarjanād dravyaṃ naivedyaṃ sarvamucyate /
column2: Whichever material is offered before allowing the invoked deity to go is told as offering.

column1: visarjite jagannāthe nirmālyanbhavati kṣaṇāt //
column2: When lord Jagannātha the lord of the world is allowed to go it becomes the remains of the offering in a moment.

column1: namo namaste 'cyuta me kṣayostu pāpasya vṛddhiṃ samupaitu puṇyaṃ /
column2: “O Acyuta one without a loss! Obeisance to you. Let my sin get destroyed and my merits grow.

column1: aiśvaryavittādi sadākṣayaṃ me kṣayañca mā santatirabhyapaitu //
column2: Let all my fortune, wealth etc. be without decay. Let not my progeny get destroyed.

column1: yathācyutastvamparataḥ parastāt sa brahmabhūtaḥ parataḥ parātman / tathācyutaṃ tvaṃ kuru vāñchitaṃ me mayā kṛtampāpaharāprameya //
column2: Just as you are decayless, greater than the greatest, that Supreme soul who has become the Brahman, in the same way, you make that desired by me as without a loss. O Immeasurable one! You take away the sin done by me.

column1: acyutānanda govinda prasīda yadabhīpsitaṃ /
column2: One without a loss! Limitless! One who protects the cows! You grace me with the desired things.

column1: akṣayaṃ māmameyātman kuruṣva puruṣottama // sapta varṣāṇi sampūjya bhuktimuktimavāpunuyāt /
column2: O Immeasurable being! You make me without a loss, O Excellent among beings!” After having worshipped for seven years one would get enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: anantavratamākhyāsye nakṣatravratakerthadaṃ //
column2: shall describe the vow known as Ananta, endless among the vows relating to asterisms, that would yield wealth.

column1: mārgaśīrṣe mṛgaśire gomūtrāśo yajeddhariṃ /
column2: One should worship lord Hari in the asterism mṛgaśīra in the month of mārgasīrṣa drinking cow’s urine.

column1: anantaṃ sarvakāmānāmananto bhagavān phalaṃ // dadātyanantañca punastadevānyatra janmani /
column2: Lord Ananta the limitless confers endless fruits for all desires and also the same endless fruits in the next birth.

column1: anantapunyopacayaṅkarotyetanmahāvrataṃ //
column2: This great vow makes one acquire a limitless acquisition of merits.

column1: yathābhilaṣitaprāptiṃ karotyakṣayameva ca /
column2: It would make one get the desired objects without loss.

column1: pādādi pūjya nakte tu bhuñjīyāttailavarjitaṃ // ghṛtenānantamuddiśya homo māsacatuṣṭayaṃ /
column2: After having worshipped the feet etc., one should eat without oil in the night. Oblation should be made for four months for the sake of Ananta with ghee.

column1: caitrādau śālinā homaḥ payasā śrāvaṇādiṣu //
column2: Oblation should be made with rice for four months commencing with caitra and with milk in the four months beginning with śrāvaṇa.

column1: māndhātābhūd yuvanāśvādanantavratakāt sutaḥ //23//
column2: Māndhātā was born as the son of Yuvanāśva as a result of doing Anantavrata.

column1: divasavratakaṃ vakṣye hy ādau dhenuvrataṃ vade /
column2: shall describe the vows to be performed on certain days . shall first explain the Dhenuvrata vow of giving a cow as a gift.

column1: yaścobhayamukhīndadyāt prabhūtakanakānvitāṃ // dinaṃ payovratastiṣṭhet sa yāti parasampadaṃ /
column2: One who gives as a gift a cow delivering a calf together with plenty of gold and observes the payovrata drinking milk oozing from the udders of a cow, reaches the exalted position.

column1: tryahaṃ payovrataṃ kṛtvā kāñcanaṃ kalpapādapaṃ // datvā brahmapadaṃ yāti kalpavṛkṣapradaṃ smṛtaṃ /
column2: After practising payovrata for three days and giving a golden replica of kalpapādapa the celestial tree that yields the desired object, one reaches the place of lord Brahmā.

column1: dadyādviṃśat palādūrdhvaṃ mahīṅkṛtvā tu kāñcanīṃ //
column2: One should give as gift golden replica of earth weighing more than twenty palas and practise payovrata that day.

column1: dinaṃ payovratastiṣṭhedrudragaḥ syāddivāvratī /
column2: That person would reach the world of Rudra.

column1: pakṣe pakṣe trirātrantu bhaktenaikena yaḥ kṣapet // vipulaṃ dhanamāpnoti trirātravratakṛddinaṃ / māse māse trirātrāśī ekabhaktī gaṇeśatāṃ //
column2: One who eats food only once a day for three days in every fortnight would get enormous wealth. One who observes the trirātravrata vow for three nights every day in every month eating only once in the nights for three nights in every month would get the place of Gaṇeśa.

column1: yastrirātravrataṃ kuryāt samuhiśya janārdanaṃ / kulānāṃ śatamādāya sa yāti bhavanaṃ hareḥ //
column2: One who practises the trirātravrata intended for lord Janārdana a form of Viṣṇu would reach the abode of lord Hari taking with him hundreds of his own family.

column1: navamyāñca site pakṣe naro mārgaśirasyatha / prārabheta trirātrāṇāṃ vratantu vidhivad vratī //
column2: One who practises the vow called trirātravrata should begin it on the ninth day in the bright fortnight in the month of mārgaśīrṣa.

column1: oṃ namo vāsudevāya sahasraṃ vā śataṃ japet /
column2: One should repeat, “Oṃ, obeisance to Vāsudeva”, a thousand or hundred times.

column1: aṣṭamyāmekabhaktāśī dinatrayamupāvaset // dvādaśyāṃ pūjayed viṣṇuṃ kārttike kārayed vrataṃ /
column2: One should eat once on the eighth, day, fast for three days worship lord Viṣṇu on the twelfth day and practise the vow in kārttika.

column1: viprān sambhojya vastrāṇi śayanānyāsanāni ca // chatropavītapātrāṇi dadet samprārthayeddvijān /
column2: After having fed the brahmins, one should give clothes, beds, seats, umbrellas, sacred threads and vessels.

column1: vrato 'smin duṣkare cāpi vikalaṃ yadabhūnmama // bhavadbhistadanujñātaṃ paripūrṇaṃ bhavatviti /
column2: He should then request brahmins “Whatever has become incomplete for me in this difficult vow, let it become complete being permitted by you”.

column1: bhuktabhogo vrajed viṣṇuṃ trirātravratakatratī //
column2: One who practises the trirātravrata would attain lord Viṣṇu after having enjoyed all comforts.

column1: kārttikavratakaṃ vakṣye bhuktimuktipradāyakaṃ /
column2: shall describe the kārttikavrata that would confer enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: daśamyāṃ pañcagavyāśo ekādaśyāmupoṣitaḥ // kārttikasya site 'bhyarcya viṣṇuṃ devavimānagaḥ /
column2: One who partakes five things got from a cow on the tenth day, fasts on the eleventh day and worships lord Viṣṇu in the bright fortnight in kārttika would reach him by the celestial vehicle.

column1: caitre trirātraṃ naktāśī ajāpañcapradaḥ sukhī //
column2: One who eats for three nights in caitra and gives five goats would be happy.

column1: trirātraṃ payasaḥ pānamupavāsaparastryahaṃ / ṣaṣṭhyādi kārttike śukre kṛcchro māhendra ucyate //
column2: Drinking milk for three nights and fasting for three days on the sixth day etc. of the bright fortnight in kārttika is said to be the expiation māhendra.

column1: pañcarātraṃ payaḥ pītvā dadhyāhāro hy upoṣitaḥ / ekādaśyāṃ kārttike tu kṛcchro 'yaṃ bhāskarorthadaḥ //
column2: After having drunk milk for five nights, fasting, taking only curd, on the eleventh day in kārttika is known to be the expiation Bhāskara, that confers wealth.

column1: yavāgūṃ yāvakaṃ śākaṃ dadhi kṣīraṃ ghṛtaṃ jalaṃ /
column2: Taking gruel made of barley and rice, curd, milk, ghee and water on the fifth day etc.

column1: pañcamyādi site pakṣe kṛcchraḥ śāntapanaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: in the bright fortnight is known to be expiation sāntapana.

column1: māsavratakamākhyāsye bhuktimuktipradāyakaṃ /
column2: shall describe vows to be performed in different months , that would yield enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: āṣāḍhādicaturmāsamabhyaṅgaṃ varjayet sudhīḥ //
column2: A wise man should avoid bathing with oil for four months commencing with āṣāḍha.

column1: vaiśākhe puṣpalavaṇantyaktvā godo nṛpo bhavet /
column2: One who abstains from using flower and salt and gives a cow as a gift in vaiśākha would become a king.

column1: godo māsopavāsī ca bhīmavratakaro hariḥ //
column2: One who gives a cow and fasts a month is said to practise a terrible vow and is deemed to be lord Hari.

column1: āṣāḍhādicaturmāsaṃ prātaḥsnāyī ca viṣṇugaḥ /
column2: One who bathes daily early in the morning for four months commencing with āṣāḍha would reach lord Viṣṇu.

column1: māghe māsyatha caitre vā guḍadhenuprado bhavet // guḍavratastṛtīyāyāṃ gaurīśaḥ syānmahāvratī /
column2: One who gives molasses and cow in the month of māgha or caitra on the third day would be the great performer of the guḍavrata vow of giving away molasses and he would get an identical form of consort of Gaurī.

column1: mārgaśīrṣādimāseṣu naktakṛdviṣṇulokabhāk //
column2: One who eats food only in the night in the months of mārgaśīrṣa etc. would attain the world of lord Viṣṇu.

column1: ekabhaktavratī tadvad dvādaśīvratakaṃ pṛṭhak /
column2: So also one who eats only once a day and observes the twelfth day vow would do.

column1: phalavratī caturmāsaṃ phalaṃ tyaktvā pradāpayet // śrāvaṇādicaturmāsaṃ vrataiḥ sarvaṃ labhedvratī /
column2: One who rejects fruit for four months commencing with śrāvaṇa and gives the fruits as gift would get everything.

column1: āṣāḍhasya site pakṣe ekādaśyāmupoṣitaḥ //
column2: One should fast on the eleventh day in the bright fortnight in āṣāḍha and prepare to do the vows lasting for four months.

column1: āṣāḍhyāñcātha saṅkrāntau karkaṭasya hariṃ yajet //
column2: One should worship lord Hari in the āṣāḍha at the entry of the Sun into a constellation in karkaṭa.

column1: idaṃ vrataṃ mayā deva gṛhītaṃ puratastava /
column2: “O lord! This vow has been undertaken by me in your presence.

column1: nirvighnāṃ siddhimāyātu prasanne tvayi keśava //
column2: O Keśava! When you are pleased let it be accomplished without impediment.

column1: gṛhīte 'smin vrate deva yadyapūrṇe mriye hy ahaṃ / tanme bhavatu sampūrṇaṃ tvatprasādājjanārdana // māṃsādi tyaktvā vipraḥ syāttailatyāgī hariṃ yajet /
column2: O lord! If die after taking this vow and the vow becomes incomplete, let it become completed by your grace, O Janārdana!” One should avoid eating flesh and a brahmin should refrain from the use of oil and worship lord Hari.

column1: ekāntaropavāsī ca trirātraṃ viṣṇulokabhāk //
column2: One who fasts on alternate days and for three nights would reach the world of lord Viṣṇu.

column1: cāndrāyaṇī viṣṇulokī maunī syān muktibhājanaṃ / prājāpatyavratī svargī śaktuyāvakabhakṣakaḥ //
column2: One who practises the cāndrāyaṇa would reach the world of Viṣṇu, the vow of silence would be fit for liberation, the vow of prājāpatya eating the flour of barley would reach heaven.

column1: gugdhādyāhāravān svargī pañcagavyāmbubhktathā /
column2: One who takes milk etc. and one who takes five things got from a cow would reach heaven.

column1: śākamūlaphalāhārī naro viṣṇupurīṃ vrajet //
column2: A person eating vegetables, roots and fruits would reach the world of Viṣṇu.

column1: māṃsavarjī yavāhāro rasavarjī hariṃ vrajet /
column2: One who avoids flesh and tasty food and takes barley would reach lord Hari.

column1: kaumudavratamākhyāsye āśvine samupoṣitaḥ //
column2: shall describe the Kaumudavrata.

column1: dvādaśyāṃ pūjayedviṣṇuṃ pralipyābjotpalādibhiḥ / ghṛtena tilatailena dīpanaivedyamarpayet //
column2: Having observed a fast on the twelfth day in kārttika one should besmear lord Viṣṇu with sandal and worship him with lotuses and blue lotuses and offer a lamp lit by ghee and sesamum oil.

column1: oṃ namo vāsudevāya mālatyā mālayā yajet /
column2: “Oṃ obeisance to Vāsudeva.” One should worship him with a garland of mālatī flowers.

column1: dharmakāmārthamokṣāṃś ca prāpnuyāt kaumudavratī //
column2: One who practises the kaumudavrata would get piety, pleasure, wealth and liberation.

column1: sarvaṃ labheddhariṃ prārcya māsopavāsakavratī /
column2: One who practises the vow of fasting in the months specified and worships lord Hari would get everything.

column1: ṛtuvratāntyahaṃ vakṣye bhuktimuktipradāni te /
column2: shall describe the vows relating to the seasons that would bestow enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: indhanāni tu yo dadyādvarṣādicaturo hy ṛtūn // ghṛtadhenupradaścānte brāhmaṇo 'gnivratī bhavet /
column2: A brahmin who gives away fuel in the four seasons beginning with the rainy season and gives ghee and cow at the end would become agnivratī.

column1: kṛtvā maunantu sandhyāyāṃ māsānte ghṛtakumbhadaḥ // tilaghaṇṭāvastradātā sukhī sārasvatavratī /
column2: Maintaining silence at the twilight and giving a pitcher with ghee at the end of the month as well as sesamum, bell and clothes one would be happy.

column1: pañcāmṛtena snapanaṃ kṛtvābdaṃ dhenudo nṛpaḥ //
column2: One who bathes with the five sweet things for a year and gives away a cow would become a king.

column1: ekādaśyāntu naktāśī caitre bhaktaṃ nivedayet /
column2: Eating only in the night on the eleventh day in caitra food should be offered to lord Viṣṇu.

column1: haimaṃ viṣṇoḥ padaṃ yāti māsante viṣṇusadvratī //
column2: That person who practises the Viṣṇumadvrata would reach the golden feet of lord ViṣṇU at the end of the month.

column1: pāyasāśī goyugadaḥ śrībhāgdevīvratī bhavet /
column2: One who eats sweet gruel and offers a pair of cows as a gift would get fortune.

column1: nivedya pitṛdevebhyo yo bhuṅkte sa bhavennṛpaḥ //
column2: One who offers to the pitṛdevas the dead ancestors and eats the food would become a king.

column1: varṣavratāni coktāni saṅkrāntivratakaṃ vade /
column2: have described the Varṣavratas the vows relating to rainy season. shall describe the vows relating to the movement of the Sun.

column1: saṅkrāntau svargalokī syādrātrijāgaraṇānnaraḥ //
column2: A person who keeps awake in the night at the time of the movement of the Sun from one constellation into another would go to heaven.

column1: amāvāsyāṃ tu saṅkrāntau śivārkayajanāttathā /
column2: Similarly worship of Śiva in the form of the Sun at the time of the newmoon and Sun’s movement would get the same result.

column1: uttare tvayane cājyaprasthasnānena keśave // dvātriṃśatpalamānena sarvapāpaiḥ pramucyate /
column2: Bathing the image of Keśava with a prastha a kind of measure of clarified butter of thirtytwo pala measures one gets free from all sins.

column1: ghṛtakṣīrādinā snāpya prāpnoti viṣuvādiṣu //
column2: One who bathes the lord with ghee, milk etc. at the time of the equinox etc. would get the same fruits.

column1: strīṇāmumāvrataṃ śrīdaṃ tṛtīyāsvaṣṭamīṣu ca /
column2: The Umāvrata done on the third day and the eighth days confers fortune on women.

column1: gaurīṃ maheśvaraṃ cāpi yajet saubhāgyamāpnuyāt //
column2: One who worships goddess Gaurī and lord Maheśvara would get all fortunes.

column1: umāmaheśvarau prārcya aviyogādi cāpnuyāt /
column2: After worshipping Umāmaheśvara one gets nonseparation.

column1: mūlavratakarī strī ca umeśavratakāriṇī //
column2: The main performer of the vow in the Umeśavrata is the woman.

column1: sūryabhaktā tu yā nārī dhruvaṃ sā puruṣo bhavet /
column2: A woman who is devoted to the Sun would certainly become a male.

column1: dīpadānavrataṃ vakṣye bhuktimuktipradāyakaṃ /
column2: shall describe the vow of making a gift of a lamp that would yield enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: devadvijātikagṛhe dīpado 'bdaṃ sa sarvabhāk //
column2: One who gives a lamp to the abode of a deity or a house of a brahmin is rewarded with everything for a year.

column1: caturmāsaṃ viṣṇulokī kārttike svargalokyapi /
column2: One who does so for four months would reach the world of Viṣṇu, and giving in kārttika would reach heaven.

column1: dīpadānāt paraṃ nāsti na bhūtaṃ na bhaviṣyati //
column2: There is nothing greater than the gift of a lamp , neither there was, nor there would be.

column1: dīpenāyuṣyacakṣuṣmāndīpāllakṣmīsutādikaṃ /
column2: One gets longevity, eyesight, fortune and progeny etc. by giving a lamp.

column1: saubhāgyaṃ dīpadaḥ prāpya svargaloke nahīyate //
column2: One who gives a lamp enjoys in heaven after getting fortune.

column1: vidarbharājaduhitā lalitā dīpadātmabhāk / cārudharmakṣmāpapatnī śatabhāryādhikābhavat //
column2: Lalitā, the daughter of the king of Vidarbha, the beautiful and faithful spouse of a king became the foremost among hundreds of wives of the king by giving a lamp.

column1: dadau dīpasahasraṃ sā viṣṇorāyatane satī /
column2: That chaste lady used to give thousand lamps to the temple of Viṣṇu.

column1: pṛṣṭā sā dīpamāhātmyaṃ sapatnībhya uvāca ha //
column2: When enquired about the greatness of the lamp she said to her cowives as follows

column1: sauvīrarājasya purā maitreyo 'bhūt purohitaḥ /
column2: In olden days Maitreya was the priest of the king of Sauvīra.

column1: tena cāyatanaṃ viṣṇoḥ kāritaṃ devikātaṭe //
column2: He caused a temple to be built for lord Viṣṇu on the banks of Devikā.

column1: kārttike dīpakastena dattaḥ samprerito mayā / vaktraprāntena naśyantyā mārjārasya tadā bhayāt // nirvāṇavān pradīpto 'bhūdvartyā mūṣikayā tadā /
column2: He gave a lamp for that temple in kārttika. The lamp which was about to be extinguished was kindled with the wick by me as a mouse with my mouth taking shelter there on account of being afraid of a cat.

column1: mṛtā rājātmajā jātā rājapatnī śatādhikā //
column2: After the death was born as the daughter of a king and became a queen among the hundred of the king’s wives.

column1: asaṅkalpitamapyasya preraṇaṃ yat kṛtaṃ mayā / viṣṇāyatanadīpasya tasyedaṃ bhujyate phalaṃ //
column2: The fruit of that act of kindling the lamp of the temple of Viṣṇu, even though not resolved, is enjoyed by me.

column1: jātismarā hy ato dīpān prayacchāmi tvahar niśaṃ /
column2: Because remember my past birth. give lamps day and night.

column1: ekadaśyāṃ dīpado vai vimāne divi modate //
column2: One who gives a lamp on the eleventh day rejoices in heaven in a vehicle.

column1: jāyate dīpahartā tu mūko vā jaḍa eva ca / andhe tamasi duṣpāre narake patate kila //
column2: One who steals a lamp would become dumb or dull or fall into the dark hell difficult to be crossed.

column1: vikrośamānāṃś ca narān yamakiṅkarāhatān /
column2: Seeing the crying men, the servant of the God of Death said to them

column1: vilāpair alamatrāpi kiṃ vo vilapite phalaṃ //
column2: “Enough of your wailing.

column1: yadā pramādibhiḥ pūrvamatyantasamupekṣitaḥ / janturjanmasahasrebhyo hy ekasmin mānuṣo yadi //
column2: What use of your wailing over misdeeds wantonly done by you before? One is born as a man after a cycle of thousand births.

column1: tatrāpyativimūḍhātmā kiṃ bhogānabhidhāvati / svahitaṃ viṣayāsvādaiḥ krandanaṃ tadihāgataṃ //
column2: O Extremely stupid fellow! Why do you run after pleasures even in that life? The result of enjoying according to one’s desire is that of coming here and wailing.

column1: bhujyate ca kṛtaṃ pūrvametat kiṃ vo na cintitaṃ / parastrīṣu kucābhyaṅgaṃ prītaye duḥkhadaṃ hi vaḥ //
column2: You are enjoying the fruits of your past deed. Why have you not thought about it? The embrace of the breasts of other women for your pleasure has given you grief.

column1: muhūrtaviṣayāsvādo 'nekakoṭyavdaduḥkhadaḥ /
column2: The worldly enjoyment for a while causes grief many crores of years.

column1: parastrīhāriyadgītaṃ hā mātaḥ kiṃ vilapyate // ko 'tibhāro harernāmni jihvayā parikīrtane / vartitaile 'lpamūlye 'pi yadagnirlabhyate sadā //
column2: O Seducer of other’s wives! Why do you cry O Mother!? What would be very heavy to bear when the name of Hari is repeated with the tongue? Fire can be had always with a wick and oil at low cost.

column1: dānāśaktair harerdīpo hṛtastadvo 'sti duḥkhadaṃ /
column2: The lamp has been stolen by you not showing inclination for giving. That is the cause of your grief.

column1: idānīṃ kiṃ vilāpena sahadhvaṃ yadupāgataṃ //
column2: What use in wailing now? You bear that which has happened.

column1: lalitoktañca tāḥ śrutvā dīpadānāddivaṃ yayuḥ /
column2: After hearing what was told by Lalitā, the other wives reached heaven after giving a lamp .

column1: tasmāddīpapradānena vratānāmadhikaṃ phalaṃ //
column2: Hence there would be great benefit by the gift of a lamp.

column1: navavyūhārcanaṃ vakṣye nāradāya harīritaṃ /
column2: shall describe the navavyūhārcana worship in nine compartments that was narrated by Hari to Nārada.

column1: maṇḍale 'bje 'rcayenmadhye avījaṃ vāsudevakaṃ // āvījañca saṅkarṣaṇam pradyumnaṃ ca dakṣiṇe / aḥ anuruddhaṃ naiṛte oṃ nārāyaṇamapsu ca // tat sadbrahmāṇamanile huṃ viṣṇuṃ kṣauṃ nṛsiṃhakaṃ / uttare bhūrvarāhañca īśe dvāri ca paścime //
column2: The letter ‘a’ with Vāsudeva should be worshipped at the centre of a lotus figure and the letter ā with Saṅkarṣaṇa and Pradyumna at the south, the letter aḥ and Aniruddha at the southwest, the letter oṃ and Nārāyaṇa at the west, the words tat sat and Brahmā at the northwest, the letter huṃ and Viṣṇu and the letter kṣauṃ and Nṛsiṃha at the north, and the letter bhūḥ and Varāha at the northeast.

column1: kaṃ ṭaṃ saṃ śaṃ garutmantaṃ pūrvavaktrañca dakṣiṇe / khaṃ chaṃ vaṃ huṃ phaḍiti ca khaṃ ṭhaṃ phaṃ śaṃ gadāṃ vidhau //
column2: The letters kaṃ, ṭaṃ, tam, śaṃ and Garutmat vehicle of Viṣṇu should be worshipped at the western entrance of that figure, the letters khaṃ, chaṃ, vaṃ, huṃ, phaṭ and the eastern face at the south, the letters khaṃ, ṭhaṃ, phaṃ, śaṃ and the mace at the north.

column1: baṃ ṇaṃ maṃ kṣaṃ koṇeśañca ghaṃ daṃ bhaṃ haṃ śriyaṃ yajet /
column2: The letters baṃ, ṇaṃ, maṃ, kṣauṃ and Īśāna should be worshipped at the northeast, the letters dhaṃ, daṃ, bhaṃ, haṃ and Śri Lakṣmī at the south and the letters gaṃ, ḍaṃ, vaṃ, śaṃ and Puṣṭi.

column1: dakṣiṇe cottare puṣṭiṃ gaṃ ḍaṃ baṃ śaṃ svavījakaṃ // pīṭhasya paścime dhaṃ vaṃ vanamālāñca paścime / śrīvatsaṃ caiva saṃ haṃ laṃ chaṃ taṃ yaṃ kaustubhaṃ jale //
column2: The letters dhaṃ, vaṃ should be worshipped and the garland of wild flowers at the west of the pedestal, the śrīvatsa the mark on the chest of lord Viṣṇu and the letters saṃ, haṃ, laṃ at the west and the letters chaṃ, taṃ, yaṃ and the kaustubha the crestjewel to the west of it.

column1: daśamāṅgakramādviṣṇornamo 'nantamadho 'rcayet / daśāṅgādimahendrādīn pūrvādau caturo ghaṭān //
column2: After having worshipped with “Obeisance to Ananta”, worship should be made below in the order of the ten forms of Viṣṇu and the four pitchers representing Mahendra and others in the east and other directions in the above order of the ten forms of Viṣṇu.

column1: toraṇāni vitānaṃ ca agnyanilenduvījakaiḥ /
column2: The arches and canopy should also be worshipped in the same way.

column1: maṇḍalāni kramāddhyātvā tanuṃ vandya tataḥ plavet // amvarasthaṃ tato dhyātvā sūkṣmarūpamathātmanaḥ / sitāmṛte nimagnañca candravimvāt srutena ca //
column2: After having contemplated the orbs of fire, wind and moon with their respective letters in order, one should worship the body and then bathe it. One should then contemplate on the subtle form of the self in the sky, submerged in the white nectar that flows from the disc of the moon.

column1: tadeva cātmano vījamamṛtaṃ plavasaṃskṛtaṃ /
column2: That is the eternal seed of one’s self that has been consecrated by the flood.

column1: utpādyamānaṃ puruṣamātmānamupakalpayet //
column2: One should thus resolve the spirit that is being produced in the self l.

column1: utpanno 'smi svayaṃ viṣṇurvījaṃ dvādaśakaṃ nyaset /
column2: Then one should do the location of twelve letters after saying “ am verily Viṣṇu produced again”.

column1: hṛcchirastu śikhā caiva kavacaṃ cāstrameva ca // vakṣomūrdhaśikhāpṛṣṭhalocaneṣu nyaseta punaḥ /
column2: The heart, head, tuft, armour and weapons should be located respectively on the chest, head, tuft, back and eyes.

column1: astraṃ karadvaye nyasya tato divyatanurbhavet //
column2: Then the weapons should be located on the two hands. Then one would have a divine body.

column1: yathātmani tathā deve śiṣyadehe nyasettathā /
column2: One should do this location on the body of the disciple in the similar way as it has been done on one’s self as well as the deity.

column1: anirmālyā smṛtā pūjā yaddhareḥ pūjanaṃ hṛdi // sanirmālyā maṇḍalādau baddhanetrāś ca śiṣyakāḥ /
column2: The worship done for Hari on the heart is known to be anirmālyā without remnant and that done in a circle as sanirmālyā together with remnant. The disciples with their eyes covered should throw the flower on the images at the commencement of the worship.

column1: puṣpaṃ kṣipeyuryanmūrtau tasya tannāma kārayet //
column2: On which images the flower falls that name should be given to them.

column1: niveśya vāmataḥ śiṣyāṃstilavrīhighṛtaṃ hunet /
column2: Then the disciples should be seated on the left and sesamum,rice and ghee should be offered as oblation.

column1: śatamaṣṭottaraṃ hutvā sahasraṃ kāyaśuddhaye //
column2: After having made one hundred aud eight oblations, one should do thousand oblations for the purification of the body.

column1: navavyūhasya mūrtīnāmaṅgānāṃ ca śatādhikaṃ /
column2: One should do more than hundred oblations for the limbs of the images of the nine compartments.

column1: pūṛṇāndattvā dīkṣayettān guruḥ pūjyaś ca tair dhanaiḥ //
column2: After having made the final oblation the preceptor should initiate them the disciples. He has to be respected by them with riches etc.

column1: puṣpagandhadhūpadīpanaivedyaistuṣyate hariḥ /
column2: Lord Hari gets pleased with flowers , perfumes , incense , lamps and offerings .

column1: puṣpāṇi devayogyāni hy ayogyāni vadāmi te //
column2: shall describe you flowers which are fit and unfit for the god.

column1: puṣpaṃ śreṣṭhaṃ mālatī ca tamālo bhuktimuktimān /
column2: Mālatī is the excellent flower. Tamāla flower confers enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: mallikā sarvapāpaghnī yūthikā viṣṇulokadā //
column2: Mallikā jasmine destroys all sins. The flower yūthikā gets the world. of Viṣṇu.

column1: atimuktamayaṃ tadvat pāṭalā viṣṇulokadā / karavīrair viṣṇulokī javāpuṣpaiś ca puṇyavān //
column2: Atimukta will also get the same fruit. The pāṭalā flower conveys one to the world of Viṣṇu. One gets the world of Viṣṇu with the karaVīra flowers.

column1: pāvantīkubjakādyaiś ca tagarair viṣṇulokabhāk /
column2: One would reach the world of Viṣṇu with the pāvantī, kubjaka and tagara flowers.

column1: karṇikārair viṣṇulokaḥ karuṇṭhaiḥ pāpanāśanaṃ //
column2: One would reach the world of Viṣṇu with the karṇikāra. There would be destruction of sin with kuruṇṭha.

column1: padmaiś ca ketakībhiś ca kundapuṣpaiḥ parā gatiḥ /
column2: One will have an excellent position with lotuses, ketakī and jasmine.

column1: vāṇapuṣpair varvarābhiḥ kṛṣṇābhirharilokabhāk //
column2: One would reach the world of Hari with bāṇa flowers, barbara and kṛṣṇā.

column1: aśokaistilakaistadvadaṭarūṣabhavais tathā /
column2: Similar result would be got by aśoka, tilaka and aṭarūṣabhava.

column1: muktibhāgī bilvapatraiḥ śamīpatraiḥ parā gatiḥ // viṣṇulokī bhṛṅgarājaistamālasya dalais tathā /
column2: The leaves of bilva would confer liberation. One will have the supreme position with the leaves of śamī. One would reach the world of Viṣṇu with the bhṛṅgarāja.

column1: tulasī kṛṣṇagaurākhyā kalhārotpalakāni ca //
column2: The black and white basil, white lotus, blue lotuses, lotus, red lotus are meritorious.

column1: padmaṃ kokanadaṃ puṇyaṃ śatābjamālayā hariḥ /
column2: Lord Hari gets pleased with a garland of hundred lotuses.

column1: nīpārjunakadambaiś ca vakulaiś ca sugandhibhiḥ // kiṃśukair munipuṣpaistu gokarṇair nāgakarṇakaiḥ / sandhyāpuṣpair bilvatakai rañjanīketakībhavaiḥ // kuṣmāṇḍatimirotthaiś ca kuśakāśaśarodbhavaiḥ /
column2: One would get enjoyment and emancipation and destruction of sin with nīpa, arjuna, kadamba, vakula, fragrant kiṃśuka, munipuṣpa, gokarṇa, nāgakarṇa, sandhyā flower, bilva, rañjanī, ketakī, kūṣmāṇḍa, timira, kuśa, kāśa, śara, dyūta etc., maruvaka leaves and other fragrant leaves and flowers.

column1: bhuktimuktiḥ pāpahānirbhaktyā sarvaistu tuṣyati /
column2: The god would get pleased with all that is offered with devotion.

column1: svarṇalakṣādhikaṃ puṣpaṃ mālā koṭiguṇādhikā //
column2: A flower is more meritorious than a lakh of gold and a garland, more than a crore times.

column1: svavane 'nyavane puṣpaistriguṇaṃ vanajaiḥ phalaṃ /
column2: It would be three times more meritorious with the forest flowers than with the flowers from one’s own garden or another’s garden.

column1: viśīrṇairnārcayedviṣṇunnādhikāṅgairna moṭitaiḥ //
column2: One should not worship lord Viṣṇu with withered or broken flowers or flowers having more than the usual parts.

column1: kāñcanāraistathonmattairgirikarṇikayā tathā / kuṭajaiḥ śālmalīyaiś ca śirīṣair narakādikaṃ //
column2: One would reach hell by worshipping with kāñcanāra, unmatta, girikarṇikā, kuṭaja śālmalīyā and śirīṣa.

column1: sugandhairbrahmapadmaiś ca puṣpairnīlotpalairhariḥ / arkamandāradhustūrakusumairarcyate haraḥ //
column2: Lord Hari is pleased with sugandha, brahma, lotuses and blue lotuses. Lord Hara is worshipped with arka mandāra and ḍhustūra flowers.

column1: kuṭajaiḥ karkaṭīpuṣpaiḥ ketakīnna śive dadet /
column2: One should not offer Kuṭaja, karkaṭī flowers and ketakī for Śiva.

column1: kuṣmāṇḍanimbasambhūtaṃ paiśācaṃ gandhavarjitaṃ //
column2: One should not use kūṣmāṇḍa, nimba and wild flowers without fragrance in worship.

column1: ahiṃsā indriyajayaḥ kṣāntirjñānaṃ dayā śrutaṃ / bhāvāṣtapuṣpaiḥ sampūjya devān syād bhuktimuktibhāk //
column2: One would get enjoyment and emancipation by worshipping gods with the eight flowers of gestures such as nonviolence, conquest of senses, forbearance, knowledge, compassion and learning.

column1: ahiṃsā prathamaṃ puṣpaṃ puṣpamindriyanigrahaḥ /
column2: Nonviolence is the first flower. The second flower is the control of senses.

column1: sarvapuṣpaṃ dayā bhūte puṣpaṃ śāntirviśiṣyate //
column2: Compassion for the beings is said to be all flowers.

column1: śamaḥ puṣpaṃ tapaḥ puṣpaṃ dhyānaṃ puṣpaṃ ca saptamaṃ /
column2: The flower of tranquility excells. Quietitude is a flower and penance is a flower. Meditation is the seventh flower.

column1: satyañcaivāṣṭamaṃ puṣpametaistuṣyati keśavaḥ // etairevāṣṭabhiḥ puṣpaistuṣyatyevārcito hariḥ /
column2: Truth is the eighth flower. Lord Keśava is pleased with these flowers. When lord Hari is worshipped with these flowers, he certainly gets pleased.

column1: puṣpāntarāṇi santyatra vāhyāni manujottama //
column2: O Excellent among men! There are other external flowers.

column1: bhaktyā dayānvitairviṣṇuḥ pūjitaḥ parituṣyati /
column2: When lord Viṣṇu is worshipped with devotion together with compassion, he gets pleased.

column1: vāruṇaṃ salilaṃ puṣpaṃ saumyaṃ ghṛtapayodadhi //
column2: Water is the flower for Varuṇa. Ghee, milk and curd are the flowers for Soma.

column1: prājāpatyaṃ tathānnādi āgneyaṃ dhūpadīpakaṃ /
column2: Food etc. are the flowers for Prajāpati Brahmā and incense and lamp for Fire god.

column1: phalapuṣpādikañcaiva vānaspatyantu pañcamaṃ //
column2: The fifth flower is the fruits and flowers of the forest.

column1: pārthivaṃ kuśamūlādyaṃ vāyavyaṃ gandhacandanaṃ /
column2: The kuśa, roots etc. are the flowers of the earth. Fragrant sandal is that of the Wind god.

column1: śraddhākhyaṃ viṣṇupuṣpañca sarvadā cāṣṭapuṣpikāḥ //
column2: Earnestness is the flower for lord Viṣṇu. These are always the eight flowers.

column1: āsanaṃ mūrtipañcāṅgaṃ viṣṇurvā cāṣṭapuṣpikāḥ /
column2: The seat, the form, the five limbs such as the heart etc. and Viṣṇu are the eight flowers.

column1: viṣṇostu vāsudevādyairīśānādyaiḥ śivasya vā //
column2: Worship should be made with the names Vāsudeva and others for Viṣṇu and Īśāna and others for Śiva.

column1: puṣpādyaiḥ pūjanādviṣṇor na yāti narakāndave /
column2: One does not go to them if he worships lord Viṣṇu with flowers and other things.

column1: āyuṣo 'nte naraḥ prāṇairanicchannapi mucyate //
column2: A man gets released from his life forces at the end of his life even though he does not wish for it.

column1: jalamagnirviṣaṃ śastraṃ kṣudvyādhiḥ patanaṃ gireḥ / nimittaṃ kiñcidāsādya dehī prāṇairvimucyate //
column2: A man gets released from his life on account of some case such as water, fire, poison, weapon, hunger, illness and fall from a mountain.

column1: anyaccharīramādatte yātanīyaṃ svakarmabhiḥ /
column2: One takes another body to be experienced as a result of one’s own acts.

column1: bhuṅkte 'tha pāpakṛt duḥkhaṃ sukhaṃ dharmāya saṅgataḥ //
column2: One who has committed a sin would experience grief and one who does good deeds would experience happiness.

column1: nīyate yamadūtaistu yamaṃ prāṇibhayaṅkaraiḥ / kupathe dakṣiṇadvāri dharmikaḥ paścimādibhiḥ //
column2: One is led to the God of Death by the dreadful messengers of God of Death through the southern gate if one has taken evil path. Pious men would be taken by the western and other doors.

column1: yamājñaptaiḥ kiṅkaraistu pātyate narakeṣu ca /
column2: They are cast into hells by the servants being ordered by the God of Death.

column1: svarge tu nīyate dharmād vasiṣṭhādyuktisaṃśrayāt //
column2: On account of piety one is led to heaven according to the words of Vasiṣṭha.

column1: goghātī tu mahāvīcyāṃ varṣalakṣantu pīḍyate /
column2: The killer of a cow is tormented for a lakh of years in the mahāvīcī one of the hells.

column1: mahāpralayakaṃ yāvadraurave pīḍyate śanaiḥ /
column2: One who steals the land would be slowly tormented in the raurava hell till the great deluge.

column1: strībālavṛddhahantā tu yāvadindrāś caturdaśa // mahārauravake raudre gṛhakṣetrādidīpakaḥ /
column2: One who kills a woman, child or the old is tormented in the dreadful mahāraurava hell till the period of fourteen Indras. One who sets fire to the house, ground etc.

column1: dahyate kalpamekaṃ sa caurastāmisrake patet // naikakalpantu śūlādyairbhidyate yamakiṅkaraiḥ /
column2: is burnt for a kalpa million years of mortals. Thieves would fall into the tāmisraka hell. They would be pierced by the attendants of the God of Death with spears etc.

column1: mahātāmisrake sarpajalaukādyaiś ca pīḍyate //
column2: Then they would be tormented in the mahatāmisraka hell by serpents, leeches etc.

column1: yāvadbhūmirmātṛhādyā asipatravane 'sibhiḥ / naikakalpantu narake karambhavālukāsu ca //
column2: One who kills his mother would be struck by swords in the asipatravana forest where the trees have leaves as sharp as swords for many kalpa periods as long as the earth remains.

column1: yena dagdho janastatra dahyate vālukādibhiḥ /
column2: One who has burnt men would be burnt in muddy region with gravel etc.

column1: kākole kṛmiviṣṭhāśī ekākī miṣṭabhojanaḥ //
column2: One who has eaten sweet food alone will suffer in kākola hell eating the excreta of insects.

column1: kuṭṭale mūtraraktāśī pañcayajñakriyojjhitaḥ / sudurgandhe raktabhojī bhaveccābhakṣyabhakṣyakaḥ //
column2: One who has discontinued doing five sacrifices would suffer in kuṭṭala hell eating urine and blood. One who has eaten the forbidden food would take blood in the filthy hell.

column1: tailapāke tu tilavat pīḍyate parapīḍakaḥ /
column2: One who afflicts others would be tormented in the hell tailapāka like sesamum.

column1: tailapāke tu pacyeta śaraṇāgataghātakaḥ // nirucchāse dānanāśī rasavikrayako 'dhvare /
column2: sought refuge would be cooked in the tailapāka. One who withholds gifts at the sacrifice and who sells. wine would be thrown into the hell nirucchvāsa.

column1: nāmnā vajrakavāṭena mahāpāte tadānṛtī //
column2: Similarly, one who lies would be thrown into the great hell vajrakavāṭa.

column1: mahājvāle pāpabuddhiḥ krakace 'gamyagāminaḥ / saṅkarī guḍapāke ca pratudet paramarmanut //
column2: Evilminded persons would suffer in the hell mahājvāla one who has cohabited the forbidden woman would suffer in the hell krakaca, the doer of mixed sins in the hell one who strikes at other’s weakness would suffer in hells guḍapāka and pratoda.

column1: kṣārahrade prāṇihantā kṣuradhāre ca bhūmihṛt / ambarīṣe gosvarṇahṛd drumacchidvajraśastrake //
column2: One who steals the land would be placed under a current as sharp as a razor. One who steals a cow or gold would be thrown into the hell ambarīṣa. One who cuts a tree would be put in the hell vajraśastraka.

column1: madhuhartā parītāpe kālasūtre parārthahṛt /
column2: One who steals wine would be put into parītāpa hell and one who steals other’s wealth into kālasūtra hell.

column1: kaśmale 'tyantamāṃsāśī ugragandhe hy apiṇḍadaḥ // durdhare tu kācabhakṣī vandigrāharatāś ca ye /
column2: One who eats flesh in excess would be thrown into kaśmala hell. One who does not offer the riceballs for the manes would be put into ugragandha hell. One who receives a bribe would be tormented in the hell durdhara.

column1: mañjuṣe narake lohe 'pratiṣṭhe śrutinindakaḥ // pūtivaktre kūṭasākṣī pariluṇṭhe dhanāpahā /
column2: One who cohabits women taken captive would suffer in the hell called mañjūṣa. One who censures scriptures would be thrown in the unstable hell loha. One who bears false witness would be put in the hell pūtivaktra.

column1: bālastrīvṛddhaghātī ca karāle brāhmaṇārtikṛt //
column2: One who steals wealth and one who kills a child, woman or the old and one who afflicts a brahmin would suffer in the hell karāla.

column1: vilepe madyapo vipro mahātāmre tu medinaḥ //20//
column2: A brahmin who drinks wine would suffer in the hell vilepa. Those who have caused breach of friendship would be put into the hell mahātāmra.

column1: tathākramya pāradārān jvalantīmāyasīṃ śilāṃ / śālmalākhye tamāliṅgen nārī bahunaraṅgamā //
column2: One who cohabits others’ wives would enter the hell śālmala and embrace glowing iron or stone. Similarly, a woman cohabiting many men would do.

column1: āsphoṭajihvoddharaṇaṃ strīkṣaṇān netrabhedanaṃ / aṅgārarāśau kṣipyante mātṛputryādigāminaḥ // caurāḥ kṣuraiś ca bhidyante svamāṃsāśī ca māṃsabhuk /
column2: Those who cohabit their mothers and daughters, those who have cut the tongue of others, those who have looked at others’ wives with lustful eyes and those who have plucked the eyes would be thrown into a heap of charcoal. Thieves would be pierced with razors. One who eats flesh would be made to eat his own flesh.

column1: māsopavāsakartā vai na yāti narakannaraḥ // ekādaśīvratakaro bhīṣmapañcakasad vratī /
column2: One who practises fasting for the stipulated months would not go to hell. So also one who practises the vow on the eleventh day and the bhīṣmapañcakavratawould not go to hell.

column1: vrataṃ māsopavāsañca sarvotkṛṣṭaṃ vadāmi te /
column2: shall describe the vow known as fasting for a month , that is the most excellent among the vows.

column1: kṛtvā tu vaiṣṇavaṃ yajñaṃ gurorājñāmavāpya ca // kṛcchrādyaiḥ svabalaṃ buddhvā kuryān māsopavāsakaṃ / vānaprastho yatirvātha nārī vā vidhavā mune //
column2: After having done the sacrifice relating to lord Viṣṇu and got the command of the preceptor and knowing one’s own strength with the practice of kṛcchra etc., O Sage! a forester or an ascetic or a woman or a widow should fast for a month.

column1: āśvinasyāmale pakṣe ekādaśyāmupoṣitaḥ / vratametattu gṛhṇīyādyāvattriṃśaddināni tu //
column2: One should undertake to observe this vow for thirtytwo days after having fasted on the eleventh day of the dark fortnight of the month of āśvina OctoberNovember.

column1: adyaprabhṛtyahaṃ viṣṇo yāvadutthānakantava / arcayetvāmanaśnan hi yāvat triṃśaddināni tu //
column2: “O lord Viṣṇu! Commencing from this day until you get up from sleep shall worship you without taking food for thirty days.

column1: kārttikāśvinayorviṣṇoryāvadutthānakantava /
column2: O Viṣṇu! this vow would be till you get up in the months of āśvina and kārttika.

column1: mriye yadyantarāle 'haṃ vratabhaṅgo na me bhavet //
column2: Let not my vow be incomplete if happen to die in the middle.”.

column1: trikālaṃ pūjayedviṣṇuṃ triḥsnāto gandhapuṣpakaiḥ /
column2: Lord Viṣṇu should be worshipped thrice with fragrant flowers after bathing thrice.

column1: viṣṇorgītādikaṃ japyandhyānaṃ kuryād vratī naraḥ //
column2: The person practising the vow should repeat the songs of lord Viṣṇu and contemplate on him.

column1: vṛthāvādampariharedarthākāṅkṣāṃ vivarjayet / nāvratasthaṃ spṛśet kañcidvikarmasthānna cālayet //
column2: He should avoid vain discussion and should avoid desire for wealth. He should not touch someone who is not practising the vow. He should not enter into conversation with those addicted to vices.

column1: devatāyatane tiṣṭhedyāvat triṃśaddināni tu /
column2: He should dwell in temple for thirty days.

column1: dvādaśyāṃ pūjayitvā tu bhojayitvā dvijānvratī // samāpya dakṣiṇāṃ dattvā pāraṇantu samācaret /
column2: The observer of the vow should worship the brahmins on the twelfth day and feed them. After completing vow and paying fees, he should break the fast.

column1: bhuktimuktimavāpnoti kalpāṃś caiva trayodaśa //
column2: One would get enjoyment and emancipation for thirteen kalpas a kalpa is equal to million years by practising thus.

column1: kārayedvaiṣṇavaṃ yajñaṃ yajedviprāṃstrayodaśa /
column2: He should do the sacrifice relating to Viṣṇu and worship thirteen brahmins.

column1: tāvanti vastrayugmāni bhājanānyāsanāni ca // chatrāṇi sapavitrāṇi tathopānadyugāni ca /
column2: He should give them as many pairs of clothes, vessels, seats, umbrellas, metal rings, pairs of sandals, upper cloth and sacred threads.

column1: yogapaṭṭopavītāni dadyādviprāya tairmataḥ // anyaviprāya śayyāyāṃ haimaṃ viṣṇuṃ prapūjya ca /
column2: All these things should also be given to another brahmin being permitted by them. After having worshipped golden lord Viṣṇu on the bed, he should worship his own form with clothes and other things.

column1: sarvapāpavinirmukto vipro viṣṇuprasādataḥ / viṣṇulokaṃ gamiṣyāmi viṣṇureva bhavāmyahaṃ //
column2: Then he should tell brahmins, “O Brahmins! am going to the world ofViṣṇu being freed from all sins by the grace of lord Viṣṇu. becoming lord Viṣṇu himself”.

column1: vraja vraja devabuddhe viṣṇoḥ sthānamanāmayaṃ / vimānenāmalastatra tiṣṭhed viṣṇusvarūpadhṛk //
column2: The brahmins should say, “O One with divine wisdom! You go to the faultless place of lord Viṣṇu by this vehicle and remain there spotless bearing the form of lord Viṣṇu”.

column1: dvijānuktvātha tāṃ śayyāṃ gurave 'tha nivedayet /
column2: Then that bed should be offered to the preceptor.

column1: kulānāṃ śatamuddhṛtya viṣṇulokannayed vratī //
column2: One who practises thus would elevate hundreds of his family and take them to the world of Viṣṇu.

column1: māsopavāsī yaddeśe sa deśo nirmalo bhavet /
column2: That country in which there is a person observing fast for a month, would become spotless.

column1: kiṃ punastatkulaṃ sarvaṃ yatra māsopavāsakṛt // vratasthaṃ mūrchitaṃ dṛṣṭvā kṣīrājyañcaiva pāyayet /
column2: What to speak about the family in which there is one who fasts for a month! Seeing the person practising a vow fallen into a swoon, one should make him drink milk and clarified butter.

column1: naite vrataṃ vinighranti havirviprānumoditaṃ //
column2: These things would not nullify the vow.

column1: kṣīraṃ gurorhitauṣadhva āpo mūlaphalāni ca /
column2: The ghee is allowed by the brahmins, and milk, water, roots are beneficial remedies administered by the preceptors.

column1: viṣṇurmahauṣadhaṃ kartā vratamasmāt samuddharet //
column2: Lord Viṣṇu is the maker of all remedies. Hence he will make the vow complete.

column1: bhīṣmapañcakamākhyāsye vratarājantu sarvadaṃ /
column2: shall describe the Bhīṣmapañcaka, that is the foremost among the vows and that which yields everything.

column1: kārttikasyāmale pakṣe ekādaśyāṃ samacaret //
column2: It should be done on the eleventh day in the bright fortnight in kārttika.

column1: dināni pañcatriḥsnātī pañcavrīhitilais tathā / tarpayeddevapitrādīn maunī sampūjayeddhariṃ //
column2: The observer of the vow should bathe thrice daily for five days and satisfy gods and manes with five kinds of grains and sesamum.

column1: pañcagavyena saṃsnāpya devaṃ pañcāmṛtena ca / candanādyaiḥ samālipya gugguluṃ saghṛtandahet //
column2: Having bathed the deity with the five things got from a cow and with the five sweet things, sandal paste should be besmeared and guggulu should be burnt along with ghee.

column1: dīpaṃ dadyāddivārātrau naivedyaṃ paramānnakaṃ /
column2: A lamp should be offered. Food offering shoud be made day and night.

column1: oṃ namo vāsudevāya japedaṣṭottaraṃ śataṃ //
column2: He should then repeat the syllable “Oṃ obeisance to Vāsudeva” one hundred and eight times.

column1: juhuyācca ghṛtābhyaktāṃstilavrīhīṃstato vratī / ṣaḍakṣareṇa mantreṇa svāhākārānvitena ca //
column2: The performer of the vow should then make oblations of sesamum and rice dipped in ghee with the sacred syllable of six letters along with the word ‘oblations.’

column1: kamalaiḥ pūjayet pādau dvitīye bilvapatrakaiḥ / jānu sakthi tṛtīye 'tha nābhiṃ bhṛṅgarajena tu // vāṇabilvajavābhistu caturthe pañcame 'hani /
column2: He should worship the feet with lotuses on the first day, the knee and thigh with the bilva leaves on the second day, the navel with the bhṛṅgarāja on the third day, with the bāṇa, bilva and japā flowers on the fourth day and with mālatī on the fifth day.

column1: mālatyā bhūmiśāyī syādekādaśyāntu gomayaṃ // gomūtraṃ dadhi dugdhaṃ ca pañcame pañcagavyakaṃ /
column2: He should use cowdung on the eleventh day and cow’s urine, curd and milk on the subsequent days. He should use five things got from a cow on the fifth day.

column1: paurṇamāsyāñcarennaktaṃ bhuktiṃ muktiṃ labhedvratī //
column2: He should take food only in the night on the full moon day. The votary would get enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: bhīṣmaḥ kṛtvā hariṃ prāptastenaiva bhīṣmapañcakaṃ /
column2: After having practised the Bhīṣmapañcaka Bhīṣma reached lord Hari.

column1: brāhmaṇaḥ pūjanādyaiś ca upavāsādikaṃ vrataṃ //
column2: One should worship lord Brahmā and fast while practising the vow.

column1: agastyo bhagavānviṣṇustamabhyarcyāpnuyāddhariṃ /
column2: Sage Agastya is verily lord Viṣṇu. After having worshipped him one would reach lord Viṣṇu.

column1: aprāpte bhāskare kanyāṃ satribhāgaistribhirdinaiḥ // arghyaṃ dadyādagastyāya pūjayitvā hy upoṣitaḥ /
column2: When the Sun has not entered the constellation Virgo one should offer libation to Agastya for three days and onethird part of a day after having fasted and worshipped him.

column1: kāśapuṣpamayīṃ mūrtiṃ pradoṣe vinyased ghaṭe // muneryajettāṃ kumbhasthāṃ rātrau kuryāt prajāgaraṃ /
column2: An image of the sage Agastya made of the kāśa flower kāśapuṣpa should be located in a pot at the time of nightfall and that image in the pot should be worshipped. He should then remain awake in the night.

column1: agastya miniśārdūla tejorāśe mahāmate // imāṃ mama kṛtāṃ pūjāṃ gṛhṇīṣva priyayā saha /
column2: “O Agastya! The foremost among sages! A multitude of brilliance! Greatminded person! You accept with your wife this worship done by me”.

column1: āvāhyārghye ca sammukhyaṃ prārcayeccandanādinā // jalāśayasamīpe tu prātarnītvārghyamarpayet /
column2: After having invoked the presence of of the sage with libation, he should worship him with sandal and other things. After having led the image near the water tank in the morning libation should be offered.

column1: kāśapuṣpapratīkāśa agnimārutasambhava // mitrāvaruṇayoḥ putra kumbhayone namo 'stu te / ātāpirbhakṣito yena vātāpiś ca mahāsuraḥ // samudraḥ śoṣito yena so 'gastyaḥ sammukho 'stu me /
column2: “O One having the colour of kāśa flower! Born of Fire and Wind gods! Son of Mitra and Varuṇa! Born in the pitcher! Obeisance be to you! That Agastya by whom Atāpi was eaten as also Vātāpi, the great demon and the ocean was dried, may he be present before me.

column1: agastiṃ prārthayiṣyāmi karmaṇā manasā girā //
column2: am praying to the sage Agastya with my deeds, mind and speech.

column1: arcayisyāmyahaṃ maitraṃ paralokābhikāṅkṣayā / dvīpāntarasamutpannaṃ devānāṃ paramaṃ priyaṃ //
