column2: One would reach heaven by giving a house, a hut for an ascetic, hall and shelter. One who builds a cattleshed and gifts it would be free from sin and reach heaven. One who makes a gift of the buffalo the vehicle of the God of Death would be free from sin and would go to heaven.

column1: brahmā haro harirdevair madhye ca yamadūtakaḥ // pāśī tasya śiraśchittvā taṃ dadyāt svargabhāgbhavet /
column2: One who gives as a gift the images of gods Brahmā Hara Śiva, Hari with the celestials and the messenger of the God of Death in their middle and the god Pāśī Varuṇa as cutting the head of the latter would reach heaven.

column1: trimukhākhyamidaṃ dānaṃ gṛhītvā tu dvijo 'ghabhāk //
column2: A brahmin who accepts this gift known as the ‘threefaced’ would incur sin.

column1: cakraṃ rūpyamayaṃ kṛtvā ke dhṛtvā tat pradāpayet / hemayuktaṃ dvijāyaitat kālacakramidammahat //
column2: One should give to a brahmin a wheel made of silver together with gold after having placed it on his own lap. This is known as the ‘wheel of time’ of great merit.

column1: ātmatulyantu yo lauhaṃ dadenna narakaṃ vrajet /
column2: One who makes a gift of iron equal to one’s weight would not go to hell.

column1: pañcāśatpalasaṃyuktaṃ lauhadaṇḍaṃ tu yo 'rpayet // vastreṇācchādya viprāya yamadaṇḍo na vidyate /
column2: One who gives an iron rod of fifty palas covered by a cloth to a brahmin would not get the chastising rod of the God of Death.

column1: mūlaṃ phalādi vā dravyaṃ saṃhataṃ vātha caikaśaḥ // mṛtyujjayaṃ samuddiśya dadyādāyurvivardhaye /
column2: One should give the root or fruit or other material collectively or separately for the Conqueror of Death for the increase of one’s life.

column1: pumān kṛṣṇatilaiḥ kāryo raupyadantaḥ suvarṇadṛk // khaḍgodyatakaro dīrgho javākusumamaṇḍalaḥ / raktāmvaradharaḥ sragvī śaṅkamālāvibhūṣitaḥ // upānadyugayuktāṅghriḥ kṛṣṇakambalapārśvakaḥ /
column2: One should make a figure of a man with black sesamum, with the teeth made of silver, eye made of gold, wielding a sword in the hand, bedecked with japā flowers, wearing red cloth, adorned with a garland of conchshells, the feet having a pair of sandals, the sides covered by black wool and holding a ball of flesh in his left hand. He is known as the embodiment of time.

column1: sampūjya tañca gandhādyaiḥ brāhmaṇāyopapādayet /
column2: After having worshipped that image with perfumes and other things, it should be given to a brahmin.

column1: maraṇavyādhihīnaḥ syādrājarājeśvaro bhavet //
column2: Such a giver would be free from death and disease and become a monarch.

column1: govṛṣau tu dvije dattvā bhuktimuktimavāpnuyāt /
column2: One who gives a gift of a, cow and a bull to a brahmin would get enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: revantādhiṣṭhitañcāśvaṃ haimaṃ dattvā na mṛtybhāk //
column2: One would not die by giving a golden hairy horse.

column1: ghaṇṭādipūrṇamapyekaṃ dattvā syādbhuktimuktibhāk /
column2: One who makes such a gift endowed with bells would also get enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: sarvān kāmānavāpnoti yaḥ prayacchati kāñcanaṃ //
column2: One who gives gold would get the desired things.

column1: suvarṇe dīyamāne tu rajataṃ dakṣiṇeṣyate / anyeṣāmapi dānānāṃ suvarṇaṃ dakṣiṇā smṛtā //
column2: When gold is given as gift, silver should be given as remuneration. Gold is the remuneration even in the case of other gifts.

column1: suvarṇaṃ rajataṃ tāmraṃ taṇḍulaṃ dhānyameva ca / nityaśrāddhaṃ devapūjā sarvametadadakṣiṇaṃ //
column2: No remuneration should be given when gold, silver, copper, rice and other grains are given as gift or at the daily ceremony for the manes and at the worship of gods.

column1: rajataṃ dakṣiṇā pitre dharmakāmārthasādhanaṃ /
column2: Silver given as remuneration at the ceremony for the manes is a means to get piety, pleasure and material comfort.

column1: suvarṇaṃ rajataṃ tāmraṃ maṇimuktāvasūni ca // sarvametanmahāprājño dadāti vasudhāndadat /
column2: A wiseman who gives land as a gift should also give gold, silver, copper, gems, pearls, wealth and all other things.

column1: pitṝṃś ca pitṛlokasthān devasthāne ca devatāḥ // santarpayati śāntātmā yo dadāti vasundharām /
column2: One who makes a gift of land, that composed man satisfies the manes in their world and the gods in the world of gods.

column1: kharvaṭaṃ kheṭakaṃ vāpi grāmaṃ vā śasyaśālinaṃ // nivartanaśataṃ vāpi tadardhaṃ vā gṛhādikaṃ /
column2: One who gives as a gift a market town or small town or village or field abound with grains or hundred nivartana or half of that or a house etc.

column1: api gocarmamātrāmbā dattvorvīṃ sarvabhāg bhavet //
column2: or only gocarma extent of land would get all things.

column1: tailavinduryathā cāpsu prasarped bhūgataṃ tathā / sarveṣāmevadānānamekajanmānugaṃ phalaṃ //
column2: Just as a drop of oil spreads on the waters so also the fruit of all gifts would follow the mortal in the next birth.

column1: hāṭakakṣitigaurīṇāṃ saptajanmānugaṃ phalaṃ /
column2: The benefit of making a gift of gold, land and an eight year old girl would follow the giver in his seven births.

column1: trisaptakulamuddhṛtya kanyādo brahmalokabhāk //
column2: One who gives a girl in marriage would elevate twentyone generations of his family and attain the world of Brahmā.

column1: gajaṃ sadakṣiṇaṃ dattvā nirmalaḥ svargabhāg bhavet / aśvaṃ dattvāyurārogyasaubhāgyasvargamāpnuyāt //
column2: Having given an elephant together with remuneration one becomes free from blemish and would attain heaven. Having given a horse one would get long and healthy life and fortune and ascend heaven.

column1: dāsīṃ dattvā dvijendrāya apsarolokamāpnuyāt /
column2: One who gives a maid servant to an excellent brahmin would reach the world of nymphs.

column1: dattvā tāmramayīṃ sthālīṃ palānāṃ pañcabhiḥ śataiḥ // ardhaistadardhair ardhair vā bhuktimuktimavāpnuyāt /
column2: Having given a copper plate weighing five hundred palas a measure of weight or half the weight or a quarter of that weight or oneeighth of the weight would get enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: śakaṭaṃ vṛṣasaṃyuktaṃ dattvā yānena nākabhāk // vastradānāllabhedāyurārogyaṃ svargamakṣayaṃ /
column2: By giving a cart together with a bull one would go to heaven by means of a cart. One who makes a gift of cloth would get longevity, health and undecaying heaven.

column1: dhānyagodhūmakalamayavādīn svargabhāg dadat // āsanaṃ taijasaṃ pātraṃ lavaṇaṃ gandhacandanaṃ /
column2: Having given as a gift a seat, metallic vessel, salt, fragrant sandal, incense, lamp, betel, iron, silver, gem and other rare materials, one would get enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: tilāṃś ca tilapātrañca dattvā svargamavāpnuyāt //
column2: One would ascend heaven by giving sesamum and a vessel for keeping sesamum.

column1: annadānāt paraṃ nāsti na bhūtaṃ na bhaviṣyati /
column2: There is nothing superior to the gift of food. Neither there was nor there would be.

column1: hastyaśvarathadānāni dāsīdāsagṛhāṇi ca // annadānasya sarvāṇi kalāṃ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīṃ /
column2: The merit of gift of an elephant, horse, chariot, maidservant, servant and house will not equal a sixteenth part of the merit of giving food.

column1: kṛtvāpi sumahatpāpaṃ yaḥ paścādannado bhavet // sarvapāpavinirmukto lokānāpnoti cākṣayān /
column2: One who gives food after committing a great sin would become free from all sins and attain undecaying worlds.

column1: pānīyañca prapāndattvā bhuktimuktimavāpnuyāt // agniṃ kāṣṭhañca mārgādau dattvā dīptyādimāpnuyāt /
column2: One who sets up a place for distributing water for drinking would get enjoyment and emancipation. By giving fire and firewood for travellers on the way, one would get radiance etc.

column1: devagandharvanārībhirvimāne sevyate divi //
column2: and would be served in the celestialvehicle in heaven by the celestials, gandharvas and women.

column1: ghṛtaṃ taikañca lavaṇaṃ dattvā sarvamavāpnuyāt /
column2: One would get all things by giving ghee, oil and salt.

column1: chatropānahakāṣṭhādi dattvā svarge sukhī vaset //
column2: After having given umbrella, sandal and firewood etc. one would dwell in heaven happily.

column1: pratipattithimukhyeṣu viṣkumbhādikayogake / caitrādau vatsarādau ca aśvinyādau hariṃ haraṃ // brahmāṇaṃ lokapālādīn prārcya dānaṃ mahāphalaṃ /
column2: A gift made after worshipping lords Hari, Hara, Brahmā and the guardian deities on the important lunar days like the first etc., on the combinations known as viṣkamhha etc., in the months caitra and others, in the years and the asterisms aśvinī etc. is of great merit.

column1: vṛkṣārāmān bhojanādīn mārgasaṃvāhanādikān // pādābhyaṅgādikaṃ dattvā bhuktimuktimavāpnuyāt /
column2: One would get enjoyment and emancipation by providing shady trees, feeding places, vehicles to carry burden and for anointing the feet.

column1: trīṇi tulyaphalānīha gāvaḥ pṛthvī sarasvatī //
column2: There are three things which are of equal merits. They arecows, land and imparting knowledge.

column1: vrāhmīṃ sarasvatīndattvā nirmalo brahmalokabhāk / saptadvīpamahīdaḥ sa brahmajñānaṃ dadāti yaḥ //
column2: By imparting knowledge one becomes blemishless and attains the world of Brahmā. One who imparts knowledge about the brahman, would be equal to one who gives earth consisting of seven continents.

column1: abhayaṃ sarvabhūtebhyo yo dadyāt sarvabhāṅ naraḥ /
column2: One who gives refuge to all beings would get all things.

column1: purāṇaṃ bhārataṃ vāpi rāmāyaṇamathāpi vā // likhitvā pustakaṃ dattvā bhuktimuktimavāpnuyāt /
column2: One who copies and gives the purāṇa or Bhārata or Rāmāyaṇa, would get enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: vedaśāstraṃ nṛtyagītaṃ yo 'dhyāpayati nākabhāk //
column2: One who teaches scriptures dancing and music would reach heaven.

column1: vittaṃ dadyādupādhyāye chātrāṇāṃ bhojanādikaṃ /
column2: Money should be given to the teacher and food etc. for the students.

column1: kimadattaṃ bhavettena dharmakāmādidarśinā //
column2: What more can be possibly given by one who does with a motive to acquire virtues and desires.

column1: vājapeyasahasrasya samyagdattasya yat phalaṃ / tatphalaṃ sarvamāpnoti vidyādānanna saṃśayaḥ //
column2: There is no doubt that one would get by imparting knowledge every benefit that he would get by performing a thousand Vājapeya sacrifices.

column1: śivālaye viṣṇugṛhe sūryasya bhavane tathā / sarvadānapradaḥ sa syāt pustakaṃ vācayettu yaḥ //
column2: One who reads a book would be the giver of all gifts at the temples of lords Śiva, Viṣṇu and the Sungod.

column1: trailokye caturo varṇāś catvāraścāśramāḥ pṛthak / brahmādyā devatāḥ sarvā vidyādāne pratiṣṭhatāḥ //
column2: All the castes and the four institutions of life separately and all the gods such as Brahmā and others are established on the gift of knowledge.

column1: vidyā kāmadughā dhenurvidyā cakṣuranuttamaṃ /
column2: Knowledge is the wishyielding cow. It is the unsurpassing eye.

column1: upavedapradānena gandharvaiḥ saha modate // vedāṅgānāñca dānena svargalokamavāpnuyāt /
column2: One rejoices with the Gandharvas by giving the Upavedas the secondary texts such as the Āyurveda. One would attain heaven by giving the accessory texts of scriptures.

column1: dharmaśāstrapradānena dharmeṇa saha modate //
column2: One would rejoice with piety by giving the religious law books.

column1: vidyādānamavāpnoti pradānāt pustakasya tu //
column2: One would reap the same benefit by giving a book as he would by imparting knowledge.

column1: śāstrāṇi ca purāṇāni dattvā sarvamavāpnuyāt /
column2: One would get everything by giving sacred religious texts and Purāṇas.

column1: śiṣyāṃś ca śikṣayedyastu puṇḍalīkaphalaṃ labhet //
column2: One would get the benefit of Puṇḍarīka by imparting knowledge to the disciples.

column1: yena jīvati taddattvā phalasyānto na vidyate /
column2: There is not known to be any limit for the benefit accrued by one who gives that by which he lives.

column1: loke sreṣṭhatamaṃ sarvamātmanaścāpi yat priyaṃ // sarvaṃ pitṝṇāṃ dātavyaṃ teṣāmevākṣayārthinā /
column2: That which is the most excellent in the world and that which is liked by one should be given to the manes by one who desires to have them without depletion.

column1: viṣṇuṃ rudraṃ padmayoniṃ devīvighneśvarādikān // pūjayitvā pradadyādyaḥ pūjādravyaṃ sa sarvabhāk /
column2: One who gives materials for worship after having worshipped lords Viṣṇu, Rudra Śiva, the Lotusborn Brahmā, Goddess, Vighneśvara lord of impediments and others would get everything.

column1: devālayaṃ ca pratimāṃ kārayat sarvamāpnuyāt //
column2: One who causes to construct a temple and to make an image would get all things.

column1: sammārjanaṃ copalepaṃ kurvan syānnirmalaḥ pumān /
column2: One would be free from blemishes by washing and cleaning the temple.

column1: nānāmaṇḍalakāryagre maṇḍalādhipatirbhavet //
column2: One who draws the mystic diagrams would become the ruler of a province subsequently.

column1: gandhaṃ puṣpaṃ dhūpadīpaṃ naivedyañca pradakṣiṇaṃ / ghaṇṭādhvajavitānañca prekṣaṇaṃ vādyagautakaṃ // vastrādidattvādevāya bhuktimuktimavāpnuyāt /
column2: After having given perfumes, flowers, incense, lamp, food offering, circumambulation, bell, banner, canopy, arranged a show, musical instruments and music and clothes for the lord, one would get enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: kastūrikāṃ śihlakañca śrīkhaṇḍamagurūntathā // karpūrañca tathāmustaṃ gugguluṃ vijayaṃ dadet /
column2: One should give musk, benzoin, sandal wood, agallochum, camphor, musta a kind of grass, guggulu a fragrant resin and vijaya.

column1: ghṛtaprasthena saṃsthāpya saṅkrāntyādau sa sarvabhāk //
column2: One who establishes light at the time of solstice and others with a prastha a measure of ghee would get everything.

column1: snānaṃ palaśataṃ jñeyamabhyaṅgaṃ pañcaviṃśatiḥ /
column2: Bathing is known to be with hundred palas of materials, bathing with oil with twentyfive palas.

column1: palānāntu sahasreṇa mahāsnānaṃ prakīrtitaṃ //
column2: A great bathing is said to be with a thousand palas of materials.

column1: daśāparādhāstoyena kṣīreṇa snāpanācchataṃ / sahasraṃ payasā dadhnā ghṛtenāyutamiṣyate //
column2: By bathing with water ten sins are washed off, by bathṃg with thick milk hundred sins are washed off, by bathing with milk a thousand sins are washed off and ten thousand sins are washed off by bathing with ghee.

column1: dāsīdāsamalaṅkāraṃ gobhūmyaśvagajādikaṃ / devāya dattvā saubhāgyaṃ dhanāyuṣmān vrajeddivaṃ //
column2: One would get fortune and wealth and would go to heaven by giving a maidservant, servant, ornaments, cow, land, horse and elephant and other things for the deity.

column1: kāmyadānāni vakṣyāmi sarvakāma pradāni te /
column2: shall describe gifts that confer the desired benefits.

column1: nityapūjāṃ māsi māsi kṛtvātho kāmyapūjanaṃ //
column2: One should do daily worship each month and do the worship for the accomplishment of one’s desires.

column1: vratārhaṇaṃ guroḥ pūjā vatsarānte mahārcanaṃ /
column2: The undertaking of the vow, worship of the preceptor and the grand worship at the end of the year are the routines.

column1: aśvaṃ vai mārgaśairṣe tu kamalaṃ piṣṭasambhavaṃ // śivāya pūjya yo dadyāt sūryaloke ciraṃ vaset /
column2: One who gives a horse and a lotus made of flour to lord Śiva after worship in mārgaśīrṣa would live in the world of Sun for a long time.

column1: gajaṃ pauṣe piṣṭamayaṃ trisaptakulamuddharet //
column2: By giving an elephant made of flour in pauṣa, one would lift twentyone generations.

column1: māghe cāśvarathaṃ paiṣṭhaṃ dattvā narakaṃ vrajet /
column2: By giving a horse and a chariot made of flour in māgha, one would not go to hell.

column1: phālgune tu vṛṣaṃ paiṣṭaṃ svargabhuk syānmahīpatiḥ //
column2: One would become a monarch and would ascend heaven by giving a bull made of flour in phālguna.

column1: caitre cekṣumayīṃ gāvandāsadāsīsamanvitāṃ / dattvā svarge ciraṃ sthitvā tadante syānmahīpatiḥ //
column2: Having given a cow made of sugarcane together with a servant and a female servant in caitra, one would remain in heaven for a long time and would become a monarch at the end.

column1: saptavrīhīṃś ca vaiśākhe dattvā śivamayo bhavet /
column2: One would become verily lord Śiva himself by giving seven kinds of rice in vaiśākha.

column1: balimaṇḍalakañcānnaiḥ kṛtvāṣāḍhe śivo bhavet //
column2: One would become identical with lord Śiva by making a circular altar in the āṣāḍha.

column1: vimānaṃ śrāvaṇe pauṣpaṃ dattvā svargī tato nṛpaḥ /
column2: One would ascend heaven and also become a king by giving a vehicle made of flowers in śrāvaṇa.

column1: śatadvayaṃ phalānāntu dattvoddhṛtya kulaṃ nṛpaḥ //
column2: By giving two hundred fruits one would elevate his family and become a king.

column1: guggulādi dahedbhādre svargī sa syāttato nṛpaḥ /
column2: One would become a king after ascending heaven by giving guggulu gum resin etc. in bhādra.

column1: kṣīrasarpirbhṛtaṃ pātramāśvine svargadambhavet // kārttike guḍakhaṇḍājyaṃ dattvā svargī tato nṛpaḥ /
column2: Giving a vessel filled with milk and clarified butter in āśvina would convey one to heaven. Having given pieces of jaggery and clarified butter in the kārttika one would go to heaven and then be a king.

column1: merudānaṃ dvādaśakaṃ vakṣye 'haṃ bhuktimuktidaṃ //
column2: shall describe the twelve varieties of gifts known as merudāna heaps of things resembling the Meru mountain that confers enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: meruvrate tu kārttikyāṃ ratnamerundaded dvije /
column2: In the meruvrata one should give a meru mountain of gems to a brahmin in kārttika.

column1: sarveṣāñcaiva merūṇāṃ pramāṇaṃ kramaśaḥ śṛṇu //
column2: Listen to me. shall describe the measure of things in all the gifts of Merus duly.

column1: vajrapadmamahānīlanīlasphaṭikasañjñitaḥ / puṣpaṃ marakataṃ muktā prasthamātreṇa cottamaḥ //
column2: Only a prastha a measure of diamond, ruby, mahānīla a kind of sapphire, sapphire, crystal, topaz, emerald and pearl are excellent.

column1: madhyo 'rdhaḥ syāttadardho 'dho vittaśāṭhyaṃ vivarjayet /
column2: Half of that measure would be medium and a quarter of that would be inferior.

column1: kārṇikāyāṃ nyasenmeruṃ brahmaviṣṇvīśadaivataṃ //
column2: The Meru should be located in the pericarps presided by the lords Brahmā, Viṣṇu and Īśa.

column1: mālyavān pūrvataḥ pūjyastatpūrve bhadarasañjñitaḥ /
column2: Mālyavān should be worshipped on the east and that is known as Bhadra still to its east.

column1: aśvarakṣastataḥ prokto niṣadho merudakṣiṇe //
column2: Aśvarakṣa is said to be the next.

column1: hemakūṭo 'tha himavān trayaṃ saumye tathā trayaṃ /
column2: The Niṣadha, Hemakūṭa and Himavān, the three, should be worshipped on the south of Meru.

column1: nīlaḥ śvetaś ca śṛṅgī ca paścime gandhamādanaḥ //
column2: The mountains Gandhamādana, Vaikaṅka and Ketumāla would be on the west.

column1: vaikaṅkaḥ ketumālaḥ syānmerurdvādaśasaṃyutaḥ /
column2: Thus the Meru would be associated with the twelve mountains.

column1: sopavāso 'rcayedviṣṇuṃ śivaṃ vā snānapūrvakaṃ //
column2: One should worship lord Viṣṇu or lord Śiva after fasting preceded by bathing.

column1: devāgre cārcya meruñca mantrair viprāya vai dadet /
column2: The Meru should be worshipped with the sacred syllables in front of the deity and given to a brahmin.

column1: viprāyāmukagotrāya merundravyamayamparaṃ // bhuktyai muktyai nirmalatve viṣṇudaivaṃ dadāmi te / indraloke brahmaloke śivaloke hareḥ pure // kulamuddhṛtya krīḍeta vimāne devapūjitaḥ /
column2: One should say “ give this excellent material of the shape of Meru belonging to god Viṣṇu to a brahmin of such and such a gotra to become sinless and for the sake of enjoyment and emancipation.” One who does so would be honoured by the celestials and would sport in the divine chariot in the worlds of Indra, Brahmā, Śiva and Viṣṇu after elevating his family.

column1: anyeṣvapi ca kāleṣu saṅkrāntyādau pradāpayet //
column2: One should make the gift even at other times such as the entry of the Sun from one constellation into another.

column1: palānāntu sahasreṇa hemamerumprakalpayet /
column2: One should offer the golden Meru of the weight of a thousand palas.

column1: śṛṅgatrayasamāyuktaṃ brahmaviṣṇuharānvitaṃ //
column2: It should have three peaks representing the lords Brahmā, Viṣṇu and Hara Śiva.

column1: ekaikaṃ parvatantasya śataikaikena kārayet /
column2: Each one of the mountains should be hundred palas.

column1: meruṇā saha śailāstu khyātāstatra trayodaśa //
column2: Together with the Meru, the mountains are known to be thirteen.

column1: ayane grahaṇādau ca viṣṇvagre harimarcya ca / svarṇameruṃ dvijāyārpya viṣṇuloke ciraṃ vaset //
column2: One who makes a gift of gold Meru to a brahmin at the time of solstices, eclipses etc., in the presence of lord Viṣṇu, after having worshipped lord Hari Viṣṇu, would live in the world of Viṣṇu for a long time.

column1: paramāṇavo yāvanta iha rājā bhavecciraṃ /
column2: One would be a king for such a long time as the infinitesimal particles of the gift.

column1: raupyameruṃ dvādaśādriyutaṃ saṅkalpato dadet //
column2: One should resolve and give a silver Meru having twelve mountains.

column1: sitavastraṃ prasannāmbhaḥ phalī vṛkṣo nabho 'malaṃ //32//

aṅgāraṃ guḍasarjau ca muṇḍābhyaktañca nagnakaṃ / ayaḥ paṅkaṃ carmakeśau unmattañca napuṃsakaṃ // caṇḍālaśvapacādyāni narā bandhanapālakāḥ / garbhiṇī strī ca vidhavāḥ piṇyakādīni vai mṛtaṃ // tuṣabhasmakapālāsthibhinnabhāṇḍamaśastakaṃ /
column2: Mixtures of herbs and black cereals are inauspicious, Cotton, grass, dried cowdung, wealth, charcoal, molasses and resin, one having a shaven head or one that has besmeared oil for bathing and one that is nude, iron, mud, hide and hair, a lunatic, an eunuch, a cāṇḍāla, a dog, an outcaste and others, men guarding the captives, a pregnant woman, widow and oilcake, etc., dead body, husk, ash, skull and bone and broken vessel are not commendable to be seen.

column1: aśasto vādyaśabdaś ca bhinnabhairavajharjharaḥ // ehīti purataḥ śabdaḥ śasyate na tu pṛṣṭhataḥ / gaccheti paścācchabdo 'gryaḥ purastāttu vigarhitaḥ //
column2: The sounds of musical instruments that are broken, frightening and harsh are also not commendable. The sound ‘come on’, heard in front of the person undertaking a journey is commendable, while that from behind is not commendable.

column1: kva yāsi tiṣṭha mā gaccha kinte tatra gatasya ca / aniṣṭaśabdā mṛtyarthaṃ kravyādaś ca dhvajādigaḥ //
column2: The undesirable sounds such as “Where do you go”, ‘stand’, ‘Do not go’, ‘What is there for you by going’ are for death.

column1: skhalanaṃ vāhanānāñca śastrabhaṅgastathaiva ca / śiroghātaś ca dvārādyaiścchatravāsādipātanaṃ //
column2: So also the appearance of carnivorous animals, banners etc., the fall of vehicles etc., the breaking of weapons, dashing of the head against the door etc., and the fall of umbrella, dress etc., are not commendable.

column1: harimabhyarcya saṃstutya syādamaṅgalyanāśanaṃ /
column2: An inauspicious augury gets destroyed by the worship and invocation of lord Hari Viṣṇu.

column1: dvitīyantu tato dṛṣṭvā viruddhaṃ praviśedgṛhaṃ //
column2: If a second inauspicious augury is seen while setting out then one should reenter the house.

column1: śvetāḥ sumanasaḥ śreṣṭhāḥ pūrṇakumbho mahottamaḥ /
column2: White flowers are excellent augury. So also a pitcher full of water is greatly meritorious.

column1: dūrvārdragomayaṃ veśyā svarṇarūpyañca ratnakaṃ // vacāsiddhārthakauṣadhyo mudga āyudhakhaḍgakaṃ / chatraṃ pīṭhaṃ rājaliṅgaṃ śavaṃ ruditavarjitaṃ // phalaṃ ghṛṭaṃ dadhi payo akṣatādarśamākṣikaṃ / śaṅkhaṃ ikṣuḥ śubhaṃ vākyaṃ bhaktavāditagītakaṃ //
column2: Meat, fish, a distant sound, an old man, an animal, goat, cows,horses, elephants, images of gods, glowing flame, dūrvā grass, wet cowdung, courtesan, gold, silver, gem, vacā, white mustard, herbs, beans, weapons, sword, umbrella, throne, insignia of royalty, a dead body without being followed by mourners, fruit, ghee, curd, milk, unbroken rice, mirror, honey, conch, sugarcane, auspicious sentence, the instrumental music of the devotee, the loud sound of thunder and lightning are all auspicious.

column1: gambhīrameghastanitaṃ taḍittuṣṭiś ca mānasī /
column2: The satisfaction in the mind of the person undertaking a journey is also auspicious.

column1: tiṣṭhato gamane praśne puruṣasya śubhāśubhaṃ / nivedayanti śakunā deśasya nagarasya ca //
column2: Birds let us know the good and bad indications for a man staying or leaving a country or town or putting a question.

column1: sarvaḥ pāpaphalo dīpto nirdiṣṭo daivacintikaiḥ / śāntaḥ śubhaphalaś caiva daivajñaiḥ samudāhṛtaḥ //
column2: All excited sounds are pointed out to indicate evil according to fortunetellers and cooing sounds are said to indicate good results by fortunetellers.

column1: ṣaṭprakārā vinirdiṣṭā śakunānāñca dīptayaḥ / velādigdeśakaraṇarutajātivibhedataḥ //
column2: The excitements of birds are said to be of six kinds based on the divisions of time, direction, place, karaṇa a division of the day, the sound and the species of the bird.

column1: pūrvā pūrvā ca vijñeyā sā teṣāṃ balavattarā /
column2: Each preceding item in the above list should be known as more powerful.

column1: divācaro rātricaras tathā rātrau divācaraḥ //
column2: The nocturnal bird moving in the daytime and that of the daytime moving in the night are known to be the excitement in time.

column1: krūreṣu dīptā vijñeyā ṛkṣalagnagrahādiṣu /
column2: One should know the malefic asterisms, ascendants and planets also as excited.

column1: dhūmitā sā tu vijñeyā yāṅgamiṣyati bhāskaraḥ // yasyāṃ sthitaḥ sā jvalitā muktā cāṅgāriṇī matā /
column2: It is known to be dhūmitā obscured, jvalitā burning and aṅgāritā burnt if the sun goes to or stays or leaves a particular quarter.

column1: etāstisraḥ smṛtā dīptāḥ pañca śāntās tathāparāḥ //
column2: These three are remembered to be the excited ones and the gentle cooings are of five kinds.

column1: dīptāyāndiśi digdīptaṃ śakunaṃ parikīrtitaṃ / grāmo 'raṇyā vane grāmyās tathā ninditapādapaḥ //
column2: It is said to be agitated bird if it makes an excited sound in the direction that is termed agitated. Similar appellations should be given to wild birds making sound in the village and the village birds in the forest as well as on an inauspicious tree.

column1: deśe caivāśubhe jñeyo deśadīpto dvijottamaḥ /
column2: O Foremost brahmin! The deśadīpta agitation in respect of a place is known to be in inauspicious place.

column1: kriyādīpto vinirdiṣṭaḥ svajātyanucitakriyaḥ //
column2: It is designated as kriyādīpta excitement in respect of an action if there is any action improper for one’s own species.

column1: rutadīptaś ca kathito bhinnabhairavanisvanaḥ /
column2: It is said to be the rutadīpta excitement in respect of sound making broken and harsh sounds.

column1: jātidīptas tathā jñeyaḥ kevalaṃ māṃsabhojanaḥ //
column2: It is known to be the jātidīpta excitement in respect of the species in the case of the carnivorous species alone.

column1: dīptācchānto vinirdiṣṭaḥ sarvair bhedaiḥ prayatnataḥ /
column2: If the excited characteristics of different categories occur together it is stated to be good.

column1: miśrair miśro vinirdiṣṭastasya vācyaṃ phalāphalaṃ //
column2: If they are mixed the result is said to be mixed.

column1: gośvoṣṭragardabhaśvānaḥ sārikā gṛhagodhikā / caṭakā bhāsakūrmādyāḥ kathitā grāmavāsinaḥ // ajāviśukanāgendrāḥ kolo mahiṣavāyasau /
column2: The cows, horses, camels, asses, dogs, birds sārikā, small houselizards, sparrows, vultures and tortoises and others are said to be living in the villages. Goats, black sheep, parrots, elephants, pig, buffalo and crow are said to be both domestic and wild.

column1: grāmyāraṇyā vinirdiṣṭāḥ sarve 'nye vanagocarāḥ //
column2: All other birds and animals are wild.

column1: mārjārakukkuṭau grāmyau tau caiva vanagocarau /
column2: The cat and the cock are both domestic and wild.

column1: tayorbhavati vijñānaṃ nityaṃ vai rūpabhedataḥ //
column2: We know about them from the change in their characteristics.

column1: gokarṇaśikhicakrāhvakharahārītavāyasāḥ / kulāhakukkubhaśyenapherukhañjanavānarāḥ // śataghnacaṭakaśyāmacāsaśyenakaliñjalāḥ / tittiraḥ śatapatrañca kapotaś ca tathā trayaḥ // khañjarīṭakadātyūhaśukarājīvakukkuṭāḥ /
column2: The snakes, peacocks, ruddy geese, mules, pigeons, cows, lightbrown horses, wild cocks, hawks, jackals, wagtails, monkeys, śataghna ?, sparrows, cuckoos, blue jays, hawks, kapiñjala the three, tittiri francoline partridge, peacocks, pigeons, wagtails, gallinules, parrots, cranes, cocks, skylarks and deer are known to be moving about during daytime.

column1: vāguryulūkaśarabhakrauñcāḥ śaśakakacchapāḥ / lomāsikāḥ piṅgalikāḥ kathitā rātrigocarāḥ //
column2: The fowlers, owls, śarabhas, curlews, hares, turtles, jackals and piṅgalikas a kind of owl are said to be nocturnal.

column1: haṃṣāś ca mṛgamārjāranakularkṣabhujaṅgamāḥ / vṛkārisiṃhavyāghroṣṭragrāmaśūkaramānuṣāḥ // śvāvidvṛṣabhagomāyuvṛkakokilasārasāḥ /
column2: Ganders, deer, cats, mongooses, bears, serpents, red dogs, lions, tigers, camels, domestic boars, men, dogs, porcupines, bulls, jackals, wolves, cuckoos, cranes, horses, men in ragged clothes and alligators wander day and night.

column1: jayāvahā vinirdiṣṭāḥ paścānnidhanakāriṇaḥ //
column2: The above seen in a group in front of the king making an expedition with the forces are stated to bring victory and seen on the back cause defeat.

column1: gṛhādgamya yadā cāso vyāharet purutaḥ sthitaḥ / nṛpāvamānaṃ vadati vāmaḥ kalahabhojane //
column2: If the blue jay comes out of the house and makes the sound remaining in front, it indicates humiliation for the king and making sound on the left indicates quarrel and gaining food.

column1: yāne taddarśanaṃ śastaṃ savyamaṅgasya vāpyatha /
column2: It being sighted on the vehicle or on the right side of the body are commended.

column1: caurair moṣamathākhyāti mayūro bhinnanisvanaḥ //
column2: The peacock making an unusual sound conveys plundering by thieves.

column1: prayātasyāgrato rāma mṛgaḥ prāṇaharo bhavet /
column2: O Rāma! a deer seen in front of one that has set out would be indicating danger to life.

column1: ṛkṣākhujambukavyāghrasiṃhamārjāragardabhāḥ // pratilomās tathā rāma kharaś ca vikṛtrasvanaḥ /
column2: O Rāma! The bears, rats, jackals, tigers, lions, cats and asses running away in the opposite direction as well as mule braying strangely would indicate the same result.

column1: vāmaḥ kapiñjalaḥ śreṣṭhas tathā dakṣiṇasaṃsthitaḥ //
column2: The kapiñjala bird seen on the left or right is an excellent augury.

column1: pṛṣṭhato ninditaphalastittiristu na śasyate /
column2: But it does not augur well if seen on the back. The tittiri bird in any one of the above positions is not commended.

column1: eṇā varāhāḥ pṛṣatā vāmā bhūtvā tu dakṣiṇāḥ // bhavantyarthakarā nityaṃ viparītā vigarhitāḥ /
column2: The black deer, boars and spotted antelopes crossing from the left to the right would always be beneficial and the contrary movements are condemned.

column1: vṛṣāśvajambukavyāghrāḥ siṃhamārjāragardabhāḥ // vāñchitārthakarā jñeyā dakṣiṇādvāmato gatāḥ /
column2: The bulls, horses, jackals, tigers, lions, cats and asses are known to confer the desired results if they move to the left from the right.

column1: śivā śyāmānanācchūcchūḥ piṅgalā gṛhagodhikā // śūkarī parapuṣṭā ca punnāmānaś ca vāmataḥ /
column2: The vixen, śyāmānana ?, chucchū a kind of animal, piṅgalā a kind of owl, house alligator, sow and a female cuckoo are said to be male omens if they are on one’s left.

column1: strīsañjñā bhāsakārūṣakapiśrīkarṇaśchitkarāḥ //
column2: The vulture, rūṣa ? monkey, śrīkarṇa antelope, and citkarā ? are known as feminine omens.

column1: kapiśrīkarṇapipyīkā ruruśyenāś ca dakṣiṇāḥ /
column2: The monkey, śrīkarṇa, pipīlikā, ruru a kind of deer, and hawks auger well seen on the right.

column1: jātīkṣāhiśaśakroḍagodhānāṃ kīrtanaṃ śubhaṃ //
column2: The sounds made by the bull that is born, the serpent, hare, hog and alligator are good.

column1: tataḥ sandarśanaṃ neṣṭaṃ pratīpaṃ vānararkṣayoḥ /
column2: Then it is not desirable to see the monkey and bear at the commencement of a work.

column1: kāryakṛdbalī śakunaḥ prasthitasya hi yo 'nvahaṃ // bhavettasya phalaṃ vācyaṃ tadeva divasaṃ budhaiḥ /
column2: The strong omen from a bird as one sets out on a day should be explained by wise men as bearing result on the same day.

column1: matā bhakṣyārthino bālā vairasaktāstathaiva ca // sīmāntamabhyantaritā vijñeyā niṣphalā dvija /
column2: O Brahmin! Mad ones, those concerned only with the prey, young ones, those mutually quarrelling and those separated by a distance should be known to bear no effect.

column1: ekadvitricaturbhistu śivā dhanyā rutair bhavet //
column2: The vixen howling alone or in groups of two or three or four forebode good.

column1: pañcabhiś ca tathā ṣaḍbhiradhanyā parikīrtitā /
column2: It is said to be not beneficial if five or six vixen howl.

column1: saptabhiś ca tathā dhanyā niṣphalā parato bhavet //
column2: It would be good if seven vixen howl and there would be no effect if more than that.

column1: nṛṇāṃ romāñcajananī vāhanānāṃ bhayapradā / jvālānalā sūryamukhī vijñeyā bhayavardhanī //
column2: The volcano facing the sun that causes the horripilation in men should be known to bring ill luck to vehicles and increase the fear.

column1: prathamaṃ sāraṅge dṛṣṭe śubhe deśe śubhaṃ vadet /
column2: When an antelope is seen at a good place it would give good results.

column1: saṃvatsaraṃ manuṣyasya aśubhe ca śubhaṃ tathā //
column2: It would give bad results for the whole year for the man if seen at a bad place.

column1: tathāvidhannaraḥ paśyetsāraṅgaṃ prathame 'hani / ātmanaś ca tathātvena jñātavyaṃ vatsaraṃ phalaṃ //
column2: One may know the result for himself for the whole year as he had seen the deer on the first day. The cātaka bird that is said to drink water directly from the rains.

column1: viśanti yena mārgeṇa vāyasā bahavaḥ puraṃ / tena mārgeṇa ruddhasya purasya grahaṇaṃ bhavet //
column2: A fabulous animal powerful than the lion. An army would take possession of a city that is under siege by that way through which many crows enter that city.

column1: senāyāṃ yadi vāsārthe niviṣṭo vāyaso ruvan / vāmo bhayāturastrasto bhayaṃ vadati dustaraṃ //
column2: It indicates unfordable fear if a crow taking its abode in the place of the army goes about cawing with agitation and fear.

column1: chāyāṅgavāhanopānacchatravastrādikuṭṭane / mṛtyustatpūjane pūjā tadiṣṭakaraṇe śubhaṃ //
column2: If the crow pecks at the shadow, body, vehicle, shoes, umbrella and clothes and other things of a person, it indicates death for that person. If it honours the person, he will be honoured.

column1: proṣitāgamakṛtkākaḥ kurvan dvāri gatāgataṃ / raktaṃ dagdhaṃ gṛhe dravyaṃ kṣipanvahnivedakaḥ //
column2: A crow going to and fro at the entrance to a house, indicates the return of the absentee owner of the house. It indicates destruction by fire if the crow throws a red or burnt thing inside the house.

column1: nyasedraktaṃ purastācca nivedayati bandhanaṃ /
column2: A red thing placed by the crow in front of a person indicates imprisonment.

column1: pītaṃ dravyaṃ tathā rukma rūpyameva tu bhārgava // yaccaivopanayed dravyaṃ tasya labdhiṃ vinirdiśet /
column2: O Bhārgava son of Bhṛgu, if a crow brings to the house a yellow substance, gold or silver, it would indicate the gain of that substance.

column1: dravyaṃ vāpanayedyattu tasya hāniṃ vinirdiśet //
column2: So also one should indicate the loss of that thing which a crow should take away.

column1: purato dhanalabdhiḥ syādāmamāṃsasya chardane / bhūlabdhiḥ syān mṛdaḥ kṣepe rājyaṃ ratnārpaṇe mahat //
column2: If a crow vomits raw flesh in front of a house there would be gain of wealth. There would be gain of land if a piece of earth is thrown. There would be gain of kingdom if a great gem is cast.

column1: yātuḥ kāko 'nukūlastu kṣemaḥ karmakṣamo bhavet / na tvarthasādhako jñeyaḥ pratikūlo bhayāvahaḥ //
column2: If the crow flies favourably to the person who undertakes a journey it bids welfare and he would be able to accomplish his task. But if it flies against him it should be known that the task would not be accomplished and would cause fear.

column1: sammukhe 'bhyeti viruvan yātrāghātakaro bhavet /
column2: If the crow comes cawing loudly against the person it would be an impediment to the journey.

column1: vāmaḥ kākaḥ smṛto dhanyo dakṣiṇo 'rthavināśakṛt // vāmo 'nulomagaḥ śreṣṭho madhyamo dakṣiṇaḥ smṛtaḥ /
column2: A crow on the left is considered to be beneficial and causing destruction of the task if on the right. If the crow flies on the left in the direction of the person undertaking a journey, it is excellent and medium if on the right.

column1: pratilomagatirvāmo gamanapratiṣedhakṛt //
column2: If it flies against the direction of the traveller on the left, it would cause impediment to the movement.

column1: nivedayati yātrārthamabhipretaṃ gṛhe gataḥ /
column2: If the crow comes to the house when the traveller is beginning to move it should be known that he can set out.

column1: ekākṣaracaraṇastvarkaṃ vīkṣamāṇo bhayāvahaḥ //
column2: If a crow stands on one leg and looks at the sun with a single eye it causes fear.

column1: koṭare vāsamānaś ca mahānarthakaro bhavet /
column2: If a crow makes its habitat in a hollow of a tree there would be great misfortune.

column1: na śubhastūṣare kākaḥ paṅkāṅkaḥ sa tu śasyate //
column2: A crow seen in the saline soil is not for good. But the same seen as having its wings with mud is commendable.

column1: amedhyapūrṇavadanaḥ kākaḥ sarvārthasādhakaḥ /
column2: A crow seen as having its mouth full of excreta accomplishes all things.

column1: jñeyāḥ patatriṇo 'nye 'pi kākavad bhṛgunandana //
column2: O Son of Bhṛgu! The other birds should also be known as indicating the same results as the crow.

column1: skandhāvārāpasavyasthāḥ śvāno vipravināśakāḥ /
column2: Dogs howling on the right of a royal camp indicate the destruction of the brahmins.

column1: indrasthāne narendrasya pureśasya tu gopure // antargṛhe gṛheśasya maraṇāya bhavedbhaṣan /
column2: If they howl at the place of Indra in the palace, at the main entrance to the royal city and inside the house, it would augur the death of the lord of the house.

column1: yasya jighrati vāmāṅgaṃ tasya syādarthasiddhaye // bhayāya dakṣiṇaṃ cāṅgaṃ tathā bhujamadakṣiṇaṃ /
column2: It indicates the accomplishment of the task, if a dog smells the left side of the body of a man and fear if it smells the right side of the body and the left arm.

column1: yātrāghātakaro yāturbhavet pratimukhāgataḥ //
column2: A dog coming against the traveller would be adverse to the journey.

column1: mārgāvarodhako mārge caurān vadati bhārgava /
column2: O Bhārgava son of Bhṛgu! a dog obstructing the path of a traveller indicates robbers on the way.

column1: alābho 'sthimukhaḥ pāpo rajjucīramukhas tathā //
column2: Similarly a dog being seen holding a rope or rag in the mouth is sinful.

column1: sopānatkamukho dhanyo māṃsapūrṇamukho 'pi ca / amaṅgalyamukhadravyaṃ keśañcaivāśubhaṃ tathā //
column2: A dog being seen as holding the shoes as well as full of meat in the mouth is also beneficial. A dog being seen as holding the hair or any filthy substance in the mouth is inauspicious.

column1: avamūtryāgrato yāti yasya tasya bhayaṃ bhavet /
column2: A dog urinating and going in front of the traveller would bring fear.

column1: yasyāvamūtrya vrajati śubhaṃ deśantathā drumaṃ // maṅgalañca tathā dravyaṃ tasya syādarthasiddhaye /
column2: If one sees a dog urinating and going to an auspicious place or tree or to an auspicious substance it indicates the accomplishment of the task for that person.

column1: śvavacca rāma vijñeyās tathā vai jambukādayaḥ // bhayāya svāmini jñeyamanimittaṃ rutaṅgavāṃ /
column2: O Rāma Paraśurāma! Jackals and other animals should also be known to indicate the same result as a dog. The lowing of the cows should be known as auguring fear for the master.

column1: niśi caurabhayāya syādvikṛtaṃ mṛtyave tathā // śivāya svāmino rātrau balīvardo nadan bhavet /
column2: If a cow lows in the night it would be indicating fear from thieves. If it wails it forebodes death. If a bull bellows in the night it would be for the welfare of the master.

column1: utsṛṣṭavṛṣabho rājño vijayaṃ samprayacchati //
column2: A bull let loose in the night would confer victory on the king.

column1: abhayaṃ bhakṣayantyaś ca gāvo dattās tathā svakāḥ / tyaktasnehāḥ svavatseṣu garbhakṣayakarā matāḥ //
column2: The cows belonging to a person that were given as gift indicate security if found eating as they wish. The cows that had withheld showing affection to the calves are known to be indicating miscarriage in the family.

column1: bhūmiṃ pādair vinighnantyo dīnā bhītā bhayāvahāḥ /
column2: The cows that pound the earth with their feet and are frightened bring fear.

column1: ārdrāṅgyo hṛṣṭaromāś ca śṛgalagnamṛdaḥ śubhāḥ //
column2: The cows that have wet skin, horripilation and earth stuck to the horns are auspicious.

column1: mahiṣyādiṣu cāpyetat sarvaṃ vācyaṃ vijānatā /
column2: It should be told in the same way in the case of the shebuffalos and others by those knowing the science.

column1: ārohaṇaṃ tathānyena saparyāṇasya vājinaḥ //
column2: A saddled horse being seen as ridden by another other than the appointed person forebodes evil.

column1: jalopaveśanaṃ neṣṭaṃ bhūmau ca parivartanaṃ /
column2: A horse being seen as plunging into the water and tumbling over the ground is not desirable.

column1: vipatkaranturaṅgasya suptaṃ vāpyanimittataḥ //
column2: A horse that is seen sleeping without a good cause causes misfortune.

column1: yavamodakayordveṣastvakasmācca na śasyate / vadanādrudhirotpattirvepanaṃ na ca śasyate //
column2: If a horse has aversion to barley and balls of grains all of a sudden it is not commended. Bleeding from the mouth and trembling of the body are also not commended.

column1: krīḍan vaikaḥ kapotaiś ca sārikābhirmṛtiṃ vadet / sāśrunetro jihvayā ca pādalehī vinaṣṭaye //
column2: If a horse plays with cranes, pigeons and the sārikās a species of birds, one should indicate death. A horse licking the leg with the tongue with tearfilled eyes forebodes ruin.

column1: svapedvā vāmapārśvena divā vā na śubhapradaḥ //
column2: If a horse scratches the earth with the left foot or sleeps during the day lying on the left side, it does not confer good.

column1: bhayāya syāt sakṛnmūtrī tathā nidrāvilānanaḥ / ārohaṇaṃ na ceddadyāt pratīpaṃ vā gṛhaṃ vrajet //
column2: The horse that passes urine once a day, that is looking drowsy, does not allow to be ridden and that returns home frantically if ridden upon, indicates impediment for the journey.

column1: yātrāvighātamācaṣṭe vāmapārśvaṃ tathā spṛśan /
column2: It indicates the same result if it touches the left side of its body.

column1: heṣamāṇaḥ śatruyodhaṃ pādasparśī jayāvahaḥ //
column2: The horse that neighs on seeing the enemy warrior and touching its leg brings victory.

column1: grāme vrajati nāgaścen maithunaṃ deśahā bhavet /
column2: If an elephant courts openly in a village it would ruin the country.

column1: ārohaṇaṃ na ceddadyāt pratīpaṃ vā gṛhaṃ vrajet / madaṃ vā vāraṇo jahyādrājaghātakaro bhavet //
column2: If an elephant does not allow itself to be ridden or frantically returns home after being ridden or ichor flows from the elephant, it foretells the death of the king.

column1: vāmaṃ dakṣiṇapādena pādamākramate śubhaḥ /
column2: An elephant crossing its left foot with its right foot and entwining its right tusk with its trunk is auspicious.

column1: vṛṣo 'śvaḥ kuñjaro vāpi ripusainyagato 'śubhaḥ / khaṇḍameghātivṛṣṭyā tu senā nāśamavāpnuyāt //
column2: A bull or a horse or an elephant entering the enemy forces is inauspicious. If clouds get broken suddenly and rain excessively, the king would get his army routed.

column1: pratikūlagraharkṣāttu tathā sammukhamārutāt / yātrākāle raṇe vāpi chatrādipatanaṃ bhayaṃ //
column2: The tumbling down of the umbrella at the time of a travel or during the war on account of adverse asterisms and planetary conditions or the wind blowing against the forces forebodes fear.

column1: hṛṣṭā narāścānulomā grahā vai jayalakṣaṇaṃ /
column2: Contended men and favourable planets are the characteristics for foreboding victory.

column1: kākair yodhābhibhavanaṃ kravyādbhirmaṇḍalakṣayaḥ //
column2: The warriors being attacked by the crows and demons forebodes the destruction of the army.

column1: prācīpaścimakaiśānī śaumyā preṣṭhā śubhā ca dik //38//
column2: The east, west, northeast and north are the excellent and auspicious directions.

column1: sarvayātrāṃ pravakṣyāmi rājadharmasamāśrayāt /
column2: shall describe all kinds of journeys relating to a sovereign.

column1: astaṅgate nīcagate vikale ripurāśige // pratilome ca vidhvaste śukre yātrāṃ visarjayet /
column2: A journey should be abandoned when the Venus has set or is in a weak house or debilitated or in the house of an enemy or retrograde or malefic.

column1: vaidhṛtau ca vyatīpāte nāge ca śakunau tathā / catuṣpāde ca kintughne tathā yātrāṃ vivarjayet //
column2: One should avoid a journey when the Mercury is retrograde, the presiding planet of the quarter or any other planet in a similar position, is under the vaidhṛti, vyatīpāta, nāga, śakuna, catuṣpada and kintughna.

column1: vipattāre naidhane ca pratyarau cātha janmani / gaṇḍe vivarjayedyātrāṃ riktāyāñca tithāvapi //
column2: One should avoid undertaking journey under the influence of vipat tāra, naidhana, pratyari, as well as the janma, the gaṇḍa and the void lunar day.

column1: udīcī ca tathā prācī tayoraikyaṃ prakīrtitaṃ / paścimā dakṣiṇā yā dik tayoraikyaṃ tathaiva ca //
column2: The north and the east are said to be having the same virtues. In the same way the west and south are of the same virtues.

column1: vāyvagnidiksamudbhūtaṃ parighanna tu laṅghayet /
column2: One should not cross the obstacle that has risen from the northwest to the southeast.

column1: ādityacandraśaurāstu divasāś ca na śobhanāḥ //
column2: Sundays, Mondays and Saturdays are not auspicious for a journey.

column1: kṛttikādyāni pūrveṇa maghādyāni ca yāmyataḥ / maitrādyānyapare cātha vāsavādyāni vāpyudak // sarvadvārāṇi śastāni chāyāmānaṃ vadāmi te /
column2: The asterisms kṛttikā and others for journey in the east, the asterisms maghā and others for journey in the south, the asterisms anurādhā and others for journey in the west and the asterisms jyeṣṭhā and others for journey in the north are all commendable.

column1: āditye viṃśatirjñeyāś candre ṣoḍaśa kīrtitāḥ // bhaume pañcadaśaivoktāś caturdaśa tathā budhe / trayodaśa tathā jīye śukre dvādaśa kīrtitāḥ //
column2: shall describe the measure of the shadows cast by the sun on different days. It is said to be twenty for the Sun, sixteen for the Moon, fifteen for the Mars, fourteen for the Mercury, thirteen for the Jupiter, twelve for the Venus and eleven for the Saturn.

column1: ekādaśa tathā saure sarvakarmasu kīrtitāḥ /
column2: These are said to be valid for all actions.

column1: janmalagne śakracāpe sammukhe na vrajennaraḥ //
column2: One should not set out on a journey under his native ascendant and in the direction of the rainbow.

column1: śakunādau śubhe yāyājjayāya harimāsmaran /
column2: One should march on an expedition after meditating on lord Hari for victory if the omens and other things are good.

column1: vakṣye maṇḍalacintānte kartavyaṃ rājarakṣaṇaṃ //
column2: shall describe the circle of twelve primary kings to be thought. about that would offer protection to the king.

column1: mitrañjanapadaś caiva rājyaṃ saptāṅgamucyate //
column2: A kingdom is said to consist of seven constituentsthe king, minister, fort, treasury, punishment law, allies and township.

column1: saptāṅgasya tu rājyasya vighnakartṝn vināśayet / maṇḍaleṣu ca sarveṣu vṛddhiḥ kāryā mahīkṣitā //
column2: One should destroy all those who obstruct the normal course of the seven constituents of a kingdom. Efforts should be made by the king to make all these circles develop.

column1: ātmamaṇḍalamevātra prathamaṃ maṇḍalaṃ bhavet /
column2: The kingdom over which a king exercises direct control would be the first circle.

column1: sāmantāstasya vijñeyā ripavo maṇḍalasya tu //
column2: The feudatories of that kingdom should be known as the enemies.

column1: upetastu suhṛj jñeyaḥ śatrumitramataḥ paraṃ / mitramitraṃ tato jñeyaṃ mitramitraripustataḥ //
column2: If they are attached to the paramount lord they should be known as friends. The next circle is the allies of the enemy. The next circle should be known as the ally of the ally.

column1: etatpurastāt kathitaṃ paścādapi nibodha me /
column2: Those in front have been described. Tell me those who are behind.

column1: pārṣṇigrāhastataḥ paścāttatastvākranda ucyate // āsārastu tato 'nyaḥ syādākrandāsāra ucyate /
column2: A hostile king would be the next one friend of the rear enemy. That which is adjacent to the former is said to be the next one friend of rear friend.

column1: jigīṣoḥ śatruyuktasya vimuktasya tathā dvija //
column2: O Brahmin! This is the way of maintaining order by an independent king that has an enemy and is desirous of conquering the same.

column1: nātrāpi niś cayaḥ śakyo vaktuṃ manujapuṅgava /
column2: O Excellent among men! It is not possible to declare that it is settled.

column1: nigrahānugrahe śakto madhyasthaḥ parikīrtitaḥ //
column2: One is said to be an intermediary that is capable of punishing and favouring.

column1: nigrahānugrahe śaktaḥ sarveṣāmapi yo bhavet / udāsīnaḥ sa kathito balavān pṛthivīpatiḥ //
column2: A mighty king that would be able to punish and favour all is said to be neutral.

column1: na kasyacidripurmitraṅkāraṇācchatrumitrake /
column2: No one is really one’s enemy or ally. One is an enemy or an ally on account of some reason.

column1: maṇḍalaṃ tava samproktametad dvādaśarājakaṃ //
column2: have described these twelve circles relating to a king.

column1: trividhā ripavo jñeyāḥ kulyānantarakṛtrimāḥ /
column2: Enemies are known to be of three kindsancestral, personal and artificial.

column1: pūrvapūrvo gurusteṣāṃ duścikitsyatamo mataḥ //
column2: Each one of the preceding class among them are known to be stronger than the succeeding ones.

column1: anantaro 'pi yaḥ śatruḥ so 'pi me kṛtrimo mataḥ /
column2: One that is a personal enemy is considered by me as artificial.

column1: pārṣṇigrāho bhavecchatrormitrāṇi ripavas tathā // pārṣṇigrāhamupāyaiś ca śamayecca tathā svakaṃ /
column2: An enemy in the rear of an enemy and his hostiles would be one’s friends. A king should subdue his hostile king in the rear by means of strategies.

column1: mitreṇa śatrorucchedaṃ praśaṃsanti purātanāḥ // mitrañca śatrutāmeti sāmantatvādanantaraṃ /
column2: The ancient authorities commend the extinction of an enemy with the help of an ally. An ally may become an enemy after being a feudal.

column1: śatruṃ jigoṣurucchindyāt svayaṃ śaknoti cedyadi //
column2: A king wishing to vanquish an enemy should himself destroy him if it is possible for him to do.

column1: pratāpavṛddhau tenāpi nāmitrājjāyate bhayaṃ /
column2: There will not be any fear from an enemy when the glory is waxing.

column1: yathāsya nodvijelloko viśvāsaś ca yathā bhavet // jigīṣurdharmavijayī tathā lokaṃ vaśannayet /
column2: A king desiring to conquer righteously should exercise control over the world in such a way that the people do not feel griefstricken and trust him.

column1: sāmabhedau mayā proktau dānadaṇḍau tathaiva ca /
column2: This and the next one are among the twentyseven yogas or combinations.

column1: daṇḍaḥ svadeśe kathitaḥ paradeśe vravīmi te //
column2: have described the punishment to be made by the king in his own country.

column1: prakāśaścāprakāśaś ca dvividho daṇḍa ucyate /
column2: Punishment is said to be of two typespublic and private.

column1: dūṣaṇañcaiva sādhūnāmudakānāñca dūṣaṇaṃ // daṇḍapraṇayaṇaṃ proktamupekṣāṃ śṛṇu bhārgava / yadā manyate nṛpatī raṇe na mama vigrahaḥ // anarthāyānubandhaḥ syāt sandhinā ca tathā bhavet /
column2: Public punishment consists of looting and the destruction of villages of the enemy country, destruction of the food grains and setting fire. The private punishment consists of killing by poisoning or setting fire or by engaging several men, dishonouring pious men and poisoning waters.

column1: sāmalabdhāspadañcātra dānañcārthakṣayaṅkaraṃ // bhedadaṇḍānubandhaḥ syāttadopekṣāṃ samāśrayet /
column2: One maybe indifferent when he would find the conciliatory measures as securing the position of the enemy, paying a bribe would be squandering money and creating dissension would have punishment as the consequence.

column1: na cāyaṃ mama śaknoti kiñcit kartumupadravaṃ // na cāhamasya śaknomi tatropekṣāṃ samāśrayet /
column2: One may resort to indifference if he is sure that ‘this person is not capable of doing any harm to me’ and ‘ am not capable of causing any harm to him’.

column1: avajñopahatastatra rājñā kāryo ripurbhavet //
column2: In that case the king should humiliate the enemy by being indifferent.

column1: māyopāyaṃ pravakṣyāmi utpātair anṛtaiś carat /
column2: shall describe the strategies of illusion to be practised by a king.

column1: sthūlasya tasya pucchasthāṃ kṛtvolkāṃ vipulāṃ dvija / visṛjecca tataś caivamulkāpātaṃ pradarśayet //
column2: The enemy should be agitated by false portents by sending extensive lighted torches tied to the tails of strong birds in the camp of the enemy. Then the fall of the meteor should be shown to them.

column1: evamanye darśanīyā utpātā bahavo 'pi ca /
column2: In this way many other portents also should be shown.

column1: udvejanaṃ tathā kuryāt kuhakair vividhair dviṣāṃ // sāṃvatsarāstāpasāś ca nāśaṃ brūyuḥ prarasya ca /
column2: The enemies should thus be agitated by different kinds of deception. The astrologers and ascetics should proclaim the fall of the enemy.

column1: jigīṣuḥ pṛthivīṃ rājā tena codvejayet parān //
column2: A king that desires toconquer the earth should agitate others by the above proclamation.

column1: devatānāṃ prasādaś ca kīrtanīyaḥ parasya tu /
column2: The favour of gods should also be proclaimed to others.

column1: āgatanno 'mitrabalaṃ praharadhvamabhītavat // evaṃ brūyādraṇe prāpte bhagnāḥ sarve pare iti /
column2: A king should declare to his men “We have received increased strength and you strike without fear all others have been routed”, when the battle has begun.

column1: kṣveḍāḥ kilakilāḥ kāryā vācyaḥ śatrurhatas tathā //
column2: Warcry and great commotion should be made saying that the enemy has been routed.

column1: devājñāvṛṃhito rājā sannaddhaḥ samaraṃ prati /
column2: It should also be proclaimed “The king has been blessed by the gods profusely and is ready for the battle”.

column1: indrajālaṃ pravakṣyāmi indraṃ kālena darśayet //
column2: shall describe Indrajāla a kind of stratagem in war.

column1: caturaṅgaṃ balaṃ rājā sahāyārthaṃ divaukasāṃ / balantu darśayet prāptaṃ raktavṛṣṭiñcendrapau //
column2: A king should exhibit the four divisions of the army such as the infantry, cavalry, men mounted on elephants and chariots to delude the enemy that the gods had sent them for aid.

column1: chinnāni ripuśīrṣāṇi prāsādāgreṣu darśayet /
column2: Severed heads of the enemy should be exhibited on the terrace of palaces.

column1: sandhiś ca vigrahaś caiva yānamāsanameva ca / dvaidhībhāvaḥ saṃśayaś ca ṣaḍguṇāḥ parikīrtitāḥ //
column2: shall describe six expedients , among which war and peace are most excellent. Making peace, war, expedition, halt, seeking shelter and duplicity are said to be the six expedients .

column1: paṇabandhaḥ smṛtaḥ sandhirapakārastu vigrahaḥ /
column2: Making peace is known to be a treaty. War is offending the enemy.

column1: jigīṣoḥ śatruviṣaye yānaṃ yātrābhidhīyate // vigraheṇa svake deśe sthitirāsanamucyate /
column2: Expedition is said to be the march against the enemy by the one that desires to conquer. It is said to be ‘the halt’ when a king remains in his own territory mobilising his forces for the war.

column1: balārdhena prayāṇantu dvaidhībhāvaḥ sa ucyate // udāsīno madhyago vā saṃśrayātsaṃśayaḥ smṛtaḥ /
column2: Mobilisation of half the army in the enemy country is said to be ‘seeking shelter. It is said to be duplicity on account of resorting to indifference or neutral position.

column1: samena sandhiranveṣyo 'hīnena ca balīyasā // hīnena vigrahaḥ kāryaḥ svayaṃ rājñā balīyasā /
column2: A king should seek a treaty with an equal person or not of lower strength and more powerful. A powerful king should make a war with a king of inferior strength.

column1: tatrāpi śuddhapārṣṇistu balīyāṃsaṃ samāśrayet //
column2: In that case he should take a stronger king as an ally when he is not having an enemy in the rear.

column1: āsīnaḥ karmavicchedaṃ śaktaḥ kartuṃ riporyadā /
column2: A king should mobilise his army when he could easily intercept the work of the enemy, though he is not free from an enemy in the rear.

column1: aśuddhapārṣṇiścāsīta vigṛhya vasudhādhipaḥ // aśuddhapārṣṇirbalavān dvaidhībhāvaṃ samāśrayet / balinā vigṛhītastu yo 'sandehena pārthivaḥ //
column2: One who is strong enough could mobilise half of his army in the territory of the enemy even though he may have an enemy in the rear. An alliance with another king is said to be the worst of all expedients a king fighting with a stronger adversary is compelled to do.

column1: bahukṣayavyayāyāsaṃ teṣāṃ yānaṃ prakīrtitaṃ //
column2: It is said to bring many a long and tedious marches, loss of many lives and expenditure.

column1: bahulābhakaraṃ paścāttadā rājā samāśrayet /
column2: A king should have an alliance only when he would have great benefits later.

column1: sarvaśaktivihīnastu tadā kuryāttu saṃśrayaṃ //
column2: Moreover, he should have an alliance only when he has been deprived of all his strength.

column1: ajasraṃ karma vakṣyāmi dinaṃ prati yadācaret /
column2: shall describe the perpetual daily duties of the king.

column1: dvimuhūrtāvaśeṣāyāṃ rātrau nidrāntyajennṛpaḥ // vādyavandisvanair gītaiḥ paśyed gūḍhāṃstato narān / vijñāyate na ye lokāstadīyā iti kenacit //
column2: The king should put an end to his sleep with the songs and music of the panegyrists when two muhūrtas fortyeight minutes are still left in the night. He should then see spies in such a way that they are not known as his own men by anybody.

column1: āyavyayasya śravaṇaṃ tataḥ kāryaṃ yathāvidhi /
column2: He should then hear the report about the income and expenditure as laid down.

column1: vegotsargaṃ tataḥ kṛtvā rājā snānagṛhaṃ vrajet //
column2: After having eased, the king should go to the bathroom. The king should then bathe preceded by cleansing the teeth.

column1: snānaṃ kuryānnṛpaḥ paścāddantadhāvanapūrvakaṃ / kṛtvā sandhyāntato japyaṃ vāsudevaṃ prapūjayet //
column2: After having done the twilight worship and the repetition of the sacred syllables the king should worship lord Vāsudeva Viṣṇu’s manifestation as Kṛṣṇa.

column1: vahnau pavitrān juhuyāt tarpayedudakaiḥ pitṝn /
column2: He should then offer unto the fire holy twigs. Libations should be offered to the ancestors.

column1: dadyātsakāñcīṃ dhenuṃ dvijāśīrvādasaṃyutaḥ //
column2: Accompanied by the blessings of brahmins, he should then give a cow as gift together with gold.

column1: anulipto 'laṅkṛtaś ca mukhaṃ paśyecca darpaṇe /
column2: He should also then see his face in clarified butter kept together with gold.

column1: sasuvarṇe dhṛte rājā śṛṇuyāddivasādikaṃ // auṣadhaṃ bhiṣajoktaṃ ca maṅgalālambhanañcaret /
column2: The king should then hear about the nature of the day etc. He should then take medicines prescribed by the physicians. He should then touch the auspicious things.

column1: paśced guruṃ tena dattāśīrvado 'tha vrajetsabhāṃ //
column2: He should then see the preceptor and go to the court after having been blessed by him.

column1: tatrastho brāhmaṇān paśyedamātyānmantriṇas tathā /
column2: O Fortunate one! He should then see brahmins, ministers, counsellors and others presented by the doorkeeper.

column1: śrutvetihāsaṃ kāryāṇi kāryāṇāṃ kāryanirṇayam /
column2: After having heard the traditional history and things to be done, he should determine the business to be done.

column1: vyavahārantataḥ paśyenmantraṃ kuryāttu mantribhiḥ //
column2: He should then look into civil disputes and have counsel with the counsellors.

column1: naikena sahitaḥ kuryānna kuryādbahubhiḥ saha / na ca mūrkhair nacānāptair guptaṃ na prakaṭaṃ caret //
column2: He should not have the counsel with a single person or with many or ignorant men or untrustworthy men. He should also not make public the secret counsel.

column1: mantraṃ svadhiṣṭhitaṃ kuryādyena rāṣṭraṃ na bādhate / ākāragrahaṇe rājño mantrarakṣā parā matā //
column2: The counsel he had should be given effect to promptly so that the state may not get affected. The secret counsel is considered to be guarded well by a king by his postures.

column1: ākārair iṅgitaiḥ prajñā mantraṃ gṛhṇanti paṇḍitāḥ /
column2: Wise men gather secrets from the postures of others.

column1: sāṃvatsarāṇāṃ vaidyānāṃ mantriṇāṃ vacane rataḥ // rājā vibhūtimāpnoti dhārayanti nṛpaṃ hi te /
column2: A king gets prosperity by following the words of astrologers, physicians and counsellors, because they sustain the king.

column1: mantraṃ kṛtvātha vyāyāmañcakre yāne ca śastrake //
column2: After having had the counsel he should do physical exercises with discs, chariot and weapon.

column1: niḥsattvādau nṛpaḥ snātaḥ paśyedviṣṇuṃ supūjitaṃ /
column2: He should then bathe in tanks not inhabited by living creatures and see lord Viṣṇu that has already been worshipped.

column1: hutañca pāvakaṃ paśyedviprān paśyetsupūjitān //
column2: He should then see fire into which oblations have been made and also see brahmins that have been worshipped well.

column1: bhūṣito bhojanaṅkuryād dānādyaiḥ suparīkṣitaṃ / bhuktvā gṛhītatāmbūlo vāmapārśvena saṃsthitaḥ //
column2: After having adorned himself he should take food after having fed beings and after having tested the food duly. After having taken food, he should chew betels and rest lying on the left.

column1: śāstrāṇi cintayed dṛṣṭvā yodhān koṣṭhāyudhaṃ gṛhaṃ / anvāsya paścimāṃ sandhyāṃ kāryāṇi ca vicintya tu // carān sampreṣya bhuktānnamantaḥpuracaro bhavet /
column2: He should then have inquiry in the sacred texts. After having met the warriors and seen the granary and the armoury he should do the evening twilight worship. He should then think of the tasks to be done, send spies, eat food and spend time in the harem with instrumental music and being guarded by others.

column1: yātrāvidhānapūrvantu vakṣye sāṅgrāmikaṃ vidhiṃ /
column2: shall describe rites to be performed before commencing a march.

column1: saptāhena yadā yātrā bhaviṣyati mahīpateḥ // pūjanīyo hariḥ śambhurmodakādyair vināyakaḥ /
column2: When a march of a king has to begin after seven days, lords Hari Viṣṇu and Śambhu Śiva should be worshipped as well as lord Vināyaka the elephantfaced god, lord of impediments with sweet balls and other things on the first day.

column1: dvitīye 'hani dikpālān sampūjya śayanañcaret //
column2: After having worshipped the guardian deities of different directions, the priest should lie down on a bed.

column1: śayyāyāṃ vā tadagre 'tha devān prārcya manuṃ smaret /
column2: He should then worship gods either remaining on the bed or in front of them. He should then think of Manu.

column1: namaḥ śambhoḥ trinetrāya rudrāya varadāya ca //
column2: “Obeisance O Śambhu conferer of good! to the threeeyed, dreadful and conferer of boons.

column1: vāmanāya virūpāya svapnādhipataye namaḥ /
column2: Obeisance to the dwarf manifestation of lord Viṣṇu, the formless lord of dreams.

column1: bhagavandevadeveśa śūlabhṛdvṛṣavāhana // iṣṭāniṣṭe mamācakṣva svapne suptasya śāśvata /
column2: O Master! Lord of the lords! Bearer of the trident! One riding the bull! O Eternal one! Let me know in my dream while sleep, the good or evil to befall me.

column1: yajjāgrato dūramiti purodhā mantramuccaret //
column2: The impressions in the waking state maybe driven far away.” The priest should thus utter these sacred syllables on the second day.

column1: tṛtīye 'hani dikpālān rudrāṃstān dikpatīnyajet / grahān yajeccaturthe 'hni pañcame cāśvinau yajet //
column2: He should worship the guardian deities of the quarters, Rudras and the lords of directions on the third day, the planets on the fourth day and the two Aśvins divine physicians on the fifth day.

column1: na te varṇayituṃ śaktā guṇān jihvāpi vedhasaḥ /
