column2: After having worshipped gods and arranging six divisions of the army the king should march against the enemy.

column1: maulaṃ bhūtaṃ śroṇisuhṛddviṣadāṭavikaṃ balaṃ //
column2: The six divisions of the army are the central force, the front, the rear, the auxiliary, hostile and the pioneer.

column1: pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ garīyastu balānāṃ vyasanaṃ tathā /
column2: Each division of the above forces are more important than the succeeding ones. The same holds good in the case of reverses also.

column1: ṣaḍaṅgaṃ mantrakoṣābhyāṃ padātyaśvarathadvipaiḥ // nadyadravanadurgeṣu yatra yatra bhayaṃ bhavet / senāpatistatra tatra gacchedvyūhīkṛtair balaiḥ //
column2: The commanderinchief should go to such places as the rivers, mountains, forests and forts wherever there may be danger, with the a^y in array consisting of six divisions, machines, treasury, footsoldiers, cavalry, chariots and elephants.

column1: nāyakaḥ purato yāyāt pravīrapuruṣāvṛtaḥ /
column2: The leader of the forces should march at its head being surrounded by best warriors.

column1: madhye kalatraṃ svāmī ca koṣaḥ phalgu ca yadbalaṃ //
column2: The queen, king, treasury and the excellent warriors of the army should be placed in the middle.

column1: pārśvayorubhayoraśvā vājināṃ pārśvayo rathāḥ / rathānāṃ pārśvayornāgā nāgānāṃ cāṭavībalaṃ //
column2: The cavalrymen should be on the two sides, the chariots by the side of the cavalry and the elephants by the side of the chariots. The pioneer forces should be by the side of the elephants.

column1: paścāt senāpatiḥ sarvaṃ puraskṛtya kṛtī svayaṃ / yāyātsannaddhasainyaughaḥ khinnānāśvāsayañcchanaiḥ //
column2: Then the commanderinchief should go slowly behind all with a fully equipped army encouraging the dejected.

column1: yāyādvyūhena mahatā makareṇa purobhaye / śyenenoddhṛtapakṣeṇa sūcyā vā vīravaktrayā //
column2: A marching army should be set in the array of a crocodile and in the array of a hawk with raised wings or a sūcī or Vīravaktra in case of danger in the front.

column1: paścādbhaye tu śakaṭaṃ pārśvayorvajrasañjñitaṃ /
column2: In case of fear behind, an array in the form of the cart should be made.

column1: sarvataḥ sarvatobhadraṃ bhaye vyūhaṃ prakalpayet //
column2: If there is danger on all sides one should set up the array known as sarvatobhadra.

column1: kandare śailagahane nimnagāvanasaṅkaṭe /
column2: A commander should guard his army while passing through a cave, mountain forest, river and dense forest.

column1: dīrghādhvani pariśrāntaṃ kṣutpipāsāhitaklamaṃ // vyādhidurbhikṣamarakapīḍitaṃ dasyuvidrutaṃ /
column2: He should also guard when the army has to go a long way, when it is tired, when it suffers hunger, thirst or adversity, when it is affected by illhealth, famine and epidemics, when attacked by robbers.

column1: paṅkāṃśujalaskandhaṃ vyastaṃ puñjīkṛtaṃ pathi //
column2: He should see that they are neither scattered nor gathered together on the way.

column1: prasuptaṃ bhojanavyagramabhūmiṣṭhamasusthitaṃ / caurāgnibhayavitrastaṃ vṛṣṭivātasamāhataṃ // ityādau svacamūṃ rakṣet prasainyaṃ ca ghatayet /
column2: He should also guard them while sleeping, eating their food, while staying at an unfit place, when they are not wellplaced, when they have been scared by robbers, fire and fear and when they have been struck by rains and wind.

column1: viśiṣṭo deśakālābhyāṃ bhinnaviprakṛtirbalī //
column2: When the army of the enemy is in a similar position it should be struck.

column1: kuryāt prakāśayuddhaṃ hi kūṭayuddhaṃ viparyaye / teṣvavaskandakāleṣu paraṃ hanyātsamākulaṃ //
column2: One should have an open encounter with an enemy only when the grounds and time are favourable and one is strong. On the contrary one should do treacherous warfare.

column1: abhūmiṣṭhaṃ svabhūmiṣṭhaṃ svabhūmau copajāyataḥ /
column2: An enemy on another’s soil could be won from staying in one’s own soil. An enemy in one’s own soil could be won by means of sowing seeds of dissension.

column1: prakṛtipragrahākṛṣṭaṃ pāśair vanacarādibhiḥ // hanyāt pravīrapuruṣair bhaṅgadānāpakarṣaṇaiḥ /
column2: An enemy subject to the wrath of his people should be made captive by employing the foresters and others and killed. They can also be conquered by employing extremely brave warriors.

column1: purastāddarśanaṃ datvā tallakṣakṛtaniś cayāt // hanyātpaścāt pravīreṇa balenopetya veginā / paścādvā saṅkulīkṛtya hanyācchūreṇa pūrvataḥ //
column2: By appearing in front of the enemy the king would become a sure object of their aim. Then the enemy should be killed by extremely brave warriors by striking swiftly with a strong force. Brave warriors could be set in an array in front or at the back and the enemy could be killed.

column1: ābhyāṃ pārśvābhighātau tu vyākhyātau kūṭayodhane /
column2: It has been explained by these two methods as to how to attack the two enemies on the adjacent sides in a treacherous warfare.

column1: purastādviṣame deśe paścāddhanyāttu vegavān // puraḥ paścāttu viṣame evameva tu pārśvayoḥ /
column2: If the front part of the hostile army is in an unfavourable land, the rear portion should be attacked swiftly. If the front and rear are both unfavourable one should strike on the sides in the same way.

column1: prathamaṃ yodhayitvā tu dūṣyāmitrāṭavībalau // śrāntaṃ mandannirākrandaṃ hanyādaśrāntavāhanaṃ /
column2: After having fought with the vanguards, allies of the enemy and the pioneers, one should attack the fatigued, slow and the one whose aid has been cut off without causing fatigue for his force.

column1: dūṣyāmitrabalair vāpi bhaṅgandatvā prayatnavān //
column2: In the alternative, one should defeat by employing the pioneer force or the allies.

column1: jitamityeva viśvastaṃ hanyānmantravyapāśrayaḥ /
column2: Or, one should feign defeat and attack the enemy that is complacent that he has won by resorting to good counsel.

column1: skandhāvārapuragrāmaśasyasvāmiprajādiṣu // viśrabhyantaṃ parānīkamapramatto vināśayet /
column2: One should destroy the enemy force when it is resting in the camps, barracks, villages, fields and among subjects without protection.

column1: athavā gograhākṛṣṭaṃ tallakṣyaṃ mārgabandhanāt //
column2: Otherwise the cattle of the enemy should be seized and then the army on their way to reach the goal.

column1: avaskandabhayādrātripūjāgarakṛtaśramaḥ / divāsuptaṃ samāhanyānnidrāvyākulasainikaṃ //
column2: Or the hostile army fatigued on account of overnight vigil fearing an attack and sleeping during the day overcome by sleep should be attacked to gain victory.

column1: niśi viśrabdhasaṃsuptaṃ nāgair vā khaḍgapāṇibhiḥ /
column2: In the alternative a hostile army sleeping during the night without any fear should be attacked by employing elephants or with men armed with swords.

column1: prayāne pūrvayāyitvaṃ vanadurgapraveśanaṃ // abhinnānāmanīkānāṃ bhedanaṃ bhinnasaṅgrahaḥ / vibhīṣakādvāraghātaṃ koṣarakṣebhakarma ca //
column2: The functions of men on elephants are proceeding in front of the marching army, entry into forest fortification, division of the united hostile army, collecting together a divided army, causing right, breaking the doors of the fort and the protection of the treasury.

column1: abhinnabhedanaṃ mitrasandhānaṃ rathakarma ca /
column2: Division of an undivided army and effecting the union of friendly forces are the task of the men on chariots.

column1: vanadiṅmārgavicaye vīvadhāsāralakṣaṇaṃ // anuyānāpasaraṇe śīghrakāryopapādanaṃ / dīnānusaraṇaṃ ghātaḥ koṭīnāṃ jaghanasya ca //
column2: The functions of cavalry are to reconnoitre the forests, different directions and the highway, guard the transport of provisions, follow the retreating army, attend to tasks requiring quick action, follow the weak and attack the last columns and rear of the hostile army.

column1: aśvakarmātha patteś ca sarvadā śastradhāraṇaṃ /
column2: The functions of infantry are to bear always the weapons, inspecting the camps and the highways and to remove obstructions.

column1: saṃsthūlasthāṇuvalmīkavṛkṣagulmāpakaṇṭakaṃ / sāpasārā padātīnāṃ bhūrnātiviṣamā matā // svalpavṛkṣopalā kṣipralaṅghanīyanagā sthirā / niḥśarkarā vipaṅkā ca sāpasārā ca vājibhūḥ //
column2: The ground suitable for infantry should not be very uneven or abound with thick rows of trees, ant hills, bushes and thorns and should have provision for escape. The ground suitable for cavalry should have scanty trees, should be quickly traversible, firm, without sand and not be marshy and have provision for escape.

column1: nisthāṇuvṛkṣakedārā rathabhūmirakardamā / mardanīyatarucchedyavratatīpaṅkavarjitā //
column2: The ground suitable for the chariot should not have trees, fields, mire, trees causing obstruction, creepers and mire.

column1: urasyādīni bhinnāni pratigṛhṇan balāni hi //
column2: The ground for the elephant are hills difficult to cross having streams.

column1: pratigraha iti khyāto rājakāryāntarakṣamaḥ /
column2: It is known as the rear of the army. It is capable of serving the needs of the king.

column1: tena śūnyastu yo vyūhaḥ sa bhinna iva lakṣyate //
column2: An array not having this the division would appear as if it has been segmented.

column1: jayārthī na ca yuddhyeta matimānapratigrahaḥ /
column2: A wise king desiring to conquer should not fight without having the array with the divisions.

column1: yatra rājā tatra koṣaḥ koṣādhīnā hi rājatā //
column2: The treasury would remain with the king. A kingship would be suzerainty over the treasure.

column1: yodhebhyastu tato dadyāt kiñciddātuṃ na yujyate /
column2: The soldiers should be paid rewards on gaining victory. It is not proper to give only a little.

column1: dravyalakṣaṃ rājaghāte tadardhaṃ tatsutārdane //
column2: A lakh should be given on the death of the enemy king and half that when the son of that king is killed.

column1: senāpatibadhe tadvaddadyāddhastyādimardane / athavā khalu yudhyeran pratyaśvarathadantinaḥ // yathā bhavedasaṃbādho vyāyāmavinivartane /
column2: Similarly the soldiers should be paid when the enemy commanderinchief is killed or at the killing of the elephant etc. Otherwise the soldiers should fight in such a way that the infantry, cavalry, men on chariots and elephants do not get affected when the battle has been completed.

column1: asaṅkareṇa yuddheran saṅkaraḥ saṅkulāvahaḥ //
column2: The soldiers should fight without confusion. Confusion causes melee.

column1: mahāsaṅkulayuddheṣu saṃśrayeranmataṅgajaṃ /
column2: One should employ an elephant in battles causing great confusion.

column1: aśvasya pratiyoddhāro bhaveyuḥ puruṣāstrayaḥ // iti kalpyāstrayaścāśvā vidheyāḥ kuñjarasya tu /
column2: Three infantry soldiers would be equal to fight a cavalryman. Three such cavalrymen should be employed to combat a single elephant man.

column1: pādagopā bhaveyuś ca puruṣā daśa pañca ca //
column2: Fifteen infantry men would guard each foot of the elephant.

column1: vidhānamiti nāgasya vihitaṃ syandanasya ca / anīkamiti vijñeyamiti kalpyā nava dvipāḥ //
column2: It is laid down that an arrangement known as an anika a unit of the elephants should be made for guarding the chariot. There should be nine elephant men.

column1: tathānīkasya randhrantu pañcadhā ca pracakṣate /
column2: The vulnerable point of such an army is said to be of five kinds.

column1: ityanīkavibhagena sthāpayed vyūhasampadaḥ //
column2: An array should be set by this division of the army.

column1: uraḥkakṣau ca pakṣau ca madhyaṃ pṛṣṭhaṃ pratigrahaḥ // koṭī ca vyūhaśāstrajñaiḥ saptāṅgo vyūha ucyate /
column2: The chest, sides and wings are said to be three divisions. An array is said to have seven parts such as the chest, sides, wings, centre, back hip, rear and the edge by those well acquainted with the arrangement of arrays.

column1: urasyakakṣapakṣāstu vyūho 'yaṃ sapratigrahaḥ // guroreṣa ca śukrasya kakṣābhyāṃ parivarjitaḥ /
column2: The array called guru consists of chest, sides and wings together with the rear. That of śukra is devoid of two sides.

column1: tiṣṭheyuḥ senāpatayaḥ pravīraiḥ puruṣair vṛtāḥ //
column2: The commanders should remain being surrounded by excellent warriors.

column1: abhedena ca yudhyeran rakṣeyuś ca parasparaṃ /
column2: They should fight without any faction defending one another.

column1: madhyavyūhe phalgu sainyaṃ yuddhavastu jaghanyataḥ //
column2: Excellent warriors of the army should be at the centre.

column1: yuddhaṃ hi nāyakaprāṇaṃ hanyate tadanāyakaṃ /
column2: A commander of an army is the life of a battle. It would be destroyed if it is without a commander.

column1: urasi sthāpayennāgān pracaṇḍān kakṣayo rathān //
column2: The powerful elephants should be placed at the chest of an array, the chariots on the sides and horses on the wings.

column1: hayāṃś ca pakṣayorvyūho madhyabhedī prakīrtitaḥ /
column2: This array is said to be breaking the central force.

column1: madhyadeśe hayānīkaṃ rathānīkañca kakṣayoḥ // pakṣayoś ca gajānīkaṃ vyūhontarbhedyayaṃ smṛtaḥ /
column2: An army of horses at the centre, an army of chariots on the sides and an army of elephants on the wings is known to be an array of breaking the inner force.

column1: rathasthāne hayān dadyāt padātīṃś ca hayaśrāye // rathābhāve tu dviradān vyūhe sarvatra dāpayet /
column2: Station the cavalry in the place of chariots, the infantry in the place of cavalry in the above order or place elephants everywhere in the array in the absence of chariots.

column1: yadi syāddaṇḍabāhulyamābādhaḥ samprakīrtitaḥ // maṇḍalāṃsaṃhato bhogo daṇḍāste bahudhā śṛṇu /
column2: If there is more than the required army it is said to be ābādha. An array called bhoga consists of arranging the army in concentric circles. An array called daṇḍa is of many kinds.

column1: tiryagvṛttistu daṇḍaḥ syād bhogo 'nyāvṛttireva ca //
column2: An array spread horizontally would be called daṇḍa. The array called bhoga is in the form of a wave.

column1: maṇḍalaḥ sarvatovṛttiḥ pṛthagvṛttirasaṃhataḥ /
column2: The array called maṇḍala would be in perfect circle. The asaṃhata class would be in concentric circles.

column1: pradaro dṛḍhako 'sahyaḥ cāpo vai kukṣireva ca // pratiṣṭhaḥ supratiṣṭhaś ca śyeno vijayasañjayau / viśālo vijayaḥ śūcī sthūṇākarṇacamūmukhau //
column2: The other arrays such as the pradara, dṛḍhaka, asahya, cāpa, kukṣi, pratiṣṭha, supratiṣṭha, śyena, vijaya, sañjaya, viśāla, vijaya, sūcī, sthūṇākarṇa, camūmukha, sarpāsya and valaya are all invincible and modifications of the array called daṇḍa.

column1: atikrāntaḥ pratikrāntaḥ kakṣābhyāñcaikakṣapakṣataḥ // atikrāntastu pakṣābhyāṃ trayo 'nye tadviparyaye /
column2: They have the following characteristicsextending on both sides, extending on one side, extending in one wing, extending on both wings, three others of the contrary nature.

column1: pakṣorasyair atikrāntaḥ pratiṣṭho 'nyo viparyayaḥ //
column2: The array pratiṣṭha extends on the wing and chest and the other supratiṣṭha is the contrary.

column1: sthūṇāpakṣo dhanuḥpakṣo dvisthūṇo daṇḍa ūrdhvagaḥ / dviguṇontastvatikrāntapakṣo 'nyasya viparyayaḥ //
column2: The arrays called sthūṇāpakṣa and dhanuḥ pakṣa, dvisthūṇa and daṇḍa after that are of doubled units at the end or an additional wing or of the reverse of another.

column1: dvicaturdaṇḍa ity ete jñeyā lakṣaṇataḥ kramāt /
column2: They should be known to have the characteristics of two or four columns of soldiers in order.

column1: gomūtrikāhisañcārīśakaṭo makaras tathā // bhogabhedāḥ samākhyātās tathā pariplavaṅgakaḥ /
column2: The arrays known as gomūtrikā, ahisañcārī, śakaṭa and makara are said to be variations of the array bhoga. So also the array called pāriplavaṅgaka.

column1: daṇḍapakṣau yugārasyaḥ śakaṭastadviparyaye //
column2: The array called yugorasya consists of two wings in the array daṇḍa.

column1: makaro vyatikīrṇaś ca śeṣaḥ kuñjararājibhiḥ /
column2: The array of the name crocodile is of mixed nature. The array śeṣa is marked by the rows of elephants.

column1: maṇḍalavyūhabhedau tu sarvatobhadradurjayau //
column2: The arrays sarvatobhadra and duryaya are the modifications of the array called maṇḍala.

column1: aṣṭānīko dvitīyastu prathamaḥ sarvatomukhaḥ /
column2: That which has openings on all sides is the first one and that having the eight army units is the second one.

column1: ardhacandraka ūrdhvāṅgo vajrabhedāstu saṃhateḥ //
column2: The arrays known as ardhacandraka of the shape of half the moon and ūrdhvāṅga elevated parts are formed by the combinations of different divisions of the class known as the vajra.

column1: tathā karkaṭaśṛṅgī ca kākapādau ca godhikā / tricatuḥsainyānāṃ jñeyā ākārabhedataḥ //
column2: In the same way the arrays known as karkaśṛṅgī the pincers of a crab, kākapāda the feet of a crow and godhikā lizard are known from their difference in shape consisting of three, four and five units of army.

column1: daṇḍasya syuḥ saptadaśa vyūhā dvau maṇḍalasya ca / asaṅghātasya ṣaṭ pañca bhogasyaiva tu saṅgare //
column2: Seventeen kinds of arrays could be formed from the array called daṇḍa. Two from the maṇḍala class, six from the asaṅghāta and five from the bhoga are combined in a battle.

column1: pakṣādīnāmathaikena hatvā śeṣaiḥ parikṣipet / urasā vā samāhatya koṭibhyāṃ pariveṣṭayet //
column2: The structures of the abovesaid battle arrays may be modified by omitting a wing or two wings. Otherwise a squadron may be taken from the chest of the army and placed around the edges.

column1: pare koṭī samākramya pakṣābhyāmapratigrahāt / koṭibhyāñjaghanaṃ hanyādurasā ca prapīḍayet //
column2: After having attacked the boundary army in the front with the army forming the wings, one should strike the army at the hip with the army at the boundaries and attack with that comprising the chest.

column1: tataścāribalaṃ hanyādātmanaścopavṛṃhayet //
column2: The routed soldiers of a hostile army as well as the reserves should be completely destroyed and one’s own should be expanded.

column1: sāraṃ dviguṇasāreṇa phalgusāreṇa pīḍayet /
column2: The main part of the hostile army should be attacked with double that of the main and the reserve force of the hostile army with the main.

column1: saṃhatañca gajānīkaiḥ pracaṇḍair dārayedbalaṃ //
column2: A compact hostile army should be scattered with a strong contingent of elephants.

column1: syāt kakṣapakṣorasyaś ca vartamānastu daṇḍakaḥ / tatra prayogo ḍaṇḍasya sthānanturyeṇa darśayet //
column2: If the hostile army is in the array daṇḍaka with the flanks, wings and chest drawn up then a general should employ the array daṇḍa and quickly show the position.

column1: syāddaṇḍasamapakṣābhyāmatikrānto dṛḍhaḥ smṛtaḥ / bhavetsa pakṣakakṣābhyāmatikrāntaḥ pradārakaḥ //
column2: The array called pradāraka would be by the addition of two wings to the daṇḍa. If it is added with wings and flanks it is known as dṛḍha. The array that is increased by adding two flanks is known to be asahya.

column1: kakṣapakṣāvadhaḥ sthapyorasyaiḥ kāntaś ca khātakaḥ //
column2: The array khātaka consists of keeping the flanks and wings down and attacking with the troops at the chest.

column1: dvau daṇḍau balayaḥ prokto kāntaś ca khātakaḥ /
column2: The array valaya is said to be the union of two daṇḍas capable of breaking the enemy.

column1: durjayaś caturvalayaḥ śatrorbalavimardanaḥ //
column2: The array durjaya consists of four valayas that is capable of routing the enemy forces.

column1: kakṣapakṣaurasyair bhogo viṣayaṃ parivartayan / sarpacārī gomūtrikā śarkaṭaḥ śakaṭākṛtiḥ //
column2: By changing the arrangement of elements troops on the flanks, wings and chest of the array bhoga we get the arrays sarpacārī and gomūtrikā. The array śakaṭa is of the shape of a cart.

column1: viparyayo 'maraḥ proktaḥ sarvaśatruvimardakaḥ /
column2: The reverse is said to be the array amara capable of destroying the enemies.

column1: syāt kakṣapakṣorasyānāmekībhāvastu maṇḍalaḥ //
column2: The arrangement of troops on the sides, wings and chest would be in the same way as the array maṇḍala.

column1: cakrapadmādayo bhedā maṇḍalasya prabhedakāḥ /
column2: The divisions called cakra, padma and others are variations of the maṇḍala.

column1: evañca sarvatobhadro vajrākṣavarakākavat // ardhacandraś ca śṛṅgāṭo hy acalo nāmarūpataḥ / vyūhā yathāsukhaṃ karyāḥ śatrūṇāṃ balavāraṇāḥ //
column2: In the same way the arrays sarvatobhadra, the excellent vajrākṣa, the crowshaped one, the half moon, śṛṅgāṭaka resembling the junction of four roads and .acala of the forms corresponding to their names should be formed according to one’s convenience that would prevent the enemy forces.

column1: rāmastu rāvaṇaṃ hatvā ayodhyāṃ prāptavān dvija / rāmoktanītyendrajitaṃ hatavāṃllakṣmaṇaḥ purā //
column2: O Brahmin! Rāma reached Ayodhyā after killing the demon Rāvaṇa. Lakṣmaṇa brother of Rāma killed Indrajit son of Rāvaṇa in days of yore by means of statesmanship narrated by Rāma.

column1: rāmoktoktā mayā nītiḥ strīṇāṃ rājan nṛṇāṃ vade /
column2: O King! Ethics were described by me to Rāma.

column1: lakṣaṇaṃ yadsamudreṇa gargāyoktaṃ yathā purā //
column2: shall now describe the characteristics of men and women as described by Samudra to sage Garga formerly.

column1: puṃsāñca lakṣaṇaṃ vakṣye strīṇāñcaiva śubhāśubhaṃ /
column2: shall describe the good and bad characteristics of men and women.

column1: ekādhiko dviśukraś ca triganbhīrastathaiva ca // tritrikastripralambaś ca tribhirvyāpnoti yas tathā / tribalīmāṃstrivinatastrikālajñaś ca suvrata // puruṣaḥ syātsulakṣaṇyo vipulaś ca tathā triṣu /
column2: O Virtuous one! column2: One should be fined sixteen paṇas for having thrown into another’s house, an object, that would cause misery or death to another. The abettor should be fined the middle sāhasa. One should duly be fined two paṇas onwards for having caused misery or bleeding injury or breaking the limbs of the body of a small animal.

column1: daṇḍaḥ kṣudrapaśūnāṃ syāddvipaṇaprabhṛtiḥ kramāt // liṅgasya cchedane mṛttau madhyamo mūlyameva ca /
column2: One should be fined the middle sāhasa and should pay the price for having cut off the genital organ of an animal or having killed it.

column1: mahāpaśūnāmeteṣu sthāneṣu dviguṇā damāḥ //
column2: In the case of bigger animals, in these instances, the fine would be double the above.

column2: The fine is forty paṇas for lopping the branches, trunk of the tree or the whole tree that is growing and providing sustenance.

column1: yaḥ sāhasaṅkārayati sa dāpyo dviguṇandamam / yastvevamuktvāhaṃ dātā kārayet sa caturguṇam // āryākrośātikramakṛdbhrātṛjāyāprahāradaḥ /
column2: One who causes another to indulge in a violent act shall have to pay double the fine and one who says that he would pay if fine is imposed and causes another to do a violent act shall be required to pay four times that fine.

column1: pañcāśatpaṇiko daṇḍa eṣāmiti viniś cayaḥ // svacchandavidhavāgāmī vikruṣṭe nābhidhāvakaḥ / akāraṇe ca vikroṣṭā caṇḍālaścottamān spṛśan //
column2: It has been fixed that, a person who reviles or shows disrespect to a respectable person, one who beats the wife of his brother, one who does not give the promised gift, one who breaks the summerhouse built in the midst of water and one who injures the neighbours, shall be fined fifty paṇas.

column1: śūdraḥ pravrajitānāñca daive paitrye ca bhojakaḥ / ayuktaṃ śapathaṃ kurvannayogyo yogyakarmakṛt // vṛṣakṣudrapaśūnāñca pūṃstvasya pratighātakṛt / sādhāraṇasyāpalopī dāsīgarbhavināśakṛt // pitāputrasvasṛbhrātṛdampatyācāryaśiṣyakāḥ /
column2: One who copulates with a licentious widow, one who assaults another uttering abuses, one who abuses another without any reason, a man of the low caste touching the men of higher castes, a śūdra a man of the fourth caste eating the meal at the time of the ceremony of a mendicant and in the divine and ancestral ceremonies, one who makes an improper oath, an incompetent person who does the act of a competent person, one who castrates the bulls or small animals, one who hides a wellknown matter, one who destroys the foetus of a servant woman, one who disregards any one of the followingfather, son, sister, brother, husband or wife, preceptor and pupil, that has not been degraded, shall be fined a hundred paṇas.

column1: vasānastrīn paṇān daṇḍyo nejakastu parāṃśukam /
column2: A washerman who wears the dress of others given to him for washing should be fined three paṇas.

column1: vikrayāvakrayādhānayāciteṣu paṇān daśa // tulāśāsanamānānāṃ kūṭakṛnnāṇakasya ca / ebhiś ca vyavahartā yaḥ sa dāpyo daṇḍamuttamam //
column2: It is ten paṇas if he sells them or requests others to take them without any charges. One who deals with those who make false marks on weights and measures and make counterfeit coins should be fined the highest sāhasa.

column1: akūṭaṃ kūṭakaṃ brūte kūṭaṃ yaścāpyakūṭakam /
column2: The cointester who declares the genuine as counterfeit and the counterfeit as genuine should be fined the first sāhasa.

column1: bhiṣaṅmithyācaran dāpyastiryakṣu prathamaṃ damam / mānuṣe madhyamaṃ rājamānuṣeṣūttamantathā //
column2: A physician who gives wrong medical treatment to birds and animals, men in general and men of royal household, should be punished with the first, middle and the highest fine respectively.

column1: abadhyaṃ yaś ca badhnāti badhyaṃ yaś ca pramuñcati / aprāptavyavahārañca sa dāpyo damamuttamam //
column2: An officer who keeps in custody a man that should not be kept incarcerated and allows an untried criminal to escape, should be fined the highest sāhasa.

column1: mānena tulayā vāpi yo 'ṃśamaṣṭamakaṃ haret / dvāviṃśatipaṇān dāpyo vṛddhau hānau ca kalpitam //
column2: One who steals an eighth part of the real weight of an article, by means of false scale or fraudulent measurement, should be fined twentytwo paṇas, no matter, whether the real weight has been increased.

column1: bheṣajasnehalavaṇagandhānyaguḍādiṣu /
column2: One who mixes lowstandard material in medicines, oils, salts, perfumes, grains and molasses etc.

column1: paṇyeṣu prakṣipan hīnaṃ paṇāndāpyastu ṣoḍaśa //
column2: should be fined sixteen paṇas.

column1: sambhūya kurvatāmarghaṃ sabādhaṃ kāruśilpināṃ / arthasya hrāsaḥ vṛddhiṃ vā sahasro daṇḍa ucyate //
column2: A thousand paṇas is said to be the fine to be imposed on the artisans who collectively indulge in affecting the value of the goods or cause the decrease or the increase of the wealth.

column1: rājāni sthāpyate yo 'rthaḥ pratyahaṃ tena vikrayaḥ / krayo vā nisravastasmādbaṇijāṃ lābhakṛt smṛtaḥ //
column2: It is considered to be profitable for the traders to sell or purchase everyday, goods that are dependent on the king.

column1: svadeśapaṇye tu śataṃ baṇij gṛhṇīta pañcakaṃ / daśakaṃ pāradeśye tu yaḥ sadyaḥ krayavikrayau // paṇyasyopari saṃsthāpya vyayaṃ paṇyasamudbhavaṃ /
column2: A trader should take five per cent profit on indigenous goods and ten percent profit on foreign goods that are bought and sold immediately. A trader, after having added the incidental expenses relating to the goods, to the price of the goods, should settle its price with the seller or purchaser.

column1: artho 'nugrahakṛt kāryaḥ kreturvikretureva ca // gṛhītamūlyaṃ yaḥ paṇyaṃ kreturnaiva prayacchati / sodayantasya dāpyo 'sau diglābhaṃ vā digāgate //
column2: A trader not delivering the goods to the purchaser from whom the cost has been collected, should be made to pay the amount along with the profit or the profit allowed on the foreign goods if the goods have come from the foreign country.

column1: vikrītamapi vikreyaṃ pūrve kretaryagṛhṇati /
column2: Goods that are sold already could again be sold, if the previous purchaser has not taken delivery of the goods.

column1: hāniścet kretṛdoṣeṇa kretureva hi sā bhavet //
column2: The defects in the goods due to the purchaser’s fault should be borne only by the purchaser.

column1: rājadaivopaghātena paṇye doṣamupāgate / hānirvikreturevāsau yācitasyāprayacchataḥ // anyahaste ca vikrītaṃ duṣṭaṃ vā duṣṭavadyadi / vikrīnīte damastatra tanmūlyādadviguṇo bhavet //
column2: In the case of any damage to the goods caused by political disturbances or natural calamities, or due to nondelivery at the desired time, the consequences have to be borne only by the seller. The fine payable by a seller for the damage or the apparent damage to goods sold through his agent would be double the value of the cost of the goods.

column1: kṣayaṃ vṛddhiñca baṇijā paṇyānāmavijānatā / krītvā nānuśayaḥ kāryaḥ kurvan ṣaḍ bhāgadaṇḍabhāk //
column2: A trader who has purchased the goods without the knowledge of the decrease or increase in their prices should not reopen the negotiation. In case he does so, he should be punished to pay one sixth of the value of the whole stock.

column1: samavāyena baṇijāṃ lābhārthaṃ karma kurvatāṃ / labhālābhau yathā dravyaṃ yathā vā saṃvidā kṛtau // pratiṣiddhamanādiṣṭaṃ pramādādyacca nāśitaṃ /
column2: The profits and losses of traders trading as partners for the sake of profit, should be divided proportionately to their shares in the capital, or according to agreement made at the commencement of the business. A partner should make good the loss sustained by him on account of doing the prohibited thing or doing a thing that he has not been asked to do or on account of folly.

column1: sa taddayādvipravācca rakṣitāddaśamāṃśabhāk // arthaprekṣapaṇādviṃśaṃ bhāgaṃ śulkaṃ nṛpā haret /
column2: A partner who has saved the goods from destruction is eligible to get one tenth of the value of the goods. The king shall take a twentieth part of the value of the abandoned goods as tax.

column1: vyāsiddhaṃ rājayogyañca vikrītaṃ rājagāmi tat //
column2: The contraband goods fit for royal use and sold to someone should go to the king.

column2: A deceitful purchaser or seller giving out false measures and going away from the toll office should be fined eight times the value of the goods.

column1: deśantaragate prete dravyaṃ dāyādabāndhavāḥ / jñātayo vā hareyustadāgatāstair vinā nṛpaḥ //
column2: Relatives and rightful heirs who have come should get the properties of a person on his death or his settlement abroad and the king should get in the absence of them the legal heirs.

column1: anena vidhirākhyāta ṛtvikkarṣakarmiṇāṃ //

column2: They should get the task done by employing another in the case of personal incapacity. A thief is apprehended by constables on finding the stolen property in his possession, by his footprint, his past crime and dirty clothes.

column1: anye 'pi śaṅkayā grāhyā jātināmādinihnavaiḥ /
column2: Others that hide their caste, name etc. should also be held on account of suspicion.

column1: dyūtastrīpānaśaktāś ca śuṣkabhinnamukhasvarāḥ //
column2: Persons addicted to gambling, wenching and drinking and those who turn pale and speak in a dry and broken voice should also be held.

column1: paradravyagṛhāṇāñca pṛcchakā gūḍhacāriṇaḥ / nirāyā vyayavantaś ca vinaṣṭa dravyavikrayāḥ //
column2: Those who enquire about the properties and houses of others, those who wander in disguise, those who spend much without income, those who sell lost goods should also be held.

column1: pañcagrāmī vahiḥ krośāddaśagrāmya.atha vā punaḥ /

column1: śastrāvapāte garbhasya pātane cottamo damaḥ //
column2: The highest sāhasa should be the punishment for causing abortion/miscarriage by means of a weapon.

column1: svajātāvuttamo daṇḍa ānulomye tu madhyamaḥ //
column2: The highest sāhasa is the fine if the woman belonged to his own caste and middle fine is prescribed if the woman belonged to the lower caste.

column2: But if the woman belonged to the higher caste than the adulterer, the man should be killed and the ears of the woman should be cut off.

column1: strī niṣedhe śataṃ dadyād dviśatantu damaṃ pumān //
column2: If it is prohibited for a woman, she has to pay a fine of one hundred paṇas and if for a man, he has to pay two hundred paṇas.

column1: pratiṣedhe tayordaṇḍo yathā saṃgrahaṇe tathā /
column2: In spite of the prohibition if they indulge in the above crimes, they have to be fined as in the case of adultery.

column2: A person mating with an animal shall be fined one hundred paṇas, and one mating with a woman of low caste or with a cow shall be fined the middle sāhasa. A person who mates with a slave girl or a maidservant held in captivity, though otherwise fit for cohabitation, should be fined fifty paṇas.

column1: prasahya dāsyabhigame daṇḍo daśapaṇaḥ smṛtaḥ /
column2: The fine is said to be ten paṇas if one forcibly copulates with a slave girl.

column2: One who mates with a woman of the last caste and a woman mendicant should be fettered and banished from the country. A person who adds or omits in copying the royal edict or one who releases a seducer should be fined the highest sāhas.

column1: abhakṣair dūṣayan vipraṃ daṇḍa uttamasāhasam /
column2: One who pollutes a brahmin by mixing forbidden food, should be fined the highest sāhasa.

column2: One who deals in counterfeit gold and one who sells unclean meat should be maimed and fined the highest sāhasa. An owner who releases the wild boars and horned cattle, though he is capable of keeping them penned, should pay the first sāhasa as fine.

column1: prathamaṃ sāhasaṃ dadyādvikruṣṭe dviguṇaṃ tathā /
column2: If it is accompanied by shouting, the owner should pay double the fine.

column1: acaurañcaure 'bhivadan dāpyaḥ pañcaśataṃ damaṃ //
column2: A man who calls an innocent man a thief should be made to pay a fine of five hundred paṇas.

column1: rājayānāsanāroḍhurdaṇḍo madhyamasāhasaḥ //
column2: The fine for a person who rides the carriage or sits on the seat of the king, is the middle sāhasa.

column1: vipratvena ca śūdrasya jīvato 'ṣṭaśato damaḥ //
column2: A śūdra living like a brahmin should be fined eight hundred paṇas.

column1: rājñānyāyena yo daṇḍo gṛhīto varuṇāyataṃ / vivedya dadyādviprebhyaḥ svayaṃ triṃśadguṇīkṛtaṃ //
column2: A king who has fined a person unjustly should offer the amount to lord VaruṇaGL_NOTE0} and pay thirty times the amount to the brahmins.

column1: dharmaścārthaś ca kīrtiñca lokapaṅktirupagrahaḥ / prajābhyo bahumānañca svargasthānañca śāśvatam // paśyato vyavahārāṃś ca guṇāḥ syuḥ sapta bhūpateḥ //84//
column2: Piety, wealth, fame, esteem of mankind, favour, love of the subjects and permanent residence in heaven, dispensing justice even as people watch are the seven qualities of a king. Lord of ocean and righteousness.

column1: ṛgyajuḥsāmātharvavidhānaṃ puṣkaroditam / bhuktimuktikaraṃ japyāddhomādrāmāya tadvade //
column2: shall now describe to you the application of the mantras of the Ṛg veda, Yajur veda, Sāma veda and Atharva veda that yield enjoyment and emancipation when repeated and are used for making oblations as described by Puṣkara to Rāma.

column1: prativedantu karmāṇi kāryāṇi pravadāmi te /
column2: shall now describe the religious rites relating to each one of the Vedas.

column1: prathamaṃ ṛgvidhānaṃ vai śṛṇu tvaṃ bhuktimuktidam //
column2: You listen first to the application of the Ṛg veda that would yield enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: antarjale tathā home japatī manasepsitam / kāmaṃ karoti gāyatrī prāṇāyāmādviśeṣataḥ //
column2: The repetition of the Gāyatrī mantra especially with the practice of prāṇāyāma regulated breathing, while remaining in the water as well as at the time of making oblations confers the fulfilment of heart’s desires.

column1: gāyatryā daśasāhasro japo naktāśano dvija / bahusnātasya tatraiva sarvakalmaṣanāśanaḥ //
column2: O Brahmin! The repetition of the Gāyatrī ten thousand times by a man eating only in the night and bathing many times during the day, destroys all the sins then and there.

column1: daśāyutāni japtvātha haviṣyāśī sa muktibhāk /
column2: One who repeats the mantra a lakh times while eating the oblations, becomes fit for emancipation.

column1: praṇavo hi paraṃ brahma tajjapaḥ sarvapāpahā //
column2: The praṇava the syllable Oṃ is identical with the Supreme Braman and its repetition destroys all the sins.

column1: oṃkāraśatajaptantu nābhimātrodake sthitaḥ / jalaṃ pivet sa sarvaistu pāpair vai vipramucyate //
column2: One who repeats the syllable Oṃ while remaining in waistdeep water and drinks the water becomes free from all sins.

column2: The praṇava consists of three mātrās syllabic instants, three Vedas, three gods Brahmā, Viṣṇu and Śiva and three fires. The mahāvyāhṛtis are the seven worlds.

column1: gāyatrī paramā jāpyā mahāvyāhṛtayas tathā /
column2: Gāyatrī is the most excellent among the mantras fit for repetition. The mahāvyāhṛtis are also of similar nature.

column1: antarjale tathā rāma proktaś caivāghamarṣaṇaḥ //
column2: O Rāma! The aghamarṣaṇa sūkta destroyer of sins should be repeated while remaining in the water.

column1: agnimīle purohitaṃ sūtko 'yaṃ vahnidaivataḥ /
column2: a. The hymn agnimīle purohitaṃ is sacred for the Firegod.

column1: ataḥ paramṛcaḥ sapta vāyvādyā yāḥ prakīrtitāḥ //
column2: Then the seven ṛks hymns known as Vāyu etc.

column2: should be daily repeated devoutly. Thus one will realise all his desires. One who desires to improve his memory should repeat the hymn known as sadasaspatim.

column1: anvayo yannimāḥ proktāḥ navarco mṛtyunāśanāḥ /
column2: These nine hymns beginning with anvayo yan are said to be destroyers of death.

column1: śunaḥśephamṛṣiṃ baddhaḥ sanniruddho 'tha vā japet //
column2: One who is a captive or being obstructed should repeat the hymn śunaḥśepaṃ ṛṣiṃ.

column1: mucyate sarvapāpebhyo gadī vāpyagado bhavet /

column1: ya icchecchāśvataṃ kāmaṃ mitraṃ prājñaṃ purandaraṃ // ṛgbhiḥ ṣoḍśabhiḥ kuryādindriyasyeti dine dine / hiraṇyastūpamityetajjapan śatrūn prabādhate //
column2: One who is desirous of gaining permanent pleasures and the friendship of the wise Purandara Indra should repeat daily the sixteen hymns beginning with indrasya. One who repeats the hymn hiraṇyastūpaṃ will cause affliction to the enemies.

column1: kṣemī bhavati cādhvāno ye te panthā japan naraḥ /
column2: One who repeats the hymn ye te panthāḥ will be safe on his journey.

column1: raudrībhiḥṣaḍbhirīśānaṃ stūyādyo vai dine dine // caruṃ vā kalpayedraudraṃ tasya śāntiḥ parā bhavet /
column2: One who praises lord Īśāna with six Rudra hymns everyday or one who offers oblation to Rudra will have greatest peace.

column1: udityudantamādityamupatiṣṭhan dine dine // kṣipejjalāñjalīn sapta manoduḥkhavināśanaṃ /
column2: One who extolls the rising Sun with the hymn ‘ud’ and offers water with folded palms seven times will be able to dispel his mental grief.

column1: dviṣantamityathārdharcaṃ yadviprāntaṃ japan smaret // āgaskṛt saptarātreṇa vidveṣamadhigacchati /
column2: One who repeats the half hymn dviṣantaṃ ending with yadvi pra will get his sin destroyed within seven nights.

column1: ārogyakāmī rogī vā praskannasyottamaṃ japet //
column2: One who desires health or one who is sick should repeat the hymn praskannasyottamaṃ.

column1: uttamastasya cārdharco japedvai vividhāsane / udayatyāyurakṣyayyaṃ tejo madhyandine japet // astaṃ pratigate sūrye dviṣantaṃ pratibādhate /
column2: One who repeats the half hymn uttamastasya in various postures will get long life if it is repeated at midday one will get radiance if repeated at sunset one will afflict his enemies.

column1: na vayaśceti sūktāni japan śatrūnniyacchati //
column2: One who repeats the hymns na vadhaḥ will destroy his enemies.

column1: ekādaśa suparṇasya sarvakāmānvinirdiśet /
column2: One who repeats the eleven suparṇa hymns will accomplish all the wishes.

column1: ādhyātmikīḥ ka ity etā japanmokṣamavāpnuyāt //
column2: One who repeats the hymn ādhyātmikīḥ ka will get emancipation.

column1: ā no bhadrā ity anena dīrghamāyuravāpnuyāt /
column2: One who repeats the hymn ā no bhadrā will get long life.

column1: tvaṃ someti ca sūktena navaṃ paśyenniśākaraṃ // upatiṣṭhet samitpāṇirvāsāṃsyāpnotyasaṃśayaṃ /
column2: One should look at the rising moon with the repetition of the hymn tvam soma and worship with the twig in the hand.

column1: āyurīpsannimamiti kautsa sūktaṃ sadā japet //
column2: One who desires long life should always repeat the hymn of Kautsa beginning with imaṃ.

column1: āpanaḥ śośucaditi stutvā madhye divākaraṃ / yathā muñcati ceṣokāṃ tathā pāpaṃ pramuñcati //
column2: By glorifying the Sun at midday with the hymn apanaḥ śośucad, one gets freed from sin like a bow when the arrow is discharged.

column1: jātavedasa ity etajjapet svastyayanaṃ pathi /
column2: One’s pathway becomes safe by the repetition of the hymn jātavedasa.

column1: bhayair vimucyate sarvaiḥ svastimānāpnuyāt gṛhān //
column2: One gets free from all fears. That person enjoying auspicious things will get houses.

column1: vyuṣṭāyāñca tathā rātryāmetadduḥsvapnanāśanaṃ / pramandineti sūyantyā japedgarbhavimocanaṃ //
column2: This hymn destroys the bad dream of the previous night. One should repeat the hymn pramandina and a woman who is delivering a child will do so with ease.

column1: japannindramiti snāto vaiśyadevantu saptakaṃ / muñcatyājyaṃ tathā juhvat sakalaṃ kilviṣaṃ naraḥ //
column2: A man will get free from all sins after bathing with the repetition of the hymn upannindraṃ and offering clarified butter as oblation while repeating the seven Vaiśvadeva hymns.

column1: imāmiti japan śaśvat kāmānāpnotyabhīpsitān /
column2: One who repeats the hymn imām always will get all his desires fulfilled.

column1: mānastoka iti dvābhyāṃ trirātropoṣitaḥ śuciḥ // auḍumbarīś ca juhuyātsamidhaścājyasaṃskṛtāḥ /
column2: One who fasts for three nights and offers the twigs of udumbara tree dipped in clarified butter with the repetition of the two hymns mā nastoka etc.

column1: chittvā sarvānmṛtyupāśān jīvedrogavivarjitaḥ //
column2: after becoming pure will cut all the fetters of death and live free from disease. la.

column1: mānastoketi ca ṛcā śikhābandhe kṛte naraḥ // aghṛṣyaḥ sarvabhūtānāṃ jāyate saṃśayaṃ vinā /
column2: One who having glorified Lord Śambhu with the repetition of this hymn with arms raised, binds the tuft into a knot while repeating the hymn mānastoka, no doubt, becomes invincible by all beings.

column1: citramityupatiṣṭheta trisandhyaṃ bhāskaraṃ tathā //
column2: One should worship the Sun daily at the three twilights with the repetition of the hymn citraṃ holding the twig.

column1: samitpāṇirnaro nityamīpsitaṃ dhanamāpnuyāt /
column2: Thus he will get the desired wealth.

column1: atha svapneti ca japan prātarmadhyandine dine // duḥsvapnañcārhate kṛtsnaṃ bhojanañcāpnuyācchubham /
column2: One will destroy the entire bad dream and get good food by the repetition of the hymn atha svapna in the morning and noon everyday.

column1: ubhe pumāniti tathā rakṣoghnaḥ parikīrtitaḥ //
column2: The hymn ubhe pumān is said to destroy the demons.

column1: ubhe vāsā iti ṛco japan kāmānavāpnuyāt /
column2: One who repeats the hymn ubhe vāsā will get all the pleasures.

column1: na sāganniti ca japan mucyate cātatāyinaḥ //
column2: A person repeating the hymn na sāgan will escape from the murderer.

column1: kayā śubheti ca japan jātiśraiṣṭhamavāpnuyāt / imannṛsomamityetat sarvān kāmānavāpnuyāt //
column2: One who repeats the hymn kayā śubha will attain casteexcellence, and the hymn imaṃ nṛsomaṃ will give all the pleasures.

column1: pitarityupatiṣṭheta nityamarthamupasthitaṃ /
column2: Conveying obeisance with the hymn pitaḥ one will always acquire riches.

column1: agne nayeti sūktena ghṛtahomaś ca mārgagaḥ //
column2: Oblation made with ghee with the repetition of the hymn agne naya also shows the path.

column1: vīrānnayamavāpnoti suślokaṃ yo japet sadā /
column2: One who repeats suśloka will always get a progeny of heroes.

column1: kaṅkato neti sūktena viṣān sarvān vyapohati //
column2: One is able to destroy all poisons by the repetition of the hymn kaṅkato na.

column1: yo jāta iti sūktena sarvān kāmānavāpnuyāt /
column2: One will get all the pleasures by the repetition of the hymn yo jāta.

column1: gaṇānāmiti sūktena śnigdhamāpnotyanuttamaṃ //
column2: One will get an excellent friend by the repetition of the hymn gaṇānām. la.

column1: yo me rājannitīmāntu duḥsvapnaśamanīmṛcaṃ /
column2: One should repeat the hymn yo me rājan that destroys bad dream.

column1: apraśastaṃ praśastaṃ vā kuvidaṅga imaṃ japet /
column2: One who commences a journey and faces an unpraiseworthy or praiseworthy enemy should repeat the hymn kuvidaṅga.

column1: dvāviṃśakaṃ japan sūktamādhyātmikamanuttamaṃ // parvasu prayato nityamiṣṭān kāmān samaśnute /
column2: One will enjoy all the desired pleasures by repeating the excellent hymn ādhyātmika consisting of twentytwo verses on the full and new moon days.

column1: kṛṇuṣveti japan sūktaṃ juhvadājyaṃ samāhitaḥ //
column2: One should offer an oblation of clarified butter with concentrated mind repeating the hymn kṛṇuṣva.

column1: ārātīnāṃ haret prāṇān rakṣāṃsyapi vināśayet /
column2: One will take away the lives of enemies and destroy even the demons by this.

column1: upatiṣṭhet svayaṃ vahniṃ parityṛcā dine dine //
column2: One should worship daily the Fire god with the hymn pari.

column1: taṃ rakṣati svayaṃ vahnirviśvato viśvatomukhaḥ /
column2: The Fire god having a face on every side Himself protects that person on all sides.

column1: haṃsaḥ śuciḥ sadityetacchucirīkṣeddivākaraṃ //
column2: One should look at the Sun, remaining pure and repeating the hymn haṃsaḥ śuciṣad.

column1: kṛṣiṃ prapadyamānastu sthālīpākaṃ yathāvidhi / juhuyāt kṣetramadhye tu svanīsvāhāstu pañcabhiḥ //
column2: A man about to cultivate a field should offer oblations of potboiled porridge at the centre of the field as laid down with the five hymns svanī svāhā.

column1: indrāya ca marudbhyastu parjanyāya bhagāya ca /
column2: A farmer should derive his plough in the approriate manner and offer oblations to the gods Indra, Maruts, Parjanya and Bhaga.

column1: yukto dhānyāya sītāyai sunāsīramathottaraṃ / gandhamālyair namaskārair yajedetāś ca devatāḥ //
column2: One should then worship Indra and these deities with perfumes, garlands and prostrations after having worshipped the ploughshare saying the yoke has been fastened for the sake of grains.

column1: pravāpane pralavane khalasītāpahārayoḥ / amoghaṅkarma bhavati vardhate sarvadā kṛṣiḥ //
column2: Agriculture will thus always thrive and the work relating to sowing the seeds, cutting, threshing and ploughing will yield profuse results.

column1: samudrāditi sūktena kāmānāpnoti pāvakāt / viśvānara iti dvābhyāṃ ya ṛgbhyāṃ vahnimarhati // sa taratyāpadaḥ sarvā yaśaḥ prāpnoti cākṣayaṃ / vipulāṃ śriyamāpnoti jayaṃ prāpnotyanuttamaṃ //
column2: One will get the desired things from the Fire god by the recitation of the hymn samudrāt One who worships the Fire god with the two hymns called viśvānara, surmounts all difficulties, gets undiminishing fame, abundant wealth and unsurpassed victory.

column1: agne tvamiti ca stutvā dhanamāpnoti vāñchitaṃ /
column2: One gets the desired riches by propitiating the Fire god with the hymn agne tvam.

column1: prajākāmo japennityaṃ varuṇadaivatatrayaṃ //
column2: A person desirous of having progeny should repeat the three hymns of Varuṇa daily.

column1: svastyā trayaṃ japet prātaḥ sadā svastyayanaṃ mahat /
column2: Each morning, one should recite the three svasti hymns, whereby one will always secure great prosperity.

column1: svasti panthā iti procya svastimān vrajate 'dhvani // vijigīṣurvanaspate śatrūṇāṃ vyādhitaṃ bhavet /
column2: By the recitation of the hymn svasti panthām one will have safe journey. One who desires to conquer should repeat the hymn vanaspate, by which enemies will be laid down with disease.

column1: striyā garbhapramūḍhāyā garbhamokṣaṇamuttamaṃ // acchāvadeti sūktañca vṛṣṭikāmaḥ prayiojayet /
column2: By the recitation of the same hymn a woman having a dead foetus will have a good delivery. One who is desirous to get rain should employ the hymn acchāvada after fasting and wearing wet clothes.

column1: nirāhāraḥ klinnavāsā na cireṇa pravarṣati //
column2: It will rain in no time.

column1: manasaḥ kāma ity etāṃ paśukāmo naro japet / kardamena iti snāyātprajākāmaḥ śucivrataḥ //
column2: A person who desires to have a cow should repeat the hymn manasaḥ kāma. One who desires to have progeny should bathe reciting the hymn kardamena, after becoming pure and practising vow.

column1: aśvapūrvā iti snāyādrājyakāmastu mānavaḥ /
column2: A man who wants to acquire kingdom should bathe with the repetition of the hymn aśvapūrvāṃ.

column1: rāhite carmaṇi snāyāt brāhmaṇastu yathāvidhi //
column2: A brahmin should bathe standing on a deerskin as laid down.

column1: rājā carmaṇi vaiyāghre chāge vaiśyastathaiva ca /
column2: A king should bathe standing on a tigerskin and a man of the merchant class on a goat skin in the same way.

column1: daśasāhasriko homaḥ pratyekaṃ parikīrtitaḥ //
column2: It has been declared that ten thousand oblations should be done in each case.

column1: āgāra iti sūktena goṣṭhe gāṃ lokamātaraṃ / upatiṣṭhedvrajeccaiva yadicchettāḥ sadākṣayāḥ //
column2: If a person desires to have the herds of cattle always undiminshing in his cowpen, he should worship the cow, the mother of the worlds, in the cowpen with the recitation of the hymn āgāvo.

column1: upetitisṛbhīrājño dundubhimabhimantrayet /
column2: A king should consecrate the royal drum with the three hymns beginning with upa.

column1: tejo bakañca prāpnoti śatruñcaiva niyacchati //
column2: By this he will get radiance and strength and rout the enemy.

column1: tṛṇapāṇirjapetsūktuṃ rakṣoghnaṃ dasyunbhirvṛtaḥ /
column2: One who is surrounded by the demons should repeat the hymn rakṣoghnam holding grass in the hand.

column1: ye ke ca umetyṛcaṃ japtvā dīrghamāyurāpnuyāt //
column2: By repeating the hymn ye ke ca jama one will gain long life.

column1: jīmūtasūktena tathā senāṅgānyabhimantrayet /
column2: One should consecrate the constituents of his army by the hymn jīmūta first like a liṅga.

column1: yadhā liṅgaṃ tato rājā vinihanti raṇe ripūn //
column2: Then the king will destroy the enemies in the battle.

column1: āgneyeti tribhiḥsūktair dhanamāpnoti cākṣayaṃ /
column2: One will gain undiminishing wealth by the recitation of the three hymns beginning with āgneya.

column1: amīvaheti sūktena bhūtāni sthāpayenniśi //
column2: One may fix goblins by the repetition of the hymn amīvaha in the night.

column1: sabādhe viṣame durge bandhā vā nirgataḥ kvacit / palāyan vā gṛhīto vā sūktametattathā japet //
column2: One should repeat this hymn in danger, difficulty, when caught in a fort, taken as a prisoner, while setting out some time, while running away, or when held as a captive.

column1: trirātraṃ niyatopoṣya śrāpayet pāyasañcaruṃ / tenāhutiśataṃ pūrṇaṃ juhuyāt tryambaketyṛcā //
column2: a One should fast for three nights with selfcontrol, boil sweat gruel and cast one hundred oblations with that with the repetition of the hymn tryambaka in honour of Lord Śiva.

column1: samuddiśya mahādevaṃ jīvedabdaśataṃ sukhaṃ /
column2: One will thus live happily for hundred years.

column1: taccakṣurityṛcā snāta upatiṣṭheddivākaraṃ // udyantaṃ madhyagañcaiva dīrghamāyurjijīviṣuḥ /
column2: One should worship the rising Sun and the Sun at the middle of the day after bathing and with the hymn taccakṣuḥ if one desires to have long life.

column1: indrā someti sūktantu kathitaṃ śatrunāśanaṃ //
column2: The hymn called indrā soma, when repeated, is said to destroy the enemy.

column1: yasya luptaṃ vrataṃ mohādvrātyair vā saṃsṛjetsaha / upoṣyājyaṃ sa juhuyāttvamagne vratapā iti //
column2: A person who has lost his vow by mistake or on account of association with the vrātyas, should fast and offer oblation with clarified butter with the recitation of the hymn tvamagne vratapā.

column1: ādityetyṛk ca samrājaṃ japtvā vāde jayī bhavet /
column2: A person who repeats the hymn āditya and samrāja will get victory in debate.

column1: mahīti ca catuṣkeṇa mucyate mahato bhayāt //
column2: One will become free from great fear by the repetition of the four hymns beginning with mahī.

column1: ṛcaṃ mahīti japtvā yadi hy etat sarvakāmānavāpnuyāt /
column2: One will get all the pleasures by the repetition of the hymn yadi hyetat.

column1: dvācatvāriṃśatiṃ caindraṃ japtvā nāśayate ripūn //
column2: One will destroy his enemies by the repetition of the fortytwo aindra hymns.

column1: vācaṃ mahīti japtvā ca prāpnotyārogyameva ca /
column2: One gets good health by repeating the hymn vācāmahī.

column1: śanno bhaveti dvābhyāntu bhuktvānnaṃ prayataḥ śuciḥ // hṛdayaṃ pāṇinā spṛṣṭvā vyādhibhir nābhibhūyate /
column2: A person who eats food repeating the two hymns śanno bhava after becoming clean and controlling the senses and touches the heart with the hand will not be attacked by diseases.

column1: uttamedamiti snāto huttvā śatruṃ pramāpayet // śannogna iti sūktena hutenānnamavāpnuyāt /
column2: One will destroy the enemy by offering oblations with the hymns uttamedaṃ after bathing. One will get food by making oblation with the hymn śannognir.

column1: kanyā vārarṣisūktena digdoṣādvipramucyate //
column2: One will get free from the defects of the quarters on journey by repeating the hymn kanyāvārarṣi.

column1: yadatya kavyetyudite japte 'vaśyaṃ jagadbhavet /
column2: One is able to subjugate the whole universe by the repetition of the hymn yadetya kavyaś at sun rise.

column1: yadvāgiti ca japtena vāṇī bhavati saṃskṛtā // vāco viditamiti tvetāṃ japan vācaṃ samaśnute /
column2: One’s speech gets refined by the repetition of the hymn yadvāk. One gill get good speech by repeating the hymn vāco vidaṃ.

column1: pavitrāṇāṃ pavitrantu pāvamānyetyṛco matāḥ //
column2: The pāvamāny hymns are considered to be most sacred.

column1: vaikhānasā ṛcastriṃśatpavitrāḥ paramā matāḥ /
column2: The thirty vaikhānasa hymns are considered to be extremely sacred.

column1: ṛco dviṣaṣṭiḥ proktāś ca parasvetyṛṣisattama //
column2: O Foremost among the sages! the parasva hymns are said to be sixtytwo.

column1: sarvakalmaṣanāśāya pāvanāya śivāya ca / svādiṣṭayetisūktānāṃ saptaṣaṣṭirudāhṛtā //
column2: The sixtyseven hymnssvādiṣṭayāare declared as destroyers of all sins, purifiers and conferrers of welfare.

column1: daśottarāṇyṛcāñcaitāḥ pāvamānyaḥ śatāni ṣaṭ / etajjapaṃś ca juhvacca ghoraṃ mṛtyubhayaṃ jayet // āpohiṣṭeti vāristho japetpāpabhayārdane /
column2: The six hundred and ten hymns of pāvamānya when repeated and used for making oblations will enable one to conquer the dread of death. One should repeat the hymns āpo hiṣṭha while standing in the water to destroy the fear of sin.

column1: pradevanneti niyato japecca marudhanvasu //
column2: A man passing through a desert should repeat the hymn pradevanna after the control of senses.

column1: prāṇāntike bhaye prāpte kṣipramāyustu vindati /
column2: When one is haunted by the fear of death, one will get the end of his life quickly.

column1: prāveyāmityṛcamekāṃ japecca manasā niśi //
column2: One should repeat the single hymn prāveyābhi mentally in the night.

column1: vyuṣṭāyāmudite sūrye dyūte jayamavāpnuyāt /
column2: If it is repeated at dawn or at sunrise one will get victory in gambling.

column1: mā pragāmeti mūḍhaś ca panthānaṃ pathi vindati //
column2: One who has lost his way will find his way by repeating the hymn mā pragāma. la.

column1: yatteyamiti tu snātastasya mūrdhānamālabhet // sahasrakṛtvaḥ pañcāhaṃ tenāyurvindate mahat /
column2: If one thinks that the life of a friend of himself is running out, he should bathe and touch the head of the friend reciting the hymn yatteyam thousand times for five days.

column1: idaṃ medhyeti juhuyāt ghṛtaṃ prājñaḥ sahasraśaḥ //
column2: A wise man should offer a thousand oblations with ghee with the repetition of the hymn idam medhya.

column1: paśukāmo gavāṃ goṣṭhe arthakāmaś catuṣpathe /
column2: One who desires to have cattle should do it at the cowpen and one who desires riches, at the crossroads.

column1: vayaḥ suparṇa ity etāṃ japan vai vindate śriyaṃ //
column2: One who repeats the hymn vayaḥ suparṇā will acquire wealth.

column1: haviṣyantīyamabhyasya sarvapāpaiḥ pramucyate /
column2: One will become free from all sins by the repetition of the hymn haviṣyantīyam.

column1: tasya rogā vinaśyanti kāyāgnirvardhate tathā //
column2: His diseases will get cured and the digestive power increased.

column1: yā oṣadhayaḥ svastyayanaṃ sarvavyādhivināśanaṃ /
column2: The hymn yā oṣadhayaḥ when repeated is a means of securing prosperity and curing all the diseases.

column1: vṛhaspate atītyetadvṛṣṭikāmaḥ prayojayet //
column2: One who wishes to have rain should employ the hymn bṛhaspate ati.

column1: sarvatreti parā śāntirjñeyā pratirathas tathā /
column2: The hymns sarvatra and pratiratha are known to confer supreme peace.

column1: sūta sāṃkāśyapannityaṃ prajākāmasya kīrtitaṃ //
column2: The recitation of the hymn sūta saṅkāśyapaṃ daily is commended for a person desirous to have progeny.

column1: ahaṃ rudreti etadvāgmī bhavati mānavaḥ /
column2: A person who recites the hymn ahaṃ rudra becomes an eloquent speaker.

column1: na yonau jāyate vidvān japanrātrīti rātriṣu //
column2: The learned person who recites the hymn rāti in the nights is not born again.

column1: rātrisūktaṃ japannrātrī rātriṃ kṣemī jayennaraḥ /
column2: The person who recites the rātrisūkta in the night spends the night safely.

column1: kalpayantīti ca japannityaṃ kṛttvārināśanaṃ //
column2: By doing the recitation of the hymn kalpayantī daily one will be able to destroy the enemies.

column1: āyuṣyañcaiva varcasyaṃ sūktaṃ dākṣāyaṇaṃ mahat /
column2: The recitation of the great Dākṣāyaṇa hymn confers longevity and radiance.

column1: uta devā iti japedāmayaghnaṃ dhṛtavrataḥ //
column2: A person who has undertaken a vow should recite the hymn uta devā, that will destroy the diseases.

column1: ayamagne janityetajjapedagnibhaye sati /
column2: When there is fear from fire, one should recite the hymn ayamagne janī.

column1: araṇyānītyaraṇyeṣu japettadbhayanāśanaṃ //
column2: One should repeat the hymn araṇyānī in the forests to destroy the fear therein.

column1: brāhmnīmāsādya sūkte dve ṛcaṃ brāhmīṃ śatāvarīṃ / pṛthagadbhirghṛtair vātha medhāṃ lakṣmīñca vindati //
column2: One who recites the two hymns with devotion to goddess Brāhmi the goddess of speech and makes use of brāhmī and śatāvarī the two herbs together with water or ghee separately will gain intelligence and wealth.

column1: māsa ity asapatnaghnaṃ saṃgrāmaṃ vijigīṣataḥ /
column2: One who desires to conquer his enemy in the battle should recite the hymn māsa.

column1: brahmaṇo 'gniḥ saṃvidānaṃ garbhamṛtyunivāraṇaṃ //
column2: The repetition of the hymn brahmaṇogniḥ saṃvidānaṃ prevents the death of the child in the womb.

column1: apahīti japetsūktaṃ śucirdusvapnanāśanaṃ /
column2: After getting pure one should recite the hymn apaihi, that destroys the effects of bad dreams.

column1: yenedamiti vaijaptvā samādhiṃ vindate paraṃ //
column2: One gains supreme concentration by the repetition of the hymn yenedaṃ.

column1: mayo bhūrvāta ity etat gavāṃ svastyayanaṃ paraṃ /
column2: The recitation of the hymn mayo bhūrvāto is an excellent means of securing the welfare of the cattle.

column1: śāmbarīmindrajālaṃ vā māyāmetena vārayet //
column2: One will ward off sorcery or jugglery by the repetition of this hymn.

column1: mahītrīṇāmavarostviti pathi svastyayanaṃ japet /
column2: One should repeat the hymn mahī trīṇāmavarostu for securing one’s welfare on his journey.

column1: agnaye vidviṣannevaṃ japecca ripunāśanaṃ //
column2: One should repeat the hymn agnaye vidviṣan, which will destroy the enemies.

column1: vāstoṣpatena mantreṇa yajeta gṛhadevatāḥ /
column2: The presiding deities of the houses should be worshipped with the hymn vāstoṣpate.

column1: japasyaiṣa vidhiḥ prokto hute jñeyo viśeṣataḥ //
column2: The procedure relating to the repetition has been told. That relating to the oblation has to be known as different.

column1: homānte dakṣiṇā deyā pāpaśāntirhutena tu / hutaṃ śāmyati cānnena annahemapradānataḥ //
column2: The prescribed fee has to be paid at the end of the oblation. There will be expiation of the sin by offering an oblation. The oblation done with food appeases by the offer of food and gold as gift.

column1: viprāśiṣastvamoghāḥ syurbahiḥsnānantu sarvataḥ /
column2: The blessings of brahmins will be unfailing. One should bathe outside in every case.

column1: siddhārthakā yavā dhānyaṃ payo ghṛtaṃ tathā //
column2: The same as in footnote above. ṚV. .0. ṚV. ...

column1: kṣīravṛkṣāstathedhmantu homā vai sarvakāmadāḥ /
column2: haviṣmatīr imā āpaḥ Taitt. Sam. ...a. MS. ..a ..

column1: samidhaḥ kaṇṭhakinyaś ca rājikā rudhiraṃ viṣaṃ //
column2: ahaṃ rudrebhir ṚV. ..la. Cf. rātriḥ ketunā Vaj. Sam.

column1: abhicāre tathā śailaṃ aśanaṃ śaktavaḥ payaḥ /
column2: Could not be traced. MS. ..a ., Cf. ayam agne jaritā ṚV.

column1: dadhi bhaikṣyaṃ phalaṃ mūlamṛgvidhānamudāhṛtaṃ //
column2: The flour of barley first fried and then ground.

column1: yajurvidhānaṃ vakṣyāmi bhuktimuktipradaṃ śṛṇu /
column2: shall describe the use of the hymns of Yajur veda , that yield enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: oṃkārapūrvikā rāma mahāvyāhṛtayo matāḥ //
column2: Listen to me O Rāma The great vyāhṛtis are considered to be preceded by the syllable oṃ.

column1: sarvakalmaṣanāśinyaḥ sarvakāmapradās tathā /
column2: They destroy all sins and yield all pleasures.

column1: ājyāhutisahasreṇa devānārādhayedbudhaḥ //
column2: A wise man should worship the gods with thousand oblations of clarified butter.

column1: manasaḥ kāṅkṣitaṃ rāma manasepsitakāmadaṃ /
column2: O Rāma This confers the desired pleasures.

column1: śāntikāmo yavaiḥ kuryāttilaiḥ pāpāpanuttaye // dhānyaiḥ siddhārthakaiś caiva sarvakāma karais tathā /
column2: One who desires peace should offer oblation with barley. One should offer with sesamum for the destruction of sin. One should offer oblation with grains and white mustard that will confer all the pleasures.

column1: audumbarībhiridhmābhiḥ pasukāmasya śasyate // dadhnā caivānnakāmasya payasā śāntimicchataḥ /
column2: Offering oblations with the twigs of udumbara tree is commended for one who desires cattle. One who desires food should offer oblation with curd and one who desires peace should with milk.

column1: apāmārgasamiddhastu kāmayan kanakaṃ bahu //
column2: One who desires plenty of gold should offer oblation with the twigs of apāmārga.

column1: kanyākāmo ghṛtāktāni yugmaśo grathitāni tu / jātīpuṣpāṇi juhuyādgrāmārthī tilataṇḍulān //
column2: One who seeks a maiden should offer oblation of jāti flowers that have been strung together in pairs and soaked in ghee. One who desires to have governorship over a village should offer oblations of sesamum and rice.

column1: vaśyakarmaṇi śākhoḍhavāsāpāmārgameva ca /
column2: The oblations of the twigs of śākhoṭa, vāsā and apāmārga trees are commended for bringing others under control.

column1: viṣāsṛṅmiśrasamidho vyādhighātasya bhārgava // kruddhastu juhuyātsamyak śatrūṇāṃ badhakāmyayā /
column2: O Son of Bhṛgu Paraśurāma oblation of twigs mixed with poison and blood should be made for causing the death of one after becoming sick. One who is angry should act perfectly in the above manner in order to kill his enemies.

column1: sarvavrīhimayīṃ kṛtvā rājñaḥ pratikṛtiṃ dvija // sahasraśastu juhuyādrājā vaśagato bhavet /
column2: O Brahmin After having made an image of the king made up of rice one should offer a thousand oblations. The king will thus be subjected to one’s control.

column1: vastrakāmasya puṣpāṇi darvā vyādhivināśinī //
column2: Flowers are to be used by one who desires clothes. The offering of dūrvā grass destroys disease.

column1: brahmavarcasakāmasya vāsograñca vidhīyate /
column2: It is laid down that strong scents should be used by one who desires to gain the splendour of a realised soul.

column1: pratyaṅgireṣu juhuyāttuṣakaṇṭakabhasmabhiḥ // vidveṣaṇe ca pakṣmāṇi kākakauśikayos tathā /
column2: Oblation should be offered with the ash of husk and thorns in retaliatory enchantments. In incantation to cause animosity, the wings of a crow and owl should be offered.

column1: kāpilañca ghṛtaṃ hutvā tathā candragrahe dvija // vacācūrṇena sampātātsamānīya ca tāṃ vacāṃ / sahasramantritāṃ bhuktvā medhāvī jāyate naraḥ //
column2: O Brahmin! One should offer the ghee of a black cow to fire at the time of the lunar eclipse and partake of it after having mixed it with the residue of powdered vacā a kind of aromatic root after incantation a thousand times. This will make him intelligent.

column1: ekādaśāṅgulaṃ śaṅku lauhaṃ khādirameva ca / dviṣato badhosīti japannikhanedripuveśmani //
column2: A peg of eleven inches made of iron or khadira tree should be buried in the house of the enemy after repeating the hymn dviṣato vadhosi.

column1: uccāṭanamidaṃ karma śatrūṇāṃ kathitaṃ tava /
column2: This act of magical incantation for the destruction of the enemy has been narrated to you.

column1: cakṣuṣyā iti japtvā ca vinaṣṭañcakṣurāpnuyāt //
column2: By the recitation of the hymn cakṣuṣyā one will get back lost eyesight.

column1: upayuñjata ity edanuvākantathānnadaṃ /
column2: The repetition of the section of the hymn beginning with upayuñjata will procure food.

column1: tanūnapāgne saditi dūrvāṃ hutvārtivarjitaḥ //
column2: One will be free from difficulties by offering oblation of dūrvā grass with the recitation of the hymn tanūnapāgne sat.

column1: bheṣajamasīti dadhyājyair homaḥ paśūpasarganut /
column2: Oblation made with curd and clarified butter with the recitation of the hymn bheṣajamasi will cure the sickness of domestic animals.

column1: tryamvakaṃ yajāmahe homaḥ saubhāgyavardhanaḥ //
column2: Oblation made with the recitation of the hymn tryambakaṃ yajāmahe will increase one’s fortune.

column1: kanyānāma gṛhītvā tu kanyalābhakaraḥ paraḥ / bhayeṣu tu japannityaṃ bhayebhyo vipramucyate //
column2: One who makes an oblation with this hymn pronouncing the name of a maiden, will secure that maiden. One who repeats this hymn daily when he is stricken with fear, will get free from fears.

column1: dhustūrapuṣpaṃ saghṛtaṃ hutvā syāt sarvakāmabhāk /
column2: By making an oblation with the dhuttūra flower along with ghee repeating this hymn, one will get all the pleasures.

column1: hutvā tu guggulaṃ rāma svapne paśyati śaṅkaraṃ //
column2: O Rāma! One who makes an oblation with guggulu a fragrant gum resin with the recitation of the hymn will see Śaṅkara Śiva in the dream.

column1: yuñjate mano 'nuvākaṃ japtvā dīrghāyurāpnuyāt /
column2: One will get long life by repeating the section yuñjate mana.

column1: viṣṇoravāṭamityetat sarvabādhāvināśanaṃ //
column2: The repetition of the hymn viṣṇorarāṭaṃ destroys all the obstacles.

column1: rakṣoghnañca yaśasyañca tathaiva vijayapradaṃ /
column2: It is capable of destroying demons. It also confers victory.

column1: ayatno agnirityetat saṃgrāme vijayapradaṃ //
column2: The repetition of the hymn ayaṃ no agniḥ yields victory in battle.

column1: idamāpaḥ pravahata snāne pāpāpanodanaṃ /
column2: The hymn idamāpaḥ pravahata when repeated while bathing is capable of destroying sins.

column1: viśvakarmannu haviṣā sūcīṃ lauhīndaśāṅgulām // kanyāyā nikhaneddvāri sānyasmai na pradīyate /
column2: If one buries an iron nail of ten inches length at the threshold of the house of a maiden with the repetition of the hymn viśvakarmannu havis she will not be given in marriage to somebody else.

column1: deva savitaretena juhuyādbalakāmo dvijottama //
column2: One who makes an oblation with the repetition of the hymn devasavitaḥ will get food.

column1: agnau svāheti juhuyādbalakāmo dvijottama / tilair yavaiś ca dharmajña tathāpāmārgataṇḍulaiḥ //
column2: O Knower of virtue! The excellent brahmin who desires strength should do oblation with sesamum, barley, rice and twigs of apāmārga with the recitation of agnau svāhā oblations to fire.

column1: sahasramantritāṃ kṛtvā tathā gorocanāṃ dvija / tilakañca tathā kṛtvā janasya priyatāmiyāt //
column2: O Brahmin! One will win the affection of the people by making a mark on the forehead with gorocanā yellow pigment got from the belly of cow after having made the incantation of the sacred syllable a thousand times.

column1: rudrāṇāñca tathā japyaṃ sarvāghavinisūdanaṃ /
column2: The repetition of the Rudra hymns is capable of destroying all the sins.

column1: sarvakarmakaro homas tathā sarvatra śantidaḥ //
column2: The oblation made with that hymn accomplishes all tasks and ensures peace everywhere.

column1: ajāvikānāmaśvānāṃ kuñjarāṇāṃ tathā gavāṃ / manuṣyāṇānnarendrāṇāṃ bālānāṃ yoṣitāmapi // grāmāṇāṃ nagarānāñca deśānāmapi bhārgava / upadrutānāṃ dharmajña vyādhitānāṃ tathaiva ca //
column2: O Bhārgava! Knower of virtue! when the goats, sheep, horses, elephants, cows, men, kings, children, women, villages, cities and countries are being attacked or afflicted by diseases, when there is the outbreak of plague and there is fear from the enemies, then the offering of oblation with Rudra hymns with sweet porridge and ghee will confer supreme peace.

column1: rudrahomaḥ parā śāntiḥ pāyasena ghṛtena ca // kuṣmāṇḍaghṛtahomena sarvān pāpān vyapohati /
column2: One gets free from all sins by offering oblation with pumpkin and ghee with the Rudra hymns.

column1: śaktuyāvakabhaikṣāśī naktaṃ manujasattama // bahiḥsnānarato māsānmucyate brahmahatyayā /
column2: Excellent man! One gets free from the sin of killing a brahmin by eating the flour of barley, barley or alms in the night and bathing for a month outside.

column1: madhuvāteti mantreṇa homādito 'khilaṃ labhet //
column2: One will get everything by offering oblation with the repetition of the hymn madhuvātā.

column1: dadhi krāvneti hutvā tu putrān prāpnotyasaṃśayaṃ / tathā ghṛtavatītyetadāyuṣyaṃ syāt ghṛtena tu //
column2: One will certainly get children by offering oblation with the recitation of the hymn dadhikrāvṇa. Similarly oblation made with ghee with the recitation of the hymn ghṛtavatī will give life.

column1: svastina indra ity etatsarvabādhāvināśanaṃ / iha gāvaḥ prajyāyadhvamiti puṣṭivivardhanam //
column2: The recitation of the hymn svasti na indra would destroy all difficulties and the hymn iha gāvaḥ prajāyadhvaṃ would increase the strength.

column1: ghṛtāhutisahasreṇa tathā lakṣmīvināśanaṃ /
column2: A thousand oblations made with ghee with this hymn will ward off illluck.

column1: śruveṇa devasya tveti hutvāpāmārgataṇḍulaṃ // mucyate vikṛtācchīghramabhicārānna saṃśayaḥ /
column2: Oblations made with the twigs of apāmārga and rice with the recitation of the hymn sruveṇa devasya tvā will without any doubt free one quickly from the deformities inflicted by incantation.

column1: rudra pātu palaśasya samidbhiḥ kanakaṃ labhet //
column2: One would get gold by oblations with the twigs of palāśa with the hymn rudra pātu Rudra protect.

column1: śivo bhavetyagnyutpāte vrīhibhirjuhuyānnaraḥ / yāḥ senā iti caitacca taskarebhyo bhayāpaham //
column2: One should offer oblations with rice with the recitation of the hymn śivo bhava The repetition of the hymn yāḥ senā removes the fear of thieves.

column1: yo asmabhyamavātīyāddhutvā kṛṣṇatilānnaraḥ / sahasraśo 'bhicārācca mucyate vikṛtāddvija //
column2: O Brahmin! One who makes a thousand oblations with black sesamum with the recitation of the hymn yo asmabhyamayātīyāt will become free from deformities caused by incantation.

column1: annenānnapatetyevaṃ hutvā cānnamavāpnuyāt / haṃsaḥ śuciḥ sadityetajjaptantoye 'ghanāśanaṃ //
column2: One will get food by offering an oblation of food with the recitation of the hymn annapate The repetition of the hymn haṃsaḥ śuciṣad while remaining in the water destroys sins.

column1: catvāri bhaṅgetyetattu sarvapāpaharaṃ jale /
column2: The repetition of the hymn catvāri śṛṅgāḥ while remaining in the water will remove all sins.

column1: devā yajñeti japtvā tu brahmaloke mahīyate //
column2: By the repetition of the hymn devā yajña one will be respected in the world of Brahmā.

column1: vasanteti ca hutvājyaṃ ādityādvaramāpnuyāt /
column2: One will obtain the favour of the Sun by offering oblation with clarified butter with the repetition of the hymn vasanta.

column1: suparṇosīti cetyasya karmavyāhṛtivadbhavet //
column2: The rites relating to the use of the hymn suparṇosi are the same as for the seven vyāhṛtis.

column1: namaḥ svāheti trirjaptvā bandhanānmokṣamāpnuyāt /
column2: One will get released from bondage by repeating namaḥ svāhā three times.

column1: antarjale trirāvartya drupadā sarvapāpamuk //
column2: By repeating the hymn drupadā three times while remaining in the water will destroy all sins.

column1: iha gāvaḥ prajāyadhvaṃ mantroyaṃ buddhivardhanaḥ / hutantu sarpiṣā dadhnā payasā pāyasena vā //
column2: The sacred formula iha gāvaḥ prajāyadhvaṃ is capable of sharpening the intellect when oblations are offered with clarified butter, curd, milk and sweet porridge.

column1: śatam ya iti caitena hutvā parṇaphalāṇi ca / ārogyaṃ śriyamāpnoti jīvitañca cirantathā //
column2: Oblations made with leaves and fruits with the recitation of the hymn śataṃ yo confers health, wealth and long life.

column1: oṣadhīḥ pratimodagdhvaṃ vapane lavane 'rthakṛt / aśvāvatī pāyasena homācchāntimavāpnuyāt //
column2: The recitation of the hymn oṣadhīḥ pratimodadhvaṃ while mowing and cutting will give returns. Oblations made with sweet porridge with the repetition of the hymn aśvāvat will secure peace.

column1: tasmā iti ca mantrena bandhanastho vimucyate /
column2: One will be released from bondage by the repetition of the sacred formula tasmā.

column1: yuvā suvāsā ity eva vāsāṃsyāpnoti cottamam //
column2: One will get excellent dress by repeating the hymn yuvā suvāsāḥ.

column1: muñcantu mā śapathyāni sarvāntakavināśanam /
column2: The recitation of the hymn muñcantu mā śapathyāt is capable of destroying all the enemies.

column1: mā māhiṃsīstilājyena hutaṃ ripuvināśanaṃ //
column2: Oblation of sesamum while reciting the hymn mā mā hiṃsīḥ is capable of destroying enemies.

column1: namo 'stu sarvasarpebhyo ghṛtena pāyasena tu / kṛṇudhavaṃ rāja ity etadabhicāravināśanaṃ //
column2: Oblations of ghee and sweet porridge with the repetition of the hymns namostu sarvasarpebhyo and kṛṇudhvaṃ rāja destroys magic incantations.

column1: dūrvākāṇḍāyutaṃ hutvā kāṇḍāt kāṇḍeti mānavaḥ / grāme janapade vāpi marakantu śamannayet //
column2: One can control an epidemic in a village or country by making ten thousand oblations of pieces of dūrvā grass with the recitation of the hymn kāṇḍāt kāṇḍāt.

column1: rogārto mucyate rogāt tathā duḥkhāttu duḥkhitaḥ /
column2: One who is suffering from a disease will be cured and the griefstricken will become free from grief by this.

column1: auḍumbarīś ca samidho madhumānno vanaspatiḥ // hutvā sahasraśo rāma dhanamāpnoti mānavaḥ /
column2: O Rāma! A person who offers a thousand twigs of udumbara treeas oblation with the recitation of the hymn madhumānno vanaspatiḥ will get wealth.

column1: saubhāgyaṃ mahadāpnoti vyavahāre tathā trayam //
column2: One will also get great fortune and victory in litigation.

column1: apāṃ garbhamiti hutvā devaṃ varṣāpayeddhruvam / apaḥ piveti ca tathā hutvā dadhi ghṛtaṃ madhu // pravartayati dharmajña mahāvṛṣṭimanantaraṃ /
column2: One will make the gods rain by offering oblations of the same with the recitation of the hymn apāṃ garbhaṃ. O Knower of virtue! By making oblations of curd, ghee and honey with the repetition of the hymn apaḥ pinva one will make it rain heavily.

column1: namaste rudra ity etat sarvopadravanāśanaṃ //
column2: The repetition of the hymn namaste rudra destroys all misfortunes.

column1: sarvaśāntikaraṃ proktaṃ mahāpātakanāśanaṃ /
column2: The above hymn is also said to ensure all peace and destroy great sins.

column1: adhyavocadityanena rakṣaṇaṃ vyādhitasya tu // rakṣoghnañca yaśasyañca cirāyuḥpuṣṭivardhanam /
column2: One who is afflicted by a disease is protected by the repetition of the hymn adhyavocat. It is also capable of destroying demons, increasing fame, long life and strength.

column1: siddhārthakānāṃ kṣepeṇa pathi caitajjapan sukhī //
column2: One will be happy by scattering white mustard and repeating this hymn on the journey.

column1: upatiṣṭheta dharmajña sāyaṃ prātaratandritaḥ // annamakṣayamāpnoti dīrghamāyuś ca vindati /
column2: O Knower of virtue! One will get long life and undiminishing food by worshipping daily the sun morning and evening unweariedly repeating the hymn asau yastāmro.

column1: pramuñca dhanvannityetat ṣaḍbhirāyudhamantraṇaṃ //
column2: Weapons are consecrated by the six hymns pramuñca dhanvanas.

column1: ripūṇāṃ bhayadaṃ yuddhenātrakāryā vicāraṇā /
column2: It will frighten enemies in battle. One need not entertain any doubt.

column1: māno mahānta ity evaṃ bālānāṃ śāntikārakaṃ //
column2: The repetition of the hymn māno mahāntaṃ confers peace on children.

column1: namo hiraṇyavāhave ity anuvākasaptakam / rājikāṃ kaṭutailāktāṃ juhuyācchatrunāśanīṃ //
column2: One should offer oblations of black mustard soaked in pungent oil with the repetition of the seven sections beginning with namo hiraṇyabāhave that will destroy enemies.

column1: namo vaḥ kirikebhyaś ca padmalakṣāhutair naraḥ / rājyalakṣmīmavāpnoti tathā bilvaiḥ suvarṇakam //
column2: One becomes a sovereign by offering oblations of a lakh lotuses with the recitation of the hymn namo vaḥ kirikebhyo. By similar offerings of bilva leaves one will acquire gold.

column1: imā rudrāyeti tilair homācca dhanamāpyate /
column2: One will obtain wealth by oblations of sesamum with the repetition of imā rudrāya.

column1: dūrvāhomena cānyena sarvavyādhivivarjitaḥ //
column2: Oblations with dūrvā grass will make one free from all diseases.

column1: āśuḥ śiśāna ity etadāyudhānāñca rakṣaṇe /
column2: The hymn āśuḥ śiśāna is used in the protection of weapons.

column1: saṃgrāme kathitaṃ rāma sarvaśatrunivarhaṇaṃ //
column2: O Rāma! It is said to destroy all the enemies in battle.

column1: rājasāmeti juhuyāt sahasraṃ pañcabhirdvija / ājyāhutīnāṃ dharmajña cakṣūrogādvimucyate //
column2: O Brahmin! Knower of virtue! One thousand oblations of clarified butter with the repetition of the five hymns rāja sāma will cure the eye disease of a person.

column1: śanno vanaspate gehe homaḥ syādvāstudoṣanut /
column2: The oblation done with the hymn śanno vanaspate gehe will destroy the defects of a building.

column1: agna āyūṃsi hutvājyaṃ dveṣaṃ nāpnoti kenacit //
column2: One will not earn enmity with anyone by offering oblations of clarified butter with the repetition of agna āyūṃṣi.

column1: apāṃ pheneti lājābhirhutvā jayamavāpnuyāt /
column2: One will gain victory by the oblation of fried paddy with the hymn apāṃ phena.

column1: bhadrā itīndriyair hīno japan syāt sakalendriyaḥ //
column2: He who has defective senseorgans will get sound ones by the repetition of the hymn bhadrā.

column1: agniś ca pṛthivī ceti vaśīkaraṇamuttamam /
column2: The hymn agniśca pṛthivī ca is an excellent charm.

column1: adhvaneti japan mantraṃ vyavahāre jayī bhavet //
column2: One who repeats the hymn adhvana will be victorious in litigation.

column1: brahma rājanyamiti ca karmārambhe tu siddhikṛt /
column2: The hymn brahma rājanyaṃ accomplishes the task when repeated at its commencement.

column1: saṃvatsarosīti dhṛtair lakṣahomādarogavān //
column2: One will be free from disease by the oblation of ghee a lakh times with the repetition of the hymn saṃvatsarosi.

column1: ketuṃ kṛṇvannitītyetat saṃgrāme jayavardhanam /
column2: The hymn ketuṃ kṛṇvan will confer victory in battle.

column1: indrognirdharma ity etadraṇe dharmanibandhanam //
column2: The hymn indrognirdharma ensures fair play in battle.

column1: dhanvā nāgeti mantraś ca dhanurgrāhanikaḥ paraḥ /
column2: The hymn dhanvanā gā is excellent for the bow wielder.

column1: yajīteti tathā mantro vijñeyo hy abhimantraṇe //
