column2: Rukmiṇī, Satyabhāmā, Satyā, Nāgnajitī, Gāndhārī, Lakṣmaṇā, Mitravindā, Kālindī, Jāmbavatī, Suśīlā, Mādrī, Kauśalyā, Vijayā, Jayā and others were the sixteen thousand wives of Kṛṣṇa among whom Satyabhāmā served Lord Hari Kṛṣṇa.

column1: pradyumnādyāś ca rukmiṇyāṃ bhīmādyāḥ satyabhāmayā // jāmbavatyāñca śāmbādyāḥ kṛṣṇasyāsaṃs tathāpare /
column2: Pradyumna and others were born to Kṛṣṇa through Rukmiṇī, Bhīma and others through Satyabhāmā, Sāmba and others through Jāmbavatī and thus were among the one hundred thousand sons of that wise man.

column1: aśītiś ca sahasrāṇi yādavāḥ kṛṣṇarakṣitāḥ /
column2: Yādavas were eighty thousand that were protected by Lord Kṛṣṇa.

column1: pradyumnasya tu vaidarbhyāmaniruddho raṇapriyaḥ //
column2: Pradyumna son of Kṛṣṇa had Aniruddha, who was fond of war, as his son through Vaidarbhī.

column1: aniruddhasya vajrādyā yādavāḥ sumahābalāḥ /
column2: The mighty Yādavas Vajra and others were the sons of Aniruddha.

column1: tisraḥ koṭyo yādavānāṃ ṣaṣṭirlakṣāṇi dānavāḥ //
column2: Thus there were three crores and sixty lakhs of Yādavas.

column1: manuṣye bādhakā ye tu tannāśāya babhūva saḥ /
column2: He Kṛṣṇa appeared for the destruction of the demons that afflicted men.

column1: kartuṃ karmavyavasthānaṃ manuṣyo jāyate hariḥ //
column2: Lord Hari Viṣṇu is born as a mortal in order to regularise the duties of men.

column1: devāsurāṇāṃ saṅgrāmā dāyārthaṃ dvādaśābhavan /
column2: There were twelve battles between the celestials and the demons for the sake of their legitimate portions.

column1: prathamo nārasiṃhastu dvitīyo vāmano raṇaḥ //
column2: The first war of Viṣṇu was in the manlion form. The second war was as a dwarf.

column1: saṅgrāmastvatha vārāhaś caturtho 'mṛtamanthanaḥ /
column2: The battle fought as the boar was the next one. The fourth one was for the churning of the nectar.

column1: tārakāmayasaṅgrāmaḥ ṣaṣṭho hy ājīvako raṇaḥ //
column2: The sixth one was the battle involving all the celestial bodies for the sake of resuscitation.

column1: traipuraścāndhakabadho navamo vṛtraghātakaḥ /
column2: The ninth one was the killing of the demon Vṛtra.

column1: jito hālāhalaścātha ghoraḥ kolāhalo raṇaḥ //
column2: The deadly poison of hālāhala was conquered in the tenth one. The demon Kolāhala was subdued in the next one.

column1: hiraṇyakaśipoścoro vidārya ca nakhaiḥ purā / nārasiṃho devapālaḥ prahnādaṃ kṛtavān nṛpam //
column2: The next one was the form as the manlion, the protector of the celestials in olden days, that pierced the chest of the demon Hiraṇyakaśipu with his nails and made Prahlāda the king.

column1: devāsure vāmanaś ca chalitvā balimūrjitam / mahendrāya dadau rājyaṃ kāśyapo 'ditisambhavaḥ //
column2: In the dispute between the celestials and the demons, the Lord was born of Kaśyapa and Aditi as a dwarf, deceived the powerful demon Bali and restored the kingdom to Indra.

column1: varāhastu hiraṇyākṣaṃ hatvā devānapālayat / ujjahāra bhuvaṃ devadevair abhiṣṭutaḥ //
column2: The manifestation as a boar was made by Lord Viṣṇu and the demon Hiraṇyākṣa was killed, protecting the celestials thus. He lifted up the earth that got submerged and was praised by the celestials.

column1: manthānaṃ mandaraṃ kṛtvā netraṃ kṛtvā tu vāsukim /
column2: The mount Mandara was made the churning rod, the serpent Vāsuki as the string and the ocean was churned by the celestials and the demons.

column1: surāsuraiś ca mathitaṃ devebhyaścāmṛtaṃ dadau //
column2: The ambrosia that was obtained was given to the celestials.

column1: tārakāmayasaṅgrāme tadā devāś ca pālitāḥ / nivāryendraṃ gurūn devān dānavānsomavaṃśakṛtam //
column2: The celestials were in the same way protected at the time of the battle of the stars after preventing Indra, Guru, the celestials and demons from a combat and thus the Lunar race was made to flourish.

column1: viśvāmitravaśiṣṭhātrikavayaś ca raṇe surān / apālayante nirvārya rāgadveṣādidānavān //
column2: The sages Viśvāmitra, Vasiṣṭha, Atri and Brahmā protected the celestials in the battle after warding off the demons that were having infatuation and hatred.

column1: pṛthvīrathe brahmayanturīśasya śaraṇo hariḥ /
column2: Lord Hari Viṣṇu was the refuge of Lord Īsāna Śiva that had Lord Brahmā as the charioteer of the earth, the chariot.

column1: dadāha tripuraṃ devapālako daityamardanaḥ //
column2: The protector of the celestials and the destroyer of the demons burnt the three cities.

column1: gaurīṃ jihīrṣuṇā rudramandhakenārditaṃ hariḥ / anuraktaś ca revatyāṃ cakrecāndhāsurārdanam //
column2: Lord Rudra Śiva was attacked by the demon Andhaka desirous of carrying away Gaurī consort of Śiva. Lord Hari, who was fond of his beloved Revatī killed the demon Andha.

column1: apāṃ phenamayo bhūtvā devāsuraraṇe haran / vṛtraṃ devaharaṃ viṣṇurdevadharmānapālayat //
column2: Lord Viṣṇu became the foam of the water at the time of the battle between the celestials and the demons and killed the demon Vṛtra that afflicted the celestials, and protected the virtues of the celestials.

column1: śālvādīn dānavān jitvā hariḥ paraśurāmakaḥ / apālayat surādīṃś ca duṣṭakṣatraṃ nihatya ca //
column2: Lord Hari, manifested as Paraśurāma, conquered the demons such as Śālva and protected the celestials after killing the wicked kṣatriyas kings.

column1: hālāhalaṃ viṣaṃ daityaṃ nirākṛtya maheśvarāt / bhayaṃ nirṇāśayāmāsa devānāṃ madhusūdanaḥ //
column2: Madhusūdana the destroyer of demon Madhu took away the demon of Hālāhala poison from Maheśvara and destroyed the fear of the celestials.

column1: devāsure raṇe yaś ca daityaḥ kolāhalo jitaḥ /
column2: The demon Kolāhala was conquered by Him at the battle of the celestials and demons.

column1: pālitāś ca surāḥ sarve viṣṇunā dharmapālanāt //
column2: All the celestials were protected by Lord Viṣṇu by protecting righteousness.

column1: rājāno rājaputrāś ca munayo devatā hariḥ / yaduktaṃ yacca naivoktamavatārā harerime //
column2: The kings, princes, sages and the gods are the manifestations of Lord Hari, whether their names have been narrated or not in the traditional list.

column1: turvasoś ca suto vargo gobhānustasya cātmajaḥ /
column2: Varga was the son of Turvasu. Gobhānu was his son.

column1: gobhānorāsīt traiśānistraiśānestu karandhamaḥ //
column2: Traiśāni was born from Gobhānu. Karandhama was the son of Taraiśāni.

column1: karandhamānmaruttobhūd duṣmantastasya cātmajaḥ /
column2: Marutta was born from Karandhama.

column1: duṣmantasya varūtho 'bhūdgāṇḍīrastu varūthataḥ //
column2: Duṣyanta was his son. Varūtha was the son of Duṣyanta.

column1: gāṇḍīrāccaiva gāndhāraḥ pañca jānapadāstataḥ / gāndhārāḥ keralāścolāḥ pāṇḍyāḥ kolā mahābalāḥ //
column2: Gāṇḍīra was born from Varātha. Gāndhāra was born from Gāṇḍīra. The mighty five peoplesGāndhāras, Keralas, Colas, Pāṇḍyas and Kolas were born then.

column1: druhyastu vabhrusetuś ca babhrusetoḥ purovasuḥ /
column2: Druhyu and Babhrusetu were the sons of Gāndhāra. Purovasu was born from Babhrusetu.

column1: tato gāndhārā gāndhārair dharmo dharmād ghṛto 'bhavat //
column2: Then Gāndhāra was born and Dharma from Gāndhāra. Ghṛta was born from Dharma.

column1: ghṛtāttu viduṣastasmāt pracetāstasya vai śatam / ānadraś ca sabhānaraścākṣuṣaḥ parameṣukaḥ //
column2: Viduṣa was born from Ghṛta. Pracetas was born from him. He had a hundred sons among whom Ānadra, Sabhānara, Cākṣuṣa and Parameṣuka were foremost.

column1: sabhānarāt kālānalaḥ kālānalajasrṛñjayaḥ /
column2: Kālānala was born from Sabhānara. Sṛñjaya, was born from Kālānala.

column1: purañjayaḥ sṛñjayasya tatputro janamejayaḥ //
column2: Purañjaya was the son of Sṛñjaya. Janamejaya was his son.

column1: tatputrastu mahāśālastatputro 'bhunmahāmanāḥ /
column2: Mahāsāla was his son. Mahāmanas was his son.

column1: tasmāduśīnaro brahmannṛgāyāntu nṛgastataḥ //
column2: O Brahman! Uśīnara was from him.

column1: narāyāntu naraścāsīt kṛmistu kṛmitaḥ sutaḥ /
column2: He had then a son Nṛga through his queen Nṛgā, a son Nara through his queen Narā and a son Kṛmi through Kṛmi.

column1: daśāyāṃ subrato jajñe dṛśadvatyāṃ śivis tathā //
column2: Suvrata was born to him through Dṛṣadvatī.

column1: śive putrāstu catvāraḥ pṛthudarbhaś ca vīrakaḥ /
column2: Pṛthudarbha, Vīraka, Kaikeya and Bhadraka were the four sons of Śibi.

column1: kaikeyo bhadrakasteṣāṃ nāmrā janapadāḥ śubhāḥ //
column2: There were prosperous regions in their names.

column1: titikṣuruśīnarajastitikṣoś ca ruṣadrathaḥ /
column2: Titikṣu was born from Uśīnara. Ruṣadratha was born from Titikṣu.

column1: ruṣadrathādabhūtpailaḥ pailācca sutapāḥ sutaḥ //
column2: Paila was born from Ruṣadratha. Sutapā was the son of Paila.

column1: mahāyogi balistasmādaṅgo vaṅgaś ca mukhyakaḥ / puṇḍraḥ kaliṅgo bāleyo baliryogī balānvitaḥ //
column2: The great ascetic Bali was born from him. Aṅga, Vaṅga, Mukhyaka, Puṇḍra and Kaliṅga were the sons of Bali. Bali, the ascetic, generated them by means of his power.

column1: aṅgāddadhivāhano 'bhūt tasmāddiviratho nṛpaḥ /
column2: Dadhivāhana was born from Aṅga. Diviratha was the next king after him.

column1: divirathāddharmarathastasya citrarathaḥ sutaḥ //
column2: Dharmaratha was born from Diviratha. Citraratha was his son. Satyaratha was born from Citraratha.

column1: citrarathātsatyaratho lomapadaś ca tatsutaḥ / lomapādāccaturaṅgaḥ pṛthulākṣaś ca tatsutaḥ //
column2: Lomapāda was his son. Caturaṅga was born from Lomapāda. Pṛṭhulākṣa was his son. Campa was born from Pṛthulākṣa.

column1: haryaṅgācca bhadraratho bṛhatkarmā ca tatsutaḥ //
column2: Haryaṅgaka was from Campa. Bhadraratha was from Haryaṅga. Bṛhatkarman was his son.

column1: tasmājjayadratho hy āsījjayadrathādvṛhadrathaḥ //
column2: Bṛhadbhanu was born from him. Bṛhātmavat was from Bṛhadbhānu.

column1: vṛhadrathādviśvajicca karṇo viśvajito 'bhavat /
column2: Viśvajit was born from Bṛhadratha. Karṇa was from Viśvajit.

column1: karṇasya vṛṣasenastu pṛthusenastadātmajaḥ /
column2: Vṛṣasena was the son of Karṇa. Pṛthusena was his son.

column1: eto 'ṅgavaṃśajā bhūpāḥ pūrorvaṃśaṃ vibodha me //
column2: These are the kings born in the race of Aṅga. Describe me the race of Puru.

column1: purorjanamejayo 'bhūtprācīnnantastu tatsutaḥ / prācīnnantānmanastyustu tasmādvītamayo nṛpaḥ //
column2: Janamejaya was born from Puru. Prācīnavān was his son. Manasyu was from Prācīnavān. Vītamaya was the next king from him.

column1: śundhurvītamayāccābhūcchundhorbahuvidhaḥ sutaḥ /
column2: Śundhu was from Vītamaya. Bahuvidha was the son of Śundhu.

column1: bahuvidhācca saṃyātirahovādī ca tatsutaḥ //
column2: Saṃyāti was from Bahuvidha.

column1: tasya putro 'tha bhadrāśoa bhadrāśvasya daśātmajāḥ /
column2: Rahovādī was his son. Bhadrāśva was his son.

column1: ghṛteyuś ca citeyuś ca sthaṇḍileyuś ca sattamaḥ / dharmeyuḥ sannateyuś ca kṛceyurmatinārakaḥ //
column2: Bhadrāśva had ten sonsṚkṣeyu, Kṛṣeyu, Sannateyu, Ghṛteyu, Citeyu, the noble Sthaṇḍileyu, Dharmeyu, Sannateyu ?, Kṛteyu and Matināra.

column1: taṃsuroghaḥ pratirathaḥ purasto matinārajāḥ /
column2: Taṃsurodha, Pratiratha and Purasta were the sons of Matināra.

column1: āsītpatirathātkaṇvaḥ kaṇvānmedhātithistvabhūt //
column2: Kaṇva was born from Pratiratha. Medhātithi was from Kaṇva.

column1: taṃsuroghācca catvāro duṣmanto 'tha pravīrakaḥ /
column2: Duṣyanta, Pravīra, Sumanta and Vīra were the four sons from Taṃsurodha.

column1: sumantaścānayo vīro duṣmantādbharato 'bhavat //
column2: Bharata was born from Duṣyanta through Śakuntalā.

column1: śakuntalāyāntu balī yasya nāmnā tu bhāratāḥ /
column2: The descendants known as Bhāratas were mighty.

column1: suteṣu mātṛkopena naṣṭeṣu bharatasya ca // tato marudbhirānīya putraḥ sa tu vṛhaspateḥ /
column2: When the sons of Bharata were lost on account of the wrath of the mother, then the Maruts gods brought Bharadvāja, son of Bṛhaspati and made him to meet Bharata.

column1: saṃkrāmito bharadvājaḥ kratubhirvitatho 'bhavat //
column2: Vitatha was born as a consequence of rituals done by Bharadvāja.

column1: sa cāpi vitathaḥ putrān janayāmāsa pañca vai / suhotrañca suhotāraṅgayaṅgarbhantathaiva ca //
column2: That Vitatha also generated five sonsSuhotra, Suhotṛ, Gaya, Garbha and the great Suketu.

column1: kapilaś ca mahātmānaṃ suketuñca sutadvayam /
column2: Kapila had two sonsKauśika and Gṛtsapati.

column1: kauśikañca gṛtsapatiṃ tathā gṛtsapateḥ sutāḥ // brahmāṇāḥ kṣatriyā vaiśyāḥ kāśe dīrghatamāḥ sutāḥ /
column2: The brahmins, warriors, tradesmen were the sons of Gṛtsapati. The Dīrghatamas were the sons of Kāśi Kauśika?.

column1: tato dhanvantariścāsīttatsuto 'bhūcca ketumān //
column2: Dhanvantari was born then. Ketumān was his son.

column1: ketumato hemaratho divodāsa itiśrutaḥ /
column2: Hemaratha was born from Ketumān. He was wellknown as Divodāsa.

column1: pratardano divodāsādbhargavatsau pratardanāt //
column2: Pratardana was from Divodāsa. Bharga and Vatsa were born from Pratardana.

column1: vatsādanarka āsīcca anarkāt kṣemako 'bhavat /
column2: Anarka was from Vatsa. Kṣemaka was born from Anarka.

column1: kṣemakadvarṣaketuś ca varṣaketorvibhuḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: Varṣaketu was from Kṣemaka. Vibhu is remembered to be from Varṣaketu.

column1: vibhorānartaḥ putro 'bhūdvibhoś ca sukumārakaḥ /
column2: Ānarta was the son of Vibhu. Sukumāraka was the son of Vibhu.

column1: sukumārātsatyaketurvatsabhūmistu vatsakāt //
column2: Satyaketu was born from Sukumāra. Vatsabhūmi was born from Vatsaka.

column1: suhotrasya vṛhatputro vṛhatastanayāstrayaḥ / ajamīḍho dvimīḍhaś ca purumīḍhaś ca vīryavān //
column2: Bṛhat was the son of Suhotra. Ajamīḍha, Dvimīḍha and the brave Purumīḍha were the three sons of Bṛhat.

column1: ajamīḍhasya keśinyāṃ jajñe jahnuḥ pratāpavān /
column2: The valorous Jahnu was born to Ajamīḍha and Keśinī.

column1: jahnorabhūdajakāśvo balākāśvastadātmajaḥ // valākāśvasya kuśikaḥ kuśikāt gādhirindrakaḥ /
column2: Ajakāśva was born from Jahnu. Balākāśva was his son. Kuśika was the son of Balākāśva, and Gādhi, the Indra, was born from Kuśika.

column1: gādheḥ satyavatī kanyā viśvāmitraḥ sūtottamaḥ //
column2: Satyavatī was the daughter of Gādhi and Viśvāmitra his excellent son.

column1: devarātaḥ katimukhā viśvāmitrasya te sutāḥ /
column2: Devarata and Katimukha were the sons of Viśvāmitra.

column1: śunaḥśepho 'ṣṭakaścānyo hy ajamīḍhāt suto 'bhavat //
column2: Śunaḥśepa known also as Aṣṭaka was the other son.

column1: nīlinyāṃ śāntiraparaḥ purujātiḥ suśāntitaḥ /
column2: Śānti was born as son to Ajamīḍha through Nīlinī. Purujāti was born from Su Śānti.

column1: purujātestu vāhyāśvo vāhyāścvāt pañca pārthivāḥ //
column2: Bāhyāśva was born from Purujāti.

column1: mukulaḥ sṛñjayaś caiva rājā vṛhadiṣus tathā / yavīnaraś ca kṛmilaḥ pāñcālā iti viśrutāḥ //
column2: The five kings Mukula, Sṛñjaya, Bṛhadiṣu, Yavīnara and Kṛmila were from Bāhyāśva. They were known as the Pāñcālas.

column1: mukulasya tu maukulyāḥ kṣetropetā dvijātayaḥ / cañcāśvo mukulājjajñe cañcāśvānmithunaṃ hy abhut //
column2: The descendants of Mukula, known as the Maukulyas were brahmins endowed with property. Cañcāśva was born from Mukula.

column1: divodāso hy ahalyā ca ahalyāyāṃ śaradvatāt /
column2: Cañcāśva had the twinsDivodāsa and Ahalyā.

column1: śatānandaḥ śatānandāt satyadhṛnmithunantataḥ //
column2: Śatānanda was born from Śaradvata through Ahalyā. Satyadhṛk was born from Śatānanda.

column1: kṛpaḥ kṛpī kivodāsānmaitreyaḥ somapastataḥ /
column2: Then a pair, Kṛpa and Kṛpī, were born from Satyadhṛk. Maitreya was born from Divodāsa and then Somapa from Maitreya.

column1: sṛñjayāt pañcadhanuṣaḥ somadattaś ca tatsutaḥ //
column2: Pañcadhanus was born from Sṛñjaya. Somadatta was his son.

column1: sahadevaḥ somadattāt sahadevāttu somakaḥ /
column2: Sahadeva was born from Somadatta. Somaka was born from Sahadeva.

column1: āsīcca somakājjanturjantoś ca pṛṣataḥ sutaḥ //
column2: Jantu was from Somaka. Pṛṣata was the son of Jantu.

column1: pṛṣatāddrupadastasmāddhṛṣṭadyumno 'tha tatsutaḥ / dhṛṣṭhaketuś ca dhūminyāmṛkṣo 'bhūdajamīḍhataḥ //
column2: Drupada was from Pṛṣata. Dhṛṣṭadyumna was from him. Dhṛṣṭaketu was his son. Ṛkṣa was born to Ajamīḍha through Dhūminī.

column1: ṛkṣātsamvaraṇo jajñe kuruḥ samvaraṇāttataḥ /
column2: Saṃvaraṇa was born from Ṛkṣa. Kuru was then born from Saṃvaraṇa.

column1: yaḥ prayāgādapākramya kurukṣetrañcakāra ha //
column2: He migrated from the city of Prayāga and founded the kingdom of Kurukṣetra.

column1: kuroḥ sudhanvā sudhanuḥ parikṣiccārimejayaḥ / sudhanvanaḥ suhotro 'bhūt suhotrāccyavano hy abhūt //
column2: Sudhanvā, Sudhanu, Parikṣit and Arimejaya were the sons of Kuru. Suhotra was from Sudhanvā. Cyavana was born from Suhotra.

column1: vaśiṣṭhaparicārābhyāṃ saptāsan girikāsutāḥ / vṛhadrathaḥ kuśo vīro yaduḥ pratyagraho balaḥ //
column2: Seven other sons such as Bṛhadratha, Kuśa, Vīra, Yadu, Pratyagraha, Bala and Matsyakālī, were born through his queen Girikā by propitiating the sage Vasiṣṭha.

column1: matsyakālī kuśāgro 'to hy āsīdrājño vṛhadrathāt / kuśāgrādvṛṣabho jajñe tasya satyahitaḥ sutaḥ //
column2: Kuśāgra was from King Bṛhadratha. Vṛṣabha was born from Kuśāgra and Satyahita was his son.

column1: sudhanvā tatsutaścorja ūrjādāsīcca sambhavaḥ /
column2: His son was Sudhanvā, Ūrja was his son.

column1: sambhavācca jarāsandhaḥ sahadevaś ca tatsutaḥ //
column2: Sambhava was born from Ūrja. Jarāsandha was from Sambhava. Sahadeva was his son.

column1: sahadevādudāpiś ca udāpeḥ śrutakarmakaḥ /
column2: Udāpi was born from Sahadeva. Śrūtakarmaka was born from Udāpi.

column1: parikṣitasya dāyādo dhārmiko janamejayaḥ // janamejayāttrasadasyurjahnostu surathaḥ sutaḥ /
column2: The righteous Janamejaya was the descendant of Parikṣit. Trasadasyu was born from Janamejaya.

column1: śrutasenograsenau ca bhīmasenaś ca nāmataḥ //
column2: Suratha, Śrutasena, Ugrasena and Bhīmasena are the names of the sons of Jahnu.

column1: janamejayasya putrau tu suratho mahimāṃs tathā /
column2: Janamejaya had two sons Suratha and Mahimān.

column1: surathādvidūratho 'bhūdṛkṣa āsīdvidūrathāt //
column2: Vidūratha was born from Suratha. Ṛkṣa was born from Vidūratha.

column1: ṛkṣasya tu dvitīyasya bhīmaseno 'bhavatsutaḥ /

column1: atīsāre purāṇānāṃ śālīnāṃ bhakṣaṇaṃ hitaṃ //

column1: godhūmaśālayo mudgā brahmarkṣakhadiro 'bhayā / pañcakolañjāṅgalāś ca nimbadhātryaḥ paṭolakāḥ // mātulaṅgarasājātiśuṣkamūlakasaindhavāḥ /

column1: nimbaparpaṭakaiḥ śākair jāṅgalānāṃ tathā rasaḥ // viḍaṅgaṃ maricaṃ mustaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ lodhraṃ suvarcikā / manaḥśilā ca vāleyaḥ kuṣṭhahā mūtrapeṣitaḥ //

column1: sūtikā ca tathā rakṣā prāṇināntu sadā hitā //

column1: arkakṣīreṇa saṃpiṣṭaṃ lopā vījaṃ palāśajaṃ // vṛścikārtasya kṛṣṇā vā śivā ca phalasaṃyutā /

column1: candanaṃ padmakaṅkuṣṭhaṃ latāmbūśīrapāṭalāḥ // nirguṇḍī śārivā selurlūtāviṣaharo gadaḥ / śirovirecanaṃ śastaṃ guḍanāgarakaṃ dvija //
column2: A mixture of sandal, padmaka, kuṣṭha, latāmbu ?, ūśīra, pāṭalā, nirguṇḍi , śārivā and selu ? would destroy the poison due to spiders. O Brahmin! Molasses and dried ginger are commended as eliminator of toxic matter from head.

column1: snehapāne tathā vastau tailaṃ dhṛtamanuttamam / svedanīyaḥ paro vahniḥ śītāmbhaḥstambhanaṃ param //

column1: trivṛddhi recane śreṣṭhā vamane madanaṃ tathā /
column2: The trivṛt the three myrobalans is the best purgative. So also madana is the best emetic.

column1: śārīramānamāgantusahajā vyādhayo matāḥ / śārīrā jvarakuṣṭhādyā krodhādyā mānasā matāḥ //
column2: Diseases are considered to be of four kinds such as, relating to the body, relating to the mind, arising accidentally and arising naturally. Fever, leprosy and the like are considered to be relating to the body. Anger etc.

column1: āgantavo vighātotthā sahajāḥ kṣujjarādayaḥ /
column2: Those that are due to a blow etc. are known as accidental. Hunger, old age and the like are known as natural.

column1: śārīrāgantunāśāya sūryavāre ghṛtaṃ guḍam // lavaṇaṃ sahiraṇyañca viprāyāpūpamarpayet /
column2: One should give ghee, molasses and salt along with gold to a brahmin on a Sunday in order to get rid of the diseases relating to the body and those that are accidental.

column1: candre cābhyaṅgado vipre sarvarogaiḥ pramucyate // tailaṃ śanaiś care dadyādāśvine gorasānnadaḥ / ghṛtena payasā liṅgaṃ saṃsnāpya syādrugujjhitaḥ //
column2: One who makes a gift of oil for bathing to a brahmin on a Monday would become free from all diseases . Oil should be given on Saturday.

column1: yasmin bhe vyādhimāpnoti tasmin snānaṃ baliḥ śubhe // mānasānāṃ rujādīnāṃ viṣṇoḥ stotraṃ haraṃ bhavet /
column2: One who makes a gift of food with cow’s milk in the month of Āśvina OctoberNovember, would also get rid of the diseases. One who bathes the liṅga representative symbol of Lord Śiva with ghee and milk would become free from diseases.

column1: vātapittakaphā doṣā dhātavaś ca tathā śṛṇu //
column2: Listen to me. shall describe the defects of the humours wind, bile and phlegm as well as the ingredients of the body such as blood.

column1: bhuktaṃ pakvāśayādannaṃ dvidhā yāti ca suśruta /
column2: O Suśruta! The food that is eaten gets two forms after leaving the stomach.

column1: aṃśenaikena kiṭṭadvaṃ rasatāñcāpareṇa ca //
column2: A part becomes secreted and the other, the constituent fluid of the body.

column1: nāsāmalaṅkarṇamalaṃ tathā dehamalañca yat // rasabhāgādrasastatra samācchoṇitatāṃ vrajet /
column2: The part that is secreted is the impurity such as feces, urine, sweat, rheum of the eyes, the mucus of the nose, the earwax and the bodily impurity.

column1: māṃsaṃ raktattito medo medaso 'sthnaś ca sambhavaḥ // asthno majjā tataḥ śukraṃ śukādrāgastathaujasaḥ /
column2: From the constituent fluid, serum is formed which again is turned into blood. Flesh is formed from blood and then fat and bones from fat. Sap is formed from bones and then semen.

column1: deśamārtiṃ balaṃ śaktiṃ kālaṃ prakṛtimeva ca // jñātvā cikitsataṃ kuryādbheṣajasya tathā balam /
column2: One should render treatment to a patient after examining the nature of the country, the disease, the strength, the stamina, the season and the nature of the patient. Then the strength of the remedy should also be examined.

column1: tithiṃ riktāntyajed bhaumaṃ mandabhandāruṇograkam // harigodvijacandrārkasurādīn pratipūjya ca /
column2: One should reject the rikta days, Tuesdays and Saturdays and baneful combination and begin treatment after worshipping Lord Hari Viṣṇu, a cow, a brahmin, the Moon and the Sun and the celestials.

column1: śṛṇu mantramimaṃ vidvan bheṣajārambhamācaret //
column2: O Learned one! Listen to this sacred formula that has to be recited before commencing the treatment.

column1: brahmadakṣāśvirudrendrabhūcandrārkānilānalāḥ / ṛṣayaś cauṣadhigrāmā bhūtasaṅghāś ca pāntu te //
column2: “May the gods Brahmā, Dakṣa, Aśvins, Rudra, Indra, the Earth, the Moon, the Sun, the Wind, the Fire, the sages, the collection of herbs and the hosts of spirits protect you.

column1: rasāyanamivarṣīṇāṃ devānāmamṛtaṃ yathā / sudhevottamanāgānāṃ bhaiṣajyamidamastu te //
column2: Let this medicine be like the elixir of life of the sages, the nectar of the gods and the ambrosia of the outstanding serpents.”

column1: vātaśleṣmātako deśo bahuvṛkṣo bahūdakaḥ /
column2: A country abounding in trees and having plenty of water is known as anūpa marshy and would produce excess of wind and phlegm.

column1: anūpaḍtibikhyāto jāṅgalastadvivarjitaḥ //
column2: A country that is devoid of the above features is known as jaṅgala rural or picturesque.

column1: kiñcidvṛkṣodako deśas tathā sādhāraṇaḥ smṛtaḥ /
column2: A country that has trees and water in moderate proportion is known as sādhāraṇa ordinary.

column1: jāṅgalaḥ pittabahulo madhyaḥ sādhāraṇaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: The country known as jāṅgala produces excessive bile. The sādhāraṇa type is known as moderate.

column1: rūkṣmaḥ śītaś calo vāyuḥ pittamuṣṇaṃ kaṭutrayam / sthirāmlasnigdhamadhuraṃ balāśañca pracakṣate //
column2: It is said that wind is dry, cool and unsteady, bile is hot like the three kinds of astringents and phlegm is steady, acid, unctuous and sweet.

column1: vṛddhiḥ samānair eteṣāṃ viparītair viparyayaḥ /
column2: They get increased by things having the same qualities and get abated by things having the opposite qualities.

column1: rasāḥ svādvamlalavaṇāḥ śleṣmalā vāyunāśanāḥ // kaṭutiktakaṣāyāś ca vātalāḥ śleṣmanāśanāḥ /
column2: Things that have sweet, sour and saline taste generate phlegm and destroy wind. Those that are pungent, bitter and astringent produce wind and destroy phlegm.

column1: kaṭvamlalavaṇā jñeyās tathā pittavivardhanāḥ // tiktasvādukaṣāyāś ca tathā pittavināśanāḥ /
column2: Similarly those that are pungent, sour and saline are known to increase bile. Those that are bitter, sweet and astringent destroy bile.

column1: rasasyaitadguṇaṃ nāsti vipākasyaitadiṣyate //
column2: This is not the effect of the taste but only of its chemical action.

column1: vīryoṣṇāḥ kaphavātaghnāḥ śītāḥ pittavināśanāḥ /
column2: O Suśruta! Those that are stimulant and hot destroy phlegm and wind. Those that are cold destroy bile.

column1: prabhāvatas tathā karma te kurvanti ca suśruta //
column2: They the herbs exert their influence according to their qualities.

column1: śiśire ca vasante ca nidāghe ca tathā kramāt / cayaprakopapraśamāḥ kaphasya tu prakīrtitāḥ // nidāghavarṣārātrau ca tathā śaradi suśruta /
column2: It is said that phlegm gets collected, deranged and subsided in winter, spring and summer respectively. O Suśruta! wind is said to get collected, deranged and subsided in the nights of summer, rainy season and autumn respectively.

column1: cayaprakopapraśamāḥ pavanasya prakīrtitāḥ // meghakāle ca śaradi hemante ca yathākramāt /
column2: Bile is said to get collected, deranged and subsided in the rainy season, autumn and forewinter respectively.

column1: varṣādyo visargastu hemantādyās tathā trayaḥ / śiśirādyās tathādānaṃ grīṣmāntā ṛtavastrayaḥ //
column2: The three seasons beginning with the rainy are said to be visargas. The three seasons beginning with winter and ending with summer are ādāna.

column1: saumyo visargastvādānamāgneyaṃ parikīrtitam /
column2: The visarga relates to the moon and the ādāna is stated to be relating to the fire.

column1: varṣādīṃstrīnṛtūn somaś caran paryāyaśo rasān // janayatyamlalavaṇamadhurāṃstrīn yathākramam /
column2: The moon going round the three seasons such as the rainy etc. by turns produces the three tastessour, saline and sweet in order.

column1: śiśirādīnṛtūnarkaś caran paryayaśo rasān // vivardhayettathā tiktakaṣāyakaṭukān kramāt /
column2: The sun going round the three seasons such as winter and the like increases the three tastesbitter, astringent and pungent flavours in order.

column1: yathā rajanyo vardhante valamekaṃ hi vardhate // kramaśo 'tha manuṣyāṇāṃ hīyamānāsu hīyate /
column2: As the duration of night increases, the strength of men also increases. When they decrease, the strength also decreases.

column1: ādimadhyāvasāneṣu kaphapittasamīraṇāḥ / prakopaṃ yānti kopādau kāle teṣāñcayaḥ smṛtaḥ // prakopottarake kāle śamasteṣāṃ prakīrtitaḥ /
column2: During the beginning, middle and end of nights, eating, days and one’s age, phlegm, bile and wind get deranged. They are said to get collected before the beginning of their derangement and get appeased after their derangement.

column1: adibhojanato vipra tathā cābhojanena ca // rogā hi sarve jāyante vegodīraṇadhāraṇaiḥ /
column2: O Brahmin! All the diseases are caused by excessive eating or not eating or forcing or retaining the flow of urine etc..

column1: annena kukṣerdvāvaṃśāvekaṃ pānena pūrayet // āśrayaṃ pavanādīnāṃ tathaikamavaśeṣayet /
column2: Two parts of the belly should be filled with food, one part with drink and one part should be left free for the wind etc. to work.

column1: vyādher nidānasya tathā viparītamathauṣadham //
column2: A remedy is only that which is the opposite of the cause of a disease.

column1: kartavyametadevātra mayā sāraṃ prakīrtitam /
column2: This is what should be done. have described to you the essence.

column1: nābherūrdhvamadhaś caiva gudaśroṇyostathaiva ca // balāśapittavātānāṃ dehe sthānaṃ prakīrtitaṃ / tathāpi sarvagāś caite dehe vāyurviśeṣataḥ //
column2: Though it is said that phlegm, bile and wind have their places above and below the umbilical region and the regions of the anus and the buttocks respectively in the body, they are capable of coursing through the entire body. Especially wind can do so.

column1: dehasya madhye hṛdayaṃ sthānaṃ tanmanasaḥ smṛtam /
column2: Heart is at the centre of body and it is known to be the place of mind.

column1: kṛśo 'lpakeśaś capalo bahuvāgviṣamānalaḥ // vyomagaś ca tathā svapne vātaprakṛtirucyate / akālapalitaḥ krodhī prasvedī madhurapriyaḥ //
column2: It is said that a man of windy temperament would be emaciated, have scanty hair, be fickleminded, garrulous, have uneven wind, and feel flying in the air in his dream. A man of bilious temperament is said to be having ultimely grey hair. He would be irritable and would perspire copiously.

column1: dṛḍhāṅgaḥ sthiracittaś ca suprabhaḥ snigdhasūrdhajaḥ // śuddhāmbudarśī svapne ca kaphaprakṛtiko naraḥ /
column2: He would be fond of sweets and would see glowing things in dream. A phlegmatic man would have strong body and firm mind. He would be brilliant. He will have glossy hair on the head.

column1: tāmasā rājasāś caiva sātvikāś ca tathā smṛtāḥ // manuṣyā munirśādūla vātapittakaphātmakāḥ /
column2: O The foremost among the sages! Men of windy, bilious and phlegmatic temperaments are known to be tāmasa inactive, rājasa passionate and sāttvika virtuous respectively.

column1: raktapittaṃ vyavāyācca gurukarmapravartanaiḥ //
column2: Raktapitta haemoptysis is caused by excessive coition and engaging in doing hard physical work.

column1: kadannabhojanādvāyurdehe śokācca kupyati /
column2: The wind in the body gets deranged on account of eating bad food or on account of grief.

column1: vidāhināṃ tatholkānāmuṣṇānnādhvanisevināṃ // pittaṃ prakopamāyāti bhayena ca tathā dvija / atyambupānagurvannabhojināṃ bhuktaśāyinām //
column2: O Brahmin! Bile gets deranged on account of internal heat, eating hot food, making a journey as well as due to fear. Phlegm gets deranged due to excessive drinking of water, eating heavy food and lying down after eating.

column1: ślekeṣmāprakopamāyāti tathā ye cālasā janāḥ /
column2: A lazy man also gets his phlegm deranged.

column1: vātādyutthāni rogāṇi jñātvā śāmyāni lakṣaṇaiḥ //
column2: After knowing the diseases caused by humours wind and the like from their characteristics, one should remedy them as below.

column1: asthibhaṅgaḥ kaṣāyatvamāsye śuṣkāsyatā tathā / jṛmbhaṇaṃ lomaharṣaś ca vātikavyādhilakṣaṇam //
column2: The characteristics of the disease due to the deranged wind arepain in the bones, bitter taste in the mouth, parched state of feeling in the mouth, yawning and bristling of the pair.

column1: nakhanetraśirāṇāntu pītatvaṃ kaṭutā mukhe / tṛṣṇā dāhoṣṇatā caiva pittavyādhinidarśanam //
column2: A disease due to deranged bile is marked by yellowness in the nails, eyes and veins, bitter taste in the mouth, thirst and burning heat in the body.

column1: ālasyañca prasekaś ca gurutā madhurāsyatā / uṣṇābhilāṣitā ceti ślaiṣmikavyādhilakṣaṇam // snigdhoṣṇamannamabhyaṅgastailapānādi vātanut /
column2: The characteristics of disease due to phlegm are laṅguor, flow of water from the mouth, heaviness of the body, sweet taste in the mouth and longing for heat. Eating of oil and hot food, anointing the body with oil and bathing and drinking of oil and the like would appease deranged wind.

column1: ājyaṃ kṣīraṃ sitādyañca candraraśmyādi pittanut // sakṣaudraṃ triphalātailaṃ vyāyāmādi kaphāpaham /
column2: Clarified butter, milk, sugar and the rays of the moon and the like would counter deranged bile. The oil of the three myrobalans together with honey and doing exercises etc.

column1: sarvarogapraśāntyai syadviṣṇordhyānañca pūjanam //
column2: Contemplation on Lord Viṣṇu and His worship would appease all the diseases.

column1: rasādilakṣaṇaṃ vakṣye bheṣajānāṃ guṇaṃ śṛṇu /
column2: Listen to me! shall describe the tastes and the other characteristics and merits of the herbs.

column1: rasavīryavipākajño nṛpādīnrakṣayennaraḥ //
column2: A physician who knows the properties of the herbs, such as taste, strength and flavour, will be able to save kings and other people.

column1: rasāḥ svādvamlalavaṇāḥ somajāḥ parikīrtitāḥ / kaṭutiktakaṣāyāni tathāgneyā mahābhuja //
column2: O One possessing powerful arms! The tastes such as sweet, sour and saline are stated to come from the moon. The tastesbitter, astringent and pungentare known to be from fire.

column1: tridhā vipāko dravyasya kaṭvamlalavaṇātmakaḥ /
column2: The herbs have three flavoursbitter, sour and saline.

column1: dvidhā vīyya samuddiṣṭamuṣṇaṃ śītaṃ tathaiva ca //
column2: The strength of the herbs is said to be of two kindshot and cold.

column1: anirdeśyaprabhāvaś ca oṣadhīnāṃ dvijottama /
column2: O Foremost among the brahmins! The effect of the herbs is indescribable.

column1: madhuraś ca kaṣāyaś ca tiktaś caiva tathā rasaḥ //
column2: Those that are sweet, astringent and bitter are said to be having cold potency.

column1: śītavīryāḥ samuddiṣṭāḥ śeṣāstūṣṇāḥ prakīrtitāḥ /
column2: The rest are stated to be hot.

column1: guḍucī tatra tiktapi bhavatyuṣṇātivīryataḥ // uṣṇā kaṣāyāpi tathā pathyā bhavati mānada /
column2: Although guḍuci has the bitter taste, it is hot on account of its high potency. O One who shows respect! Pathyā, though an astringent, is considered hot.

column1: madhuropi tathā māṃsa uṣṇa eva prakīrtitaḥ //
column2: Although meat is sweet, it is said to be hot.

column1: lavaṇo madhraś caiva vipākamadhurau smṛtau /
column2: The saline and sweet tastes would become sweet flavour.

column1: amloṣṇaś ca tathā proktaḥ śeṣāḥ kaṭuvipākinaḥ //
column2: The sour things that are hot are also said to become so. The rest would have pungent flavour.

column1: vīryapāke viparyaste prabhāvāttatra niś cayaḥ /
column2: One has to determine the drugs that have got modified in their potency and flavour from their efficacy.

column1: madhuro 'pi kaṭuḥ pāke yacca kṣaudraṃ prakīrtitaṃ // kvāthayet ṣoḍaśaguṇaṃ viveddravyāccaturguṇam /
column2: Honey, although sweet, is said to be pungent in flavour. The herb should be boiled with water, sixteen times its proportion, until it comes down to four times the proportion.

column1: kalpanaiṣā kaṣāyasya yatra nokto vidhirbhavet //
column2: This is the general rule for preparing a decoction wherever something else has not been stated.

column1: kaṣāyantu bhavettoyaṃ snehapāke caturguṇaṃ / dravyatulyaṃ samuddhṛtya dravyaṃ snehaṃ kṣipedbudhaḥ //
column2: The decoction thus prepared should be composed of water alone. In a decoction prepared with oil, it should be four times that of the drug. A wise man should take equal quantity of water to that of the herb.

column1: tāvatpramāṇaṃ dravyasya snehapādaṃ tataḥ kṣipet / toyavarjantu yaddravyaṃ snehadravyaṃ tathā bhavet //
column2: Then the herb and oil should be added. Oil should be onefourth the measure of the substance. The herb that is free from water would be known as extraction in oil.

column1: saṃvartitauṣadhaḥ pākaḥ snehānāṃ parikīrtitaḥ /
column2: The process of preparing decoctions of the herbs in oil has been explained.

column1: tattulyatā tu lehyasya tathā bhavati suśruta //
column2: O Suśruta! The method of preparation of the lambative is also similar.

column1: svacchamalpauṣadhaṃ kvāthaṃ kaṣāyañcoktavadbhavet / akṣaṃ cūrṇasya nirdiṣṭaṃ kaṣāyasya catuṣpalaṃ //
column2: The decoction that is clear and having little medicinal ingredient would be as above described. The dosage for pulverised drugs is stated to be an akṣa a particular measure of weight equal to māṣas and four palas a particular weight for the decoction.

column1: madhyamaiṣā smṛtā mātrā nāsti mātrāvikalpanā /
column2: This measure is said to be middling. There is no hard and fast rule about the dosage.

column1: vayaḥ kālaṃ balaṃ vahniṃ deśaṃ dravyaṃ rujaṃ tathā //
column2: O Fortunate one! The measure of the dosage has to be decided according to the age, time, strength, digestive power, place, herb and disease.

column1: saumyāstatra rasāḥ prāyo vijñeyā dhātuvardhanāḥ //
column2: Those tastes are known to be saumyāḥ which increase the quality of the ingredients.

column1: madhurāstu viśeṣeṇa vijñeyā dhātuvardhanāḥ /
column2: Those that are madhurāḥ are specially known to increase the quality.

column1: doṣāṇāñcaiva dhātūnāṃ dravyaṃ samaguṇantu yat //
column2: That substance which has the qualities in equal proportion to the defects would be for betterment.

column1: tadeva vṛddhaye jñeyaṃ viparītaṃ kṣamāvaham /
column2: The opposite would subdue the effect.

column1: upastambhatrayaṃ proktaṃ dehe 'sminmanujottama // āhāro maithunaṃ nidrā teṣu yatnaḥ sadā bhavet /
column2: O Foremost among men! There are said to be three functions in this body, such as, eating, sleeping and coition. One has to pay attention to these always.

column1: asevanāt sevanācca atyantaṃ nāśamāpnuyāt //
column2: One would get destroyed if there is no indulgence or is overindulgence in any one of these.

column1: kṣayasya bṛṃhaṇaṃ kāryaṃ sthuladehasya karṣaṇam /
column2: An exhausted body has to be strengthened. Obesity of a person should be reduced.

column1: rakṣaṇaṃ madhyakāyasya dehabhedāstrayo matāḥ //
column2: The middle type has to be protected. These are considered to be the three different types of bodies.

column1: upakramadvayaṃ proktaṃ tarpaṇaṃ vāpyatarpaṇaṃ /
column2: Gratification and nongratification are said to be the two courses of action.

column1: oṣadhīnāṃ pañcavidhā tathā bhavati kalpanā / rasaḥ kalkaḥ śṛtaḥ śītaḥ phāṇḍaś ca manujottama //
column2: One should moderately eat food that is good for health after the food already taken had been digested. O Foremost among men! The remedies are classified into five groupsjuice, levigated powder, the distilled, the cold and decoction.

column1: rasaś ca pīḍako jñeyaḥ kalka āloḍitād bhavet / kvathitaś ca śṛto jñeyaḥ śītaḥ paryuṣito niśāṃ //
column2: Juice is known to be that got by pressing. Levigated powder is got by pulverising the drug after heating. The distilled is that got after boiling. The cold one is that allowed to cool the previous night.

column1: sadyobhiśṛtapūtaṃ yat tat phāṇṭamabhidhīyate /
column2: Decoction is that distilled immediately after boiling.

column1: karaṇānāṃ śatañcaiva ṣaṣṭiś caivādhikā smṛtā //
column2: There are one hundred and sixty ways of doing so.

column1: yo vetti sa hy ajeyaḥ sthātsambandhe vāhuśauṇḍikaḥ /
column2: One who knows the ways would become inconquerable. That person is skilled in the preparation of mixtures.

column1: āhāraśuddhiragnyarthamagnimūlaṃ balaṃ nṛṇāṃ //
column2: The purity of food is for the sake of digestion. A good digestion is the root cause of the strength of men.

column1: sasindhutriphalāñcādyātsurājñi abhivarṇadāṃ / jāṅgalañca rasaṃ sindhuyuktaṃ dadhi payaḥ kaṇāṃ //
column2: One should eat the three myrobalans together with the rocksalt, that would give good complexion to a king. One would get similar benefit by using the juice of venison together with rocksalt or curd or small quantities of milk.

column1: rasādhikaṃ samaṃ kuryānnaro vātādhiko 'pi vā / nidāghe mardanaṃ proktaṃ śiśire ca samaṃ bahu //
column2: One whose constitution is windy should eat a food that has either more juice or the same proportion of juice. It is said that massaging the body should be done in summer. In winter it should be in equilibrium.

column1: vasante madhyamaṃ jñeyannidāghe mardanolvaṇaṃ / tvacantu prathamaṃ mardyamaṅgañca tadanantaraṃ //
column2: It is known to be of middling type in the spring. The intense massaging in the summer is first done on the skin and then on the muscles, veins, blood and the body.

column1: snāyurudhiradeheṣu asthi bhātīva māṃsalaṃ /
column2: The bones would get strengthened and become fleshy.

column1: skandhau bāhū tathaiveha tathā jaṅghe sajānunī // arivanmardayet prajño jatru vakṣaś ca pūrvavat /
column2: A wise man should massage well the shoulders, arms, shanks, knees, collarbones and the chest as before as if one is attacking an enemy.

column1: aṅgasandhiṣu sarveṣu niṣpīḍya bahulaṃ tathā //
column2: After having massaged the joints well, one should stretch them slowly without making a violent jerk.

column1: prasārayedaṅgasandhīnna ca kṣepeṇa cākramāt / nījīrṇe tu śramaṃ kuryānna bhuktvā pītavānnaraḥ //
column2: One should not do any physical exercise while the food still remains undigested nor after taking food, nor after drinking water. One should never do any exercise in the half of the prahara after a quarter part of the day.

column1: vyāyāmaṃ naiva kartavyaṃ snāyācchītāmbunā sakṛt // vāryuṣṇañca śramaṃ jahyāddhṛdā śvāsanna dhārayet /
column2: One should bathe in cold water only once. Bathing intrepid water would remove fatigue. One should not forcibly retain the breath in the heart. Physical exercises would remove the excessive phlegm.

column1: vyāyāmaś ca kaphaṃ hanyādvātaṃ hanyācca mardanaṃ // snānaṃ pittādhikaṃ hanyāttasyānte cātapāḥ priyāḥ /
column2: Massaging would remove the excessive wind. Bathing would remove the excessive bile. One should not expose his body to sunlight or enjoy the company of women after doing exercises.

column2: “Rāma one that makes us pleased, Paraśurāma the Rāma, with the battleaxe, Nṛsiṃha the manlion form of lord Viṣṇu, Viṣṇu, Trivikrama the lord that measured three spaces with three strides” are the names that are to be repeated by those who desire to conquer.

column1: vidyāmabhyasyatāṃ nityaṃ japtavyaḥ puruṣottamaḥ //
column2: One who desires to acquire knowledge should repeat daily the name “Puruṣottama” foremost among beings.

column1: dāmodaro bandhaharaḥ puṣkarākṣo 'kṣiroganut / hṛṣīkeśo bhayaharo japedauṣadhakarmaṇi //
column2: The repetition of the name Dāmodara one having a string around the belly, denotes lord Kṛṣṇa would remove bondage. The repetition of the name Puṣkarākṣa lotuseyed would cure eyedisease.

column1: acyutañcāmṛtaṃ mantraṃ saṅgrāme cāparājitaḥ /
column2: This has to be repeated while preparing medicines. The name ‘Acyuta’ the changeless one is an immortal one and confers victory in the battle.

column1: jalatāre nārasiṃhaṃ pūrvādau kṣemakāmavān // cakriṇaṅgadinañcaiva śārṅgiṇaṃ khaḍginaṃ smaret /
column2: One who desires to have welfare in the east and other directions should remember “Cakrin the bearer of the disc, Gadin the wielder of the mace, Śārṅgin the bearer of the bow, and Khaḍgin the bearer of a sword”.

column1: nārāyaṇaṃ sarvakāle nṛsiṃho 'khilabhītinut //
column2: One should repeat the name ‘Nārāyaṇa’ at all times.

column1: garuḍadhvajaś ca viṣahṛt vāsudevaṃ sadājapet /
column2: The repetition of the name “Garuḍavāhana” one having the eagle on the banner would remove poison. The name “Vāsudeva” son of Vasudeva has to be repeated always.

column1: dhānyādisthāpane svapne anantācyutamīrayet //
column2: One should repeat the names ‘Ananta’ endless and ‘Acyuta’ changeless while storing grains etc. and while going to sleep.

column1: nārāyaṇañca duḥsvapne dāhādau jalaśāyinaṃ /
column2: One should repeat ‘Nārāyaṇa’ when getting a bad dream and the term ‘Jalaśāyin’ one who reposes on the water when there is outbreak of fire etc.

column1: hayagrīvañca vidyārthī jagatsūtiṃ sutāptaye /
column2: One who desires to gain progeny should repeat the word Jagatsūti the progenitor of the universe.

column1: balabhadraṃ śaurakārye ekaṃ nāmārthasādhakam //
column2: The name Balabhadra the elder brother of lord Kṛṣṇa should be repeated during acts of valour. This single name accomplishes things.

column1: siddhayogān punarvakṣe mṛtasañjīvanīkarān/
column2: shall describe to you the infallible recipes that would revive the dead .

column1: ātreyabhāṣitān divyān sarvavyādhivimardanān //
column2: They were expounded to me by the sage Ātreya. They are divine and are capable of curing all diseases.

column1: vilvādipañcamūlasya kvāthaḥ syādvātike jvare / pāvanaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ guḍūcī viṣvajo 'tha vā //
column2: A decoction of the five roots, such as those of bilva, is an excellent remedy for fever due to deranged wind. Otherwise a decoction of the root of long pepper, guḍūcī and dry ginger is purifying.

column1: āmalakyabhayā kṛṣṇa vahniḥ sarvajvarāntakaḥ /
column2: A decoction of the herbs emblic myrobalan, mustard, black pepper and vahni would cure all fevers.

column1: vilvāgnimanthaśyonākakāśmaryaḥ pārlā sthirā // trikaṇṭakaṃ pṛśnaparṇī vṛhatī kaṇṭakārikāḥ /
column2: Bilva, agnimantha, śyonāka, Kāśmarī, pāṭalā, sthirā, trikaṇṭaka, pṛśniparṇī, bṛhatī and kaṇṭakārikā are remedies for fever, indigestion, pain on the sides of the body and cough.

column1: jvarāvipākapārśvārtikāśanut kuśamūlakam // guḍūcī parpaṭī mustaṃ kirātaṃ viśvabheṣajam /
column2: The root of kuśa grass should also be added to this. Guḍūcī, parpaṭī, musta, kirāta and dry ginger should be given in fever due to deranged wind and bile.

column1: vātapittajvare deyaṃ pañcabhadramidaṃ smṛtam //
column2: This is known as pañcabhadra the five beneficial things.

column1: trivṛdviśālakaṭukātriphalāragbadhaiḥ kṛtaḥ / sṃskāro bhedanakvāthaḥ peyaḥ sarvajvarāpahaḥ //
column2: A decoction made of trivṛt, viśāla, kaṭukā, the three myrobalans and āragvadha is a purifier, loosens the bowels and has to be drunk to get relief from all fevers.

column1: devadārubalāvāsātriphalāvyopapadmakaiḥ / saviḍaṅgaiḥ sitātulyaṃ taccurṇaṃ pañcakāśajit //
column2: Devadāru, balā, vāsā, the three myrobalans, vyoṣa, padmaka, and viḍaṅga with an equal proportion of candied sugar made into a powder would conquer five kinds of cough.

column1: daśamūlīśaṭīrāsnāpippalībilvapauṣkaraiḥ / śṛṅgītāmalakībhārgīguḍūcīnāgavallibhiḥ //
column2: Daśamūlī, śaṭī, rāsnā, long pepper, bilva, pauṣkara, śṛṅgīta, emblic myrobalan, bhārṅgī , guḍūcī, nāgavallī and barley compounded well and a decoction prepared from that should be drunk.

column1: kāśahṛdgrahaṇīpārśvahikvāśvāsapraśāntaye //
column2: It would remedy cough, diarrhoea, pain on the sides, hiccough and difficult breathing.

column1: madhukaṃ madhunā yuktaṃ vippalīṃ śarkarānvitāṃ / nāgaraṃ guḍasaṃyuktaṃ hikvāghnaṃ lāvaṇatrayam //
column2: The three kinds of salts as well as madhuka together with honey, long pepper together with sugar, and nāgara together with treacle would remove hiccough.

column1: kāravyajājīmaricaṃ drākṣā vṛkṣāmladāḍimam / sauvarcalaṃ guḍaṃ kṣaudraṃ sarvārocananāśanam //
column2: Kāravya, jājī, pepper, grapes, hogplum, pomegranate, natrum, treacle and honey would remedy all kinds of loss of appetite.

column1: śṛṅgaverarasañcaiva madhunā saha pāyayet /
column2: One should be made to drink the juice of śṛṅgavera ginger together with honey.

column1: aruciśvāsakāśaghnaṃ pratiśyāyakaphāntakam //
column2: It would remedy loss of appetite, difficult breathing and cough.

column1: vaṭaṃ śṛṅgī śilālodhradāḍimaṃ madhukaṃ madhu / pivet taṇḍulatoyena ccharditṛṣṇānivāraṇam //
column2: It would also remedy catarrh and excess of phlegm. The root of banyan, śṛṅgī, red earth, the bark of lodhra, pomegranate, madhuka and honey should be taken with the scum.

column1: guḍucī vāsakaṃ lodhraṃ pippalīkṣaudrasaṃyutam / kaphānvitañjayedraktaṃ tṛṣṇākāsajvarāpaham //
column2: Guḍūcī, vāsaka, lodhra and long pepper together with honey would remedy fever accompanied by thirst, cough and expectoration of phlegm together with blood.

column1: vāsakasya rasastadvat samadhustāmrajo rasaḥ / śirīṣapuṣpasurasabhāvitaṃ maricaṃ hitaṃ //
column2: Likewise the juice of vāsaka, the juice of tāmraja mixed with honey, and pepper infused in the juice of the śirīṣa flower would also be beneficial.

column1: sarvārtinunmasūro 'tha pittamuk taṇḍlīyakaṃ /
column2: The pulse called masūra removes all kinds of pain.

column1: nirguṇḍī śārivā śelu raṅgolaś ca viṣāpahaḥ //
column2: The washings of rice would remove excess of bile. Nirguṇḍī, śārivā, śelu and aṅkola would remove poisons.

column1: mahauṣadhaṃ mṛtāṃ kṣudrāṃ puṣkaraṃ granthikodbhavaṃ / pivet kaṇāyutaṃ kvāthaṃ mūrchāyāñca madeṣu ca //
column2: Dry ginger, amṛtā, kṣudrā, puṣkara and granthika made into powder should be taken with decoction of long pepper when one suffers unconsciousness and intoxication.

column1: hiṅgusaurcalavyoṣairdviplāṃśairghṛtāḍhakaṃ / caturguṇe gavāṃ mūtre siddhamunmādanāśanaṃ // śaṅkhapuṣpīvattākuṣṭhaiḥ siddhaṃ brāhmīrasair yutaṃ /
column2: Asafoetida, natrum and vyoṣa dry ginger and pepper each weighing two palas, an āḍhaka a measure of ghee soaked in four parts of cow’s urine would remedy insanity. Śaṅkha flower, vacā and kuṣṭha soaked in the juice of brāhmī destroys longstanding epilepsy and insanity.

column1: purāṇaṃ hantyapasmāraṃ sonmādaṃ medhyamuttamaṃ //
column2: It is also excellent for improving memory.

column1: pañcagavyaṃ ghṛtaṃ tadvat kuṣṭhanuccābhayāyutaṃ /
column2: The ghee made up of the five products got from a cow has also similar effects.

column1: paṭolatriphalānimbaguḍucīdhāvaṇīvṛṣaiḥ // sakarañjair ghṛtaṃ siddhaṃ kuṣṭhanudvajrakaṃ smṛtaṃ / nimbaṃ paṭolaṃ vyāghrī ca guḍūcī vāsakaṃ tathā //
column2: The same with mustard is a remedy for leprosy. Snakegourd, the three myrobalans, neem, guḍūcī, dhāvanī, vṛṣa and karañja boiled with ghee destroys leprosy and is known as vajraka potent remedy. Neem, snake gourd, vyāghrī, guḍūcī and vāsaka should be taken ten palas each and pounded well.

column1: kuryāddaśapalān bhāgān ekaikasya sakuṭṭitān / jaladroṇe vipaktavyaṃ yāvatpādāvaśeṣitaṃ //
column2: The mixture should then be heated in water vessel with water till it is reduced to one fourth of its original volume.

column1: ghṛtaprasthampacettena triphalāgarbhasaṃyutaṃ /
column2: It should then be soaked in one prastha a measure ghee and boiled with the three myrobalans.

column1: pañcatiktamiti khyātaṃ sarpiḥ kuṣṭhavināśanaṃ //
column2: This ghee is known as pañcatiktaka five bitter things. This ghee is capable of curing leprosy.

column1: aśītiṃ vātajānrogān catvāriṃśacca paittikān / viṃśatiṃ ślaiṣmikān kāsapīnasārśovraṇādikān // hantyanyān yogarajo 'yaṃ yathārkastimiraṃ khalu /
column2: This excellent recipe would cure eighty varieties of diseases due to deranged wind, forty diseases due to deranged bile, twenty diseases due to deranged phlegm as well as cough, catarrh, piles, wounds and other diseases just as the sun would remove darkness.

column1: triphalāyāḥ kaṣāyena bhṛṅnarājarasena ca // vraṇaprakṣālanaṅkuryādupadaṃśapraśāntaye / paṭīladalacūrṇena dāḍimatvagrajo 'tha vā // guṇḍayecca gajenāpi triphalācūrṇakena ca /
column2: One should sprinkle a wound with the decoction of the three myrobalans and the juice of bhṛṅgarāja for the cure of the venereal disease. The powder of the leaves of snakegourd and the five particles of the skin of pomegranate should be pounded with gaja a variety of pepper and the powder of the three kinds of myrobalans.

column1: triphalāyorajoyaṣṭhimārkavotpalamāricaiḥ // samaindhavaiḥ pacettailamabhyaṅgācchardikāpahaṃ /
column2: Oil boiled with the three myrobalans, grains of iron, yaṣṭi, mārkava, blue lotus, pepper and rocksalt would remedy vomitting when used for bathing.

column1: sakṣīrān mārkavarasān dviprasthamadhukotpalaiḥ // pacettu tailakuḍavaṃ tannasyaṃ palitāpahaṃ /
column2: Oil boiled with milk, juice of mārkava, two prasthas each of madhuka and utpala made into one guḍava a measure, if used as sternutatory would arrest greying of hair.

column1: nimbampaṭolaṃ triphalā guḍūcī svadiraṃ vṛṣaṃ // bhūnimbapāṭhātriphalāguḍūcīraktacandanaṃ / yogadvayaṃ jvaraṃ hanti kuṣṭhavisphoṭakādikaṃ //
column2: The two compoundsneem, snakegourd, the three kinds of myrobalans, guḍūcī, khadira and vṛṣa as well as bhūnimba, pāṭhā, the three kinds of myrabolans, guḍūcī and red sandal would remedy fever, leprosy, tumour and the like.

column1: paṭolāmṛtabhūnimbavāsāriṣṭakaparpaṭaiḥ / khadirāntayutaiḥ kvātho visphoṭajvaraśāntikṛt //
column2: A decoction prepared from snakegourd, amṛta, bhūnimba, vāsā, ariṣṭaka, parpaṭa and bark of khadira would appease the fever due to tumour.

column1: daśamūlī cchinnaruhā pathyā dāru punarnavā / jvaravidradhiśotheṣu śigruviśvajitā hitāḥ //
column2: The daśamūlī, chinnaruhā, mustard, dāru, punamavā, śigru and dry ginger are beneficial for remedying fevers, abscess and swelling.

column1: madhūkaṃ nimbapatrāṇi lepaḥ syadvraṇaśodhanaḥ /
column2: Besmearing with a paste of madhūka and neem leaves would clean the wounds.

column1: triphalā khadiro dārvī nyagrodhātibalākuśāḥ // nimbamūlakapatrāṇāṃ kaṣāyāḥ śodhane hitāḥ /
column2: A decoction of the three myrobalans and the leaves of khadira, dārvī, nyagrodha, atibalā, kuśa grass, neem, and mūlaka are beneficial in cleaning wounds.

column1: karañjāriṣṭanirguṇḍīraso hanyādvraṇakramīn //
column2: The juice of karañja, ariṣṭa and nirguṇḍī would destroy the parasites of wounds.

column1: dhātakicandanabalāsamaṅgāmadhukotpalaiḥ / dārvīmedonvitair lepaḥ samarpirvraṇaropaṇaḥ //
column2: Besmearing with a paste made up of dhātakī, sandal, balā, maṅgā, madhuka, blue lotus, dārvī and meda mixed with clarified butter would heal a wound.

column1: guggulutriphalāvyoṣasamāṃrśair ghṛtayogataḥ / nāḍī duṣṭavraṇaṃ śūlambhagandaramukhaṃ haret // haritakīṃ mūtrasiddhāṃ satailalavaṇānvitāṃ /
column2: Guggulu, the three myrobalans, dry ginger, pepper and long pepper in equal proportions mixed with ghee would heal wounds due to affected arteries and painful fistula. The yellow myrobalan boiled in cow’s urine with oil and salt should be used every morning.

column1: prātaḥ prātaś ca seveta kaphavātāmayāpahāṃ // trikaṭutriphalākvāthaṃ sakṣāralavaṇaṃ pivet /
column2: A decoction of dry ginger, pepper, long pepper and the three myrobalans should be drunk with alkali and salt as a purgative in deranged phlegm and wind.

column1: kaphavātātmakeṣveva virekaḥ kaphavṛddhinut //
column2: It arrests the increase of phlegm.

column1: pappalīpippalīmūlavacācitrakanāgaraiḥ / kvāthitaṃ vā pivetpeyamāmavātavināśanaṃ //
column2: The decoction of long pepper, the root of long pepper, vacā, citraka and dry ginger should be drunk to remedying constipation.

column1: rāsnāṃ guḍucīmeraṇḍadevadārumahauṣadhaṃ / pivet sarvāṅgike vāte sāme sandhyasthimajjage //
column2: One should drink the great remedyrāsnā, guḍūcī, root of castor and devadāru in case of rheumatism that affects all the limbs, joints, bones and marrow.

column1: daśamūlakaśāyaṃ vā piveddhā nāgarāmbhasā /
column2: Otherwise one may drink a decoction of daśamūla together with dry ginger and water.

column1: śuṇṭhīgokṣurakakvāthaḥ prātaḥ prātir niṣevitaḥ // sāmavātakaṭīśūlapācano rukpraṇāśanaḥ /
column2: By the use of a decoction of dry ginger and gokṣuraka every morning one would get back digestive power that has been impaired and would get relief from rheumatic pain in the hip.

column1: samūlapatraśākhāyāḥ prasāraṇyāś ca tailakaṃ // guḍucyāḥ surasaḥ kalkaḥ cūrṇaṃ vā kvāthameva ca /
column2: The oil extracted from the roots, leaves and branches of prasāriṇī, an extracted juice or paste or powder or decoction of guḍūcī would relieve one from acute gout when used for a long time. Long pepper and castoroil may be used.

column1: pippalī vardhamānaṃ vā sevyaṃ pathyā guḍena vā / paṭolatriphalātīvrakaṭukāsṛtasādhitaṃ //
column2: One would conquer quickly acute gout accompanied by burning sensation by drinking snakegourd, the three varieties of myrobalans, tivrakaṭuka and amṛta boiled with mustard or treacle.

column1: guggulaṃ koṣṇaśīte tu guḍucī triphalāmbhasā // balāpunar navair aṇḍavṛhatīdvayagokṣuraiḥ / sahiṅgu lavanaiḥ pītaṃ sadyo vātarujāpahaṃ //
column2: Rheumatic pain would be relieved at once by drinking guggulu in warm water or drinking guḍūcī with the three myrobalans in water together with balā, punarnavā, castor seed, the two kinds of bṛhatī, gokṣura, asafoetida and salt.

column1: kārṣikaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ pañcaiva lavaṇāni ca / pippalī citrakaṃ śuṇṭhī triphalā trivṛtā vacā // dvau kṣārau śādvalā dantī svarṇakṣīrī viṣāṇikā / kolapramāṇāṃ guṭikāṃ pivet sauvīrakāyutāṃ //
column2: A kārṣika a measure of weight each of the root of long pepper, the five kinds of salts, long pepper, citraka, dry ginger, the three varieties of myrobalans, trivṛt, vacā, two sorts of alkali, śādvala, dantī, svarṇakṣīrī and viṣāṇikā should be ground well and kola a measure of weight measure of pill should be drunk with jujube.

column1: śothāvapāke trivṛtā pravṛddhe codarādike / kṣīraṃ śothaharaṃ dāru varṣābhūrnāgaraiḥ śubham //
column2: It is an excellent remedy with trivṛt for indigestion and enlargement of the abdomen etc. Milk together with dāru, varṣābhū and dry ginger would be excellent for removing swelling.

column1: sekas tathārkavarṣābhūnimbakvāthena śothajit /
column2: Sprinkling with a decoction of arka, varṣābhū and bhūnimba would remove swelling.

column1: vyoṣagarbhaṃ palāśasya triguṇe bhasmavāriṇi // sādhitaṃ pivataḥ sarpiḥ patatyarśo na saṃśayaḥ /
column2: Piles would go without any doubt if the clarified butter boiled with three parts of ashes of dry ginger, pepper and long pepper mixed with palāśa dissolved in water is used.

column1: viśvaksenāvanirguṇḍīsādhitaṃ cāpi lāvaṇaṃ //
column2: Viṣvakṣena, lotus flower and nirguṇḍī boiled with salt would also have similar results.

column1: viḍaṅgānalasindhūttharāsnāgrakṣāradārubhiḥ / tailañcaturguṇaṃ siddhaṃ kaṭudravyaṃ jalena vā // gaṇḍamālāpahaṃ tailamabhyaṅgāt galagaṇḍanut / śaṭīkunāgabalayakvāthaḥ kṣīrarase yutam //
column2: Oil prepared with viḍaṅga, anala, rocksalt, rāsnā, agrakṣāra and dāru boiled with four times water saturated with a pungent material would remove inflammation of the glands of the neck and would remedy goitre if used as an unguent. Decoction of śaṭī, kunāga and valaya together with the juice of kṣira boiled with the paste of payasyā, long pepper and vāsā would be beneficial for consumption.

column1: vacāviḍabhayāśuṇṭhīhiṅgukuṣṭhāgnidīpyakān // dvitriṣaṭcaturekāṃśasaptapañcāśikāḥ kramāt / cūrṇaṃ pītaṃ hanti gulmaṃ udaraṃ śūlakāsanut //
column2: A compound of vacā, viḍ, mustard, dry ginger, asafoetida, kuṣṭha, agni, dīpyaka mixed in the proportion of two, three, six, four, one, seven parts and a fiftieth part respectively, if drunk would destroy tumours in the abdomen, abdominal colic and coughs.

column1: pāṭhānikumbhatrikaṭutriphalāgniṣu sādhitam / mūtreṇa cūrṇaguṭikā gulmaplīhādimardanī //
column2: Pills made of pāṭhā, nikumbha, pepper, dry ginger, long pepper, the three kinds of myrobalans and agni boiled with cow’s urine would remedy abdominal tumour, spleen and the like.

column1: vāsānimbapaṭīlāni triphalā vātapittanut /
column2: Vāsā, margosa, snakegourd and the three myrobalans would destroy deranged wind and bile.

column1: lihyāt kṣaudreṇa viḍaṅgaṃ cūrṇaṃ kṛmivināśanam // viḍaṅgasaindhavakṣāramūtrenāpi harītakī /
column2: Powdered viḍaṅga if licked with honey would destroy worms. The yellow myrobalan together with viḍaṅga, rock salt, kṣāra alkaline salt and cow’s urine will also produce the same effect.

column1: śallakīvadarījambupiyālāmrārjunatvacaḥ // pītāḥ kṣīreṇa madhvaktāḥ pṛthakśīṇitavāraṇāḥ / vilvāmraghātakīpāṭhāśuṇṭhīmocarasāḥ samāḥ //
column2: The barks of sallakī, jujube, rose apple, piyāla, mango and arjuna trees soaked in honey and taken with milk separately would arrest haemorrhage. Equal proportions of the juice of bilva, mango bark, dhātakī, pāṭhā, dry ginger and mocā when taken with treacle or buttermilk would arrest severe dysentery.

column1: cāṅgerīkoladadhyambunāgarakṣārasaṃyutam // ghṛtayukkvāthitaṃ peyaṃ gudaṃbhrase rujāpaham / viḍaṅgātiviṣāmustaṃ dārupāthākaliṅgakam //
column2: The drinking of a decoction of aṅgerī, kola, curd water, dry ginger and kṣāra an alkaline salt together with ghee would remove pain due to inflammation of anus. Viḍaṅga, ativiṣā, musta, dāru, pāṭhā and kaliṅga taken together with black pepper would cure dysentery accompanied by swelling of the limbs.

column1: śarkarāsindhuśuṇṭhībhiḥ kṛṣṇāmadhuguḍena vā // dve dve khādeddharītakyau jīvedvarṣaśataṃ sukhī /
column2: One would live for a hundred years happily by eating two yellow myrobalans everyday together with sugar, rocksalt and dry ginger or long, pepper, honey and treacle.

column1: triphalā pippalīyuktā samdhvājyā tathaiva sā // cūrnamāmalakaṃ tena surasena tu bhavitam /
column2: The same would be the result of taking the three kinds of myrobalans and long pepper together with honey and clarified butter.

column1: madhvājyaśarkarāyuktaṃ liḍhvā strīśaḥ payaḥ pivet // māsapippaliśālīnāṃ yavagodhūmayos tathā /
column2: One should lick powdered emblic myrobalan soaked in the juice of the same with honey, clarified butter and sugar and drink milk if desirous of enjoying women.

column1: cūrṇabhāgaiḥ samāṃśaiś ca pacet pippalīkāṃ śubhāṃ // tāṃ bhakṣayitvā ca pivet śarkarāmadhuraṃ payaḥ /
column2: Powdered black gram, long pepper, śāli a variety of rice, barley and wheat in equal proportion should be fried with long pepper. One should eat them and drink sweet milk with sugar.

column1: navaś caṭakavajjambhed daśavārān striyaṃ dhruvam //
column2: Such a person would gain strength to enjoy women ten times like a sparrow.

column1: virekaḥ sarvarogaghnaḥ śreṣṭho nārācasaṃjñakaḥ /

column2: The three myrobalans and amṛtā together with honey and clarified butter would cure disease and would make one live for three hundred years.

column1: rudantikājyamadhubhuk dugdhabhojī ca mṛtyujit //

column1: yaṣṭikaṃ mudgasūpena śāradena tathā pivet /

column1: bālabilvais tathā lepaḥ phaṭurogeṣu śasyate //

column2: The juice of flesh that has been cooked with the substances that are stimulants is good.

column1: anenāñjitanetrastu karoti kadanaṃ raṇe /

column2: The bed of an elephant would be powdered dry cow dung. It is commended that the elephants should be anointed with clarified butter in the autumn and summer.
