column1: yadgṛhe duḥkhitā gāvaḥ sa yāti narakannaraḥ //
column2: In whose house cows are illkept, that person would go to hell.

column1: paragogrāsadaḥ svargī gohito brahmalokabhāk /
column2: One who does good to a cow would reach the world of Brahmā.

column1: godānātkīrtanādrakṣāṃ kṛtvā coddharate kulam //
column2: One who makes a gift of a cow, one who sings her praise and one who saves her life would elevate his family.

column1: gavāṃ śvāsāt pavitrā bhūḥ sparśanātkilviṣakṣayaḥ /
column2: The earth becomes pure by the breath of cows. Sins get destroyed by their touch.

column1: gomūtraṃ gomayaṃ kṣīraṃ dadhi sarpiḥ kuśodakam // ekarātropavāsaś ca śvapākamapi śodhayet /
column2: The urine of a cow, the feces, milk, curd, clarified butter and the water in which kuśa grass has been dipped being taken and a night’s fasting would purify even a vile person.

column1: sarvāśubhavināśāya purācīratamīśvaraiḥ //
column2: It was practised by the gods in days of yore to destroy all inauspiciousness.

column1: pratyekañca tryahābhyamtaṃ mahāsāntapanaṃ smṛtaṃ /
column2: If each one of the above was practised for three days, it was known as the mahāsāntapana.

column1: sarvakāmapradañcaitat sarvāśubhavimardanam //
column2: This is capable of fulfilling all the desires of a person and destroying all that is inauspicious.

column1: kṛcchrātikṛcchraṃ payasā divasānekaviṃśatiṃ /
column2: It was known as kṛcchrātikṛcchra, if one lived on milk for twentyone days.

column1: nirmalāḥ sarvakāmāptyā syurgagāḥ spur natottamāḥ //
column2: The excellent men who practised it would become stainless, would get all the desires fulfilled and attain heaven.

column1: tryahamuṣṇaṃ payaḥ pītvā vāyubhakṣaḥ paraṃ tryaham //
column2: One should drink hot urine, hot ghee, and hot milk, each one for three days and consume air only for the next three days.

column1: taptakṛcchravrataṃ sarvapāpaghnaṃ brahmalokadaṃ /
column2: This vow known as taptakṛcchra would destroy all sins and confer the world of Brahmā.

column1: śītaistu śītakṛcchraṃ syādbrahmoktaṃ brahmalokadaṃ //
column2: It is known as śītakṛcchra if done with cold things as above. It was described by Brahmā. It would yield the world of Brahmā.

column1: gomūtreṇācaretsnānaṃ vṛttiṃ kuryācca gorasaiḥ / gobhirvrajecca bhuktāsu bhuñjītātha ca govratī //
column2: One should bathe in the urine of a cow, maintain himself with milk and move with the cows eating after they had eaten. It is known as govrata.

column1: māsenaikena niṣpāpo golokī svargago bhavet /
column2: One would become free from the sins in a month. He would attain the world of cows and reach heaven.

column1: vidyāñca gomatīṃ japtvā golokaṃ paramaṃ vrajet //
column2: One who mutters the gomatī vidyā a sacred formula would reach the excellent world of cows.

column1: gitair nṛtyair apsarobhirvimāne tatra modate /
column2: Therein he will enjoy music, dance and the company of nymphs in the celestial car.

column1: gāvaḥ surabhayo nityaṃ gāvo guggulagandhikāḥ //
column2: Cows are always fragrant. They give out the perfume of guggulu fragrant resin.

column1: gāvaḥ pratiṣṭhā bhūtānāṃ gāvaḥ svastyayanaṃ paraṃ /
column2: They are the sustainers of beings. Cows are the supreme conferers of welfare.

column1: annameva paraṃ gāvo devānāṃ haviruttamam //
column2: The excellent food for gods is the clarified butter from cows.

column1: pāvanaṃ sarvabhūtānāṃ kṣaranti ca vadanti ca /
column2: They pour out and utter purity for all the beings.

column1: haviṣā mantrapūtena tarpayantyamarāndivi // ṛṣīṇāmagnihotreṣu gāvo homeṣu yojitāḥ /
column2: They satisfy the immortals in heaven with the clarified butter purified by mystic formulas. Cows are connected with sacrificial rites such as agnihotra of the sages.

column1: sarveṣāmeva bhūtānāṃ gāvaḥ śaraṇamuttamaṃ //
column2: Cows are the excellent refuge of all beings.

column1: gāvaḥ pavitraṃ paramaṃ gāvo māṅgalyamuttamaṃ /
column2: They are supremely holy and are exceedingly auspicious. Cows are the steps leading to heaven.

column1: namo gobhyaḥ śrīmatībhyaḥ saurabheyībhya eva ca / namo brahmasutābhyaś ca pavitrābhyo namo namaḥ //
column2: They are the perpetually blessed ones. Obeisance to cows! To the fortunate ones! To the fragrant ones! Obeisance to the daughters of Brahmā! Obeisance to the holy ones!

column1: brāhmaṇāś caiva gāvaś ca kulamekaṃ dvidhā kṛtam /
column2: One family has been made into two such as brahmins and cows.

column1: ekatra mantrāstiṣṭhanti havirekatra tiṣṭhati //
column2: The sacred formulas remain on one side and clarified butter on the other.

column1: devabrāhmaṇagosādhusādhvībhiḥ sakalaṃ jagat /
column2: The entire universe is supported by gods, brahmins, cows, holy men and chaste women.

column1: dhāryate vai sadā tasmāt sarve pūjyatamā matāḥ //
column2: Hence they are always considered to be the fittest to be worshipped.

column1: pivanti yatra tattīrthaṃ gaṅgādyā gāva eva hi /
column2: Wherefrom cows would drink is known to be a sacred spot. Cows are really the Ganges and others.

column1: gavāṃ māhātmyamuktaṃ hi cikitsāñca tathā śṛṇu //
column2: The greatness of cows has been told. Listen to me! shall now describe the treatment of their diseases.

column1: śṛṅgāmayeṣu dhenūnāṃ tailaṃ dadyāt sasaindhavaṃ / śṛṅgaverabalāmāṃsakalkasiddhaṃ samākṣikaṃ // karṇaśūleṣu sarveṣu mañjiṣṭhāhiṅgusaindhavaiḥ /
column2: Oil mixed with rock salt and decoction of śṛṅgavera, balā and māṃsa, together with honey should be used for the diseases affecting the horns of cows. Oil prepared with mañjiṣṭhā, asafoetida and rock salt or garlic alone should be used in all kinds of pain in the ears.

column1: bilvamūlamapāmārgandhātakī casapāṭalā / kuṭajandantamūleṣu lepāttacchūlanāśanaṃ //
column2: Besmearing a paste of the roots of bilva, apāmārga, dhātakī, pāṭalā and kuṭaja at the base of the teeth would remove the pain therein.

column1: dantaśūlaharair dravyair ghṛtaṃ rāma vipācitaṃ / mukharogaharaṃ jñeyaṃ jihvārogeṣu saindhavaṃ //
column2: O Rāma! Ghee heated with the ingredients used for removing toothache is known to remove the disease of mouth. Rocksalt is used for the diseases of tongue.

column1: śṛṅgaveraṃ haridre dve triphalā ca galagrahe / hṛcchūle vastiśūle ca vātaroge kṣaye tathā // triphalā ghṛtamiśrā ca gavāṃ pāne praśasyate /
column2: Śṛṅgavera, the two varieties of turmeric and the three kinds of myrobalans are useful to remedy the stiffness of neck. The three myrobalans mixed with ghee given as a drink to cows is commended in heartache, stomachache, rheumatic complaints and pulmonary diseases.

column1: atīsāre haridre dve pāṭhāñcaiva pradāpayet //
column2: The two varieties of turmeric and pāṭhā may be given for dysentery.

column1: śṛṅgaverañca bhārgīñca kāse śvāse pradāpayet // dātavyā bhagnasandhāne priyaṅgurlabaṇānvitā /
column2: Śṛṅgavera and bhārgī may be given for the diseases of the digestive organs and the pulmonary capillaries, cough and asthma. Priyaṅgu together with salt should be given for joining the broken bones.

column1: tailaṃ vātaharaṃ pitte madhuyaṣṭīvipācitaṃ // kaphe vyoṣañca samadhu sapuṣṭakarajo 'sraje /
column2: Oil that removes wind, when heated with madhuyaṣṭī would cure biliousness. Mustard mixed with honey would be the remedy for deranged phlegm.

column1: tailājyaṃ haritālañca bhagnakṣatiśṛtandadet // māsāstilāḥ sagodhūmāḥ paśukṣīraṃ ghṛtaṃ tathā /
column2: One should apply oil, clarified butter and haritāla on wounds from which blood oozes out. Blackgram, sesamum, wheat, cow’s milk and ghee made into a ball with salt gives nourishment to the calves.

column1: eṣāṃ piṇḍī salavaṇā vatsānāṃ puṣṭidātviyaṃ //
column2: It would give strength to the young bulls.

column1: balapradā viṣāṇāṃ syadgrahanāśāya dhūpakaḥ /
column2: Fumigation would destroy the affliction due to evil planets.

column1: devadāru vacā māṃsī guggulurhiṅgusarṣapāḥ // grahādigadanāśāya eṣa dhūpo gavāṃ hitaḥ /
column2: Fumigation with devadāru, vacā, māṃsī, guggulu, asafoetida and mustard is beneficial for cows against pain due to evil planets.

column1: ghaṇṭhā caiva gavāṃ kāryā dhūpenānena bhūpitā //
column2: After fumigation a bell should be tied to cows.

column1: aśvagandhātilaiḥ śuklaṃ tena gauḥ kṣīriṇī bhavet / rasāyanañca pinyākaṃ matto yo dhāryate gṛhe //
column2: If a cow is fed with aśvagandhā and sesamum it would increase its strength and make it yield profuse milk. For a bull that is maintained in the house, oilcake would be the elixir.

column1: bhavāṃ purīṣe pañcabhyāṃ nityaṃ śāntyai śriyaṃ yajet /
column2: The goddess of fortune should always be worshipped in the feces of the cows on the fifth lunar day for peace.

column1: vāsudevañca gandhādyair aparā śāntirucyate //
column2: Lord Vāsudeva should also be worshipped with perfumes etc.

column1: aśvayukśuklapakṣasya pañcadaśyāṃ yajeddhariṃ /
column2: Lord Hari Viṣṇu should be worshipped on the fifteenth day of the bright fortnight in the month of aśvayuk OctoberNovember.

column1: harirudramajaṃ sūryaṃ śriyamagniṃ ghṛtena ca //
column2: Lord Hari, Rudra, Aja Brahmā, Sun, goddess of Fortune and Firegod should be worshipped with ghee.

column1: dadhi samprāśya gāḥ pūjya kāryaṃ vāhnipradakṣiṇaṃ / vṛṣāṇāṃ yojeyed yuddhaṃ gītavādyaravair vahiḥ //
column2: After feeding cows with curd and worshipping them, one should circumambulate the fire. One should also arrange for a bullfight accompanied by singing and instrumental music outside the place.

column1: gavāntu lavaṇandeyaṃ brāhmaṇānāñca dakṣiṇā /
column2: Salt should be given to cows. Brahmins should be paid the fees.

column1: naimittike mākarādau yajedviṣṇuṃ saha śriyā //
column2: In the periodical propitiatory rite Lord Viṣṇu should be worshipped at the centre of a lotus diagram on the ground along with goddess Śrī on the occasion of Sun’s transit through Capricorn etc.

column1: sthaṇḍilebje madhyagate dikṣu keśaragān surān /
column2: The celestials should be worshipped in the filaments in the different directions.

column1: subhadrājo raviḥ pūjyo bahurūpo balirvahiḥ //
column2: The Sun, the Subhadrāja born as fortunate and Bali, the Bahurūpa should be worshipped outside.

column1: khaṃ viśvarūpā siddhiś ca ṛddhiḥ śāntiś ca rohiṇī /
column2: The Sky, Viśvarūpā, Siddhi, Ṛddhi, Śānti, Rohiṇī should also be worshipped.

column1: digdhenavo hi pūrvādyāḥ kṛśaraiś candra īśvaraḥ // dikpālāḥ padmapatreṣu kumbheṣvagnau ca homayet /
column2: The guardian cows of the cardinal pointseast etc., the Moon and Īśvara should be worshipped in the filaments. The guardian deities of the cardinal points should be worshipped in the pitchers placed on the petals of the lotus.

column1: kṣīravṛkṣasya samidhaḥ sarṣapākṣatataṇḍulān //
column2: Oblation should be made unto the fire with the twigs of the kṣīra tree, mustard and unbroken rice a hundred times each.

column1: śataṃ śataṃ suvarṇañca kāṃsyādikaṃ dvije dadet /
column2: Gold and bronze should be given away to brahmins.

column1: gāvaḥ pūjyā vimoktavyāḥ śāntyai kṣīrādisaṃyutāḥ //
column2: Cows should then be worshipped and released for the sake of peace and to be endowed with milk etc.

column1: śālihotraḥ suśrutāya hayāyurvedamuktavān /
column2: Śālihotra narrated the veterinary science relating to the horses to Suśruta.

column1: pālakāpyo 'ṅgarājāya gajāyurvedamabravīt //
column2: Pālakāpya narrated the science relating to the elephants to Aṅgarāja.

column1: mantravidyāhariṃ vakṣye bhuktimuktipradaṃ śṛṇu /
column2: Listen to me! shall describe the science relating to the mystic formulas that would yield enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: viṃśatyarṇādhikā mantrā mālāmantrāḥ smṛtā dvija //
column2: O Brahmin! The mystic formulas containing more than twenty letters are known to be mālāmantras.

column1: daśākṣarādhikā mantrāstadarvāgvījasaṃjñitāḥ /
column2: The mystic formulas having more than ten letters and less than twenty are designated as arvāgbījas.

column1: vardhakye siddhidā hy ete mālāmantrāstu yauvena //
column2: These yield results in the old age, while the mālāmantras in the youth.

column1: pañcākṣarādhikā mantrāḥ siddhidāḥ sarvadāpare /
column2: The formulas having more than five letters yield fruits always.

column1: strīpuṃnapuṃsakatvena tridhāḥ syurmantrajātayaḥ //
column2: The other formulas belonging to the group of mantras are of three kinds such as feminine, masculine and neuter.

column1: strīmantrā vahnijāyantā namontāś ca napuṃsakāḥ /
column2: The feminine mantras end with the term Svāhā consort of Fire. The neuter mantras end with the term obeisance.

column1: śeṣāḥ pumāṃsaste śastā vakṣyoccāṭaviṣeṣu ca //
column2: The rest are masculine. They are commended to be used in charms to subjugate and to drive away evil.

column1: kṣudrakriyāmayadhvaṃse striyo 'nyatra napuṃsakāḥ / mantrāvāgneyasaumyākhyau tārādyantārdvayorjapet //
column2: The feminine mantras are used to destroy diseases due to mean acts, while the neuter ones in other cases. Mantras are also classified as āgneya fiery and saumya pleasing.

column1: tārāntyāgniviyatprāyo mantra āgneya iṣyate /
column2: The āgneya mantra is generally laid down as having the asterism at the end and the fire and the ether in greater proportions.

column1: śiṣṭaḥ saumyaḥ praśastau tau karmaṇoḥ krūrasaumyayoḥ //
column2: The rest are said to be saumya. The two varieties of mantras are commended to be used in cruel and good deeds respectively.

column1: āgneyamantraḥ saumyaḥ syātprāyaśo 'nte namo 'nvitaḥ /
column2: The āgneya mantra may perhaps be saumya by the addition of ‘obeisance’ at the end.

column1: saumyamantras tathāgneyaḥ phaṭkāreṇāntato yutaḥ //
column2: Saumya mantra would also in the same way be āgneya by the addition of the syllable phaṭ.

column1: suptaḥ prabuddhamātro vā mantraḥ siddhiṃ na yacchati /
column2: A mantra would not accomplish the result if it is either asleep or awakened.

column1: śvāpakālo mahāvāho jāgaro dakṣiṇāvahaḥ // āgneyasya manoḥ saumyamantrasyaitadviparyayāt /
column2: The sleeping state of a mantra is when there is powerful breath through the nostrils and the waking state when the breath flows through the right nostril.

column1: prabodhakālaṃ jānīyādubhayorubhayorahaḥ //
column2: One should ascertain the waking state of both the mantras and the day for both.

column1: duṣṭarkṣarāśividveṣivarṇādīn varjayenmanūn /
column2: The mantras, whose letters are presided over by baneful asterisms and constellations, should be avoided.

column1: rājyalābhopakārāya prārabhyāriḥ svaraḥ kurūn // gopālakakuṭīṃ prāyāt pūrṇāmityuditā lipiḥ /
column2: In order to acquire kingdom, the vowel letters which are inimical to the component letters of one’s name, should be first arranged in due order. “May you go and fill the abode of the king”.

column1: nakṣetrekṣakramādyojyā svarāntyau revatīyujau //
column2: The vowels should be arranged in the different asterisms in order ending with the asterism Revatī.

column1: velā guruḥ svarāḥ śoṇaḥ karmaṇaivetibheditāḥ / lipyarṇā vaśiṣu jñeyā ṣaṣṭheśādīṃś ca yojayet // lipau catuṣpathasthāyāmākhyavarṇapadāntarāḥ / siddhāḥ sādhyā dvitīyasthāḥ susiddhā vairiṇaḥ pare //
column2: The chambers should be marked as the siddhas successful, such as the ninth, the first and the fifth chamber, the sādhyas successful in time, such as the sixth the tenth and the second chamber, the susiddhas extremely successful, such as the third, the seventh and the eleventh chamber, and the ari hostile, such as the fourth, the eighth and the twelfth chamber and the character of each mantra in relation to the name of the individual to whom it should be imparted, should be calculated therefrom.

column1: siddhādīn kalpayedevaṃ siddhātyantaguṇair api / siddhe siddho japāt sādhyo japapūjāhutādinā //
column2: One accomplishes merely by the repetition of the siddha mantra. The sādhya mantra could accomplish by the repetition, worship and making an oblation.

column1: susiddho dhyānamātreṇa sādhakaṃ nāśayedariḥ /
column2: The susiddha mantra would accomplish by mere contemplation.

column1: duṣṭārṇapracuro yaḥ syānmantraḥ sarvavininditaḥ //
column2: The mantra known as ari would destroy the votary. A mantra full of baneful letters of the alphabet is condemned by all.

column1: praviśya vidhivaddīkṣāmabhiṣekāvasānikām / śrutvā tantraṃ guror labdhaṃ sādhayedīpsitaṃ manum //
column2: After having been duly initiated ending with the ceremonial bathing and after having had the exposition of the tantra from the preceptor, one has to practise the desired mantra got from the preceptor.

column1: dhīro dakṣaḥ śucirbhakto japadhyānāditatparaḥ / siddhastapasvī kuśalastantrajñaḥ satyabhāṣaṇaḥ // nigrahānugrahe śakto gururityabhidhīyate /
column2: A person who is bold, competent, pure, devoted, bent on repetition, contemplation and the like, accomplished, who practises penance, is intelligent, knows the tantra, speaks the truth and is capable of restraining and blessing the disciple is said to be a preceptor.

column1: śānto dāntaḥ paṭuścīrṇabrahmacaryo haviṣyabhuk // kurvannācāryaśuśrūṣāṃ siddhotsāhī sa śiṣyakaḥ /
column2: A disciple should be calm, restrained, clever, studied, celebate, and eating food fit for oblation. He should do service to the preceptor. He should be eager to accomplish.

column1: sa tūpadeśyaḥ putraś ca vinayī vasudas tathā //
column2: He should be instructed. He should be like a son, modest and capable of giving money.

column1: mantrandadyāt susiddhau tu sahasraṃ deśikaṃ japet /
column2: A mantra should be imparted by the preceptor. When it is accomplished the preceptor should repeat it a thousand times.

column1: yadṛcchayā śrutaṃ mantraṃ chalenātha balena vā // patre sthitañca gāthāñca janayedyadyanarthakam /
column2: A mantra that has been heard accidentally, or got by fraudulent means or by force or written on a leaf or got in the form of a gāthā a verse would not bear any fruit.

column1: mantraṃ yaḥ sādhayedekaṃ japahomārcanādibhiḥ // kriyābhirbhūribhistasya sidhyante svalpasādhanāt /
column2: One who practises a mantra by means of several acts such as repetition, oblation, worship and the like, attains success by little practice.

column1: samyaksiddhaikamantrasya nāsādhyamiha kiñcana //
column2: There is nothing which cannot be achieved by means of a mantra that has been perfectly practised.

column1: bahumantravataḥ puṃsaḥ kā kathā śiva eva saḥ /
column2: What to say about a person who has practised many mantras. He is really Śiva Himself.

column1: daśalakṣajapādeka varṇo mantraḥ prasidhyati // varṇavṛddhyā japahrāsastenānyeṣāṃ samūhayet /
column2: A mantra consisting of a single letter bears fruit after repetition for ten lakh a million times. The repetition is reduced as the number of letters in the mantra is increased.

column1: vījāddvitriguṇānmantrānmālāmantre japakriyā //
column2: The mantras containing letters twice or thrice the bīja mantras should be repeated like a mālāmantra.

column1: saṅkhyānuktau śataṃ sāṣṭaṃ sahasraṃ vā japādiṣu / japāddaśāṃśaṃ sarvatra sābhiśekaṃ hutaṃ viduḥ //
column2: A mantra should be repeated a hundred and eight or a thousand times if the number of their repetition has not been specified. It is known that the number of libations and anointments is in general a tenth part of the number of repetitions.

column1: dravyānuktau ghṛtaṃ home japo 'śaktasya sarvataḥ /
column2: For one who is not able to repeat, ghee would be the material for libation, in all the cases, if the material has not been specified.

column1: mūlamantrāddaśāṃśaḥ syādaṅgādīnāṃ japādikam //
column2: The number of repetitions of the component mantras would be a tenth as that of the main mantra.

column1: japātsaśaktimantrasya kāmadā mantradevatāḥ / sādhakasya bhavet tṛptā dhyānahomārcanādinā //
column2: When the mantras are repeated according to their potency, the presiding deities of the mantras yield the desired fruits. They get pleased with the contemplation, oblation and worship etc.

column1: uccairjapādviśiṣṭaḥ syādupāṃśurdaśabhirguṇaiḥ / jihvājape śataguṇaḥ sahasro mānasaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: The muttering of a mantra is ten times more meritorious than their loud repetition. Repetition with the tongue within the mouth is hundred times meritorious. The mental repetition is known to be a thousand times more meritorious.

column1: prāṅmukho 'vāṅmukho vāpi mantrakarma samārabhet /
column2: One should begin the repetition of a mantra facing the east or looking downwards.

column1: praṇavādyāḥ sarvamantrā vāgyato vihitāśanaḥ // āsīnastu japenmantrāndevatācāryatulyadṛk /
column2: All the mantras should begin with the praṇava the syllable Oṃ. One should restrain from conversing and eat the prescribed food. One has to repeat the mantras remaining seated.

column1: kuṭīviviktā deśāḥ syurdevālayanadīhradāḥ //
column2: The places suited for the practice are a solitary cottage, temples and banks of rivers and tanks.

column1: siddhau yavāgūpūpair vā payo bhakṣyaṃ haviṣyakam /
column2: One who wants to gain perfection in a mantra, should live on ricegruel, cakes, milk or haviṣya that is to be offered to fire food.

column1: mantrasya devatā tāvat tithivāreṣu vai japet // kṛṣṇāṣṭamīcaturdaśyorgrahaṇādau ca sādhakaḥ /
column2: The votary should worship the presiding deity of the mantra on the lunar days and weekdays such as the eighth and fourteenth days of the dark fortnight and eclipses etc.

column1: dasro yamo 'nalo dhātā śaśī rudro gururditiḥ // sarpāḥ pitaro 'tha bhago 'ryamā śotetaradyutiḥ / tvaṣṭā maruta indrāgnī mitrendrau nirṛtirjalam //

column1: ājānutaḥ suvarṇābhamānābhestuhinaprabham // kuṅkumāruṇamākaṇṭhādākeśāntāt sitetaraṃ / brahmāṇḍavyāpinaṃ tārkṣañcandrākhyaṃ nāgabhūṣaṇam // nīlogranāśamātmānaṃ mahāpakṣaṃ smaredbudhaḥ /
column2: A wise man should contemplate Tārkṣa the Eagle, who pervades the cosmic universal egg, who wears the serpent ornament known as the candra reflecting the blue hue of his dreadful beak and who has the great wings from the knee to the navel as golden coloured, from the navel to the neck as snowcoloured, from the neck to the hair as red like the saffron and from the ends of the hair as black.

column1: evantātkṣātmano vākyānmantraḥ syānmantriṇo viṣe //
column2: There would thus be a charm for a poison from the statement of a charmer who is pervaded by the letters of the Tārkṣya mantra.

column1: suṣṭistārkṣakarasyāntaḥsthitāṅguṣṭhaviṣāpahā / tārkṣaṃ hastaṃ samudyamya tatpañcāṅgulicālanāt // kuryādviṣasya stambhādīṃstaduktamadavīṣayā /
column2: A blow with the fist, thus charged with the Tārkṣya mantra, would remove poison. Raising the hand charged with the Tārkṣya mantra and passing over the place of bite the five fingers, and by having a look at the person intoxicated, one would arrest the spread of the poison.

column1: ākāśādeṣa bhūvījaḥ pañcārṇādhipatirmanuḥ //
column2: One should arrest the spread of the poison by the repetition of the following mantra “This bhūbīja mantra, the lord of the five letters has descended from the sky.

column1: saṃstambhayetiviṣato bhāṣayā stambhyedviṣam /

column1: vyatyastabhūṣayā vījo mantro 'yaṃ sādhusādhitaḥ //
column2: This would raise one like a stick, by bathing him with water after repeating this mantra well.

column1: saṃplavaḥ plāvaya yamaḥ śabdādyaḥ saṃharedviṣaṃ / daṇḍamutthāpayedeṣa sujaptāmbho 'bhiṣekataḥ // sujaptaśaṅkhabheryādinisvanaśravaṇena vā /
column2: Similar result could be obtained by hearing the sound produced by a conch or bherī war drum after repeating this mantra properly. This mantra with the inversion of the components of earth and splendour would burn the poison.

column1: bhūvāyuvyatyayānmantro viṣaṃ saṃkrāmayatyasau /
column2: This mantra with the inversion of the components of earth and wind would transfer the poison.

column1: antastho nijaveśmastho vījāgnīndujalātmabhiḥ // etat karma nayenmantrī garuḍākṛtivigrahaḥ /
column2: The practitioner of this charm possessing the shape of the figure of Garuḍa, should practise this act inside his own house with the components of earth, fire, moon and water.

column1: tārkṣavarṇagehasthastajjapānnāśayedviṣam //
column2: The repetition of this mantra in the abodes of Garuḍa and Lord Varuṇa would destroy the poison.

column1: jāmudaṇḍīdamuditaṃ svadhāśrīvījalāñchitaṃ / snānapānātsarvaviṣaṃ jvarātogāpamṛtyujit //
column2: It would destroy all posions and ward off fever, diseases and untimely death by bathing and drinking the water consecrated by its repetition marked with the components of the syllables svadhā and śrī.

column1: pakṣi pakṣi mahāpakṣi mahāpakṣi vidhi svāhā / pakṣi pakṣi mahāpakṣi mahāpakṣi kṣi kṣi svāhā //
column2: “Oh! Bird! Bird! Great bird! Great bird! Vi! Vi! Oblations! Oh! Bird! Bird! Great bird! Great bird! Kṣi! Kṣi! Oblations!” These two mantras of the king of birds are capable of destroying poison by chanting.

column1: sakālo lāṅgalī ceti nīlakaṇṭhādyamīritaṃ / vakṣaḥkaṇṭhaśikhāśvetaṃ nyasetstambhe susaṃskṛtau //
column2: Then “Kāla and Lāṅgalī”, the mantra of Nīlakaṇṭha bluenecked, an epithet of Śiva bearing the insignia of tooth and stick should be assigned on the chest, neck, tuft etc.

column1: abhayaṃ varadaṃ cāpaṃ vāsukiñca dadhadbhujaiḥ /
column2: The Lord should be contemplated as offering protection and boon and holding the bow and the serpent in His hands.

column1: yasyoparītapārśvasthagaurīrudro 'sya devatā //
column2: Goddess Gaurī and Lord Rudra are contemplated as His presiding deity above and on the left.

column1: pādajānuguhānābhihṛtkaṇṭhānanamūrdhasu / mantrārṇānnyasya karayoraṅguṣṭhādyaṅgulīṣu ca // tarjanyāditadantāsu sarvamaṅguṣṭhayor nyaset /
column2: After having assigned the letters of the mantra on foot, knee, private organ, navel, heart, neck, face, head, hands, fingers beginning with the thumb, forefinger and folds on the fingers and then all of them should be assigned on the thumb.

column1: dhyātvaivaṃ saṃharet kṣipraṃ vaddhayā śūlamudrayā //
column2: After having contemplated thus, they should be bound quickly with the mudrā formation made with the fingers, in the shape of a spike.

column1: kaniṣṭhā jyeṣṭhayā vaddhā tiśro 'nyāḥ prasṛterjavāḥ /
column2: The little finger should be held by the thumb. The other three are stretched out quickly.

column1: viṣanāśe vāmahastamanyasmin dakṣiṇaṃ karaṃ //
column2: This is that mudrā. The left hand is used for destroying the poison and the right hand in other acts.

column1: yajedrudravidhānena nīlagrīvaṃ maheśvaram /
column2: Lord Bluenecked, the great lord should be worshipped by following the rule laid down for the worship of Rudra.

column1: viṣavyādhivināśaḥ syāt kṛtvā rudravidhānakaṃ //
column2: One would destroy the poison and disease by doing worship according to the rules of Rudra worship.

column1: vakṣye rudravidhānantu pañcāṅgaṃ sarvadaṃ paraṃ /
column2: shall describe the five constituents of the worship of Rudra. It is the most excellent that confers everything.

column1: hṛdayaṃ śivasaṅkalpaḥ śivaḥ sūktantu pauruṣam // śikhābhyaḥ sambhṛtaṃ sūktamāśuḥ kavacameva ca /
column2: The śivasaṅkalpa resolve for Śiva is the heart. The Puruṣasūkta is the head. The hymn adbhyaḥ sambhūta is the tuft. The hymn called āśu is the armour.

column1: śatarudriyamastrañca rudrasyāṅgāni pañca hi // pañcāṅgānnyasya taṃ dhyātvā japedrudrāṃstaḥ kramāt /
column2: The śatarudrīya hymn is the weapon. These are the five constituents in the worship of Rudra. After having assigned the five constituents and contemplating Him, the Rudra hymns are repeated in order.

column1: yajjāgrata iti sūktaṃ yadṛcaṃ mānasaṃ viduḥ //
column2: The hymn beginning with yajjāgrata is known to be repeated mentally.

column1: ṛṣiḥ syācchivamaṅkalpaśchandastriṣṭuvudāhṛtaṃ / śivaḥ sahasraśīrṣeti tasya nārāyaṇo 'pyṛṣiḥ //
column2: The sage of that hymn is śivasaṅkalpa resolve and the metre is said to be triṣṭubh consisting of syllables in a quarter. For the hymn sahasraśīrṣā for the head the sage is Nārāyaṇa.

column1: devatā puruṣo 'nuṣṭupchando jñeyañca traiṣṭubham / abhyaśrasambhṛtaṃ sūktamṛṣiruttaragonaraḥ //
column2: The deity of this hymn is the supreme soul. The metre is known to be triṣṭubh. The sage for the hymn adbhyaḥ sambhūta is the person going to the north.

column1: ādyānāntimṛṇāṃ triṣṭupchando 'nuṣṭhuvdvayorapi /
column2: Iriṣṭubh is the metre for the first three hymns, anuṣṭubh for the next two and triṣṭubh for the last hymn.

column1: chandastriṣṭubhamantyāyāḥ puruṣo 'syāpi deṣatā //
column2: The deity for this hymn also is the supreme soul.

column1: āśurintro dvādaśānāṃ chandastriṣṭuvudāhṛtaṃ /
column2: Indra is the lord for the twelve hymns beginning with āśu.

column2: Triṣṭubh is said to be the metre and Pratiratha, the sage. The deities are separate for each one of the verses in the hymn of seventeen verses. The deity of the constituent part is Puruvit.

column1: avaśiṣṭadaivateṣu chando 'nuṣṭuvudāhṛtaṃ // asau yamo bhavitrīndraḥ puruliṅgoktadevatāḥ /
column2: The metre of the remaining deities is said to be anuṣṭubh. Indra is the deity for the hymn asau yastāmraḥ. Puruliṅga is the deity for the constituent parts.

column1: paṅkticchando 'tha marmāṇi tvapaliṅgoktadevatāḥ //
column2: Paṅkti is the metre. The deities of the constituent parts are vital.

column1: raudrādhyāye ca sarvasminnārṣaṃ syāt parameṣvapi /
column2: Parameṣṭhin is the sage for all the hymns of the Rudrādhyāya.

column1: prajāpatirvā devānāṃ kutsasya tisṛṇām punaḥ //

column1: manodvayorumaikā syādrudro rudrāś ca devatāḥ /

column1: ṛgdvitīyā trijagatī triṣṭuveva ca /

column1: trailokyamohanenāpi viṣavyādhyarimardanaṃ /
column2: One would be able to destroy the poison, disease and the enemy with the repetition of the mantra trailokyamohana one that stupefies the three worlds.

column1: nṛsiṃhaṃ bhīṣaṇaṃ mṛtyumṛtyumnamāmyahaṃ //
column2: He is the frightening Nṛsiṃha, who is benevolent and is the destroyer of death.”

column2: This is the mantra of five parts that accomplishes all things.

column2: The poison gets destroyed by the repetition of the mantra of the bird.

column2: A person bitten by a snake should cauterize with log or stone for subduing the poison immediately after being bitten. The bitten part of the body should be cauterized with burning red lotus etc.

column2: The drinking or besmearing or collyrium of the three pungent thingsseeds of śirīṣa flower, arka flower and kṣīra seeds would destroy the poison.

column1: koṣātakīvacāhiṅguśirīśārkapayoyutaṃ // kuṭutrayaṃ sameṣāmbho harennasyādinā viṣaṃ /

column2: The powder of asafoetida and all parts of ikṣvāku used as a sternutatory would remove the poison.

column1: pañcāṅgaṃ kṛṣṇapañcabhyāṃ śirīṣasya viṣāpahaṃ //
column2: The five parts of the śirīṣa eaten on the fifth lunar day of the dark fortnight would remove the poison.

column1: gonasādicikitsāñca vaśiṣṭha śṛṇu vacmi te /
column2: O Vasiṣṭha! Listen to me! shall describe to you the treatment for the poison due to gonasa and others snakes.

column1: tāmbūlakhādanānmantrī harenmaṇḍalino viṣaṃ //
column2: Hrīṃ, hrīṃ oblations to the stainless bird! A charmer would remove the poison due to maṇḍalin a kind of snake by eating the betel leaf after consecrating it with the above mantra.

column1: laśunaṃ rāmaṭhaphalaṃ kuṣṭhāgnivyoṣakaṃ viṣe / snuhīkṣīraṃ gavyaghṛtaṃ pakṣaṃ pītvāhije viṣe // atha rājiladaṣṭe ca peyā kṛṣṇā samaindhavā /
column2: Garlic, asafoetida, kuṣṭha, agni, dried ginger, pepper and long pepper are remedies for poison. The milk of snuhī and clarified butter from the cow would remove the poison due to a class of snakes called ahi, when it is drunk for a fortnight. When one is bitten by the snake called rājila, he should drink pepper with rocksalt.

column1: ājyakṣaudraśakṛttoyaṃ purītatyā viṣāpahaṃ // sakṛṣṇākhaṇḍadugdhājyaṃ pātavyantena mākṣikaṃ / vyoṣaṃ picchaṃ viḍālāsthi nakulāṅgaruhaiḥ samaiḥ //
column2: Clarified butter, honey and cowdung water taken with purītaki would remove poison. Thick milk and clarified butter together with pepper should be drunk with honey. Pepper, dried ginger and long pepper, the feather of a peacock, the bone of a cat and the hair of a mongoose in equal parts should be powdered after soaking with the milk of a goat.

column1: cūrṇitair meṣadugdhāktair dhūpaḥ sarvaviṣāpahaḥ /
column2: Fumigation with the above powder would remove all kinds of poisons.

column1: romanirguṇḍikākokavarṇair vā laśunaṃ samaṃ // munipatraiḥ kṛtasvedaṃ daṣṭaṃ kāñcikapācitaiḥ /
column2: The hair of mongoose, nirguṇḍī, and kola with same proportion of garlic burnt with the leaf of the plant muni and boiled with sour gruel could be used for fumigation to remove poison.

column1: mūṣikāḥ ṣoḍaśa proktā rasaṅkārpāsajampivet //
column2: Rats are of sixteen kinds. One should drink the juice of cotton together with oil to remove the poison due to them.

column1: satailaṃ mūṣikārtighnaṃ phalinīkusumantathā / sanāgaraguḍambhakṣyaṃ tadviṣārocakāpahaṃ //
column2: The phalinī flower will also destroy the affliction due to the rats. Eating of molasses together with nāgara would also remove that poison and the loss of appetite.

column1: cikitsā viṃṣatirbhūtā lūtāviṣaharo gaṇaḥ /
column2: There are twenty ways of treating this poison.

column1: padmakaṃ pāṭalī kuṣṭhaṃ natamūśīracandanaṃ // nirguṇḍī śārivā śelu lūtārtaṃ secayejjalaiḥ / guñjānirguṇḍikaṅkolaparṇaṃ śuṇṭhī niśādvayaṃ //
column2: The group of remedies for removing the poison due to a spider etc. padmaka, pāṭalī, kuṣṭha, uśīra, sandal, nirguṇḍī, śārikā and śelu should be made into a paste and applied for affliction due to the spider. The leaves of guñjā, nirguṇḍī and aṅkola, dried ginger, the two kinds of turmeric, the kernel of karañja made into a paste and applied would also remedy that poison.

column1: karañjāsthi ca tatpaṅkaiḥ vṛścikārtiharaṃ śṛṇu /
column2: Listen to me! shall describe the remedy that would remove the poison due to a scorpion.

column1: mañjiṣṭhā candanaṃ vyoṣapuṣpaṃ śirīṣakaumudaṃ // saṃyojyāś caturo yogā lepādau vṛścikāpahāḥ /
column2: A paste of the mixture of mañjiṣṭhā, sandal, dried ginger, pepper, long pepper and the flowers of śirīṣa and the white waterlily used in four ways such as ointment and the like would remove the poison due to a scorpion.

column1: mantreṇa mantrito deyo gardhabhādīnnikṛntati //
column2: When the herb is given after the repetition of the above mantra, it would destroy the poison due to an ass and others animals.

column1: triphalośīramustāmbumāṃsīpadmakacandanaṃ / ajākṣīreṇa pānādergardhabhāderviṣaṃ haret // haret śirīṣapañcāṅgaṃ vyoṣaṃ śatapadīviṣaṃ /
column2: The three myrobalans, uśīra, musta water, māṃsī, padmaka and sandal being drunk together with goat’s milk would remove the poison due to an ass and others animals. Five parts of śirīṣa together with dried ginger, pepper and long pepper would remove the venom due to the centipedes.

column1: sakandharaṃ śirīṣāsthi haredundūrajaṃ viṣaṃ // vyoṣaṃ sasarpiḥ piṇḍītamūlamasya viṣaṃ haret /
column2: The neck of the śirīṣa and its kernel would remove the poison due to a rat. The dried ginger, pepper and long pepper together with clarified butter and made into a paste with the root of long pepper would remove the poison.

column1: kṣāravyoṣavacāḍiṅguviḍaṅgaṃ saindhavannataṃ // ambaṣṭhātibalākuṣṭhaṃ sarvakīṭaviṣaṃ haret /
column2: A mixture of alkali, dried ginger, pepper and long pepper, vacā, asafoetida, viḍaṅga, rocksalt, ambaṣṭha, atibala and kuṣṭha would remove the venom due to all insects.

column1: yaṣṭivyoṣaguḍakṣīrayogaḥ śūno viṣāpahaḥ //

column2: The asterism is located on the index finger, the lagnas on the thumb as also with the middle finger.

column1: taleṅguṣṭhe taduttāraṃ vījottāraṃ tato nyaset /
column2: are located on the palm and thumb.

column1: raktagauradhūmraharijjātarūpāḥ sitāstrayaḥ //
column2: The letters of the mantras should be contemplatedas red, white, tawny, green, golden and the remaining three as white.

column1: evaṃ rūpānimān varṇān bhāvabuddhānnyaset kramāt / hṛdāsyanetramūrdhāṅghritāluguhyakarādiṣu // aṅgāni ca nyasedvījānnyasyātha karadehayoḥ /
column2: These letters having the above colours and set with their true state should be located in order at the heart, face, eyes, head, feet, palate, private organ and hands. After having assigned the principal letters on the hand and body, the location of the constituent parts.

column1: yathātmani tathā deve nyāsaḥ kāryaḥ karaṃ vinā //
column2: The location on the image of the deity should be done as in the case of oneself except that the hand is not involved.

column1: hṛdādisthānagān varṇān gandhapuṣpai samarcayet /
column2: The letters located in the different places such as the heart should be worshipped with incense and flowers.

column1: dharmādyagnyādyadharmādi gātre pīṭhe 'mbuje nyaset //
column2: The virtues etc., fire etc. and unrighteousness etc.

column1: yatra keśarakiñjalkavyāpisūryendudāhināṃ / maṇḍalantritayantāvad bhedaistatra nyaset kramāt //
column2: are located respectively on the body, seat and the lotus. The three orbs of the Sun, Moon and Fire pervading the filaments of the lotus should be located in order with their distinctions.

column1: guṇāś ca tantrasatvādyāḥ keśarasthāś ca śaktayaḥ /
column2: The qualities sattva etc.

column1: vimalotkarṣaṇījñānakriyāyogāś ca vai kramāt // prahvī satyā tatheśānānugrahā madhyatastataḥ /
column2: and the female energies Vimalā, Utkarṣiṇī, Jñāna, Kriyā, Yogā, Prahvī, Satyā and Īśānānugrahā are to be located in the filaments therein in order.

column1: yogapīṭhaṃ samabhyarcya samāvahya hariṃ yajet //
column2: After having worshipped the yogic seat at the centre, Lord Hari should be invoked and worshipped.

column1: pādyārghyācamanīyañca pītavastravibhūṣaṇaṃ / etat pañcopacārañca sarvaṃ mūlena dīyate //
column2: The five practices of worship such as water for washing the feet, arghya respectful offering, water for sipping, yellow clothes and ornament are all offered with the principal mantra.

column1: vāsudevādayaḥ pūjyāś catvāro dikṣu mūrtayaḥ /
column2: The images of gods Vāsudeva a form of Viṣṇu and others, namely four, should be worshipped in the four principal directions.

column1: vidikṣu śrīsarasvatyai ratiśāntyai ca pūjayet //
column2: Goddesses Śrī Lakṣmī, Sarasvatī, Rati and Śānti should be worshipped in the intermediary directions.

column1: śaṅkhaṃ cakraṃ gadāṃ padmaṃ muṣalaṃ khaḍgaśārṅgike / vanamālānvitaṃ dikṣu vidikṣu ca yajet kramāt //
column2: The conch, disc, mace, lotus, pestle, sword, śārṅga bow and the garland of wild flowers should duly be worshipped in the principal and intermediary directions.

column1: abhyarcya ca vahistārkṣyaṃ devasya purato 'rcayet / viśvaksenañca someśaṃ madhye āvaraṇādvahiḥ /
column2: After having worshipped Tārkṣya eagle vehicle of Lord Viṣṇu outside in front of the Lord, Viṣvaksena and Someśa should be worshipped outside at the centre and Indra and other attendant gods outside the enclosure.

column1: indrādiparicāreṇa pūjya sarvamavāpnuyāt //
column2: One would obtain everything by this worship.

column1: meṣaḥ saṃjñā viṣaṃ sādyamasti dīrghodakaṃ rasaḥ / etat pañcākṣaraṃ mantraṃ śivadañca śivātmakaṃ //
column2: Vāsudeva, Pradyumna, Aniruddha and Saṅkarṣaṇa. “Meṣaḥ, Saṃjñā, viṣaṃ, sājyaṃ, asti, dīrghodakaṃ, rasaḥ.” This is the mantra sacred to Lord Śiva that confers good .

column1: tārakādi samabhyarcya devatvādi samāpnuyāt /
column2: After having worshipped the asterisms etc. well one would gain the status of the celestials etc.

column1: jñānātmakaṃ paraṃ brahma paraṃ buddhiḥ śivo hṛdi //
column2: Lord Śiva, the embodiment of knowledge, the Supreme Brahman and the highest intellect should be contemplated in one’s heart.

column1: tacchaktibhūtaḥ sarveśo bhinno brahmādimūrtibhiḥ /
column2: Brahmā and other gods are born of His power and are only His manifestations.

column1: mantrārṇāḥ pañca bhūtāni tanmantrā viṣayās tathā //
column2: The letters of the mantra gave rise to the five elements, their respective mantras and their respective matter.

column1: prāṇādivāyavaḥ pañca jñānakarmendriyāṇi ca / sarvaṃ pañcākṣaraṃ brahma tadvadaṣṭākṣarāntakaḥ //
column2: Prāṇa and other vital winds, the five organs of sense and five organs of action, everything are the manifestation of Brahman, namely, the five letters . Similarly we have the embodiment of eight syllables.

column1: gavyena prakṣayeddīkṣāsthānaṃ mantreṇa coditaṃ /
column2: The place of initiation sanctified by the mantra should be washed with the five things got from a cow.

column1: tantrasambhūtasambhāvaḥ śivamiṣṭvā vidhānataḥ // mūlamūrtyaṅgavidyābhistaṇḍulakṣepaṇādikam /
column2: The essential articles for worship should be taken to the place and Lord Śiva should be worshipped as laid down. After having practised the location of the mantras on the main image and the limbs, rice should be scattered.

column1: kṛtvā caruñca yat kṣīraṃ punastadvibhajet tridhā //
column2: Then the porridge should be made ready and the milk boiled. Then it should be divided into three parts.

column1: ācamya sakalīkṛtya dadyāccchiṣyāya deśikaḥ // dantakāṣṭhaṃ hṛdā japtaṃ kṣīravṛkṣādisambhavam / saṃśodhya dantān saṃkṣiptvā prajñālyaitat kṣipedbhuvi //
column2: After rinsing the mouth and accomplishing the transformation, the preceptor should give the disciple a twig of the kṣīra tree for cleansing the teeth after sanctifying it with the mantra of the heart. After having cleaned the teeth and washed the mouth, he should throw it on the ground.

column1: pūrveṇa saumyavārīśagataṃ śubhamatau śubham /
column2: It indicates good if it falls in the northern or western direction from the east and bad otherwise.

column1: punastaṃ śiṣyamāyāntaṃ śiśvābandhādirakṣitaṃ // kṛtvā vedyāṃ sahānena svapeddarbhāstare budhaḥ / suṣuptaṃ vīkṣya taṃ śiṣyaḥ prabhāte śrāvayedguruṃ //
column2: The wise preceptor should make it dry by tying the tuft of the disciple who has come and make him lie down on the sacrificial altar on the bed of darbha grass together with himself. At dawn the pupil should meet the preceptor who has slept well and let him know the dream he had.

column1: śubhaiḥ siddhipadair bhaktistaiḥ punarmaṇḍalārcanam / maṇḍalaṃ bhadrakādyuktaṃ pūjayetsarvasiddhidaṃ //
column2: Then worship should be done with those benevolent words that accomplish the desires. One should worship in the circles such as the bhadraka that would confer all the perfections.

column1: snātvācamya mṛdā dehaṃ mantrair ālipya kalpyate / śivatīrthe naraḥ snāyādaghamarṣaṇapūrvakam //
column2: After having bathed, rinsing the mouth with water and besmearing the body with mud with the recitation of the mantras, one should bathe in the watercourse sacred to Lord Śiva, preceded by the recitation of the aghamarṣaṇa hymn.

column1: hastābhiṣekaṃ kṛtvātha prāyāt pūjādikaṃ budhaḥ /
column2: After having washed the hands the wise person should enter the place of worship.

column1: mūlenābjāsanaṃ kuryāttena pūrakakumbhakān // ātmānaṃ yojayitvordhvaṃ śikhānte dvādaśāṅgule / saṃśoṣya dagdhvā svatanuṃ plāvayedamṛtena ca //
column2: One has to sit in the padmāsana crossed legs and do the pūraka and kumbhaka forms of breathing with the repetition of the principal mantra. One has to yoke one’s soul twelve inches above the tuft, dry up and burn one’s body and flood it with ambrosia.

column1: dhmātvā divyaṃ vapustasminnātmānañca punarnayet /
column2: After having contemplated the divine body in that body one has to lead one’s soul again there.

column1: kṛtvevaṃ cātmaśuddhiḥ syādvinyasyārcanamārabhet //
column2: One will be purifying one’s self by doing thus.

column1: kramāt kṛṣṇasitaśyāmaraktapītā nagādayaḥ / mantrārṇā daṇḍināṅgāni teṣu sarvāstu mūrtayaḥ //
column2: After having located the mantras on the limbs one has to commence the worship. The limbs should be touched by the preceptor with the letters of the mantra such as naga etc. of the colours black, white, darkblue, red and yellow.

column1: aṅguṣṭhādikaniṣṭhāntaṃ vinyasyāṅgāni sarvataḥ / nyasenmantrākṣaraṃ pādaguhyahṛdvaktramūrdhasu //
column2: The images of all the gods should be located in all the limbs beginning with the thumb and ending with the little finger. The letters of the mantra should be located on the feet, genital organ, heart, face and head.

column1: vyāpakaṃ nyasya mūrdhādi mūlamaṅgāni vinyaset /
column2: After having caused the principal mantra to pervade the head etc., one should locate the auxiliaries.

column1: raktapītaśyāmasitān pīṭhapādān svakālajān // svāṅgānmantrair nyasedgātrāṇyadharmādīni dikṣu ca /
column2: The four feet of the pedestal having red, yellow, black and white colours in the angular points, the different limbs, the bodies and unrighteousness etc.

column1: tatra padmañca suryādimaṇḍale tritayaṃ guṇān //
column2: One should worship therein the lotus, the three orbs such as the Sun and the three qualities.

column1: pūrvādipatre kāmādyā navakaṃ karṇikopari /
column2: on the petals of the lotus beginning with the east. The ninth one should be worshipped on the filament.

column1: vāmā jyeṣṭhā kramādraudro kālī kalavikāriṇī // balavikāriṇī cārtha balapramathanī tathā / sarvabhūtadamanī ca navamī ca manonmanī // śvetā raktā sitā pītā śyāmā vahninibhāṣitā /
column2: The nine energies Vāmā, Jyeṣṭhā, Raudrī, Kālī, Kalavikāriṇī, Balavikāriṇī, Balapramathanī, Sarvabhūtadamanī and Manonmanī respectively of the colours white, red, white, yellow, darkblue, golden, black, black and light red, of the form of glowing light should duly be remembered.

column1: kṛṣṇāruṇāś ca tāḥ śaktīrjvālārūpāḥ smaret kramāt // anantayogapīṭhāya āvāhyātha hṛdabjataḥ / sphaṭikābhaṃ caturvāhuṃ phalaśūladharaṃ śivam // sābhayaṃ varadaṃ pañcavadaṃnañca trilocanam /
column2: After having invoked Lord Śiva of the colour of crystal, having four arms, bearing the plough and trident, offering protection and conferring boons, having five faces and three eyes, from the lotus of the heart to the infinite yogic base the images of the five forms such as the Tatpuruṣa and other of Lord Śiva should be established on the petals.

column1: pūrve tatpuruṣaḥ śveto aghoro 'ṣṭabhujo 'sitāḥ /
column2: Tatpuruṣa, white in colour is placed in the east. Aghora of black complexion and having eight hands should be located in the south.

column1: caturvāhumukhaḥ pītāḥ sadyojātaś ca paścime //
column2: Sadyojāta of yellow complexion and having four hands and four faces should be placed in the west.

column1: vāmadevaḥ strīvilāsī caturvaktrabhujo 'ruṇaḥ /
column2: Vāmadeva of light red colour and of the nature of sporting with women and having four faces and four hands should be located in the north.

column1: saumye pañcāsya īśāne īśānaḥ sarvadaḥ sitaḥ //
column2: Īśāna, the conferer of all things, having white complexion and five faces, should be located in the northeast.

column1: iṣṭāṅgāni yathānyāyamanantaṃ sūkṣmamarcayet /
column2: After having worshipped duly the limbs, one has to worship the subtle Ananta.

column1: siddheśvaraṃ tvekanetraṃ pūrvādau diśa pūjayet // ekarudraṃ trinetrañca śrīkaṇṭhañca śikhaṇḍinam /
column2: One should worship Lords Siddheśvara having a single eye, Ekarudra having three eyes, Śrīkaṇṭḥa wearing the peacock’s tail in the directions of east etc.

column1: aiśānyādividikṣvete vidyeśāḥ kamalāsanāḥ // śvetaḥ pītaḥ sito rakto dhūmro rakto 'ruṇaḥ śitaḥ / śūlāśaniśareśvāsavāhavaś caturānanāḥ //
column2: One has to worship the lords of learning, seated on the lotuses and having white, yellow, white, red, tawny, red, light red and white colours respectively bearing the trident, thunderbolt, arrow, bow and having four faces in the different directions such as the northeast etc.

column1: umā vaṇḍeśanandīśau mahākālo gaṇeśvaraḥ / vṛṣo bhṛṅgariṭiskandānuttarādau prapūjayet // kuliśaṃ śaktidaṇḍau ca khaḍgapāśadhvajau gadāṃ / śūlaṃ cakraṃ yajet padmaṃ pūvvādau devamarcya ca //
column2: The goddess Umā and Lords Caṇḍeśa, Nandīśa, Mahākāla, Gaṇeśvara, Vṛṣa, Bhṛṅgariṭi and Skanda should be worshipped in the directions north etc. After having worshipped the lord, the thunderbolt, club, sword, noose, banner, mace, trident, disc and lotus should be worshipped in the directions beginning with the east.

column1: tato 'dhivāsitaṃ śiṣyaṃ pāyayedgavyapañcakam / ācāntaṃ prokṣye netrāntair netre netreṇa bandhayet //
column2: After rinsing the mouth, he must be sprinkled with water with the mantras relating to the limbs upto the eyes and the eyes should be covered with the recitation of the mantra of the eye.

column1: dvāraṃ praveśayecchipyaṃ maṇḍapasyātha dakṣiṇe / sāsanādikuśāsīnaṃ tatra saṃśodhayedguruḥ //
column2: Then the pupil should be made to enter the door. Then the preceptor should purify the pupil seated on the kuśa grass to the south of the shed together with the seat.

column1: āditattvāni saṃhṛtya paramārthe layaḥ kramāt /
column2: Then the preceptor should withdraw the primary principles of the pupil and duly get him absorbed in the supreme principle.

column1: punarutpādayecchiṣyaṃ sṛṣṭimārgeṇa deśikaḥ // nyāsaṃ śiṣye tataḥ kṛtvā taṃ pradakṣiṇamānayet / paścimadvāramānīya kṣepayet kusumāñjalim //
column2: Then the preceptor should regenerate the pupil by the process of tantric creation. After having located the supreme principle in the pupil, he must be led circumambulating. After bringing him to the western door, the preceptor should make the pupil throw the flowers held in the folded hands.

column1: yasmin patanti puṣpāṇi tannāmādyaṃ vinirdiśet /
column2: On whatever place the flowers fall that name should first be given to the pupil.

column1: pārśveyāgabhuvaḥ khāte kuṇḍe sannabhimekhale // śivāgniṃ janayitveṣṭvā punaḥ śiṣyeṇa cārcayet /
column2: By the side of the sacrificial shed a pit should be dug up in such a way that it has the navel and girdle. The fire of Lord Śiva should be generated and worshipped. It should again be worshipped by the pupil.

column1: dhyānenātmanibhaṃ śiṣyaṃ saṃhṛtya pralayaḥ kramāt //
column2: Then the preceptor should absorb the pupil in his own self after contemplation by means of the process of dissolution.

column1: punarutpādya tatpāṇau dadyāddarbhāṃś ca mantritān /
column2: Again regenerating him, darbha grass consecrated with the repetition of mantras should be placed in his hand.

column1: pṛthivyādīni tattvāni juhuyāddhṛdayādibhiḥ //
column2: The principles such as the earth and others should be offered to the fire with the repetition of the mantras of the heart and others.

column1: ekaikasya śataṃ hutvā vyomamūlena homayet /
column2: After having offered hundred oblations for each one of the principles, one should do oblation with the principal mantra of the principle of sky.

column1: hutvā pūrṇāhutiṃ kuryādastreṇāṣṭāhutīrhunet //
column2: After having offered the final oblation, one should offer eight oblations with the mantra of the weapon.

column1: prāyaścittaṃ viśuddhyarthaṃ tataḥ śeṣaṃ samāpayet /
column2: After having performed the rite of atonement for the sake of purification, it should be completed with the residual offering.

column1: kumbhaṃ samantritaṃ prārcya śiśuṃ pīṭhe 'bhiṣecayet // śiṣye tu samayaṃ datvā svarṇādyaiḥ svaguruṃ yajet /
column2: Then a consecrated pitcher should be worshipped well and the pupil bathed on the seat. Then the preceptor should instruct the pupil in the ceremonial practice and the pupil should pay respect to his preceptor by offering gold and other things.

column1: dīkṣā pañcākṣarasyoktā viṣṇvāderevameva hi //
column2: Thus the initiation into the five syllables relating to god Viṣṇu and others has been narrated.

column1: japan vai pañcapañcāśadviṣṇunāmāni yo naraḥ / mantrajapyādiphalabhāk tīrtheṣvarcādi cākṣayam //
column2: A person who repeats the fiftyfive names of Lord Viṣṇu would get the fruits of repeating the mantras and the worship with these names at the sacred places of pilgrimage would have undiminishing fruits.

column1: puṣkare puṇḍarīkākṣaṃ gayāyāñca gadādharam / rāghavañcitrakūṭe tu prabhāse daityasūdanam //
column2: Puṇḍarīkākṣa lotuseyed should be contemplated at Puṣkara, Gadādhara one who wields the club at Gayā, Rāghava Rāma as the scion of Raghu at Citrakūṭa and Daityasūdana the destroyer of the demons at Prabhāsa.

column1: jayaṃ jayantyāṃ tadvacca jayantaṃ hastināpure / vārāhaṃ vardhamāne ca kāśmīre cakrapāṇinam //
column2: Similarly Jaya the victor should be worshipped at Jayantī, Jayanta one who gains victory at Hastināpura, Vārāha manifestation as boar at Vardhamāna and Cakrapāṇi one who holds the disc at Kāśmīra.

column1: janārdanañca kubjāmre mathurāyāñca keśavam / kubjāmrake hṛṣīkeśaṃ gaṅgādvāre jaṭādharam //
column2: One should contemplate Janārdana one that removes the difficulties of people at Kubjāmra, Keśava at Mathurā, Hṛṣīkeśa lord of the senses at Kubjāmra and Jaṭādhara one who bears the matted hair at the place where the Ganges enters the plains.

column1: śālagrāme mahāyogaṃ hariṃ gobardhanācale / piṇḍārake caturvāhuṃ śaṅkhoddhāre ca śaṅkhinam //
column2: One should contemplate Mahāyoga one who ardently practises Yoga at Śālagrāma, Hari at the Govardhana mountain, Caturbāhu one having four arms at Piṇḍāraka and Śaṅkhin the holder of the conch at Śaṅkhadvāra..

column1: vāmanañca kurukṣetre yamunāyāṃ trivikramam / viśveśvaraṃ tathā śoṇe kapilaṃ pūrvasāgare //
column2: Vāmana the Dwarf manifestation is worshipped at Kurukṣetra, Trivikrama the conqueror of three worlds at the river Yamunā, Viśveśvara the lord of the universe at the river Śoṇā and Kapila propounder of the Sāṅkhya philosophy on the banks of the eastern ocean.

column1: viṣṇuṃ mahodadhau vidyādgaṅgāsāgarasaṅgame / vanamālañca kiṣkindhyāṃ devaṃ raivatakaṃ viduḥ //
column2: One should repeat the name of Viṣṇu on the shore of the great ocean at the confluence of the river Ganges with the ocean, Vanamāla the bearer of garland of wild flowers at Kiṣkindhā and Deva lord at Raivataka.

column1: kāśītaṭe mahāyogaṃ virajāyāṃ ripuñjayam / viśākhayūpe hy ajitannepāle lokabhāvanam //
column2: Mahāyoga the great yoga is contemplated at Kāśī, Ripuñjaya the conqueror of enemies at Vīrajā, Ajita the unconquered at Viśākhayūpa and Lokabhāvana the creator of the world at Nepāla.

column1: dvārakāyāṃ viddhi kṛṣṇaṃ mandare madhusūdanam / lokākule ripuharaṃ śālagrāme hariṃ smaret //
column2: One should know that one has to repeat the name Kṛṣṇa at Dvārakā, Madhusūdana the slayer of the demon Madhu at Mandara mountain and Ripuhara the destroyer of enemies at Lokākula and one should think of Hari at Śālagrāma.

column1: puruṣaṃ pūruṣavaṭe vimale ca jagatprabhuṃ / anantaṃ saindhavāraṇye daṇḍake śārṅgadhāriṇam //
column2: One should repeat the name Puruṣa the Supreme person at Puruṣavaṭa, Jagatprabhu the lord of the world at Vimala, Ananta the endless at the Saindhava forest and Śārṅgadhārin the wielder of the bow at Daṇḍaka forest.

column1: utpalāvartake śaurīṃ narmadāyāṃ śriyaḥ patiṃ / dāmodaraṃ raivatake nandāyāṃ jalaśāyinaṃ //
column2: Śauri the hero should be contemplated at the whirlpool called Utpala, Śriyaḥpati the consort of Lakṣmī at the river Narmadā, Dāmodara having the enlarged belly at Raivataka and Jalaśāyin one who reclines on the water at Nandā.

column1: gopīśvarañca sindhvavdhau māhendre cācyutaṃ viṭuḥ / sahādrau devadeveśaṃ vaikuṇṭhaṃ māgadhe vane //
column2: It is known that one has to repeat the name Gopīśvara on the shore of the Sindhu ocean, Acyuta unswerving at Māhendra hill, Devadeveśa the lord of gods at the Sahya mountain and Vaikuṇṭha one who has united the earth etc., at the Māgadha forest.

column1: sarvapāpaharaṃ vindhye auḍre tu puruṣottamam /
column2: One should repeat the name Sarvapāpahara Destroyer of all sins at the Vindhya mountain and Puruṣottama the foremost among men in the region of Oḍhra.

column1: ātmānaṃ hṛdaye viddhi japatāṃ bhuktimuktidam //
column2: One should know the universal soul residing in one’s heart. The recitation of these names confers enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: vaṭe vaṭe vaiśravaṇaṃ catvare catvare śivam / parvate parvate rāmaṃ sarvatra madhusūdanaṃ //
column2: One has to contemplate the Vaiśravaṇa the great fig tree at every fig tree, Lord Śiva the auspicious at every quadrangle, Rāma on every mountain and Madhusūdana the slayer of the demon Madhu everywhere.

column1: naraṃ bhūmau tathā vyomni vaśiṣṭhe garuḍadhvajam / vāsudevañca sarvatra saṃsmaran bhuktimuktibhāk //
column2: One who contemplates the Supreme spirit on the earth and sky, the god having eagle in the banner in the great sage Vasiṣṭha and Vāsudeva epithet of Kṛṣṇa everywhere would get enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: nāmānyetāni viṣṇīś ca japtvā sarvamavāpnuyāt /

To the conqueror! Protect! Oṃ be firm by the command of Goddess Tvaritā vaṣaṭ! This is the incantation known as Tvaritā.

column1: saptābhimantritañcānnaṃ bhuñjaṃstasya śriyaḥ sadā //
column2: A person who eats food that has been charmed seven times with the above would always get fortune.

column1: ardhanārīśarūpo 'yaṃ lakṣmyādivaiṣṇavādikaḥ / anaṅgarūpā śaktiś ca dvitīyā madanāturā //
column2: This mantra is a form of Ardhanārīśa hermaphrodite form of lord Śiva, as well as Goddess Lakṣmī, lord Viṣṇu and others.

column1: pavanavegā bhuvanapālā vai savvasiddhidā / anaṅgamadanānaṅgamekhalāntāñcapecchriye //
column2: One has to repeat the mantras of Goddesses Anaṅgarūpā, Madanāturā, Pavanavegā, Bhuvanapālā, Sarvasiddhidā, Anaṅgamadanā and Anaṅgamekhalā for gaining fortune.

column1: padmamadhyadaleṣu hrīṃ svarān kādīṃstitaḥ striyāḥ / ṣaṭkoṇe vā ghaṭe vātha likhitvā syādvaśīkaraṃ //
column2: The syllable hrīṃ, the vowels and the letters ka etc. should be written at the centre and on the petals of a lotus or on a hexagon or on a pot. A person that looks at women after doing thus would captivate the women.

column1: mūlamantraḥ ṣaḍaṅgaoyaṃ raktavarṇe trikoṇake / dravaṇī hlādakāriṇī kṣobhiṇī guruśaktikā // īśānādau ca madhye tāṃ nityāṃ pāśāṅkuśau tathā / kapālakalpakataruṃ vīṇā raktā ca tadvatī //
column2: Oṃ, hrīṃ, chūṃ, O Nityaklinnā ever moist! O Madadravā one who exudes intoxicating fluid! Oṃ, Oṃ. This principal mantra after location on the six limbs the two shanks, two arms, head and middle and then written on redcoloured triangle and worn on the body would have great power to melt the heart, make happy and agitate.

column1: nityābhayā maṅgalā ca navavīrā ca maṅgalā / durbhagā manonmanī pūjyā drāvā pūrvāditaḥ sthitā //
column2: Goddesses Nityā, Abhayā, Maṅgalā, Navavīrā, Maṅgalā ?, Durbhagā, Manonmanī and Drāvā should be worshipped in the directions commencing with the east.

column1: manmathāya ca mārāya kāmāyaivañca pañcadhā / kāmāḥ pāśāṅkuśau cāpavāṇāḥ dhyeyāś ca vibhrataḥ // ratiś ca viratiḥ prītirviprītiś ca matirdhṛtiḥ /
column2: The five forms of God of love should be contemplated as holding a noose, goad, bow and arrows and as in the union of Rati Goddess of love and her companions Vīrati nonattachment, Prīti pleasure, Viprīti displeasure, Mati thought, Dhṛti firmness, Vidhṛti ficklemindedness, and Puṣṭi nourishment.

column1: vidhṛtiḥ puṣṭirebhiś ca kramāt kāmādikair yutāḥ / ādhāraśaktiṃ padmañca siṃhe devīṃ hṛdādiṣu //
column2: Oṃ, chaṃ oblations to Nityaklinnā and Madadravā, The energy of support and the lotus should be worshipped on the lion and the Goddess in the heart and other limbs.

column1: tvaritāṃ pūjayennyasya dvibhujāñcāṣṭavāhukāṃ /
column2: After doing the nyāsa location of the mantra Goddess Tvaritā possessing two or eight arms should be worshipped.

column1: ādhāraśaktiṃ padmañca siṃhe devīṃ hṛdādikam //
column2: The energy of support and lotus should be worshipped in a diagram of a lion and the Goddess and the heart etc.

column1: pūrvādau gāyatrīṃ yajenmaṇḍale vai praṇītayā /
column2: Gāyatrī persanification of the mantra should be worshipped in a circle in the east and other directions showing the praṇītā mudrā.

column1: huṃkārāṃ khecarīṃ caṇḍāṃ chedanīṃ kṣepaṇīṃ striyāḥ //
column2: The Goddesses Huṃkārā, Khecarī, Caṇḍā, Chedanī and Kṣepaṇī should also be worshipped.

column1: huṃkārāṃ kṣemakārīñca phaṭkārīṃ madhyato yajet /
column2: Hūṃkārā, Kṣemakārī and Phaṭkārī should be worshipped at the centre.

column1: jayāñca vijayāṃ dvāri kiṅkarañca tadagrataḥ //
column2: Jayā and Vijayā should be worshipped at the entrance. The servant should be worshipped in front of them.

column1: lilaihīmaiś ca sarvāptyai nāmavyāhṛtibhis tathā /
column2: One should do oblations with sesamum with the repetition of the vyāhṛtis in order to get all things.

column1: anantāya namaḥ svāhā kulikāya namaḥ svadhā //
column2: Obeisance to Ananta! Oblations. Obeisance to Kalikā! Svadhā.

column1: svāhā vāsukirājāya śaṅkhapālāya vauṣaṭ /
column2: Oblations to King Vāsuki. Vauṣaṭ to Śaṅkhapāla.

column1: takṣakāya vaṣannityaṃ mahāpadmāya vai namaḥ //
column2: Vaṣaṭ to Takṣaka always. Obeisance to Mahāpadma.

column1: svāhā karkoṭanāgāya phaṭ padmāya ca vai namaḥ /
column2: Oblations to Karkoṭanāga phaṭ. Obeisance to Padma.

column1: likhennigrahacakrantu ekāśītipadair naraḥ //
column2: The diagram of nigrahacakra the magic circle that causes obstruction should be drawn on one’s clothes, or a piece of cloth or on the body, or the birchbark leaf or on a slab or on staffs.

column1: vaste paṭe tarau bhūrje śilāyāṃ yaṣṭikāsu ca / madhye koṣṭhe sādhyanāma pūrvādau paṭṭikāsu ca // aiśādāvambupādau ca yamarājyañca vāhyataḥ /
column2: The name of the sādhya the object to be accomplished, namely, the enemy should be written in the middle chamber and the syllables oṃ, hrīṃ, kṣūṃ on the chambers on the east and other directions. The thorns and Kālarātrikā should be written in the northeast, west etc. and lord Yama the lord of death outside.

column1: kālīnāravamālī kālīnāmākṣamālinī //
column2: kālīnāravamālī kālīnāmākṣamālinī

column1: māmodetattadomomā rakṣata svasva bhakṣavā /
column2: māmodetattadomomā rakṣata svasva bhakṣavā

column1: yamapāṭaṭayāmaya maṭamo ṭaṭa moṭamā //
column2: yamapāṭaṭayāmaya maṭamo ṭaṭa moṭamā

column1: vāmo bhūrivibhūmeyā ṭaṭa rīśva śvarī ṭaṭa /
column2: vāmo bhūrivibhūmeyā ṭaṭa rīśva śvarī ṭaṭa

column1: yamarājādvāhyato vaṃ taṃ toyaṃ māraṇātmakaṃ //
column2: The syllable vaṃ should be located outside the chamber of lord Yama and the syllable taṃ that has the potency to kill.

column1: kajjalaṃ nimbaniryāsamajjāsṛgviṣasaṃyutam / kākapakṣasya lekhanyā śmaśāne vā catuṣpathe // nidhāpayet kumbhādhastādvalmīke vātha nikṣipet /
column2: The above verse should be written with crow’s quill at the cremation ground or the junction of four roads with a mixture of lamp soot, the resin of neem, marrow, blood, poison, charcoal, and piṅgaladhārā ? and placed under a pitcher. Otherwise it should be placed in an anthill.

column1: vibhītadrumaśāsvādho yantraṃ sarvārimardanam //
column2: The spell placed under a bibhītaka tree is capable of destroying all the enemies.

column1: likheccānugrahañcakraṃ śuklapatre 'tha bhūrjake / lākṣayā kuṅkumenātha sphaṭikācandanena vā //
column2: The anugrahacakra a circular figure that confers grace should be written on a white leaf or on the bhūrja bark with shellac or saffron or red sandal.

column1: bhuvi bhittau pūrvadale nāma madhyamakoṣṭhake /
column2: The name of the enemy should be written in the central chamber on the earth and the wall.

column1: khaṇḍe tu vārimadhyasthaṃ oṃ haṃso vāpi paṭṭiśam //
column2: The mantra Oṃ haṃsa and the paṭṭiśa a kind of spear should be written in the region of the west.

column1: lakṣmīślokaṃ śivādau ca rākṣasādikramāllikhet /
column2: The charm of Goddess Lakṣmī and Śiva and others should be written in the northwest etc.

column1: śrīḥsāmamomā sā śrīḥ sānau yājñe jñeyā nausā //
column2: śrīḥ sāmamomā sā śrīḥ sānau yājñe jñeyā nausā

column1: māyā līlā lālī yāmā yājñe jñeyā nausā māyā /
column2: māyā līlā lālī yāmā yājñe jñeyā nausā māyā

column1: yatra jñeyā vahiḥ śīghrā dikṣuraṃ kalasaṃ vahiḥ //
column2: Śīghrā is outside where jñeyā is placed. The syllable raṃ is in the different direction.

column1: padmasthaṃ padmacakrañca bhṛtyujit svargagandhṛtiṃ /
column2: The wheel of lotus on a lotus figure would conquer death, convey a person to heaven and give firmness.

column1: śāntīnāṃ paramā sāntiḥ saubhāgyādipradāyakam //
column2: It is the foremost appeasing rite among such rites. It confers fortune etc.

column1: rudre rudrasamāḥ kāryāḥ koṣṭhakāstatra tā likhet /
column2: In the wheel known as Rudra, there should be chambers of the number of Rudras i.e.

column1: omādyāhrūṃphaḍantā ca ādivarṇamathānutaḥ // vidyāvarṇakrameneva saṃjñāñca vaṣaḍantikāṃ /
column2: That mantra should be written therein beginning with the syllable oṃ and ending with hrūṃ phaṭ, the first letters of the vidyā being written at the end.

column1: adhasthāt pratyaṅgiraiṣā sarvakāmārthasādhikā //
column2: This is known as the pratyaṅgirā which accomplishes all the desired objects.

column1: ekāśītipade sarvāmādivarṇakrameṇa tu / ādimaṃ yāvadantaṃ syādvaṣaḍantañca nāma vai //
column2: In a circle having eightyone chambers, the first letters of the vidyā should be located such that they would be from the beginning to the end and the name of the enemy should be added ending with vaṣaṭ.

column1: eṣā pratyaṅgirā cānyā sarvakāryādisādhanī /
column2: This is known as a different pratyaṅgirā vidyā which would accomplish all tasks.

column1: nigrahānugrahañcakrañcatuḥṣaṣṭipadair likhet //
column2: The nigraha and anugraha obstruction and grace circles should be drawn to have sixtyfour chambers.

column1: amṛtī sā ca vidyā ca krīṃ saḥ hūṃ nāmātha madhyataḥ /
column2: This is known as amṛtī vidyā reviving.

column1: phaṭkārādyāṃ patragatāṃ trihrīṃkāreṇa veṣṭayet //
column2: The syllables krīṃ saḥ hūṃ with the name of the enemy at the centre and the syllable phaṭ at the beginning written on a leaf should be encircled by three syllables of hrīṃ.

column1: kumbhavavaddhāritā sarvaśatruhṛt sarvadāyikā /
column2: This charm worn with a mark of a pitcher will kill all enemies and yield all things.

column1: viṣannaśyet karṇajapādakṣarādyaiś ca daṇḍakaiḥ //
column2: If this mantra is repeated in the ear letter by letter or as a daṇḍaka a group of letters, it would destroy poison.

column1: stambhanaṃ mohanaṃ vaśyaṃ vidveṣoccāṭanaṃ vade / viṣavyādhimarogañca māraṇaṃ śamanaṃ punaḥ //
column2: shall describe to you the mantras and acts relating to paralysing , stupefying , captivating , ruining the enemy , neutralising the effects of poison and diseases and causing the death of an enemy .

column1: bhūrje kūrmaṃ samālikhya tāḍanena ṣaḍṅgulam / mukhapādacaturṣkeṣu tato mantraṃ nyaseddvijaḥ //
column2: A twiceborn should draw the figure of a tortoise of six inches length on a birchbark by the act of tāḍana and then locate the mantra on the face and four feet.

column1: catuṣpādeṣu krīṃ kāraṃ hrīṃ kāraṃ mukhamadhyataḥ / garbhe vidyāṃ tato likhya sādhakaṃ pṛṣṭhato likhet //
column2: The syllable krīṃ should be written on the four feet, the syllable hrīṃ at the centre of the face, the vidyā mantras on the belly and the name of the person concerned on the back.

column1: mālāmantraistu saṃveṣṭya iṣṭakopari sannyamet /
column2: After having encircled it with the mālāmantras garland of letters, it should be placed over a brick.

column1: vidhāya kūrmapṛṣṭhena karālenābhisampaṭhenat //
column2: It should then be covered with the back of a tortoise and then charmed with the karāla mantra.

column1: mahākūrmaṃ pūjayitvā pādaprokṣantu nikṣipet /
column2: After having worshipped the great tortoise manifestation of Viṣṇu, the votary should sprinkle water on the feet of that form.

column1: tāḍayedvāmapādena smṛtvā śatruñca saptadhā //
column2: After having thought of the enemy, the votary should kick seven times on the ground with the left foot of the toroise .

column1: tataḥ sañjāyate śatrostambhanaṃ mukharāgataḥ / kṛtvā tu bhairavaṃ rūpaṃ mālāmantraṃ samālikhet //
column2: It would cause paralysis to the enemy. One should assume a terrible form by having change in the complexion of the face and write the garland of mantras.

column1: phaṭ hetuñca samālikhya tajjapāntaṃ mahābalaṃ /
column2: Oṃ! One who paralyses the face of the enemy! An embodiment of desire! One that stands with arm discharging an arrow! Hrīṃ pheṃ, Phetkariṇī ! Paralyse the face of my enemies given by the gods! Paralyse the face of all my enemies! Oṃ, hūṃ, pheṃ, Phetkāriṇī! Oblations! Phaṭ! After having written the mantra, one would gain great strength at the end of its repetition.

column1: vāmenaiva nagaṃ śūlaṃ saṃlikheddakṣiṇe kare // likhenmantramaghorasya saṃgrāme stambhayedarīn /
column2: One should draw the figure of a tree and the trident on the right hand with the left hand. The mantra of lord Aghora a form of Śiva should then be written. One would paralyse the enemies in the battle.

column1: etena rocanādyaistu tilakāmmohayejjagat //
column2: One who wears a mask with the resin with the repetition of this mantra would stupefy the world.

column1: anena tilakaṃ kṛtvā rājādīnāṃ vaśīkaraṃ /
column2: One would captivate the king and others by making a forehead mark with this mantra.

column1: gardhabhasya rajo gṛhya kusumaṃ sūtakasya ca // nārīrajaḥ kṣipedrātrau śayyādau dveṣakṛdbhavet /
column2: The dust under the feet of a donkey mixed with the sūtaka fluid and the menstrual blood of a woman should be thrown on the bed of a person in the night.

column1: gokhurañca tathā śṛṅgamaśvasya ca khuraṃ tathā // śiraḥ sarpasya saṃkṣiptaṃ hṛheṣūccāṭanaṃ bhavet /
column2: The hoof and horn of a cow, the hoof of a horse and the head of a serpent charmed as before and thrown into the house of a person would cause the ruin of the enemy.

column1: karavīraśiphā pītā sasiddhārthā ca maraṇe //
column2: The root of the yellow karavīra together with mustard would be potent to cause death.

column1: saraṭaṃ ṣaṭpadañcāpi tathā karkaṭavṛścikam //
column2: The blood of a serpent and a muskrat together with karavīra would also produce similar result.

column1: cūrṇīkṛtya kṣipettaile tadabhyaṅgaś ca kuṣṭhakṛt /
column2: A lizard, bee, crab and scorpion are ground well and thrown into oil. One who anoints with that oil would get leprosy.

column1: anenārkaśatair arcya śmaśāne tu nidhāpayet //
column2: After having worshipped the planets with hundreds of arka flowers, this should be placed in a cremation ground.

column1: bhūrje vā pratimāyāṃ vā māraṇāya riporgrahāḥ /
column2: The planets should be drawn on a birchbark or in an image for the ruin of the enemies.

column1: bhūrje nāma riporlikhya śmaśāne pūjite mriyet //
column2: After having written the name of the enemy on a birchbark, if it is worshipped in the cremation ground, the foe would die.

column1: ādau hūṃkārasaṃyuktā khecache padabhūṣitā / vargātītavisargeṇa hrīṃ hūṃkṣepaphaḍantakā //
column2: The syllable hūṃ is at the beginning. Then the letters khe, ca, che, and the visarga that is outside the group of consonants are added. It ends with strīṃ, hūṃ, kṣepa and phaṭ.

column1: sarvakarmakarī vidyā viṣasandhādimardanī /
column2: This vidyā is known as subduing all things.

column1: oṃ kṣecachetiprayogaś ca kāladaṣṭasya jīvane // oṃ hūṃ kekṣaḥ prayogoyaṃ viṣaśatrupramardanaḥ /
column2: It also destroys the poisons of serpents. Oṃ, khe, che should be practised to revive a person bitten by a deadly serpent. Oṃ, hūṃ, ke, kṣaḥ should be used to destroy poison and enemies.

column1: strīṃ hūṃ phaḍitiyogoyaṃ pāparogādikaṃ jayet //
column2: Strīṃ, hūṃ, phaṭ is the mantra to be used for conquering sins and diseases etc.

column1: khecheti ca prayogo 'yaṃ vighnaduṣṭādi vārayet /
column2: The application of khe, strīṃ, khe, cha should be used for captivating and conquest.

column1: hrūṃ strīṃ omitiyogo 'yaṃ yoṣidādivaśīkaraḥ // khe strīṃ khe ca prayogo 'yaṃ vaśāya vijayāya ca /
column2: Aiṃ, hrīṃ, śrīṃ, spheṃ, kaiṃ, kṣauṃ, Bhagavatī! Ambikā! Kubjikā! spheṃ, oṃ, bhaṃ, taṃ subjugate. Obeisance to Aghora on the face! Brāṃ, brāṃ, kili, kili, viccā, sphauṃ, heṃ, sphūṃ, śrauṃ, hrīṃ, aiṃ, śrīṃ.

column1: bhūyaḥ skandāya yānāha mantrānīśaś ca tān vade //
column2: shall describe to you again the mantras narrated by lord Īśa Śiva to lord Skanda.

column1: sakalaṃ niṣkalaṃ śūnyaṃ kalāḍhyaṃ svamalaṅkṛtam / kṣapaṇaṃ kṣayamantasthaṃ kaṇṭhoṣṭhaṃ cāṣṭamaṃ śivam //
column2: The mantras of Śiva are divided into eight kinds, such as sakala endowed with parts, niṣkala without parts, śūnya void, kalāḍhya abounding in parts, khamalaṅkṛta adorning the sky, kṣapaṇa suppressing, kṣaya destroying and śiva benevolent.

column1: prāsādasya parākhyasya smṛtaṃ rūpaṃ guhāṣṭadhā /
column2: The letters which lay inside and belong to the regions of the throat and lips should be present in them.

column1: sadāśivasya śabdasya rūpasyākhilasiddhaye //
column2: The form of the word Sadāśiva is efficacious for accomplishing all things.

column1: amṛtaścāṃśubhāṃścenduśceśvaraścogra ūhakaḥ / ekapādena ojākhya auṣadhaścāṃśumān vaśī //
column2: The forms of the vowels are Amṛta, Aṃśumat, Indu, Īśvara, Ugra, Ūhaka, Ekapāda, Oja and Auṣadha. Aṃśumat among these is capable of subjugating.

column1: kāmadevaḥ śikhaṇḍī ca gaṇeśaḥ kālaśaṅkarau // ekanetro dvinetraś ca triśikho dīrghabāhukaḥ / ekapādardhacandraś ca balapo yoginīpriyaḥ // śaktīśvaro mahāgranthistarpakaḥ sthāṇudanturau / nidhīśo nandī padmaś ca tathānyaḥ śākinīpriyaḥ //
column2: The forms of the letters ka to kṣa are Kāmadeva, Śikhaṇḍī, Gaṇeśa, Kāla, Śaṅkara, Ekanetra, Dvinetra, Triśikha, Dīrghabāhuka, Ekapād, Arddhacandra, Balapa, Yoginīpriya, Śaktīśvara, Mahāgranthi, Tarpaka, Sthāṇu, Dantura, Nidhīśa, Nandī, Padma, Śākinīpriya, Mukhabimba, Bhīṣaṇa, Kṛtānta, Prāṇa, Tejasvī, Śakra, Udadhi, Śrīkaṇṭha, Siṃha, Śaśāṃka, Viśvarūpa and Narasiṃha representing kṣa.

column1: sūryamātrāsamākrāntaṃ viśvarūpantu kārayet //
column2: The syllable of Viśvarūpa should be made to be pervaded by the syllables of Sūrya Sun.

column1: aṃśumatsaṃyutaṃ kṛtvā śaśivījaṃ vināyutam / īśānamojasākrāntaṃ prathamantu samuddharet //
column2: After having coupled the syllable of Śaśi Moon with Aṃśumat, the syllable of Īśāna pervaded by the syllable of Ojas should first be raised up.

column1: tṛtīyaṃ puruṣaṃ viddhi dakṣiṇaṃ pañcamaṃ tathā / saptamaṃ vāmadevantu sadyojātantataḥparaṃ //
column2: Among the above names, the third should be known as TatPuruṣa, the fifth as Dakṣiṇa, the seventh as Vāmadeva, the next one as Sadyojāta and the ninth as coupled with the rasa bīja.

column1: rasayuktantu navamaṃ brahmapañcapañcakamīritam /
column2: This is known as the brahmapañcaka the five brahmans.

column1: oṃkārādyāś caturthyantā namontāḥ sarvamantrakāḥ //
column2: All the mantras begin with the syllable oṃ and end with the name in the fourth case and obeisance.

column1: sadyodevā dvitīyantu hṛdayañcāṅgasaṃyutam /
column2: The first one is presided over by Sadyojāta. The second one is the heart together with the subordinate one.

column1: caturthantu śiro viddhi īśvarannāmanāmataḥ //
column2: The fourth should be known as the head known by the name Īśvara.

column1: ūhakantu śikhā jñeyā viśvarūpasamanvitā /
column2: Ūhaka should be known as the tuft endowed with Viśvarūpa.

column1: tanmantramaṣṭamaṃ khyātaṃ netrantu daśamaṃ matam //
column2: Its mantra is known to be the eighth. The eye is considered as the tenth.

column1: astraṃ śaśī samākhyātaṃ śivasaṃjñaṃ śikhidhyajaḥ / namaḥ svāhā tathā vauṣat hūṃ ca phatkakrameṇa tu //
column2: O Śikhidhvaja Kumāra, having peacock as the banner! The weapon is said to be the Moon known as Śiva. Obeisance, oblation, vauṣaṭ, hūṃ and phaṭka is the order.

column1: jātiphaṭkaṃ hṛdādīnāṃ prāsādaṃ mantramāvade /
column2: shall describe the prāsāda mantra the benevolent one relating to the heart etc.

column2: belonging to phaṭka. One should raise the syllable known as Rudra from Īśāna adorned with Aṃśu that remains above the group in the region of head pervaded by Auṣadha. It has halfcrescent nāda nasal sound upwards having two dots in the middle.

column1: tadante viśvarūpantu kuṭilantu tridhā tataḥ /
column2: Viśvarūpa is at the end bent thrice.

column1: evaṃ prāsādamantraś ca sarvakarmakaro manuḥ //
column2: This is the prāsāda mantra capable of accomplishing all the things. la.

column1: śikhāvījaṃ samuddhṛtya phaṭkārāntantu caiva phaṭ / ardhacandrāsanaṃ jñeyaṃ kāmadevaṃ sasarpakam // mahāpāśupatāstrantu sarvaduṣṭapramardanam /
column2: After having raised the syllables of the tuft ending with the syllable phaṭ placed on the half crescent, it is known as Kāmadeva that flows and is verily the great Pāśupata weapon that destroys all evils.

column1: prāsādaḥ sakalaḥ prokto niṣkalaḥ procyate 'dhunā //
column2: have described the prāsāda mantra endowed with parts. will describe the mantra without parts now.

column2: This consists of Auṣadha, Viśvarūpa, Rudra, orb of Sun, coupled with nāda of the form of halfmoon, without designation and bent. The niṣkala mantra confers enjoyment and emancipation.

column1: niṣkalo bhuktimuktau syātpañcāṅgo 'yaṃ sadāśivaḥ /
column2: It is always benevolent because it is endowed with five parts.

column1: vighnanāśāya bhavati pūjito bālabāliśaiḥ //
column2: It destroys obstacles when worshipped by boys and ignorant men.

column2: The khamalaṅkṛta consists of Narasiṃha mantras situated in Kṛtānta pervading above the radiant life force, coupled with Aṃśumat and pervaded by Ūhaka above and below.

column1: candrārdhanādanādāntaṃ brahmaviṣṇuvibhūśita /
column2: It is composed of halfmoon nāda adorned by Brahmā and Viṣṇu.

column1: udadhiṃ narasiṃhañca sūryamātrāvibheditam //
column2: The Udadhi mantras and Narasiṃha should be divided with the vowels of Sūrya.

column1: yadā kṛtaṃ tadā tasya brahmāṇyaṅgāni pūrvavat /
column2: The other subsidiary rites should be done as before.

column1: asyārdhaṃ tṛtīyañcaiva pañcamaṃ saptamaṃ tathā //
column2: The third, fifth and seventh would number half of it.

column1: sadyojātantu navamaṃ dvitīyāddhṛdayādikam /
column2: The Sadyojāta would be the ninth, the hṛd and other mantras taken from the second.

column1: daśārṇapraṇavaṃ yattu phaḍantañcāstramuddharet //
column2: The mantras consisting of the above said ten syllables should end with phaṭ.

column1: namaskārayutānyatra brahmāṅgāni tu nānyathā /
column2: The subordinate mantras in the above should be coupled with obeisance. It is not done in any other way.

column1: dvitīyādaṣṭau yāvadaṣṭau vidyeśvarā matāḥ // ananteśaś ca sūkṣmaś ca tṛtīyaś ca śivoktamaḥ / ekamūrcyekarūpastu trimūrtiraparas tathā //
column2: From the second to the eighth are considered as the Vidyeśvaras the lords of the mantrasAnanteśa, Sūkṣma, Śivottama the third, Ekamūrti, Ekarūpa, Trimūrti the next one, Śrīkaṇṭha and Śikhaṇḍī are known to be the eight Vidyeśvaras.

column1: śikhaṇḍino 'pyanantāntaṃ mantrāntaṃ mūrtirīritā //
column2: The ends of the mantras from that of Śikhaṇḍī to the end of Ananta are said to be the embodied form.

column1: viśvarūpaṃ samuddhṛtya tejasyupari saṃsthitam /
column2: The Viśvarūpa syllable should be raised and placed above the Tejas.

column1: narasiṃhaṃ tato 'dhastāt kṛtāntaṃ tadadho nyaset //
column2: Then the Narasiṃha and Kṛtānta are placed below one below the other.

column1: praṇavaṃ tadadhaḥkṛtvā ūhakaṃ tadadhaḥ punaḥ / aṃśumān viśvamūrtisthaṃ kaṇṭhoṣṭhapraṇavādikam //
column2: The praṇava oṃ should be placed below that and the Udaka below that. The Aṃśumat that remains in the Viśvamūrti, the letter of the throat and lip region and the praṇava oṃ should be below that.

column1: namo 'ntaḥ syāccaturvarṇo viśvarūpañca kāraṇam /
column2: The first four letters should end with obeisance.

column2: The syllable oṃ should be raised first and the luminous form without a second one should be repeated.

column1: ghoraghorataraṃ paścāt tatra rūpamataḥ smaret //
column2: The Ghoraghoratara terrible one should be repeated. That form should then be remembered.

column2: After having made the caṭa sound twice, the syllable om should be repeated.
