column2: Then one has to repeat twice ‘burn’ and then twice ‘vama’.

column1: ghātayeti dvidhākṛtya hūṃphaḍantaṃ samuccaret /
column2: After having stated ‘kill’ twice, one should repeat hūṃ phaṭ at the end.

column1: aghorāstrantu netraṃ syād gāyatrī cocyate 'dhunā // tanmaheśāya vidmahe mahādevāya dhīmahi /
column2: This would be the mantra of the weapon for lord Aghora. shall describe the gāyatrī mantra sacred to the same deity now“We know the true self of lord Maheśa.

column1: tatraḥ śivaḥ pracodayāt gāyatrī sarvasādhanī //
column2: May that auspicious god kindle our mind to that.” This gāyatrī mantra is capable of accomplishing all things.

column1: yātrāyāṃ vijayādau ca yajet pūrvaṅgaṇaṃ śriye /

column2: The central lotus should be red. The lotuses outside that should also be red.

column2: A sacrificial pitcher should be worshipped as before.

column2: The mantra made up of syllable of Ūhaka together with that of Kāla added with the letters would be the mantra for the Goddess. O Niṣāda hunter denotes Kumāra! The mantra for Goddess Vāgīśvarī should be used like that of the Moon and Sun.

column1: dhyeyā sarasvatīvacca kapilājyena homakaḥ /
column2: Oblations should be done with clarified butter from the milk of a tawny cow.

column2: One would then become a Saṃskṛta and Prākṛta poet and one who is wellversed in the science of poesy and other things.

column1: sarvato bhadrakānyaṣṭamaṇḍalāni vade guha /

column1: jāyate tatra kartavyaṃ bhadrasvedakaraṃ śubham /

column1: kīṇabandhavicitrantu dvipadaṃ tatra vartayet //

column2: Listen to me! shall describe the mode of drawing a lotus for an occasional rite.

column1: madhye 'bjaṃ paṭṭikāvījaṃ dvāreṇābjasya mānataḥ / kaṇṭhopakaṇṭhamuktāni tadvāhye vīthikā matā //
column2: A lotus should be drawn at the centre having a banner at the centre and a door proportionate in size to that of the lotus. Leaving its neck portion and the adjacent parts, a pathway should be made outside.

column1: pavitrārohaṇādau ca mahāmaṇḍalamālikhet //
column2: One should draw a great circle in connection with the investiture of the sacred thread on the idol etc.

column2: Eight blue lotuses should be marked in the different directions and the spaces in between.

column2: There should be the figure of svastikas above that.

column2: The circle having five lotuses should measure five cubits. It should be wholly divided into ten parts.

column2: The pathway should occupy two chambers of the lotus, and the tablet in one chamber. There should be four lotuses at the cardinal points. There should be a pathway on the rear in one chamber or two chambers.

column2: The doors should be endowed with boundaries and adjacent spaces. There should be a lotus at the centre.

column2: In this circle consisting of five lotuses, the lotus in the east is white and yellow, the lotus in the south is of the hue of lapis lazuli, the lotus in the west is of the colour of jasmine, the lotus in the north is of the colour of a conch and all the rest of varied colour.

column1: sarvakāmapradaṃ vakṣye daśahastantu maṇḍalam /
column2: shall describe a circle of ten cubits which yields all the desires.

column1: vikārabhaktanturyāśraṃ dvārantu dvipadaṃ bhavet //
column2: It should be a foursided one divided into ten parts. The door would occupy two chambers.

column2: As described earlier there should be a lotus at the centre.

column1: caturhastaṃ puraṃ kṛtvā vṛtrañcaiva karadvayam //

column1: hṛdayādīni pūrvādau vidikṣvastrāṇi vai yajet //
column2: The heart and other limbs should be worshipped in the east and other directions.

column2: As before the five Brahmans forms of Śiva should be worshipped. shall describe the support of intellect.

column1: mekhalābhāgasaṃyuktaṃ kaṇṭhaṃ dvipadikaṃ bhavet /
column2: The girdle should occupy a part and the boundary would be in two chambers.

column2: The preceptor should provide decorative festoons etc.

column2: making use of his creative thinking. There are one thousand fourhundred and forty circles for the gods Hari, Śambhu and Sun and the goddess.

column2: Fifteen, one, three and five chambers in the cardinal points should be erased.

column1: madhyena dbipadaṃ padmamatha caikañca paṅkajaṃ //
column2: A lotus should be drawn in two chambers at the centre.

column1: liṅgasya pārśvayorbhadre padadvāramalopanāt /
column2: A lotus should be drawn in one chamber on either side of the liṅga.

column1: tatpārśvaśobhāḥ ṣaḍlopya latāḥ śeṣās tathā hareḥ //
column2: By destroying the six lines of the decorations the remaining would form lines for lord Hari.

column1: ūrdhvaṃ dvipadikaṃ lopya harerbhadrāṣṭakaṃ smṛtam /

column1: pañcaviṃśatikaṃ padmaṃ tataḥ pīṭhamapīṭhakam /
column2: Then the lotus for a seat is made in twentyfive chambers.

column1: dvayaṃ dvayaṃ rakṣayitvā upaśobhās tathāṣṭa ca //
column2: After having retained two chambers on each side, the eight secondary decorations are made.

column1: devyādikhyāpakaṃ bhadraṃ vṛhanmadhye paraṃ laghu /
column2: The diagram sacred to the goddess is big at the centre and small above.

column1: madhye navapadaṃ padmaṃ koṇe bhadracatuṣṭayam //
column2: There should be a lotus at the centre in nine chambers and four chambers in the cardinal points.

column1: astrayāgaḥ purā kāryaḥ sarvakarmasu siddhidaḥ /

column2: The weapons relating to lord Śiva and others should be worshipped at the centre. The thunderbolt and others weapons should be worshipped from the east onwards in order.

column1: pañcacakraṃ daśakaraṃ raṇādau pūjitaṃ jaye /
column2: One would gain victory in battle etc. by worshipping five discs in a place measuring ten cubits.

column1: grahapūjā ravirmadhye pūrvādyāḥ somakādayaḥ //

column1: sarva ekādaśasthāstu grahāḥ syuḥ grahapūjanāt /

column1: astraśāntiṃ pravakṣyāmi sarvotpātavināśinīṃ // graharogādiśamanīṃ mārīśatruvimardanīṃ / vināyakopataptighnamaghorāstraṃ japennaraḥ //

column1: lakṣaṃ grahādināśaḥ syādutpāte tilahomanam / divye lakṣaṃ tadardhena vyomajotpātanāśanaṃ // ghṛtena lakṣapātena utpāte bhumije hitam /

column1: ghṛtagugguluhome ca sarvotpātādimardanam //
column2: All types of portents are nullified by doing oblation with ghee and gnggulu fragrant gumresin.

column1: bhūtavedālaśāntistu guggulorayutena ca /

column1: tilājyalakṣahomantu uttamāsiddhisādhane // madhyamāyāṃ tadardhena tatpādādadhamāsu ca /

column1: yathā japas tathā homaḥ saṃgrāme vijayo bhavet /

column1: vakṣye pāśupatāstreṇa śāntijāpādi pūrvataḥ /
column2: shall describe first the appeasing rite and repetition with the mantra of the weapon of Paśupati.

column1: pādataḥpūrvanāśo hi phaḍantaṃ cāpadādinut //
column2: If it is repeated with phaṭ at the end it would remove one’s misfortune.

column1: sakṛdāvartanādeva sarvavighnān vināśayet / śatāvartena cotpātānraṇādau vijayo bhavet //

column1: ghṛtagugguluhomācca asādhyānapi sādhayet /
column2: One would accomplish even that one could not accomplish by doing oblation with ghee and guggulu fragrant gumresin.

column1: paṭhanātsarvaśāntiḥ syacchastrapāśupatasya ca //

column1: lakṣāhutibhirdūrvābhiḥ śāntiṃ puṣṭiṃ prasādhayet //

column1: oṃ lakṣaṃ japtvā daśāṃśena hutvā syāt sarvakarmakṛt /

column1: vaśaṃ nayati śakrādīnmānuṣeṣveṣu ka kathā //
column2: One would subjugate Śakra Indra, the chief of the celestials. One need not say about its influence on the mortals.

column2: This mantra is capable of making the votary invisible, captivating and paralysing others.

column1: vaśannayati śatrūṇāṃ śatrubuddhipramohinī //

column1: kāmadhenuriyaṃ vidyā saptadhā parikīrtitā /

column1: anena mantrarājena kṣālayitvā tu taṇḍulān // triṃśadvārāni japtāni taccaureṣu pradāpayet /

column1: dantaiścūrṇāni śuklāni patitāni hi śuddhaye //
column2: It would establish their innocence if the chewed cud ejected by them is white.

Accept the offering am giving! Oblations! After having offered the victim to the guardian of the ground and the performance of the rite of locating the planets, the enemy would be subjugated.

Obeisance to Sadyojāta!

column1: bhave bhave 'nādibhave bhajasva māṃ bhavodbhava //
column2: On the lord of the beings ! On the lord of eternal being! Be manifest in me.

column1: pañcabrahmāṅgaṣaṭkañca vakṣye 'haṃ bhuktimuktidaṃ /

column1: śivaśāntiṃ pravakṣyāmi kalpāghoraprapūrvakam /

column2: kaḥ + chindyāt = kaśchindyāt kaḥ + caret = kaścaret kaḥ + ṭaḥ = kaṣṭaḥ kaḥ + sthaḥ = kaṣṭhaḥ kaḥ + calet = kaścalet In the following cases the visarga becomes the upadhmānīya

column1: kaśchindyāt kaś caret kaṣṭaḥ kaṣṭhaḥ kasthaś ca kaś calet / ka .. khanet ka .. karoti sma ka ,, paṭhet ka ,, vā //
column2: kaḥ + khanet = kaḥ ≍ khanet kaḥ + karoti = kaḥ ≍ karoti sma kaḥ + paṭhet = kaḥ ≍ paṭhet or kaḥ + phaleta kaḥ ≍ phaleta The following may occur in two forms

column1: kaśśvaśuraḥ kaḥśvaśuraḥ kassāvaraḥ kaḥsāvaraḥ /
column2: kaḥ + śvaśuraḥ = kaśśvaśuraḥ or kaḥ śvaśuraḥ kaḥ + sāvaraḥ = kassāvaraḥ or kaḥ sāvaraḥ In the following cases there is no change

column1: kaḥ phaleta kaḥ śayitā ko 'tra yodhaḥ ka uttamaḥ //
column2: kaḥ + phaleta = kaḥ phaleta kaḥ + śayitā = kaḥ śayitā The following is an instance of change

column1: devā ete bho iha sodarā yānti bhago vraja /
column2: kaḥ + uttamaḥ = ka uttamaḥ devāḥ + ete = devā ete bhoḥ + iha = bho iha sodarāḥ + yānti = sodarā yānti bhago + vraja = bhago vraja In the following the visarga becomes repha r

column1: supūḥ sudūrātriratra vāyuryāti punarna hi //
column2: supūḥ+sudūḥ+rātriḥ = supūḥ sudūrātriḥ vāyuḥ + yāti = vāyuryāti punaḥ + nahi = punarnahi punaḥ + eti = punareti The visarga is dropped in the following cases

column1: punareti sa yātīha eṣa yāti ka īśvaraḥ /
column2: saḥ + yāti + iha = sa yātīha eṣaḥ + yāti = eṣa yāti kaḥ + īśvaraḥ = ka īśvaraḥ jyotiḥ + rūpaṃ = jyotīrūpam The following are examples of other kinds of union

column1: jyotīrūpaṃ tavacchatraṃ mlecchadhīśchidramacchidat //
column2: tava + chatram = tavacchatram mlecchadhīḥ + chidraṃ + ā + chidat = mlecchadhīśchidramācchidat The text gives only the combined forms.

column1: vibhaktisiddharūpañca kātyāyana vadāmi te /
column2: O Kātyāyana! shall describe to you the finished forms of inflections.

column1: dve vibhaktī suptiṅaś caya supaḥ sapta vibhaktayaḥ //
column2: There are two kinds of inflectionssup substantives and tiṅ verbs. The substantives have seven cases.

column1: su+aujasiti prathamā amauṭśaso dvitīyā /
column2: Aṃ, au, śas are the inflections of the second case Accusative.

column1: ṭābhyāṃ bhisiti tṛtīyā ṅebhyāṃbhyasaś caturthyapi //
column2: Ṭā, bhyāṃ, bhis are the terminations of the third case Instrumental. Ṇe, bhyāṃ, bhyas constitute the fourth case Dative.

column1: ṅasibhyāṃbhyasaḥ pañcamī syātṅasomiti ṣaṣṭhyapi /
column2: Ṇasi , bhyāṃ, bhyas are the inflections of the fifth case Ablative. Ṇas, os, ām are the terminations for the sixth case Genitive.

column1: ṅi+ossuviti saptamī syāt syuḥ prātipadikātparāḥ //
column2: Ṇi, os, sup are for the seventh case Locative. These would be added after the uninflected substantives.

column1: dvividhaṃ prātipadikaṃ hy ajantañca halantakaṃ /
column2: The substantives are twofoldending in vowels and ending in consonants.

column1: pratyekaṃ trividhaṃ tat syāt pumāṃstrī ca napuṃsakaṃ //
column2: Each one of this would again be threefold masculine, feminine and neuter.

column1: darśyante nāyakāsteṣāmanuktānāñca vīryataḥ /
column2: The models of these are given. Those which are not mentioned here follow those on account of their strength.

column1: vṛkṣaḥ sarvo 'tha pūrvaś ca prathamaś ca dvitīyakaḥ // tṛtīyaḥ khaṇḍapā vahniḥ sakhāpatiraharpatiḥ / paṭurnīrgrāmanīndraś ca khalapūrmitrabhūḥ svabhūḥ // auśrīḥ sudhīḥ pitā bhrātā nā karta kroṣṭunaptṛnaptṛkau / surā rā gaus tathā dyaurglauḥ svarāntāḥ puṃsi nāyakāḥ //
column2: Vṛkṣaḥ tree, Sarvaḥ all, Pūrvaḥ former, Prathamaḥ first, Dvitīyakaḥ second, Tṛtīyaḥ third, Khaṇḍapā protector of a group, Vahniḥ fire, Sakhā friend, Patiḥ husband, Aharpatiḥ Sun, Paṭuḥ clever, Grāmaṇī chief of the village, Indra the lord of the celestials, Khalapūḥ one who sweeps, Mitrabhūḥ being a friend, Svabhūḥ an epithet of Brahmā, Suśrīḥ good fortune, Sudhīḥ a wiseman, Pitā father, Bhrātā brother, Nā a man, Kartā doer, Kroṣṭu a jackal, Naptṛ grandson, Surā intoxicating drink, Rā Rai means wealth, Gauḥ cow, Dyauḥ heaven, Glauḥ Moon are examples for the masculine nouns ending in vowels.

column1: suvāk tvak pṛṣat samrāṭ janmabhāk ca aveḍapi / āpo marudbhavan dīvyan bhavāṃś ca maghavān pivan // bhagavānadhavānarvānvahnimat sarvitsupṛt / susīmā kuṇḍī rājā ca śvā yuvā maghavā tathā // pūṣā sukarmā yajvā ca suvarmā ca sudharmaṇā /
column2: Examples for substantives ending with the consonants Suvāk good expression or speech, Tvak skin, Pṛṣat a drop of water or any other liquid, Samrāṭ a paramount sovereign, Janmabhāk one who has obtained birth, Surāṭ a good sovereign, Āpaḥ water, Marut Wind, Bhavan becoming, Dīpyan shining, Bhavān you polite form, Maghavān Indra prosperous, Piban drinking, Bhagavān fortunate, hence denotes the lord, Aghavān a sinner, Arvān a horse, Vahnimat possessing fire, Sarvavit knower of all things, Supṛt a good army, Susīmā good boundary, Kuṇḍī Kuṇḍin denotes Śiva, holding a bowl, Rājā king, Śvā horse, Yuvā youth, Maghavā Indra, Pūṣā Sun, Sukarmā doer of good deeds, Yajvā sacrificer, Suvarmā good armour, Sudharmaṇā council of gods, courthall of Indra, Aryamā Sun, Vṛtrahā Indra, killer of Vṛtra, Panthāḥ path, Sukakud good summit etc.

column1: aryamā vṛtrahā panthāḥ sukakudādipañca ca // praśān sutāṃś ca pañcādyāḥ sugīḥ surāḥ supūrapi / candramāḥ suvacāḥ śreyān vidvāṃśceśanasā saha // pecivān gauravānaḍvān godhūṅmitradruhau śvaliṭ /
column2: and Pañca five, Praśān one who is tranquil, Sutān one who spreads well, Pañca five etc., Sugauḥ good cow, Surāḥ one who is wealthy and Supūḥ good city, Candramāḥ Moon, Suvacāḥ good speech, Śreyān excellent, Vidvān learned, and Uśanas the preceptor of the demons, Pecivān one who has cooked, Gauḥ cow, Anaḍvān an ox, Godhuṅ one who milks a cow, Mitradruh one who is treacherous to a friend, Śvaliṭ one who licks like a dog.

column1: striyāṃ jāyā jarā bālā eḍkā saha vṛddhayā // kṣatriyā bahurājā ca bahudā mātha bālikā / māyā kaumudagandhā ca sarvā pūrvā sahānyayā // dvitīyā ca tṛtīyā ca buddhiḥ strī śrīr nadī sudhaiḥ / bhavantī caiva dīvyantī bhātī bhāntī ca yānyapi //
column2: Substantives in the feminine are Jāyā wife, Jarā old age, Bālā young girl, Eḍakā a ewe, Vṛddhā old woman, Kṣatriyā a woman of the Kṣatriya class, Bahurājā land having many rulers, Bahudāmā having many garlands and Bālikā an young girl, Māyā illusion, Kaumudagandhā smelling like a lily, Sarvā all, Pūrvā the preceding one and Anyā someone else, Dvitīyā second one, Tṛtīyā third one, Buddhi intellect, Strī woman, Śrī Lakṣmī, goddess of wealth, Nadī river, Sudhīḥ wise, Bhavantī one who becomes, Dīvyantī one who shines, Bhātī one who appears, Bhāntī one who shines, and Yāntī one who goes, Śṛṅvatī one who hears, Tudatī tormenting, Kartrī doer, Tudantī tormenting, Kurvatī one who is doing, Mahī earth, Rudhantī one who is obstructing, Krīḍatī one who is playing, Dāntī one who is restrained, Pālayantī one who is protecting, and Surāṇī a celestial woman, Gaurī having white complexion, denotes consort of Śiva, Putravatī one who is having a son, Nauḥ ship or boat, Vadhūḥ bride, Devatā deity and Bhūḥ earth.

column1: tisro dve kati varṣābhūḥ svasā mātā varā gauḥ // naurvāktvakprācyavākṣīti tiraścī samudīcyapi / śaradvidyut saridyoṣit agnivit saspadā dṛśat // yaiṣā sā vedavitsaṃvit bahvī rājñī tvayā mayā / somā pañcādayo rājī dhūḥ pūś caiva diśā girā //
column2: Tisra three and Dve two both denoting feminine, Kati how many, Varṣābhūḥ a female frog, Svasā sister, Mātā mother, Varā excellent, Gauḥ cow, Nauḥ ship or boat, Vāk speech, Tvak skin, Prācī east, Avācī south, Tiraścī the female of an animal or bird, Samīcī a doe, Udīcī north, Śarat autumn, Vidyut lightning, Sarit river, Yoṣit lady in separation, Agnivit knower of fire, Sampat wealth, Dṛṣat stone, Yā who, Eṣā this, Vedavit knower of the Veda, Saṃvit knowledge, Bahvī many, Rājñī queen, Tvayā by you, Mayā be me, Sīmā boundary, Pañca five etc., Rājī line or row, Dhūḥ shaking, Pūḥ purifying, Diśā direction, Girā speech, Catasraḥ four, Viduṣī learned person, Kā who, Iyaṃ this, Dik direction, Dṛk look, Tādṛśī that kind.

column1: asau striyāṃ nāyakāś ca nāyakāś ca napuṃsake //
column2: These are chief among the substantives belonging to the feminine gender. shall describe the chief among the substantives belonging to the neuter.

column1: kuṇḍaṃ sarvaṃ somapañca dadhi vāri khalapvatha / madhu trapu kartṛ bhaktṛ ativaktṛ payaḥ puraḥ // prākpratyak ca tiryagudak jagad jāgrattathā sakṛt / susampacca sudaṇḍīha ahaḥ kiñcedamityapi // ṣaṭsarpiḥ śreyaś catvāri ado 'nye hīdṛśāḥ pare /
column2: Kuṇḍaṃ a bowl or pit, Sarvaṃ all, Somapaṃ Dadhi curd, Vāri water, Khalapū that which sweeps, Madhu honey, Trapu tin, Bhartṛ, Atibhartṛ, Payaḥ milk, Puraḥ city, Prāk east, Pratyak ? backwards, Tiryak across, Udak above or nothward, Jagat world, Jāgrat awakening state, Śakṛt excrement, Susampat good wealth, Sudaṇḍī good stick, Ahaḥ day, Kiṃ what, Idaṃ this, Śaṭ six, Sarpiḥ clarified butter, Śreyaḥ fortune, Catvāri four, Adaḥ that thing.

column1: etebhyaḥ prathamādayaś ca syuḥ prātipadikātparāḥ //
column2: The inflections of the first case Nominative etc. would come after these uninflected forms.

column1: dhātupratyayahīnaṃ yatsyāt prātipadikantu tat / prātipadikāt svaliṅgārthavacane prathamā bhavet //
column2: A form of a word which is neither a verbal root dhātu, nor an affix pratyaya is a nominal base prātipadika. The first case from the nominal base is employed to denote the subject.

column1: sambodhane ca prathamā ukte karmaṇi kartari /
column2: The first case is also employed in addressing when the agent and the object are mentioned.

column1: karma yat kriyate tatsyāt dvitīyā karmaṇi smṛtā //
column2: That which is done by the agent is the object karma. Second case Accusative is used in the object.

column1: kriyate yena karaṇaṃ kartā yaś ca karoti saḥ /
column2: That by which something is done is the instrument karaṇa. One who does is the agent kartā.

column1: anukte tiṅkṛttaddhitaistṛtīyā karaṇe bhavet //
column2: When the object is not specified to be the agent through the verbal affix or suffixes of the kṛt and taddhita type, the third case Instrumental is used in denoting the instrument and the agent.

column1: kārake kartari ca sā sampradāne caturthyapi /
column2: The fourth case is employed in sampradāna to be given.

column1: yasmai ditsā dhārayate sampradānaṃ tadoritaṃ //
column2: It is said to be sampradāna in which the desire to give is indicated.

column1: apādānaṃ yato 'paiti ādatte ca bhayaṃ yataḥ /
column2: Apādāna, is that from which something moves away or taken away.

column1: apādāne pañcamī syāt svasvāmyādau ca ṣaṣṭhyapi //
column2: The fifth case Ablative is used to denote apādāna. The sixth case Genitive is used to denote one’s ownership.

column1: ādhāro yo 'dhikaraṇaṃ vibhaktistatra saptamī /
column2: The term adhikaraṇa is used in the sense of the base ādhāra. The seventh case Locative is used therein.

column1: ekārthe caikavanacaṃ dvyarthe dvivacanaṃ bhavet //
column2: Singular is used to denote a single thing. Dual comes in the sense of two things.

column1: bahuṣu bahuvacanaṃ siddharūpāṇyatho vade /
column2: Plural would occur in the sense of many. shall describe the finished forms now.

column1: vṛkṣaḥ sūryo 'mbuvāho 'rka herave hedvijātayaḥ //
column2: The following are examples for the Nominative Vṛkṣaḥ tree, Sūryaḥ Sun, Ambuvāhaḥ cloud, Arkaḥ Sun.

column1: viprau gajānmahendreṇa yamābhyāmanalaiḥ kṛtaṃ /
column2: Then the example for the Accusative Gajān the elephants.

column1: rāmāya munivaryābhyāṃ kebhyo dharmāt harau ratiḥ // śarābhyāṃ pustakebhyaś ca arthasyeśvarayorgatiḥ /
column2: Rāmāya for Rāma, Munivaryābhyām for the two excellent sages, Kebhyaḥ for whoṃ, plural are examples for the Dative. Dharmāt from Dharma, Harau ratiḥ ?, Śarābhyāṃ from the two arrows, Pustakebhyaḥ from the books are illustrations for the Ablative.

column1: bālānāṃ sajjane prītirhaṃsayoḥ kamaleṣu ca //
column2: Sajjane prītiḥ pleased in good people, Haṃsayoḥ in the two haṃsas, Kamaleṣu in the lotuses are examples for the Locative.

column1: evaṃ kāmamaheśādyāḥ śabdā jñeyāñca vṛkṣavat /
column2: In the same way, the words Kāma God of love, Maheśa the great lord and other words should be known like the word Vṛkṣa tree.

column1: sarve viśve ca sarvasmai sarvasmātkataro mataḥ // sarveṣāṃ svañca viśvasmin śeṣaṃ rūpañca vṛkṣavat /
column2: Sarve all, Viśve all or entire or whole, Sarvasmai for all, Sarvasmāt from all and Katara who or which of two are regarded as similar. Sarveṣām of all, Svam one’s self, Viśvasmin in the whole.

column1: evañcobhayakatarakatamānyatarādayaḥ //
column2: Similarly Ubhaya both, Katara who or which of the two, Katama who or which of many, Anyatara one of two etc.

column1: pūrve pūrvāś ca pūrvasmai pūrvasmāt susamāgataḥ / pūrve buddhiś ca pūrvasmin śeṣarūpantu sarvavat //
column2: Pūrve all the former, Pūrvāḥ all the former, feminine, Pūrvasmai for the former, Pūrvasmāt from the former, Pūrve in the former, Pūrvasmin in the former.

column1: evaṃ parāvarādyāś ca dakṣiṇottarakāntarāḥ /
column2: Para superior, Avara inferior as well as Dakṣiṇa south, Uttara north, Antara in between, Aparāḥ others, Adharaḥ below are to be known in the same way.

column1: aparaścādharo nemāḥ prathamāḥ prathame 'rkavat //
column2: Nemāḥ parts, Prathamāḥ the first ones, Prathame in the first one are like the word Arka Sun.

column1: evaṃ caramāyatayā alpārdhā nema+ādayaḥ /
column2: In the same way we whould have Caramāḥ last, Alpa little, Ardha half and the Nema part and others.

column1: dvitīyasmai dvitīyāya dvitīyasmāt dvitīyakāt // dvitīyasmin dvitīye ca tṛtīyaś ca tathārkavat /
column2: Dvitīyasmai or Dvitīyāya for the second, Dvitīyasmāt or Dvitīyakāt from the second, Dvitīyasmin or Dvitīye in the second and Tṛtīya third like the word Arka Sun.

column1: somapāḥ somapau jñeyau somapāḥ somapāṃ vraja //
column2: Somapāḥ a drinker of Soma and Somapau two drinkers of Soma should be known.

column1: kīlālapau somapaś ca somapā somape dada / somapābhyāṃ somapābhyaḥ somapaḥ somapoḥ kulaṃ //
column2: Kīlālapau two drinkers of a heavenly drink similar to nectar and Somapaḥ drinker of Soma, Somapāḥ drinkers of Soma, Somape dada give to a drinker of Soma, Somapābhyāṃ to two drinkers of Soma, Somapābhyaḥ to many drinkers of Soma, Somapaḥ drinker of Soma, Somapau two drinkers of Soma belong to a group.

column1: evaṃ kīlālapādyāḥ syuḥ kaviragnis tathārayaḥ /
column2: The words such as Kīlālapāḥ drinkers of a celestial drink would be similar.

column1: hekave kavimagnī tān harīn sātyakinā hṛtaṃ // ravibhyāṃ ravibhirdehi vahṇaye yaḥ samāgataḥ / agneragnyos tathāgnīnāṃ kavau kavyoḥ kaviṣv atha //
column2: Kaviḥ poet, Agniḥ fire and Arayaḥ enemies, He kave! O poet!, Kaviṃ the poet, accusative, Agni two fires, accusative, Tān Harīn those Haris, Sātyakinā hṛtaṃ taken by Sātyaki, Ravibhyāṃ by two Suns, Ravibhiḥ by the Suns, Dehi vahnaye yaḥ samāgataḥ Give to Fire who has come, Agneḥ of fire, Agnyoḥ of two fires, Agnīnāṃ of many fires, Kavau in the poet, Kavyoḥ in the two poets and Kaviṣu in many poets are examples for words ending in ‘i’.

column1: evaṃ susṛtirabhrāntiḥ sukīrtiḥ sudhṛtis tathā /
column2: Similarly Susṛtiḥ good path, Abhrāntiḥ not an error, Sukīrtiḥ good fame and Sudhṛtiḥ firmness are to be declined.

column1: sakhā sakhāyau sakhāyaḥ hesakhe vraja satpatiṃ //
column2: ‘He sakhe! vraja satpatiṃ’ O Friend! go to a good master, Sakhāyaṃ the friend, Sakhāyau the two friends, Sakhīn the friends are accusative forms.

column1: sakhāyañca sakhāyau ca sakhīn sakhyā gato dada /
column2: Sakhyā gataḥ gone with the friend. Dada sakhye give to the friend.

column1: sakhye sakhyuś ca sakhyuś ca sakhyoḥ śeṣaḥ kaveriva //
column2: Sakhyuḥ from a friend, Sakhyuḥ of the friend, Sakhyoḥ of the two friends.

column1: patyā patye ca patyuś ca patyuḥ patyos tathāgnivat /
column2: Patyā by the master, Patye for the master, Patyuḥ from the master, Patyuḥ of the master, Patyoḥ of the two masters are like the word Agni fire.

column1: dvau dvau dvābhyāṃ dvābhyāṃ dvitvādyarthe dvayordvayoḥ //
column2: Dvau two, Dvau the two, Dvābhyām by the two, Dvābhyām for the two, Dvayoḥ from the two and Dvayoḥ of the two are in the sense of dual.

column1: trayastrīṃś ca tribhistribhyastrayāṇāñca triṣu kramāt /
column2: Trayaḥ three, Trīn the three, Tribhiḥ by the three, Tribhyaḥ for the three, Trayāṇāṃ of the three and Triṣu in the three are in order.

column1: kavivat katikatītiśeṣaṃ vahuvacanaṃ smṛtam //
column2: The other plural forms are like Kavi poet in the plural.

column1: nīrniyau ca niyo henīḥ niyaṃ niyo niyo niyā / nībhyāṃ nībhirniye nībhyaḥ niyānniyi niyos tathā //
column2: Niyā by a leader, Nībhyāṃ by two leaders, Nibhiḥ by many leaders. Niye for a leader, Nībhyaḥ for many leaders. Niyāṃ of many leaders, Niyi in a leader and Niyoḥ in two leaders.

column1: suśrīḥ sudhīḥ prabhṛtayo grāmaṇīḥ pūjayeddhariṃ /
column2: Suśrīḥ good fortune, Sudhīḥ good intellect etc. Grāmaṇīḥ a leader, pūjayeddhariṃ should worship Hari.

column1: grāmaṇyau grāmaṇyo grāmaṇyaṃ grāmaṇyā grāmaṇībhiḥ // grāmaṇyo grāmaṇyāmevaṃ senānīpramukhāḥ subhūḥ /
column2: Grāmaṇyau the two chiefs, Grāmaṇyaḥ the many chiefs, Gramaṇyaṃ the chief, accusative, Grāmaṇyā by the chief, Grāmaṇibhiḥ by many chiefs, Grāmaṇyaḥ of a chief, Grāmaṇyāṃ in a chief.

column1: subhuvau ca svayambhuvaḥ svayambhuñca svayambhuvaḥ // svayambhuvā svayambhuvi evaṃ pratitebhuvādayaḥ /
column2: Subhūḥ good land and Sabhuvau two good lands. Svayambhuvaḥ selfborn, Svayambhuvaṃ selfborn, accusative, Svayambhuvā by the selfborn, Svayambhuvi in the selfborn.

column1: khalapūḥ khalapvau śreṣṭhau khalapvañca khalapvi ca //
column2: Khalapūḥ that which sweeps, Khalapvau the two which sweep, Śreṣṭhau that are excellent, Khalapvaṃ that which sweeps, accusative, and Khalapvi in a sweeper.

column1: evaṃ śarapūmukhāḥ syuḥ kroṣṭā kroṣṭāra īritāḥ /
column2: The words beginning with Śarapūḥ would be in the same way.

column1: kroṣṭūṃś ca kroṣṭunā kroṣṭrā kroṣṭūnāṃ kroṣṭarīddṛśaṃ //
column2: Kroṣṭhā a jackal and Kroṣṭhāraḥ many jackals, Kroṣṭhūn the jackals, accusative plural, Kroṣṭhunā or Kroṣṭhrā by a jackal, Kroṣṭhūnāṃ of the jackals, Kroṣṭhari in a jackal are said to be formed thus.

column1: pitā pitarau pitaraḥ hepitaḥ pitarau śubhau / pitṝn pituḥ pituḥ pitroḥ pitṝṇāṃ pitarīdṛśaṃ //
column2: Pitā father, Pitarau two fathers, Pitaraḥ many fathers, He pitaḥ O Father!, Pitarau śubhau O Auspicious fathers!, Pitṝn the fathers, accusative, Pituḥ from the father, Pituḥ of the father, Pitroḥ of the two fathers, Pitṝṇāṃ of many fathers, Pitari in the father are formed thus.

column1: evaṃ bhrātā ca jāmātṛmukhā nṝṇāṃ nṛṇāṃ tathā /
column2: In the same way Bhrātā a brother, Jāmātṛ soninlaw and others words are formed. Then Nṝṇāṃ or Nṛṇāṃ of the men.

column1: kartā kartārau kartṝṃś ca kartṝṇāṃ kartarīdṛśaṃ //

column1: svatantraḥ kartā vidyāntaṃ kṛtinaḥ samupāsate / hetukartālambhayate hitaṃ vai karmakartari //

column1: kartā pañcavidhaḥ proktaḥ karma saptavidhaṃ śṛṇu //

column1: īpsitaṃ karma ca yathā śraddadhāti hariṃ yatiḥ / anīpsitaṃ karma yathā ahiṃ laṅghayate bhṛśaṃ // naivepsitaṃ nānīpsitaṃ dugdhaṃ sambhakṣyanrajaḥ /
column2: The first one is the desired object such as “An ascetic pays respect to lord Hari Viṣṇu”. The second one is the object that is not desired, such as “A person jumps over a serpent repeatedly.” “After drinking milk, eat dust” is an example for neither desired nor not desired object of the third kind.

column1: bhakṣyedpyakathitaṃ gopālo dogdhi gāṃ payaḥ // kartṛkarmātha gamayecchiṣyaṃ grāmaṃ gururyathā /

column1: karma cābhihitaṃ pūjā kriyate vai śriye hareḥ // karmānabhihitaṃ stotraṃ hareḥ kuryāt sarvadaṃ /

column1: karaṇaṃ dvividhaṃ proktaṃ vāhyamabhyantaraṃ tathā //

column1: sampradānaṃ tridhā proktaṃ prerakaṃ brāhmaṇāya gāṃ // naro dadāpi nṛpataye dāsantadanumantṛkaṃ / anirākartṛkaṃ bhartre dadyāt puṣpāṇi sajjanaḥ //

column1: āyuḥ svāduś ca hetvādyāḥ kiṃśārurdhānyaśūkakaḥ //
column2: The other examples are āyuḥ life, svādu sweet, hetu cause etc. Kiṃśāruḥ means the beard of a corn.

column1: kṛkavākuḥ kukkuṭaḥ syād gururbhartā marus tathā /
column2: Kṛkavāku denotes a cock. Guru is the master. Maru is a desert.

column1: śayuścājagaro jñeyaḥ sa harāyudhamucyate //
column2: Śayu is known as a big serpent. Saru is said to be a weapon sword.

column1: svarurvaṃjñaṃ trapurusi samasāraṃ phalgurīritaṃ /
column2: Svaru denotes the thunderbolt. Trapu means sīsam . Phalgu is said to mean worthless thing.

column1: gṛdhnaś ca krani kiraci mandiraṃ timiraṃ tamaḥ // ilaci salilaṃ vāri kalyāṇaṃ bhaṇḍilaṃ smṛtaṃ /
column2: The following words are known to be derived by adding the corresponding suffixes gṛdhraḥ vulture from kran, mandiram an abode and timiraṃ meaning darkness from kirac, salilaṃ meaning water and bhaṇḍila meaning auspicious from ilac.

column1: budho vidvān kvasau syācca śiviraṃ guptasaṃsthitiḥ //
column2: Budhaḥ meaning a learned person from kvasu. The word śibira denotes a concealed position.

column1: oturviḍālaś ca tuni abhidhānādugādayaḥ / karṇaḥ kāmī ca gṛhabhūrvāsturjaivātṛkaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: The words karṇaḥ ear, kāmī a lustful person, gṛhaṃ house, bhūḥ earth, vāstu the site of a house and jaivātṛkaḥ the moon are known to be uṇādis because they denote objects.

column1: anaḍvān vahatervini syājjātau jīvārṇavauṣadhaṃ /
column2: The word anaḍvān a bull is from the root vaḥ to bear with ḍvan. Jīva life, arṇava ocean and auṣadha herb convey genus.

column1: nau vahnirinani hariṇaḥ mṛgaḥ kāmī ca bhājanam //
column2: The word vahni fire is by adding the suffix ni, hariṇaḥ meaning a deer from inan and kāmī one who is lustful denotes a fit person.

column1: kambojo bhājanambhāṇḍaṃ saraṇḍaś ca catuṣpadaḥ / tarureraṇḍaḥ saṅghāto varūḍaḥ sāma nirbharaṃ //
column2: Saṅghāta a collection varūḍa mixed caste, saraṇḍa means an animal, eraṇḍa is a kind of tree sāma chant. nirbhara full.

column1: sphāraṃ prabhūtaṃ syānnāntapratyaye cīravalkalaṃ /
column2: The word sphāraṃ would mean plenty...

column1: kātaro bhīrurugrastu pracaṇḍo javasaṃ tṛṇaṃ // jagaccaiva tu bhūrloko kṛśānurjyotirarkakaḥ /
column2: The words cīra denoting a bark garment belongs to the same category. The word kātara means timid. But ugra means fierce. Javasa denotes grass.

column1: varvaraḥ kuṭilo dhūrtaś catvarañca catuṣpathaṃ //
column2: Varvara means curled and dhūrta a wicked person. Catvaraṃ denotes a junction of four roads.

column1: cīvaraṃ bhikṣuprāvṛttirādityo mitra īritaḥ /
column2: Cīvara is the dress of a mendicant. Āditya is said to be Mitra the Sun.

column1: putra sūnuḥ pitā tātaḥ pṛdākurvyāghravṛścike /
column2: The word putra stands for a son and pitā, for father. The words pṛdāku denotes a tiger and a scorpion.

column1: garto 'vaṭo 'tha bharato naṭo 'parepyuṇādayaḥ //
column2: Bharata means an actor. These are the other uṇādis. But trapu denotes tin and sīsam , lead. .

column1: tiṅvibhaktiṃ pravakṣyāmi tathādeśaṃ samāsataḥ / tiṅstriṣvapi vartante bhāve karmaṇi kartari //
column2: shall describe the terminations which are added to the verbs as well as the substitutes in brief The verbs occur in three forms such as bhāve impersonal, karmaṇi passive and kartari active.

column1: sakarmakārmakācca kartari dvipade smṛtāḥ / sakarmakākarmaṇi ca tadādeśastatheritaḥ //
column2: They are known to be transitive and intransitive in the two padas Ātmanepada and Parasmaipada in the Active. In the same way the substitutes in the transitive and intransitive.

column1: vartamāne laḍākhyāto vidhyādyarthe liṅīritaḥ / vidhyādau loḍāśiṣi ca bhūtānadyatane ca laṅ //
column2: Laṭ is the designation for the present tense. Liṅ is said to be in the sense of the potential mood etc. Loṭ is for benediction and conditional etc.

column1: bhūte luṅliṭ parokṣe 'tha bhāvinyadyatane ca luṭ / liṅāśiṣi ca śeṣe 'rthe laḍbhaviṣyati ḷṅbhavet //
column2: Luṅ is the name for the past Aorist and liṭ for remote past and luṭ for immediate first future. Liṅ is used for benediction and lṛṭ in the remaining senses. Lṛṅ would denote the second future.

column1: liṅnimimitte kriyātipattau pare navātmanepadam / pūrvaṃ nava parasmaipadantiptasantīti prathamaḥ pumāna //
column2: The latter nine are Ātmanepada the result of the action accruing to one’s self and the former nine are Parasmaipada the result of the action accruing to another person. Tip, tas and anti are the terminations of the prathamapuruṣa.

column1: sipthastha madhyamanaro mipvasmascottamaḥ pumān /
column2: Sip, thas and tha are the terminations of the madhyamapuruṣa and mip, vas and mas for the uttamapuruṣa.

column1: ta ātāṃ antātmane mukhyaḥ thāsāthāṃ dhvañca madhyamaḥ // uttama i vahi mahi bhūvādyā dhātavaḥ smṛtāḥ /
column2: Ta, ātāṃ and anta are the prathamapuruṣa terminations in the Ātmanepada, thās, āthāṃ, dhvaṃ in the madhyama and i, vahi, mahi in the uttama in the imperfect. Bhū to be etc.

column1: bhuviredhiḥ pacirnandirdhvaṃsiḥ śraṃsiḥ padistvadiḥ //
column2: The roots bhū to be, edh to prosper, pac to cook, nand to rejoice, dhvaṃs to perish, śaṃs to praise belong to the first conjugation.

column1: śīṅaḥ krīḍo juhotiś ca jahātiś ca dadhātyapi / dīvyatiḥ svapitirnahiḥ sunotirvasireva ca //
column2: Pad to go fourth, ad to eat second, śīṅ to lie down, second, krīḍ to buy first , juhoti hū to offer in a sacrifice third, jahāti hā to abandon, third, dadhāti dhā to bear, third, dīvyati di to play or to shine, fourth, svapiti svap to sleep, second, nah to tie, fourth, sunoti su, to press out juice, fifth, vas to dwell, tud to strike, wound, sixth, mṛśati mṛś to touch, sixth, muñcati muñc to lose, sixth, rudh to hold up, seventh, bhuj to enjoy, seventh, tyaj to abandon, first, and tan to spread, eighth.

column1: tudirmṛśatirmuñcatiḥ rudhirbhujistyajistaniḥ / śavādike vikaraṇe maniś caiva karotyapi // krīḍtirvṛṅo grahiścoriḥ pā nīrarciś ca nāyakāḥ /
column2: The roots man to think, karoti kṛ, to do, krīḍati krīḍ, to play, vṛṅ to choose, graḥ to seize, cor cur, to steal, pā to drink and protect, nī to carry and arc to worship are the important in the śap and other modifications.

column1: bhuvi syāt tiṅ bhavati saḥ bhavatastau bhavanti te //
column2: In the root bhū by adding tiṅ, we would have saḥ bhavati he becomes, tau bhavataḥ they two become and te bhavanti they all become.

column1: bhavasi tvaṃ yuvāṃ bhavatho yūyaṃ bhavatha cāpyahaṃ /
column2: Similarly we have you become, you two become and you all become and become, we two become and we all become.

column1: bhavāmyāvāṃ bhavāvaś ca bhavāmo hy edhate kulaṃ // edhete dve tathaidhante edhase tvaṃ hi medhayā /
column2: You grow with intellect, you two prosper and you all prosper. We two grow with intellect. We all prosper with devotion to lord Hari.

column1: edhethe ca samedhadhve edhe hy edhāvahe dhiyā // edhāmahe harerbhaktyā pacatītyādi pūrvavat /
column2: He cooks etc. are as before. One becomes and one enjoys are examples for the impersonal forms. The passive is formed by adding yak.

column1: bhūyate 'nubhūyate 'sau bhāve karmaṇi vai yaki // vubhūṣati samītyevaṃ ṇici bhāvayatīśvaraṃ /
column2: Thus in the causal one meditates on the lord. In the frequentative we have the form bobhūyate Ātmanepada or bobhoti when yoṅ is dropped is the form in the Parasmaipada frequentative.

column1: yaṅi vobhūyate vādyaṃ vobhotei syācca yaṅluki // putrīyati putrakāmyatyevaṃ paṭapaṭāyate /
column2: Putrīyati treats like a son on account of desire for children and thus paṭapaṭāyate utters the sound paṭpaṭ, ghaṭayati brings about are examples of the desiderative.

column1: ghaṭayaty atha sani ṇici bubhūṣayati rūpakaṃ //
column2: He causes the figure to be adorned bubhūṣayatī is the form in the causal.

column1: bhavedbhavetāñca liṅi bhaveyuś ca bhaveḥ pare / bhavetañca bhavetaivaṃ bhaveyañca bhaveva ca bhavema ca //
column2: Bhavet may become, bhavetāṃ, bhaveyuḥ, bhaveḥ bhavetaṃ, bhaveta, bhaveyaṃ, bhaveva, bhavema are the forms in the three persons in the singular, dual and plural in the Potential mood in the Parasmaipada.

column1: edheta edheyātāmedheran manasā śriyā / edhethāś ca edheyāthāmedhedhvamedheya edhevahi edhemahi //
column2: Edheta, edheyātāṃ, edheran grow or prosper with the mind and prosperity, edhetāḥ, edheyāthāṃ, edhedhvaṃ, edheya, edhevahi, edhemahi are the forms of the Potential moon in the Ātmanepada.

column1: astu tāvadbhavatām loṭi bhavantu bhavatādbhava / bhavataṃ bhavata bhavāni bhavāva ca bhavāma ca //
column2: Let it be. Bhavatāṃ, bhavantu, bhavatād or bhava, bhavataṃ, bhavata, bhavāni, bhavāva, bhavāma are the forms in the Imperative mood.

column1: edhatāmedhetāmedhantāmedhai pacāvahai pacāmahai / abhyanandadapacatāmacannapacas tathā // abhavatamabhavatāpacamapacāvāpacāma ca /
column2: Abhyanandat felicitated, apacatāṃ cooked, apacan they cooked, apacaḥ you cooked, abhavataṃ you two became, abhavata you all became, apacaṃ cooked, apacāva we two cooked, apacāma we all cooked are the examples for the past imperfect in the Parasmaipada.

column1: aidhatairdhetāmaidhadhvaṃ aidhe caidhāmahīritaṃ //
column2: Aidhata, aidhetāṃ third person singular and dual, aidhadhvaṃ second person plural, aidhe, aidhāmahi first person singular and plural are said to be the forms in the past tense, Ātmanepada.

column1: abhūdabhūtāmabhūvanabhūścābhūvameva luṅ /
column2: Abhūt, abhūtāṃ, abhūvan, abhūḥ and abhūvaṃ are the forms of the root bhū to be or become in the Aorist.

column1: aidhiṣṭaidhisātāṃ narāvaidhiṣṭhā eidhiṣīdṛśaṃ //
column2: Aidhiṣṭa, Aidhiṣātāṃ Men prospered, aidhiṣṭhāḥ, aidhiṣī are thus the forms of the Aorist Ātmanepada.

column1: liṭi babhūva babhūvatuḥ babhūvuś ca bavhūvitha / babhūvathurvabhūva ca babhūviva babhūvima //
column2: The root bhū becomes babhūva, babhūvatuḥ, babhūvuḥ, babhūvitha, babhūvathuḥ, babhūva, babhūva, babhūviva and babhūvima are the forms in the Perfect tense in the Parasmaipada.

column1: pece pecāte pecire tvamedhāñcakṛṣe tathā / edhāñcakrāthe pecidhve pece pecimahe tathā //
column2: Pece, pecāte, pecire cooked and edhāñcakṛṣe tvaṃ you prospered, edhāñcakrāthe, pecidhve, pece, pecimahe are the forms in the Perfect in the Ātmanepada and Periphrastic perfect.

column1: luṭi bhavitā bhavitārau bhavitāro harādayaḥ /
column2: In the first future the root bhū has the forms bhavitā, bhavitārau, bhavitāraḥ will become Hara and others.

column1: bhavitāsi bhavitāstho bhavitāsmas tathā vayaṃ //
column2: Bhavitāsi, bhavitāsthaḥ bhavitāsmaḥ vayam we are the other forms.

column1: paktā paktārau paktāraḥ paktāse tvaṃ śubhaudanaṃ / paktādhve paktāhe cāhaṃ paktāsmahe hareś caruṃ //
column2: You will cook paktāse good food. Paktādhve, will cook paktāhe, paktāsmahe we will cook the porridge for lord Hari are examples for some of the forms of the root pac in the first future Ātmanepada.

column1: liṅāśiṣi sukhaṃ bhūyāt bhūyāstāṃ hariśaṅkarau / bhūyāsuste ca bhūyāstvaṃ yuvāṃ bhūyāstamīśvarau // bhūyāsta yūyaṃ bhūyāsamahaṃ bhūyāsma sarvadā /
column2: In the benedictive May there be bhūyāt happiness, Hari and Saṅkara bhūyāstām be benevolent, bhūyāsuḥ they, you bhūyāḥ, you two gods bhūyāstaṃ, you all bhūyāsta, ahaṃ bhūyāsaṃ May be, bhūyāsma we all may be always happy.

column1: yakṣīṣṭa hy edhiṣīyāstāṃ yakṣīrannedhisīya ca // yakṣīvahyedhisīmahi liṅi cāyakṣyateti ḷṅ /
column2: Yakṣīṣṭa, edhiṣīyāstāṃ, yakṣīran, edhiṣīya, yakṣīvahi, edhiṣīmahi are some of the forms of the roots yaj, to sacrifice and edh to prosper in the Ātmanepada in the Benedictive.

column1: ayakṣyetāmayakṣyantāyakṣye 'yakṣyethāṃ yuvāṃ // ayakṣyadhvamaidhiṣyāvahyaidhiṣyāmahyarervayam /
column2: Ayakṣyata, ayakṣeyātāṃ, ayakṣyanta, ayakṣye, ayakṣyethāṃ you two, ayakṣyadhvaṃ, aidhiṣyāvahi, aidhiṣyāmahi we all are the forms in the Conditional mood in the Parasmaipada, Ātmanepada.

column1: ḷṭi syādbhaviṣyatīti edhiṣyāmaha īdṛśam //
column2: Bhaviṣyati would be the form in the second future. Edhiṣyāmahe is similar.

column1: evaṃ vibhāvayiṣyanti bobhaviṣyati rūpakaṃ /
column2: In the same way vibhāvayiṣyanti, bobhaviṣyati frequentative second future will become again and again.

column1: ghaṭayet paṭayettadvat putrīyati ca kāmyati //
column2: Ghaṭayet, paṭayet, putrīyati, kāmyati are other forms of nominal verbs and frequentatives.

column1: kṛtastriṣvapi vijñeyā bhāve karmaṇi kartari /
column2: The kṛts are to be known in all the three forms such as the impersonal, passive and active.

column1: ajlyuṭ ktin ghaño bhāve yujakārata eva ca //
column2: Ac, lyuṭ to form neuter abstract nouns by adding na, ktin ti to form feminine abstract nouns, ghañ added to roots ending in consonants, and yuc in the impersonal are the affixes.

column1: aci dharmasya vinaya utkaraḥ prakaras tathā / devo bhadraḥ śrīkaraś ca lpuṭi rūpantu śobhanam //
column2: Their examples are in the ac vinaya modesty, utkaraḥ heap, multitude, prakaraḥ collection, heap, devaḥ lord, bhadraḥ good, śrīkaraḥ conferer of prosperity.

column1: ktini vṛddhistutimatī ghañi bhāvo 'tha yucyapi / kāraṇā bhāvanetyādi akāre ca cikitsayā //
column2: The form in ghañ is bhāva feeling or state, in yuñkāraṇā doing action, bhāvanā bringing into existence etc. and in the syllable arepresented by cikitsā remedy.

column1: tathā tavyo hy anīyaś ca kartavyaṃ karṇīyakam / deyaṃ dhyeyañcaiva yati ṇyati kāryañca kṛtyakāḥ //
column2: Then the affixes tavya and anīya forming the words kartavyaṃ, karaṇīyakaṃ fit to be done, the affix yat to form deyaṃ ought to be given and dhyeyaṃ ought to be meditated, in ṇyat to form kāryaṃ a work or task and kṛtyakāḥ work to be done.

column1: kartari ktādayo jñeyā bhāve karmaṇi ca kvacit /
column2: Kta and other affixes are to be known in the active, and some in the impersonal and passive.

column1: gato grāmaṃ gato grāma āśliṣṭaś ca gurustvayā //
column2: A person has gone to the village. The village has been reached. The preceptor has been embraced by you.

column1: śatṛṅ śānacau bhavan edhamāno bhavantyapi /
column2: Śatṛṅ present participle in the Parasmaipada and śānac present participle in the Ātmanepada are bhavan becoming and edhamāna being prosperous.

column1: vuṇ tṛcau sarvadhātubhyo bhāvako bhavitā pathā // kvibantaś ca svayambhūś ca bhūte liṭaḥ kvansu kāna ca /
column2: Nvuh and tṛc are added to all the roots to form agents such as bhāvakaḥ and bhavitā feeling or manifestation and that which is about to become. An example for ending in kvip is Svayambhūḥ selforiginated.

column1: babhūvivān pecivāṃś ca pecānaḥ śraddadhānakaḥ //
column2: Babhūvivat and pecivat in the Parasmaipada and pecānaḥ and śraddadhānakaḥ in the Ātmanepada are the examples.

column1: aṇi syuḥ kumbhakārādyā bhūtepyuṇādayaḥ smṛtāḥ /
column2: Kumbhakāra a potter etc. would be formed by adding the affix aṇ. The uṇādis are known to be in the past.

column1: vāyuḥ pāyuś ca kāruḥ syādvahulaṃ chandasīritaṃ //
column2: Vāyuḥ wind, pāyuḥ the anus and kāru artisan would be formed from them.

column1: svargādināmaliṅgo yo haristaṃ pravadāmi te /
column2: shall describe to you the synonyms of heaven etc. of which lord Hari is the indication.

column1: svaḥsvarganākatridivā dyodivau dvetripiṣṭapaṃ //
column2: Svaḥ , svargaḥ , nākaḥ , tridivaḥ , dyauḥ , triviṣṭapa are synonyms denoting heaven.

column1: devā vṛndārakā lekhā rudrādyā gaṇadevatāḥ /
column2: Devas, Vṛndārakas and Lekhas are the names for the celestials. Rudra and others are the chief ofgroup of gods.

column1: vidyādharo 'psaroyakṣarakṣogandharvakinnarāḥ // piśāco guhyakaḥ siddho bhūto 'mī devayonayaḥ /
column2: Vidyādharas, Apsaras, Yakṣas, Rakṣas, Gandharvas, Kinnaras, Piśācas, Guhyakas, Siddhas and Bhūtas had celestial origin.

column1: devadviṣo 'surā daityāḥ sugataḥ syāttathāgataḥ //
column2: The enemies of the Devas, Asuras and Daityas born of Diti are the names of the demons. Sugataḥ and Tathāgataḥ denote Buddha.

column1: brahmātmabhūḥ surajyeṣṭho viṣṇur nārāyaṇo hariḥ /
column2: Brahmā, Ātmabhūḥ selfborn, Surajyeṣṭha chief of the Devas are the synonyms of Brahmā. Viṣṇu, Nārāyaṇa and Hari are the names of Viṣṇu.

column1: revatīśo halī rāmaḥ kāmaḥ pañcaśaraḥ smaraḥ //
column2: Kāma, Pañcaśara having five shafts and Smara are the names of God of love.

column1: lakṣmīḥ padmālayā padmā sarvaḥ sarveśvaraḥ śivaḥ /
column2: Sarva all things, Sarveevara lord of all beings, and Śiva auspicious are the names of Śiva.

column1: kapardo 'sya jaṭājūṭaḥ pināko 'jagavandhanuḥ //
column2: Kaparda is his matted hair. Pināka is the bow of lord Śiva also known as Ajagava.

column1: pramathāḥ syuḥ pāriṣadā mṛḍānī caṇḍikāmbikā /
column2: Mṛḍānī compassionate, Caṇḍikā fierce and Ambikā mother are the names of Goddess Pārvatī.

column1: dvaimāturo gajāsyaś ca senānīragnibhūrguhaḥ //
column2: Dvaimātura having two mothers and Gajāsya having an elephant face are the names of lord Gaṇeśa.

column1: ākhāṇḍalaḥ sunāsīraḥ sūtrāmāṇo divaspatiḥ /
column2: Ākhaṇḍala breaker, Sunāsīra favourable for the growth of grain, Sūtrāman guarding well and Divaspati lord of the heaven are the names of Indra.

column1: pulomajā śacīndrāṇī devī tasya tu vallabhā //
column2: Pulomajā duaghter of Puloman, a demon, Śacī powerful and Indrāṇī are the names of wife of Indra.

column1: syāt prāsādo vaijayanto jayantaḥ pākaśāsaniḥ /
column2: Jayanta victorious is the name of Pākaśāsani son of Pākaśāsana, Indra.

column1: airāvate 'bhramātaṅgairāvaṇābhramuvallabhāḥ //
column2: Airāvata, Abhramātaṅga elephantine cloud, Airāvaṇa and Abhramuvallabha mate of the female elephant of the east are the names of the elephant of Indra.

column1: hrīdinī vajramastrī syāt kuliśambhiduraṃ paviḥ /
column2: Hlādinī that which delights, Vajra, that it not a feminine word, Kuliśa, Bhidura neuter words and Pavi masculine are the words denoting Indra’s club.

column1: vyomayānaṃ vimāno 'strī pīyūṣamamṛtaṃ sudhā //
column2: The latter word is not feminine. Pīyūṣa, Amṛta and Sudhā denote ambrosia.

column1: syāt sudharmā devasabhā svargaṅgā suradīrghikā /
column2: Sudharmā is the council of gods. Svargaṅgā and Suradīrghikā denote the celestial Ganges.

column1: striyāṃ bahuṣvapsrasaḥ svarveśyā urvaśīmukhāḥ //
column2: The celestial women such as Urvaśī and others are denoted by the words Svarveśyā and Apsarasaḥ .

column1: hāhā hūhūś ca gandharvā agnirvahnirdhanañcayaḥ /
column2: Hāhā and Hūhū are the names of Gandharvas semidivine beings.

column1: jātavedāḥ kṛṣṇavartmā āśrayāśaś ca pāvakaḥ // hiraṇyaretāḥ saptārciḥ śukraś caivāśuśukṣaṇiḥ /
column2: Agni, Vahni, Dhanañjaya conqueror of wealth, Jātavedas knower of all things, Kṛṣṇavartman whose way is black, Āśrayāśa consuming everything with which it comes into contact, Pāvaka purifier, Hiraṇyaretas having golden seed, Saptārcis having seven rays, Śukra white.

column1: śucirappittamaurvastu vāḍavo vaḍavānalaḥ //
column2: Aurva, Vāḍava and Vaḍavānala denote the submarine fire.

column1: vahnerdvayorjvālakīlāvarcirhetiḥ śikhā striyāṃ /
column2: Among the words denoting the flames of fire, Jvāla and Kīla are masculine and feminine, Arcis feminine and neuter and Heti and Śikhā are feminine.

column1: triṣu sphuliṅgo 'gnikaṇo dharmarājaḥ paretarāṭ //
column2: Sphuliṅga and Agnikaṇa denote a spark of fire. These words are used in all the three genders.

column1: kālo 'ntako daṇḍadharaḥ śrāddhedevo 'tha rākṣasaḥ / kauṇapāsrapakravyādā yātudhānaś ca nairṛtiḥ //
column2: Rākṣasa, Kauṇapa coming from a corpse, Asrapa blood drinker, Kravyāda flesh eater, Yātudhāna and Nairṛti are the words denoting a demon.

column1: precetā varuṇaḥ pāśī śvasanaḥ sparśano 'nilaḥ / sadāgatirmātariśvā prāṇo marut samīraṇaḥ //
column2: Pracetas, Varuṇa and Pāśī having a noose denote Varuṇa, the upholder of moral laws. Śvasana who breathes, Sparśana who touches, Anila, Sadāgati always moving, Mātariśvan, Prāṇa life breath, Marut and Samīraṇa denote wind.

column1: javo raṃhastarasī tu laghukṣipramarandrutam /
column2: Java, raṃha and tara denote speed.

column1: satvaraṃ capalaṃ tūrṇamavilambitamāśu ca //
column2: Laghu, kṣipram , aram , drutam , satvaram , capalam , tūrṇam , avilambitam and āśu denote haste.

column1: satate 'nāratāśrāntasantatāviratāniśaṃ / nityānavaratājasramapyathātiśayo bharaḥ //
column2: Satatam , anāratam , aśrāntam , santatam , avīratam , aniśam , nityaṃ , anavaratam and ajasram mean eternally.

column1: ativelabhṛśātyarthātimātrodgāṭanirbharam / tīvraikāntanitāntāni gāḍhavāḍhadṛḍhāni ca //
column2: Atiśaya, bhara, ativelam , bhṛśam , atyartham , atimātram , udgāḍham , nirbharam , tīvram , ekāntam , nitāntam , gāḍham , bāḍham , and dṛḍham denote excess.

column1: guhyakeśo yakṣarājo rājarājo dhanādhipaḥ /
column2: Guhyakeśa, Yakṣarāja chief of Yakṣas, Rājaraja and Dhanādhipa lord of riches denote Kubera.

column1: syāt kinnaraḥ kiṃpuruṣasturaṅgavadano mayuḥ //
column2: Kinnara, Kimpuruṣa, Turaṅgavadana horsefaced and Mayu denote the Kinnaras, a class of semidivine beings.

column1: nidhir nā sevadhirvyoma tvabhraṃ puṣkaramambaram / dyodivau cāntarīkṣaṃ khaṃ kāṣṭhāśākakubho diśaḥ //
column2: Vyoma, abhram , puṣkaram , ambaram , dyo, divam , antarikṣam and kham denote the sky. Kāṣṭhā, āśā and kakubha denote the direction.

column1: abhyantarantvantarālañcakravāḍantu manḍalaṃ /
column2: Abhyantara and antarāla mean the interspace between the heaven and earth. Cakravāla and maṇḍala mean a range or orb of things.

column1: taḍitvān vārido meghastanayitnurvalāhakaḥ // kādambanī meghamālā stanitaṃ garjitaṃ tathā /
column2: Taḍitvān having lightning, vārida giver of water, megha, stanayitnu that which makes sound and balāhaka stand for cloud. Kādambinī and meghamālā denote a row of clouds.

column1: śampāśatahradāhrādinyairāvatyaḥ kṣaṇaprabhāḥ // taḍitsaudāminī vidyuccañcalā capalāpi ca /
column2: Stanita and garjita mean the rumbling of thunder clouds. Śampā, Śatahradā, hrādinī, airāvatī, kṣaṇaprabhā, taḍit, saudāminī, vidyut, cañcalā and capalā denote lightning.

column1: sphurjathurvajraniṣpeṣo vṛṣṭighātastvavagrahaḥ //
column2: Sphūrjathuḥ and vajranirghoṣa mean the peel of thunder. The cessation of rain is denoted by the word avagraha.

column1: dhārā sampāta āśāraḥ śīkaro 'mbukaṇāḥ smṛtāḥ /
column2: Dhārāsampāta and āsāra denote incessant rain. Śīkara is known to be drops of water carried by wind.

column1: varṣopalastu karakā meghachanne 'hni durdinaṃ //
column2: Varṣopala and karakāḥ are the first rain drops falling like a stone. A cloudy day is known as durdinam a bad day.

column1: antardhā vyavadhā puṃsi tvantardhirapavāraṇaṃ / apidhānatirodhānapidhānacchadanāni ca //
column2: Antardhā, vyavadhā feminine, antardhi masculine, apavāraṇam , apidhānam , tirodhānam , pidhānam , and ācchādanam mean concealing or covering.

column1: abjo jaivātṛkaḥ somo glaurmṛgāṅkaḥ kalānidhiḥ / vidhuḥ kumudavandhuś ca vimbo 'strī maṇḍalaṃ triṣu //
column2: The words Abja, Jaivātṛka, Soma, Glauḥ , Mṛgāṅka, Kalānidhi, Vidhu and Kumudabandhu denote the Moon. Bimba and maṇḍala are the words denoting the orb of the moon, the former is feminine and the latter is used in all the genders.

column1: kalā tu ṣoḍśo bhāgo bhittaṃ śakalakhaṇḍake /
column2: A sixteenth digit of the moon is kalā. Bhitta, śakala and khaṇḍaka denote a part.

column1: candrikā kaumudī jyotsnā prasādastu prasannatā //
column2: Candrikā, kaumudī and jyotsnā denote the lustre of the moon. Prasāda and prasannatā denote clear lustre.

column1: lakṣaṇaṃ lakṣmakaṃ cihnaṃ śobhā kāntirdyutiśchaviḥ /
column2: Lakṣaṇam , lakṣmakam and cihnam stand for a mark. Śobhā, kānti, dyuti and chavī denote lustre.

column1: suṣamā parmā śobhā tuṣārastuhinaṃ himaṃ // avasyāyastu nīhāraḥ prāleyaḥ śiśiro himaḥ /
column2: Suṣamā denotes exquisite lustre. Tuṣāra, tuhinam , himam , avaśyāya, nīhāra, prāleyaṃ , śiśira and himam denote snow.

column1: nakṣatramṛkṣaṃ bhantārā tārakā pyuḍu vā striyāṃ //
column2: Nakṣatram , ṛkṣam , bham , tārā, tārakā and uḍu denote an asterism. There the last word may also be feminine.

column1: gururjīva āṅgirasa uśanā bhārgavaḥ kaviḥ /
column2: Guru, Jīva and Āṅgirasa are the words standing for Jupiter. Uśanas, Bhārgava and Kavi denote Venus.

column1: vidhuntudastamo rāhur lagnaṃ rāśyudayaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: Vidhuntuda afflicting Moon and Tama denote Rāhu. The rise of the constellations is known to be lagna.

column1: saptarṣayo marīcyatrimukhāścitraśikhaṇḍinaḥ /
column2: Sages such as Marīci, Atri and others are the seven sages. They are known collectively as Citraśikhaṇḍins.

column1: haridaśvavraghmapūṣadyumaṇirmihiro raviḥ //
column2: Haridaśva, Bradhna, Pūṣā, Dyumaṇi, Mihira and Ravi denote the Sun.

column1: pariveṣastu paridhirupasūryakabhaṇḍale /
column2: The halo around the Sun is known as pariveṣa, paridhi, upasūryakam and maṇḍalam .

column1: kiraṇo 'sramayūkhāṃśugabhastighṛṇidhṛṣṇayaḥ // bhānuḥ karo marīciḥ strīpuṃsayordīdhitiḥ striyāṃ / syuḥ prabhā rugrucistviḍbhābhāśchavidyutidīptayaḥ //
column2: The ray of the Sun is denoted by the words kiraṇa, usra, mayūkha, aṃśu, gabhasti, ghṛmi, dhṛṣṇi, bhānu, kara, marīci, and dīdhiti where marīci is feminine and masculine while dīdhiti is feminine. The lustre is denoted by the words prabhā, ruk, ruci, tviṭ, bhā, bhāḥ, chavi, dyuti, dīpti, roci and śoci, where the last two are neuter, while the other words are feminine.

column1: rociḥ śocirubhe klīve prakāśo dyota ātapaḥ /
column2: The lustre of the Sun is denoted by the words prakāśa, dyota and ātapa.

column1: koṣṇaṃ kavoṣṇaṃ mandoṣṇaṃ kaduṣṇaṃ triṣu tadvati //
column2: The words koṣṇam , kavoṣṇam , mandoṣṇam and kaduṣṇam denote little heat.

column1: tirmaṃ tīkṣṇaṃ kharaṃ tadvaddiṣṭo 'nehā ca kālakaḥ /
column2: The words diṣṭa, anehā and kālaka denote time.

column1: ghasro dināhanī caiva sāyaṃsandhyā pitṛprasūḥ //
column2: The words ghasra, dinam and ahas denote day. Sāyaṃ , sandhyā and pitṛprasūḥ denote the evening.

column1: pratyūṣo 'harmukhaṃ kalyamuṣaḥpratyūṣasī api /
column2: Pratyūṣas , aharmukham , kalyaṃ , uṣas and pratyūṣas denote dawn.

column1: prāhṇāparāhṇamadhyāhṇāstrisandhyamatha śarvarī //
column2: Night is denoted by the words śarvarī, yāmī and tamī.

column1: yāmī tamī tamisrā ca jyotsnī candrakayānvitā /
column2: The night endowed with darkness is tamisrā and that with moonlight is jyotsnī.

column1: āgāmivartamānāharyuktāyāṃ niśi pakṣiṇī //
column2: The night together with the preceding and succeeding days is known as pakṣiṇī.

column1: ardharātraniśīthau pradoṣo rajanīmukhaṃ /
column2: Pradoṣa and rajanīmukham is the period preceding the night.

column1: sa parvasandhiḥ pratipatpañcadaśyorya dantaram // pakṣāntau pañcadaśyau dve paurṇamāsī tu pūrṇimā / kalāhīne sānumatiḥ pūrṇe rākā niśākare //
column2: The intervening period between the pratipat first lunar day and the fifteenth lunar day is parvan. There are two fifteenth days at the end of each one of the fortnights. Paurṇamāsī and pūrṇimā denote the last days of the bright lunar fortnight.

column1: amāvāsyā tvamāvasyā darśaḥ sūryendusaṅgamaḥ /
column2: Amāvāsyā, is being near darśa and sūryendusaṅgama union of Sun and Moon denote the last days of the dark lunar fortnight.

column1: sā dṛṣṭenduḥ sinīvālī sā naṣṭendukalā kuhūḥ //
column2: If the moon is perceived on the new moon day, it is sinīvāli and if the same is seen a digit less, it is kuhū.

column1: saṃvartaḥ pralayaḥ kalpaḥ kṣayaḥ kalpānta ity api /
column2: Saṃvarta, pralaya, kalpa, kṣaya and kalpānta denote deluge.

column1: kaluṣaṃ vṛjinaino 'ghamaṃhoduritaduṣkṛtam //
column2: The words kaluṣam , vṛjinam , enaḥ, agham , aṃhaḥ, durītam and duṣkṛtam denote sin.

column1: syāddharmamastriyāṃ puṇyaśreyasī sukṛtaṃ vṛṣaḥ /
column2: The words dharmam , puṇyaṃ , śreyas, sukṛtam and vṛṣa denote good deeds.

column1: mutprītiḥ pramado harṣaḥ pramodāmodasammadāḥ // syādānandathurānandaḥ śarmaśātasukhāni ca /
column2: The words mut, prīti, pramada, harṣa, pramoda, āmoda, sammada, ānandathuḥ , ānanda, śarma, sātam and sukham denote rejoice.

column1: śvaḥ śreyasaṃ śivaṃ bhadraṃ kalyāṇaṃ maṅgalaṃ śubham // bhāvukaṃ bhavikaṃ bhavyaṃ kuśalaṃ kṣemamastriyāṃ /
column2: The words śvaḥśreyasam , śivam , bhadram , kalyāṇam , maṅgalam , śubham , bhūvukam , bhavikam , bhavyaṃ , kuśalam and kṣemam denote only welfare. There kṣemam is used in masculine and neuter.

column1: daivaṃ diṣṭaṃ māgadheyaṃ bhāgyaṃ strī niyatirvidhiḥ //
column2: Daivam , diṣṭam , bhāgadheyam , bhāgyam , niyati and vidhi relate to fruits of previous birth.

column1: kṣetrajña ātmā puruṣaḥ pradhānaṃ prakṛtiḥ striyāṃ /
column2: The latter two are feminine. Kṣetrajña, ātman and puruṣa relate to the soul in the body.

column1: heturnā kāraṇaṃ vījaṃ nidānaṃ tvādikāraṇam //
column2: Hetu, kāraṇam and bījam denote cause. But nidāna is the primary cause.

column1: cittantu ceto hṛdayaṃ svāntaṃ hṛnmānasammanaḥ /
column2: Cittam , cetas, hṛdayaṃ , svāntam , hṛt, mānasam and manas denote mind.

column1: buddhirmanīṣā dhiṣaṇā dhīḥ prajñā śemuṣī matiḥ // prekṣopalibdhiścitsambitpratipajjñapticetanāḥ /
column2: Buddhi, manīṣā, dhiṣaṇā, dhīḥ, prajñā, śemuṣī, mati, prekṣā, upalabdhi, cit, saṃvit, pratipat, jñapti and cetanā denote intellect.

column1: dhīrdhāraṇāvatī medhā saṅkalpaḥ karma mānasaṃ //
column2: The intellect dhī which possesses retentive power is known as medhā. Saṅkalpa resolve is an activity of mind.

column1: saṅkhyā vicāraṇā carcā vicikitsā tu saṃśayaḥ / adhyāhārastarka ūhaḥ samau nirṇayaniś cayau //
column2: Carcā discussion, Saṅkhyā deliberation and vicāraṇā inquiry relate to examination of an object by means of knowledge. Vicīkitsā and saṃśaya relate to doubtful knowledge.

column1: mithyādṛṣṭirnāstikatā bhrāntirmithyāmatirbhramaḥ /
column2: Bhrānti, mithyāmati and bhrama mean false knowledge.

column1: aṅgīkārābhyupagamapratiśravasamādhayaḥ //
column2: Aṅgikāra, abhyupagama, pratiśraya and samāśraya denote acceptance. la.

column1: mokṣe dhīrjñānamanyatra vijñānaṃ śilpaśāstrayoḥ /
column2: Knowledge relating to liberation from mundane existence is jñānam .

column1: muktiḥ kaivalyanirvāṇaśreyoniḥśreyasāmṛtaṃ // mokṣo 'pavargo 'thājñānamavidyāhammatiḥ striyāṃ /
column2: Mukti, kaivalyam , nirvāṇam , śreyas, niḥṣreyasam , amṛtam , mokṣa and apavarga denote liberation from mundane existence. The words ajñānam , avidyā and ahammati stand for ignorance.

column1: vimardotthe parimalo gandhe janamanohare // āmodaḥ so 'tinirhārī surabhirghrāṇatarpaṇaḥ /
column2: The word parimala is used to denote fragrance arising from pounding or rubbing which attracts men. That which attracts very much is known as āmoda.

column1: śuklaśubhraśuciśvetaviśadaśvetapāṇḍarāḥ // avadātaḥ sito gauro valakṣo dhavalo 'rjunaḥ / hariṇaḥ pāṇḍuraḥ pāṇḍurīṣatpāṇḍustu dhūsaraḥ //
column2: The words surabhi and ghrāṇatarpaṇa denote an object possessing good fragrance. The words śukla, śubhra, śuci, śveta, viśada, śyeta, pāṇḍara, avadāta, sita, gaura, valakṣa, dhavala, arjuna, hariṇa, pāṇḍura and pāṇḍu denote white.

column1: kṛṣṇe nīlāsitaśyāmakālaśyāmalamecakāḥ /
column2: The words nīla, asita, śyāma, kāla, syāmala and mecaka denote black.

column1: pīto gauro haridrābhaḥ pālāśo harito harit //
column2: The words pīta, gaura and haridrābha denote yellow. The words pālāśa, harita and harit mean the green colour.

column1: rohito lohito raktaḥ śoṇaḥ kokanadacchaviḥ / avyaktarāgastvaruṇaḥ śvetaraktastu pāṭalaḥ //
column2: The words rohita, lohita and rakta denote red colour. The word śoṇa denotes the colour resembling red lotus. Little redness is denoted by the word aruṇa.

column1: śyāvaḥ syātkapiśo dhūmradhūmalau kṛṣṇalohite /
column2: Śyāva and kapiśa denote whitish red. Dhūmra and dhūmala denote red and black mixed.

column1: kaḍāraḥ kapilaḥ piṅgapiśaṅgaukadrupiṅgalau //
column2: Kaḍāra, kapila, piṅga, piśaṅga, kadru and piṅgala denote reddish brown.

column1: citraṃ kirmīrakalmāṣaśavalaitātha karvure /
column2: Citram , kirmīra, kalmāṣa, sabala, eta and and karbura denote variegated colours.

column1: vyāhara uktirlapitamapabhraṃśo 'paśabdakaḥ //
column2: The words vyāhāra, ukti and lapitam denote speech. Apabhraṃśa means a corrupted word.

column1: tiṅsuvantacayo kāvyaṃ kriyā vā kārakānvitā /
column2: A collection of tiṅ verb and subanta noun is a sentence. Or it may be an activity together with the case relation between a noun and a verb.

column1: itihāsaḥ purāvṛttaṃ purāṇaṃ pañcalakṣaṇaṃ //
column2: Itihāsa is that which has happened in the past. Purāṇa has five characteristics.

column1: ākhyāyikopalabdhārthā prabandhaḥ kalpanā kathā / samāhāraḥ saṃgrahastu pravahlikā prahelikā //
column2: Ākhyāyikā is a narrative of a past event. Prabandha is an imaginary story. Samāhāra and saṅgraha denote a collection of stories. Pravahlikā and prahelikā are involving conjecture.

column1: samasyā tu samāsārthā smṛtistu dharmasaṃhitā /
column2: Smṛti is a collection of texts composed for propagating religious and moral duties.

column1: ākhyāhve cābhidhānañca vārtā vṛttānta īritaḥ // hūtirākāraṇāhvānamupanyāsastu vāṅmukhaṃ /
column2: Vārtā and vṛttānta are said to denote narration ofworldly course of events. The words hūti, ākāraṇā and āhvānam denote calling. Upanyāsa and vāṅmukha mean beginning of a speech.

column1: vivādo vyavahāraḥ syāt prativākyottare same //
column2: Vivāda and vyavahāra are used in the sense of disputes relating debts, gifts etc..

column1: upoddhāta udāhāro hy artha mithyābhisaṃśanam /
column2: Mithyābhiśaṃsanam and abhiśāpa mean insult or abuse.

column1: abhiśāpo yaśaḥ kīrtiḥ praśnaḥ pṛcchānuyogakaḥ //
column2: The words yaśas and kīrti denote fame. The words praśna, pṛcchā and anuyogaka mean a query.

column1: āmreḍitaṃ dvistriruktaṃ kutsāninde ca garhaṇe / syādābhāṣaṇamālāpaḥ pralāpo 'narthakaṃ vacaḥ //
column2: The word āmreḍitam means repetition two or three times. The words kutsā, nindā and garhaṇam denote censure. The words ābhāṣaṇam and ālāpa would mean conversation preceded by mutual call.

column1: anulāpo muhurbhāṣā volāpaḥ paridevanaṃ / vipralāpo virodhoktiḥ saṃlāpo bhāṣaṇaṃ mithaḥ //
column2: Anulāpa and muhurbhāṣa mean repeated coṇversation. Vilāpa and paridevana denote speech preceded by weeping. Vipralāpa and virodhokti denote mutually contradictory utterances.

column1: supralāpaḥ suvacanamapalāpastu nihnavaḥ /
column2: Supralāpa and suvacanam mean good utterance.

column1: uṣatī vāgakalyāṇī saṅgataṃ hṛdayaṅgamaṃ //
column2: Saṅgatam and hṛdayaṅgamam would denote wellconstructed sentence.

column1: atyarthamadhuraṃ sāntvamabaddhaṃ syādanarthakaṃ / niṣṭhurāślīlaparuṣaṃ grāmyaṃ vai sunṛtaṃ priye //66ā//
column2: Abaddham and anarthakam would mean absurd. Niṣṭhuram and paruṣam mean harsh utterance. Aślīlam and grāmyam mean unrefined utterance. The statement which is pleasing and true is sūnṛtam .

column1: satyaṃ tathyamṛtaṃ samyaṅnādanisvānanisvanāḥ /
column2: Satyaṃ , tathyaṃ , ṛtam and samyak would mean truth.

column1: āravārāvasaṃrāvavirāvā atha marmaraḥ //67ā//
column2: The words nāda, nisvāna, nisvana, ārava, ārāva, saṃrāva and virāva denote ordinary sound. Marmara denotes the sound made by cloth and leaves.

column1: svanite vastraparṇānāṃ bhūṣaṇānāntu śiñjitaṃ / vīṇāyā nikvaṇaḥ kvāṇaḥ tiraścāṃ vāśitaṃ rutaṃ //68ā//
column2: The sound made by the ornaments is śiñjitam . Nikvaṇa and kvāṇa denote the sound of a lute. The sound made by birds is vāsitam . Kolāhala and kalakala mean the clear sound made by many.

column1: kolāhalaḥ kalakalo gītaṃ gānamime same /
column2: The two words gītam and gānam mean the same namely, a song.

column1: strī pratiśrut pratidhvāne tantrīkaṇṭhānnisādakaḥ //69ā//
column2: Pratiśrut and pratidhvāna mean echo, where the former is feminine.

column1: kākalī tu kale sūkṣme dhvanau tu madhurāsphuṭe /
column2: A subtle sound is kākalī. That which is sweet and not explicit is kala. Mandara is a lofty sound.

column1: kalo mantrastu gambhīre tāro 'tyuccaistrayastriṣu //70ā// samanvitalayastvekatālo vīṇā tu vallakī /
column2: Tāra is a very loud sound. Where there is a resonance and well blending of the last three sounds it is said to be ekatāla. Vīṇā, vallakī and vipañcī denote lute.

column1: vipañcī sā tu tantrībhiḥ saptabhiḥ parivādinī //71ā//
column2: That which is known to have seven strings is parivādinī.

column1: tataṃ vīṇādikaṃ vādyamānaddhaṃ murajādikaṃ / vaṃśyādikantu śuṣiraṃ kāṇsyatālādikaṃ ghanaṃ //72ā//
column2: Vīṇā and other instruments are spread out. Muraja and the like are bound. Vaṃśa flute and others have holes. An instrument made of bellmetal and the like is ghanam .

column1: caturvidhamidaṃ vādyaṃ vāditrātodyanāmakaṃ /
column2: Thus there are four kinds of musical instruments having the appellation vāditram and ātodyam .

column1: mṛdaṅgā murajā bhedāstvaṅkyāliṅgyo 'rdhakāstrayaḥ //73ā//
column2: Mṛdaṅga and Muraja are synonyms. Aṅkyāḥ , āliṅgyaḥ and ūrdhvaka are different kinds of Mṛdaṅgas.

column1: syādyaśaḥpaṭaho ṭakkā bheryāmānakadundubhiḥ / ānakaḥ paṭaho bhedā jharjharīḍiṇḍimādayaḥ //74ā// mardalaḥ paṇavastulyau kriyāmānantu tālakaḥ /
column2: Bherī and Dundubhi are synonyms, the fo^er is feminine and the latter masculine. Ānaka and Paṭaha are synonyms. Jharjharī, Ḍiṇḍima, Mardala and Paṇava are different kinds of percussion instruments. Tāla is the measure of time relating to the performance.

column1: layaḥ sāmyaṃ tāṇḍavantu nāṭyaṃ lāsyañca nartanaṃ //75ā//
column2: Laya is the equal proportion of the performance and time relating to music, dance etc. Tāṇḍavam , nāṭyaṃ , lāsyam and nartanam are synonyms.

column1: tauryatrikaṃ nṛtyagītavādyaṃ nāṭyamidaṃ trayam /
column2: Nṛtyam dance, gītam singing and vādyam instrumental, the three are known collectively as tauryatrikam .

column1: rājā bhaṭṭārako devaḥ sābhiṣekā ca devyapi //76ā//
column2: The king is known as Bhaṭṭāraka and Deva. The queen who had been anointed is Devī.

column1: śṛṅgāravīrakaruṇādbhutahāsyabhayānakāḥ / vībhatsaraudre ca rasāḥ śṛṅgāraḥ śucirujjvalaḥ //77ā//
column2: Śṛṅgāra erotic, vīra heroic, karuṇa pathos, adbhuta wonder, hāsya mirth, bhayānaka frightening, bībhatsa disgust and raudra wrath are the sentiments. The erotic is also denoted by the words śuci and ujjvala.

column1: utsāhavardhano vīraḥ kāruṇyaṃ karuṇā ghṛṇā / kṛpā dayā cānukampāpyanukrośo 'pyatho hasaḥ //78ā//
column2: The heroic sentiment is also known as utsāhavardhana. Kāruṇyam , karuṇā, ghṛṇā, kṛpā, dayā, anukampā and anukrośa denote the sentiment of pathos.

column1: hāso hāsyañca vībhatsaṃ vikṛtaṃ triṣvidaṃ dvayaṃ /
column2: Hasa, hāsa and hāsyam mean the same. Bībhatsa is also known as vikṛta.

column1: vismayo 'dbhutamāś caryaṃ citramapyatha bhairavaṃ //66B//
column2: Vismaya, adbhutam , āścaryam and citram denote wonder.

column1: dāruṇaṃ bhīṣaṇaṃ bhīṣmaṃ ghoraṃ bhīmaṃ bhayānakaṃ /
column2: Bhairavam , dāruṇam , bhīṣaṇam , bhīṣmam , ghoram , bhīmam , bhayānakam , bhayankaram and pratibhayam denote frightening.

column1: bhayaṅkaraṃ pratibhayaṃ raudrantūgramamī triṣu //67B// caturdaśa daratrāsau bhītirbhīḥ sādhvasambhayaṃ /
column2: Raudra is ugra terrible. These fourteen beginning with adbhuta are masculine relating to a sentiment. Otherwise they take the three genders. Dara, trāsa, bhītiḥ , bhīḥ , sādhvasam and bhayam mean fear.

column1: vikāro mānaso bhāvo 'nubhāvo bhāvabodhanaḥ //68B//
column2: The change relating to mind is bhāva. Anubhāva is the expression of the mental change.

column1: garvo 'bhimāno 'haṅkāro mānaścittasamunnatiḥ /
column2: The words garva, abhimāna and ahaṃkāra denote pride. Māna is elevated thinking.

column1: anādaraḥ paribhavaḥ paribhāvastiraskriyā //69B//
column2: Anādara, paribhava, paribhāva and tiraskriyā mean disrespect.

column1: vrīḍā lajjā trapā hrīḥ syādabhidhyānaṃ dhane spṛhā /
column2: The words vrīḍā, lajjā, trapā and hrī would mean shyness. The desire for wealth is abhidhyānam .

column1: kautūhalaṃ kautukañca kutukañca kutūhalaṃ //70B//
column2: The words kautūhalam , kautukam , kutukam and kutūhalam denote curiosity.

column1: stroṇāṃ vilāsavivvokavibhramā lalitantathā / helā līletyamī hāvāḥ kriyāḥ śṛṅgārabhāvajāḥ //71B//
column2: The words vilāsa, bibboka, vibhrama, lalitam , helā and līlā denoting the behaviour of women are known as hāva produced from erotic state.

column1: dravakeliparīhāsāḥ krīḍā līlā ca kūrdanaṃ /
column2: The words drava, keli, parihāsa, krīḍā and līlā denote only erotic sport.

column1: syādāchuritakaṃ hāsaḥ sotprāsaḥ samanāksmitaṃ //72B//
column2: A burst of laughter with a motive is ācchuritakam .

column1: adhobhuvanapātālaṃ chidraṃ śvabhraṃ vapā śuṣiḥ / gartāvaṭau bhuvi śvebhre tamiśrantimiraṃ tamaḥ //73B//
column2: Adhobhuvanam and pātālam denote the nether world. The words chidram , śvabhram , vapā and śuṣi denote a hole in general. Garta and avaṭa denote a hole or pit in the earth.

column1: sarpaḥ pṛdākurbhujago dandaśūko vileśayaḥ /
column2: The words sarpa, pṛdākuḥ , bhujaga, dantaśūka and bileśaya denote a serpent.

column1: viṣaṃ kṣveḍaś ca garalaṃ nirayo durgatiḥ striyāṃ //74B//
column2: The words viṣam , kṣveḍa and garalam mean poison. The words niraya and durgati mean hell. The latter is feminine.

column1: payaḥ kīlālamamṛtamudakaṃ bhuvanaṃ vanaṃ /
column2: The words payaḥ , kilālam , amṛtam , udakam , bhuvanam and vanam are used in the sense of water.

column1: bhaṅgastaraṅga ūrmirvā kallolollolakau ca tau //75B//
column2: Bhaṅga, taraṅga and ūrmi denote waves. Kallola and ullola denote mighty waves.

column1: pṛṣantivindupṛṣatāḥ kūlaṃ rodhaś ca tīrakaṃ /
column2: The words kūlam , rodhas and tīram {or tīrakam } denote banks.

column1: toyotthitaṃ tat pulinaṃ jambālaṃ paṅkakardamau //76B//
column2: That which rises from water is pulinam sand. The words jambāla, paṅka and kardama mean mire.

column1: jalocchāsāḥ parīvāhāḥ kūpakāstu vidārakāḥ /
column2: The overflow of floods is denoted by the words jalocchvāsāḥ and parīvāhāḥ .

column1: ātārastarapaṇyaṃ syāddroṇī kāṣṭhāmbuvāhinī //77B//
column2: Ātara and tarapaṇyam are used in the sense of ferry charges.

column1: kaluṣaścāvilo 'cchastu prasanno 'tha gabhīrakaṃ /
column2: Kaluṣa and āvila are used to mean impure and accha, pure. The word gabhīrakam denotes deep.

column1: agādhaṃ dāsakaivartau śambūkā jalaśuktayaḥ //78B// saugandhikantu kahlāraṃ nīlamindīvaraṃ kajaṃ /
column2: Jambūkas bivalve shells are oysters in the water. Saugandhika and kalhāra denote white lotus blossoming in the evening. Indīvara is a blue lotus. Utpala and kuvalaya denote blue lotus.

column1: syādutpalaṃ kuvalayaṃ site kumudakairave //
column2: Kumuda and kairava are used to denote white lotus.

column1: śālūkameṣāṃ kandaḥ syāt padmaṃ tāmarasaṅkajaṃ / nīlotpalaṃ kuvalayaṃ raktaṃ kokanadaṃ smṛtam //
column2: The root of these lotuses is śālūka. The words padmam and tāmarasam denote a lotus. Nīlotpalam and kuvalayam denote a lily. The red lotus is known as kokanadam .

column1: karahāṭaḥ śiphā kandaṃ kiñjalkaḥ keśaro 'striyāṃ / khaniḥ striyāmākaraḥ syāt pādāḥ pratyantaparvatāḥ //
column2: Kiñjalka and kesara mean the filament, not in feminine. The words khani and ākara denote the place from where the gems are produced. The former is feminine. Pāda and pratyantaparvata denote smaller hills.

column1: upatyakādrerāsannā bhūmirūrdhvamadhityakā / svargapātālavargādyā uktā nānārthakān śṛṇu //
column2: The earth above the hill is known as adhityakā. The groups of words belonging to the heaven and hell have been described. Listen to me! shall describe words having different meaning.

column1: āṅīṣadarthe 'bhivyāptau sīmārthe dhātuyogaje / ā pragṛhyaḥ smṛtau vākye 'pyāstu syāt kopapīḍyoḥ //
column2: The indeclinable āṅ is used in the following in the sense of a little, pervading, limit and in combination with verbs. The particle ā known as pragṛhya is used in sentences to denote remembrance.

column1: pāpakutseṣadarthe ku dhigjugupsananindayoḥ /
column2: The particle ku is used in the sense of sin, condemnation and little. Dhik is used in the sense of disgust and censure.

column1: cānvācayasamāhāretaretarasamuccaye // svastyāśīḥ kṣemapuṇyādau prakarṣe laṅghane 'pyati /
column2: Ca is used to connect with another, as a collection, union with one another, for connecting mutually independent words with a common word. Svasti is used in the sense of benediction, wellbeing and meritorious act.

column1: svitpraśne ca vitarke ca tu syādbhede 'vadhāraṇe // sakṛtsahaikavāre syādārāddūrasamīpayoḥ /
column2: Svit is used in the sense of interrogation and doubt. Tu is used to denote division and limitation. Sakṛt is used in the sense of together with and once.

column1: pratīcyāṃ carame paścādutāpyarthavikalpayoḥ //
column2: The word paścāt is used in the sense of western direction and the end.

column1: punaḥsadārthayoḥ śaśvat sākṣāt pratyakṣatulyayoḥ / khedānukampāsantoṣavismayāmantraṇe vata //
column2: Śaśvat is used in the sense of repetition and together with. Sākṣāt denotes perception and identity. Bata is used in the following senses grief, pity, pleasure, surprise and invitation.

column1: hanta harṣe 'nukampāyāṃ vākyārambhaviṣādayoḥ / prati pratinidhau vīpsālakṣaṇādau prayogataḥ //
column2: Hanta is used to express rejoice pity, beginning of a sentence and grief. Prati is used according to tradition in the sense of a representative both as repetition and as indicative etc.

column1: iti hetau prakaraṇe prakāśādisamāptiṣu /
column2: Iti is used in the sense of cause, context, making explicit etc. and conclusion.

column1: prācyāṃ purastāt prathame purārthe 'grata ity api //
column2: Purastāt is used to denote in the east, at first, before and in front of. Api is also used in the same sense.

column1: yāvattāvacca sākalye 'vadhau māne 'vadhāraṇe / maṅgalānantarārambhapraśnakārtsneṣv athotha ca //
column2: Yāvat and tāvat are used in the sense of whole, end, measure and determination. Atha is used to express auspiciousness, continuity, beginning, query and whole.

column1: vṛthā nirarthakāvidhyornānānekobhayārthayoḥ /
column2: Vṛthā is used to convey uselessness and devoid of injunction.

column1: nu pṛcchāyāṃ vikalpe ca paścātsādṛśyayoranu //
column2: Nu expresses query and option.

column1: praśnāvadhāraṇānujñānunayāmantraṇe nanu / garhāsamuccayapraśnaśaṅkāsambhāvanāsv api //
column2: Nanu is used to indicate query, determination, permission, pacification and invitation. Api is used to denote censure, collection, query, doubt and conjecture.

column1: upamāyāṃ vikalpe vā sāmitvardhe jugupsite / amā saha samīpe ca kaṃ vāriṇi ca mūrdhani //
column2: Vā expresses comparison and option. Sāmi conveys half and disgust. Amā denote togetherness and proximity. Kam means water and head.

column1: ivetthamarthayorevaṃ nūnaṃ tarke 'rthaniś caye /
column2: Evam is used to convey similarity and such and such a manner. Nūnam is used in logic and determination.

column1: tūṣṇīmarthe sukhe joṣaṃ kimpṛcchāyāṃ jugupsane //
column2: Joṣam is used to mean silence and happiness. Kim is used to convey query and disgust.

column1: nāma prākāśyasambhāvyakrodhopagamakutsane / alaṃ bhūṣaṇaparyāptiśaktivāraṇavācakam //
column2: Nāma is used to mean making explicit, conjecture, anger, approximation and censure. Alam conveys the sense of ornament, satiety, ability and prevention.

column1: hūṃ vitarke paripraśne samayāntikamadhyayoḥ /
column2: Hūm is used to convey doubt and inquiry. Samayā denotes proximity and middle.

column1: punaraprathame bhede nirniś cayaniṣedhayoḥ //
column2: Punaḥ conveys not being the first and difference.

column1: syātprabandhe cirātīte nikaṭāgāmike purā /
column2: Purā would be used to indicate continuity, long past, nearness and the future.

column1: uraryurī corarī ca vistāre 'ṅgīkṛte trayam // svarge pare ca loke svarvārtāsambhāvayoḥ kila /
column2: The three words ūrarī, ūrī and urarī are used in the sense of expansion and that which is agreed upon. Svaḥ is used in the sense of heaven and other world.

column1: niṣedhavākyālaṅkāre jijñāsāvasare khalu // samīpobhayataḥśīghrasākalyābhimukhe 'bhitaḥ /
column2: Kila is used in the sense of tidings and conjecture. The word khalu is used to denote prohibition, verbal embellishment, desire to know and pacification.

column1: nāmaprakāśayoḥ prādurmitho 'nyonyaṃ rahasyapi //
column2: Prāduḥ is used to convey name and explicitness.

column1: tiro 'ntardhau tiryagarthe hā viṣādaśugartiṣu /
column2: The word tiraḥ is used to denote disappearance and horizontal.

column1: ahahetyadbhute khede hi hetāvavadhāraṇe //
column2: The particle hi is used to denote cause and determination.

column1: cirāya cirarātrāya cirasyādyāścirārthakāḥ /
column2: The words cirāya, cirārātrāya, cirasya and others are used in the sense of long time.

column1: muhuḥ punaḥ punaḥ śaśvadabhīkṣṇamasakṛt samāḥ //
column2: Muhuḥ, punaḥ punaḥ, śaśvat, abhīkṣṇam and asakṛt again and again have the same sense.

column1: srāgjhaṭityañcasāhnāya sapadi drāṅmaṅkhu ca drute /
column2: The words śrāk, jhaṭiti, anjasā, ahnāiya, sapadi, drāk and maṅkṣu are used in the sense of quickness.

column1: balavat suṣṭhu kimuta vikalpe kiṃ kimūta ca //
column2: The words balavat, Suṣṭhu and kimuta denote excessive. Kim, kimu and uta are used in the sense of option.

column1: tu hi ca sma ha vai pādapūraṇe pūjanepyati /
column2: Su and ati are used to denote worship reverence.

column1: divāhnītyatha doṣā ca naktañca rajanāviti //
column2: Divā is used to denote at day. Doṣā and naktam are used in the sense of night.

column1: tiryagarthe sāci tiro 'pyatha sambodhanārthakāḥ / syuḥ pyāṭpāḍṅga he hai bhoḥ samayā nikaṣā hiruk //
column2: Sāci and tiraḥ are used in the sense of horizontally. The words pyāṭ, pāṭ, anga, he, hai and bhoḥ are used in the sense of calling a person. Samayā, nikaṣā and hiruk have the sense of proximity.

column1: atarkite tu sahasā syāt puraḥ purato 'grataḥ /
column2: Puraḥ, purataḥ and agrataḥ mean in front of.

column1: svāhā devahavirdāne śrauṣaṭ vauṣaṭ vaṣaṭ svadhā //
column2: Svāhā, śrauṣat, vauṣaṭ, vaṣaṭ and svadhā are used in offering made to the gods.

column1: kiñcidīṣanmanāgalpe pretyāmutra bhavāntare /
column2: The words kiñcit, īṣat and manāk are used in the sense of a little.

column1: yathā tathā caiva sāmye aho ho iti vismaye //
column2: Yathā and tathā convey similarity. Aho and ho indicate surprise.

column1: maune tu tūṣṇīṃ tūṣṇīkaṃ sadyaḥ sapadi tatkṣaṇe / diṣṭyā śamupayoṣañcetyānande 'thāntare 'ntarā //
column2: The words tūṣṇīm and tūṣṇikam are used in the sense of silence. Sadyaḥ and sapadi denote the present moment. Diṣṭyā and samupajoṣam convey rejoice.

column1: antareṇa ca madhye syuḥ prasahya tu haṭārthakam /
column2: The words antare, antarā and antareṇa denote ‘in the middle’.

column1: yukte dve sāmprataṃ sthāne 'bhīkṣṇaṃ śasvadanārate //
column2: The two words Sāmpratam and sthāne convey the sense appropriate. Abhīkṣṇam and śaśvat mean eternally.

column1: abhāve nahyano nāpi māsma mālañca vāraṇe /
column2: The words māsma, mā and alaṃ are used in the sense of restraining.

column1: pakṣāntare cedyadi ca tattve tv addhāñjasā dvayam //
column2: Cet and yadi are used to denote alternative. The two words addhā and añjasā are employed to convey truth.

column1: prākāśye prādurāviḥ syādomevaṃ paramaṃ mate /
column2: Prāduḥ and āviḥ indicate explicitness. Oṃ, evaṃ and paramaṃ convey opinion.

column1: samantatastu paritaḥ sarvato viśvagityapi //
column2: The words samantataḥ, paritaḥ, sarvataḥ and viśvak convey all around.

column1: akāmānumatau kāmamasūyopagame 'stu ca /
column2: Kāmam is used to convey permission unwillingly granted.

column1: nanu ca syādvirodhoktau kaccit kāmapravedane //
column2: The word kāmam is also used in the same sense.

column1: niḥṣamaṃ duḥṣamaṃ garhye yathāsvantu yathāyathaṃ /
column2: The words niḥ samam and duḥ samam are used to convey condemned. Yathāsvaṃ and yathāyatham convey the sense of appropriate or befitting.

column1: mṛṣā mithyā ca vitathe yathārthantu yathātathaṃ //
column2: Mṛṣā and mithyā indicate false. Yathārtham and yathātatham denote truth.

column1: syurevantu punarvaivetyavadhāraṇavācakāḥ /
