column2: The words evaṃ, tu, punaḥ, vai and vā are expressions indicating conclusion.

column1: prāgatītārthakaṃ nūnamavaśyaṃ niś caye dvayaṃ //
column2: The two words nūnam and avaśyam are used to indicate certainty. Saṃvat is used to mean the year.

column1: saṃvadvarṣe 'vare tvarvāgāmevaṃ svayamātmanā /
column2: Ām and evaṃ convey approval. Svayam means by the self Nīcaiḥ means low.

column1: alpe nīcair mahatyuccaiḥ prāyobhūmny adrute śanaiḥ //
column2: Uccaiḥ means great. Prāyaḥ denotes a great quantity. Śanaiḥ is used in the sense of slowly.

column1: sanā nitye vahirvāhye smātīte 'stamadarśane /
column2: The word sanā denotes eternal. Bahiḥ conveys the meaning outside. Sma indicates the past.

column1: asti sattve ruṣoktāvūmuṃ praśne 'nunaye tvayi //
column2: Asti conveys the sense of reality. U is an expression of anger. Ūm indicates a query.

column1: hūṃ tarke syāduṣā rātreravasāne namo natau /
column2: The word uṣā has the sense of end of the night. Namaḥ conveys obeisance.

column1: punararthe 'ṅganindāyāṃ duṣṭhu suṣṭhu praśaṃsane //
column2: Aṅga is used in the sense of again. Duṣṭu is an expression of censure and suṣṭu, of praise.

column1: sāyaṃ sāye prage prātaḥ prabhāte nikaṣāntike /
column2: Sāyam conveys the sense in the evening. The words prage and prātaḥ convey the sense ‘in the morning’.

column1: parutparāryaisamo 'bde pūrve pūrvatare yati // adyātrāhny atha pūrvehnītyādau pūrvottarā parāt /
column2: The word parut denotes the last year and parāri, the year before the last. Yati denotes the current year. Adya denotes the present day. The words pūrvedyuḥ etc.

column1: tathādharānyānyataretarātpūrvedyurādayaḥ //
column2: convey the sense of the previous day etc.

column1: ubhayadyuścobhayedyuḥ pare tvahni paredyapi /
column2: Ubhayadyuḥ and ubhayedyuḥ convey the sense of both the days.

column1: hyo gate 'nāgate 'hni śvaḥ paraśvaḥ śvaḥpare 'hani //
column2: Hyaḥ denotes yesterday and śvaḥ, the day yet to come next. Paraśvaḥ denotes the day after tomorrow.

column1: tadā tadānīṃ yugapadekadā sarvadā sadā /
column2: The words tadā and tadānīm denote at that time. Yugapat means once. Sarvadā and sadā mean always.

column1: etarhi sampratīdānīmadhunā sāmpratantathā //
column2: Etarhi, samprati, idānīm, adhunā and sāmpratam mean the present moment.

column1: ākāśe tridive nāko lokastu bhavane jane /
column2: The word nāka is used to denote the sky and heaven. The word loka means the world and people.

column1: padye yaśasi ca ślokaḥśare khaḍge ca sāyakaḥ //
column2: Śloka is used to mean a verse and fame. Sāyaka has the meaning an arrow and sword.

column1: ānakaḥ paṭaho bherī kalaṅko 'ṅkāpavādayoḥ /
column2: Ānaka denotes a bherī as well as paṭaha two kinds of drums. Kalaṅka is a mark as well as a scandal.

column1: mārute vedhasi vradhne puṃsi kaḥ kaṃ śiro 'mbunoḥ //
column2: The letter ka in the masculine is used to denote wind, Brahmā and the Sun and kaṃ in the neuter is used to denote head and water.

column1: syāt pulākastucchadhānye saṃkṣepe bhaktasikthake /
column2: The word pulāka denotes empty or bad grain, abridgement and ricewater.

column1: mahendraguggulūlūkavyālagrāhiṣu kauśikaḥ // śālāvṛkau kapiśvānau mānaṃ syānmitisādhanaṃ /
column2: The word kauśika is used in the sense of Mahendra, guggulu resin got from cow, owl, serpent and alligator. A monkey and a dog are denoted by the word śālāvṛka.

column1: sargaḥ svabhāvanirmokṣaniś cayādhyāyasmṛṣṭiṣu //
column2: Sarga is used in the sense of one’s nature, natural state, relinquishment, decision, chapter and creation.

column1: yogaḥ sannahanopāyadhyānasaṅgatiyuktiṣu /
column2: The word yoga is used in the sense of an armour, means expedience, contemplation and union.

column1: bhogaḥ sukhe stryādibhṛtāvabjau śaṅkaniśākarau //
column2: The word bhoga has the meaning of happiness and enjoying the company of a harlot. The word abja is used to denote conch and moon.

column1: kāke bhagaṇḍau karaṭau duś carmā śipiviṣṭakaḥ /
column2: Karaṭa denotes a crow and the cheek of an elephant. Śipiviṣṭa denotes a leprous person.

column1: riṣṭaṃ kṣemāśubhābhāveṣvariṣṭe tu śubhāśubhe //
column2: The word riṣṭa is used in the sense of prosperity, good and bad luck and ariṣṭa, good and bad luck.

column1: vyuṣṭiḥ phale samṛddhau ca dṛṣṭirjñāne 'kṣṇi darśane /
column2: The word vyuṣṭi is used in the sense of a fruit and plenty. The word dṛṣṭi is used to denote knowledge, eye and perception.

column1: niṣṭhāniṣpattināśāntāḥ kāṣṭhotkarṣe sthitau diśi //
column2: The word niṣṭah has the sense of accomplishing, nonexistence and destruction. The word kāṣṭhā is used to denote excellence, state and direction.

column1: bhūgovācastviḍā ilāḥ pragāḍhaṃ bhṛṣakṛcchrayoḥ / bhṛśapratijñayorvāḍhaṃ śaktasthūlau dṛḍhau triṣu //
column2: The words iḍā and ilā convey the sense of a cow, earth and speech. Pragāḍham denotes much and difficult. The word dṛḍha means capable of and stout. Vyūḍha has the meaning placed in order and firmness.

column1: vinyastasaṃhatau vyūḍhau kṛṣṇo vyāse 'rjune harau /
column2: The word Kṛṣṇa denotes Vyāsa, Arjuna and Hari.

column1: paṇo dūyatādiṣūtsṛṣṭe bhṛtau mūlye dhane 'pi ca //
column2: Paṇa is used to denote the stake in gambling etc., wages, price and a particular coin. 0.

column1: maurvyāṃ dravyāśrite satvaśuklasandhyādike guṇaḥ /
column2: The word guṇa is used in the sense of the bowstring, quality of a substance, qualities like sattva goodness, bravery and treaty etc.

column1: śreṣṭhe 'dhipe grāmaṇīḥ syāt jugpsākaruṇe ghṛṇe //
column2: The word grāmaṇī is used to denote excellent person and leader in a village.

column1: tṛṣṇā spṛhāpipāse dve vipaṇiḥ syādvaṇikpathe /
column2: . Tṛṣṇā is used to convey desire and desire to drink. The word vipaṇi is used to denote a merchant’s shop.

column1: viṣābhimaraloheṣu tīkṣṇaṃ klīve khare triṣu //
column2: Tīkṣṇam is used to mean poison, battle and iron in the neuter, but in all the three genders when denoting sharpedged.

column1: pramāṇaṃ hetumaryādāśāstreyattāpramātṛṣu /
column2: The word pramāṇa is used to mean cause, limit in the śāsira, extent and the knower.

column1: karaṇaṃ kṣetragātrādāvīriṇaṃ śūnyamūṣaraṃ // yantā hastipake sūte vahnijvālā ca hetayaḥ /
column2: The word īriṇam is used to convey a barren land and a desert. The word yantṛ is used in the sense of a mahout and a charioteer. The word heti denotes flame.

column1: srutaṃ śāstrāvadhṛtayoryugaparyāptayoḥ kṛtaṃ // khyāte hṛṣṭe pratīto 'bhijātastu kulaje budhe /
column2: The word śrutam is used to convey scriptures and accurate knowledge. Kṛtam is used to mean the first yuga and enough. Pratīta is used to mean wellknown and delight. Abhijāta is used to denote born in a good family and wise.

column1: viviktau pūtavijanau mūrchitau mūḍsocchayau //
column2: The word vivikta means pure and devoid of men. Mūrchita means stupefied and elevated prosperous.

column1: artho 'bhidheyaraivastuprayojananivṛttiṣu /
column2: Artha conveys the sense ‘to be expressed’, riches, an object, use and end.

column1: nidānāgamayostīrthamṛṣijuṣṭajale gurau //
column2: tīrtham expresses the sense of water tank, scriptures, water courses honoured by sages and preceptor.

column1: prādhānye rājaliṅge ca vṛṣāṅge kakudo 'striyāṃ /
column2: Kakudaḥ is used in the sense of importance, the insignia of a king and a limb of a bull hump on the shoulder in the masculine and neuter.

column1: strī sambijjñānasambhāṣākriyākārājināmasu //
column2: The feminine word saṃvit conveys the sense of knowledge, conversation, a disciplined action, battle and name.

column1: dharme rahasyupaniṣat syādṛtau vatsare śarat /
column2: The word upaniṣat is used in the sense of dharma and secret doctrine such as philosophy.

column1: padaṃ vyavasititrāṇasthānalakṣmāṅghrivastuṣu // triṣvaṣṭamadhurau svādū mṛdū cātīkṣṇakomalau /
column2: The word padam is used in the sense of endeavour, protection, position, mark, foot and object. These are used in all the three genders The word svādū denotes favourite and sweet, Mṛdū denotes not sharp and soft.

column1: satye sādhau vidyamāne praśaste 'bhyarhite ca sat //
column2: Sat is used to convey truth, good people, existence, praiseworthy and respectable.

column1: vidhirvidhāne daive 'pi praṇidhiḥ prārthane care /
column2: Praṇidhi conveys the meaning of request and a spy.

column1: vadhūrjāyā snuṣā ca sudhālepo 'mṛtaṃ snuhī //
column2: Sudhā. denotes plaster used in temples etc., nectar and the milkhedge plant.

column1: spṛhā sampratyayaḥ śraddhā paṇḍitammanyagarvitau /
column2: The word śraddhā denotes respect and desire. Paṇḍitammanyaḥ is one who thinks himself as learned and proud as well.

column1: brahmabandhuradhikṣepe bhānū raṣmidivākarau //
column2: Brahmabandhu is used in the sense of censure. Bhānu means ray as well as Sun.

column1: grāvāṇau śailapāṣānau mūrkhanīcau pṛthagjanau / taruśailau śikhariṇau tanustvagdehayorapi //
column2: Grāvan is used to denote a hill and a stone. The word pṛthakjana denotes a fool and also a low class man. The word śikharin denotes a tree as well as a mountain. Tanu denotes the skin and the body.

column1: ātmā yatno dhṛtirvuddhiḥ svabhāvo brahmavarṣma ca /
column2: The word yatna denotes soul, firmness, intellect, nature and path of Brahman.

column1: utthānaṃ pauruṣe tantre vyutthānaṃ pratirodhane //
column2: Utthānaṃ denotes effort and remedial act for family. Vyutthānaṃ denotes rejection.

column1: niryātanaṃ vairaśuddhau dāne nyāsārpaṇe 'pi ca /
column2: The word niryātana is used to denote revenge, gift and restitution of a deposit.

column1: vyasanaṃ vipadi bhraśe doṣe kāmajakopaje //
column2: Vyasanam has the sense of grief, fall and crime due to passion or wrath.

column1: mṛgayākṣo divāsvapnaḥ parivādaḥ striyo madaḥ / tauryatrikaṃ vṛthāṭyā ca kāmajo daśako gaṇaḥ //
column2: Hunting, diceplay, dreaming during the day, accusation, women, intoxication, the triple symphony dance, music and instrumental music and strolling about idly are the group of crime arising from passion.

column1: paiśūnyaṃ sāhasaṃ droha īrṣyāsūyārthadūṣaṇam / vāgdaṇḍaś caiva pāruṣyaṃ krodhajo 'pi gaṇo 'ṣṭakaḥ //
column2: Slandering, bravery, offence, hatred, jealousy, extravagance, reprimand and harshness are the eight crimes arising from wrath. Kaupinam is used to denote a wrong deed, secret and organ of generation.

column1: akarmaguhye kaupīnaṃ maithunaṃ saṅgatau ratau /
column2: Maithunam is employed in the sense of relating to union with wife and sexual union.

column1: pradhānaṃ paramārthā dhīḥ prajñānaṃ buddhicihnayoḥ //
column2: Pradhānam denotes the supreme spirit and intellect. Prajñānam is used to mean intellect and mark.

column1: krandane rodanāhvāne varṣma dehapramāṇayoḥ /
column2: Krandanam means crying and calling. Varṣma denotes body and extent.

column1: ārādhanaṃ sādhane syādavāptau toṣaṇe 'pi ca //
column2: Ārādhanam means accomplishing, attainment and satisfaction.

column1: ratnaṃ svajātiśreṣṭhe 'pi lakṣma cihnapradhānayoḥ /
column2: Ratnam is used to mean that which is excellent among its own class. Lakṣma is used to denote a mark and chief.

column1: kalāpo bhūṣaṇe varhe tūṇīre saṃhate 'pi ca // talpaṃ śayyāṭṭāreṣu ḍimbhau tu śiśuvāliśau /
column2: Kalāpa denotes an ornament, peacock’s plumes, quiver and a collection. The word talpam is used to denote bed, an apartment on the roof and woman.

column1: stambhau sthūṇājaḍībhāvau sabhye saṃsadi vai sabhā //
column2: The word stambha is used to denote a pillar of a building and dull. The word sabhā is used to convey the meaning of an assembly and member of a house.

column1: kiraṇapragrahau raśmī dharmāḥ puṇyayamādayaḥ /
column2: Raśmī is a ray of light as well as rein of horses etc.. The word dharma is used to denote merit and selfcontrol etc.

column1: lalāmaṃ pucchapuṇḍrāśvabhūṣāprādhānyaketuṣu //
column2: The word lalāma conveys the meaning of tail, mark on the forehead of horses etc., horse, ornament, prominence and banner.

column1: pratyayo 'dhīnaśapathajñānaviśvāsahetuṣu /
column2: The word pratyaya is employed in the sense of subject to control, oath, knowledge, faith and cause.

column1: samayāḥ śapathācārakālasiddhāntasaṃvidaḥ //
column2: The word samaya is used to convey an agreement, practice, time, a dogma and knowledge.

column1: atyayo 'tikrame kṛcchre satyaṃ śapathatathyayoḥ /
column2: The word atyaya is used to mean transgression and crime. Satyam means an oath and truth.

column1: vīryaṃ balaprabhāvau ca rūpyaṃ rūpe praśastake //
column2: The word vīryam is used in the sense of strength, and greatness. Rūpyam is used to mean praiseworthy form.

column1: durodaro dyūtakāre paṇe dyūte durodaraṃ /
column2: Durodara is employed to denote a gambler and durodaram to denote the stake in gambling.

column1: mahāraṇye durgapathe kāntāraḥ punnapuṃsakaṃ //
column2: The word kāntāra is used to mean a great forest or a difficult path, in the masculine and neuter.

column1: yamānilendracandrārkaviṣṇusiṃhādike hariḥ /
column2: The word hari is used to denote Yama god of death, Anila wind, Indra ruler of the celestials, Candra Moon, Arka Sun, Viṣṇu and a lion etc.

column1: daro 'striyāṃ bhaye śvabhre jaṭharaḥ kaṭhine 'pi ca //
column2: The word dara is employed to mean a hole and fear, in the masculine and neuter. The word jaṭhara means hard besides stomach.

column1: udāro dātṛmahatoritarastvanyanīcayoḥ /
column2: Udāra is used to denote giver and great. Itara means different as well as low.

column1: cūḍā kirīṭaṃ keśāś ca saṃyatā maulayastrayaḥ //
column2: Cūḍā denotes crown and hair. The lock of hair is called mauli.

column1: baliḥ karopahārādau sainyasthair yādike balaṃ /
column2: The word bali is used to mean tax, offering etc. The word balam is used to denote an army and firmness.

column1: strīkaṭīvastrabandhe 'pi nīvī paripaṇe 'pi ca //
column2: The word nīvī is employed to mean the knot on the waist garment of a women and ransom against the prince etc.

column1: śukrale mūṣike śreṣṭhe sukṛte vṛṣabhe vṛṣaḥ / dyūtākṣe sāriphalake 'pyākarṣo 'thākṣamindriye // nā dyūtāṅge ca karṣe ca vyavahāre kalidrume /
column2: The word vṛṣa is used in the following senses the scrotum that discharges semen, rat, excellence, good deed and a bull. The word ākarṣa is used to denote diceplay, the die and the board for diceplay. The word akṣam means an organ, and in the masculine, the dice, difference in the measure, dispute and the vibhītaka one of the three myrobalans.

column1: ūṣṇīṣaḥ syāt kirīṭādau karṣūḥ kulyābhidhāyinī //
column2: The word uṣṇīṣa is used to mean crown etc. Karṣū conveys the sense of a small river.

column1: pratyakṣe 'dhikṛte 'dhyakṣaḥ sūryavahnī vibhāvasū /
column2: The word adhyakṣa means visible and one who presides over. The word vibhāvasu denotes the Sun and Fire.

column1: śṛṅgārādau viṣe vīrye guṇe rāge drave rasaḥ // tejaḥpurīṣayorvarca āgaḥ pāpāparādhayoḥ /
column2: The word rasa is employed to denote the sentiments such as erotic and others, poison, splendour, qualities such as sweet, sour etc., passion and juice. The word varcas denotes feces as well as splendour. The word āga denotes sin and crime.

column1: chandaḥ padye 'bhilāse ca sādhīyān sādhuvāḍhayoḥ /
column2: The word chandas means poetry and desire. Sādhīyān is used to denote good as well as strong.

column1: vyūho vṛnde 'pyahirvṛtre 'pyagnīndvarkāstamonudaḥ //
column2: Vyūha means a collection as well as strength. The word ahiḥ denotes Vṛtra as well as a serpent.

column1: vakṣye bhūpurādrivanauṣadhisiṃhādinargakān /
column2: l. shall describe the words denoting earth, city, forest, herbs and lion etc.

column1: bhūranantā kakṣamā dhātrī kṣmāpyākuḥ syāddharitryapi //
column2: The following words denote the earth bhūḥ , anantā, kṣamā, dhātrī, kṣmā, jyā, kuḥ and dharitrī.

column1: mṛnmṛttikā praśastā tu mṛtsā mṛtsnā ca mṛttikā /
column2: The words mṛt and mṛttikā denote a piece of earth. Commendable earth is denoted by the words mṛtsā and mṛtsnā.

column1: jagattrapiṣṭapaṃ lokaṃ bhuvanaṃ jagatī samā //
column2: The land space on the earth is denoted by the words jagat, viṣṭapam , loka, bhuvanam and jagati.

column1: ayanaṃ vartma mārgādhvapanthānaḥ padavī sṛtiḥ / saraṇiḥ paddhattiḥ padyā vartanyekapadīti ca //
column2: The words, ayanam , vartma, mārga, adhva, panthā, padavī, sṛti, saraṇī, paddhati, padyā, vartanī and ekapadī denote a path.

column1: pūḥ strī purīnagaryau vā pāttanaṃ puṭabhedanam /
column2: The words pūḥ, purī, nagarī, pattanam and puṭabhedanam denote a town.

column1: sthānīyaṃ nigamo 'nyattu yanmūlanagarātpuram // tacchākhānagaraṃ veśo veśyājanasamāśrayaḥ /
column2: Sthānīyam is a big city surrounding big pathways. Śākhānagaraṃ is a suburb of a principal city. The suburb where the harlots dwell is veśa.

column1: āpaṇastu niṣadyāyāṃ vipaṇiḥ paṇyavīthikā //
column2: Āpaṇa and niṣadyā denote the place for selling goods. Vipaṇi and paṇyavīthikā denote the market street.

column1: rathyā pratolī viśikhā syāccayo vapramastriyāṃ /
column2: Rathyā, pratolī and viśikhā denote the pathways in the interior of a village.

column1: prākāro varaṇaḥ śālaḥ prācīraṃ prāntato vṛtiḥ // bhittiḥ strī kuhyameḍūkaṃ yadantarnastakīkasaṃ /
column2: Prākāra, varaṇa and śāla denote the surrounding fence set up with poles, thorns etc.. A surrounding fence made up at the border with bamboo, thorns etc. is called prācīnam . Bhitti and kuḍyam denote a wall.

column1: vāsaḥ kūṭo dvayoḥ śālā sabhā sañjavanantvidam //
column2: The words vāsa, kuṭī, śālā and sabhā denote the assembly hall.

column1: catuḥśālaṃ munīnāntu parṇaśāloṭajo 'striyāṃ /
column2: Sāñjavanam and catuḥśālam is a group of four houses forming a court. Parṇaśālā and uṭaja not feminine denote a hermitage.

column1: caityamāyatanantulye vājiśālā tu mandurā //
column2: Vājiśālā and mandurā denote a stable.

column1: harmyādi dhanināṃ vāsaḥprāsādo devabhūbhujāṃ /
column2: The dwelling place of the rich is harmyādi. The place of the gods and kings is called prāsāda.

column1: strī dvārdvāraṃ pratīhāraḥ syādvitardistu vedikā //
column2: The words Dvāḥ , dvāram and pratihāra denote a door, where the word Dvāḥ is feminine. Vitardi and vedikā mean a fence.

column1: kapotapālikāyantu viṭaṅkaṃ puṃ napuṃsakaṃ / kavāṭamavarantulye niḥśreṇistvadhirohiṇī //
column2: lla. The words kapotapālikā and viṭaṅkam , respectively masculine and neuter denote a pigeonhouse made of wood etc.. Kapāṭa and arara are synonṭyms meaning a door.

column1: sammārjanī śodhanī syāt saṅkaro 'vakaras tathā /
column2: Sammārjanī and Śodhanī mean broomstick. Saṅkara and avakara denote sweepings.

column1: adrigotrigirigrāvā gahanaṃ kānanaṃ vanaṃ //
column2: The words adri, gotra, giri and grāvā denote mountains in general.

column1: ārāmaḥ syādupavanaṃ kṛtrimaṃ vanameva yat / syādetadeva pramadavanamantaḥpurocitaṃ //
column2: The words ārāma and upavanam denote an artificial garden that has been accomplished. The same that is fit for harem is called pramadavanam .

column1: vīthyālirāvaliḥ paṅktiśreṇīlekhāstu rājayaḥ /
column2: The words vīthī, āliḥ , āvaliḥ , paṅktiḥ and śreṇī denote a row. The words lekhāḥ and rājayaḥ denote lines.

column1: vānaspatyaḥ phalaiḥ puṣpāttairapuṣpādvanaspatiḥ //
column2: A tree that is seen with fruits produced from flowers is vānaspatyaḥ . A tree that is seen with fruits not produced from flowers is vanaspatiḥ .

column1: oṣadhyaḥ phalapākāntāḥ palāśī drudrumāgamāḥ /
column2: Those which end with fruitbearing are known as oṣadhīs. The words palāśī, druḥ , druma and agama denote a tree.

column1: sthāṇu vā nā dhruvaḥ śaṅkuḥ praphullotphullasaṃsphuṭāḥ //
column2: The words sthāṇu, dhruva and śaṅku denote a cut tree. The word stāiṇu is optionally masculine.

column1: palāśaṃ chadanaṃ parṇamidhmamedhaḥ samit striyāṃ /
column2: The words palāśam , chadanam and parṇam denote a leaf.

column1: bodhidrumaś caladalo dadhitthagrāhimanmathāḥ //
column2: Bodhidruma and caladala denote the holy fig tree.

column1: tasmin dadhiphalaḥ puṣpaphaladantaśaṭhāvapi /
column2: Dadhittha, grāhī, manmatha, dadhiphala, puṣpaphala and dantaśaṭha denote the woodapple tree.

column1: uḍumbare hemadugdhaḥ kovidāre dvipatrakaḥ //
column2: The words udumbara, hemadugdha, kovidāra and dvipatraka denote udumbara.

column1: saptaparṇo viśālatvak kṛtamālaṃ suvarṇakaḥ / ārevatavyādhighātasampākacaturaṅgulāḥ //
column2: The saptaparṇa tree is also known as viśālatvak. The kṛtamāla tree is also known as suvarṇaka, ārevata, vyādhighāta, śampāka and cuturaṅgala.

column1: syājjambīre dantaśaṭho varuṇe tiktaśāvakaḥ /
column2: The Jambīra tree is also called dantaśaṭha. The Varuṇa tree is also called tiktaśāka.

column1: putrāge puruṣastuṅgaḥ keśaro devavallabhaḥ //
column2: Punnāga tree is also called puruṣa, tuṅga, kesara and devavallabha.

column1: pāribhadre nimbatarurmandāraḥ pārijātakaḥ /
column2: Nimbataru, mandāra and pārijātaka are the other names of pāribhadra tree.

column1: vañjulaścitrakṛccātha dvau pītanakapītanau //
column2: Pītana and kapītana denote the āmrātaka tree.

column1: āmrātake madhūke tu guḍapuṣpamadhudrumau /
column2: The other names of madhūka are guḍapuṣpa and madhudruma.

column1: pīlau guḍaphalaḥ sraṃsī nādeyī cāmbuvetasaḥ //
column2: Guḍaphala and sraṃsī are the other names of pīlu. Nādeyī is the other name of ambhuvetas.

column1: śobhāñjane śigrutīkṣṇagandhakākṣīramocakāḥ /
column2: Śigruḥ , tīkṣṇagandhaka, akṣīva and mocaka are the other names of śobhāñjana.

column1: rakto 'sau madhuśigruḥ syādariṣṭaḥ pheṇilaḥ samau //
column2: If this śobhāñjana is red it is called madhuśigruḥ . Ariṣṭa and phenila are synonyms.

column1: gālavaḥśāvaro lodhrastirīṭastilvamārjanau /
column2: Lodhra is also called gālava, śābara, tirīṭa, tilva and mārjana.

column1: śeluḥ śleṣmātakaḥ śīta uddālo bahuvārakaḥ //
column2: Uddālaka is also known as śeluḥ , śleṣmātaka, śīta and bahuvāraka.

column1: vaikaṅkataḥ śruvāvṛkṣo granthilo vyāghrapādapi / tindukaḥ sphūrjakaḥ kālo nādeyī bhūmijambukaḥ //
column2: The other names of vikaṅkata are sruvāvṛkṣa, granthila and vyāghrapāt. Tinduka is also called sphūrjaka and kāla skandha. The terms nādeyī and bhūmijambuka denote nāgaraṅga.

column1: kākatindau pīlukaḥ syāt pāṭalirmokṣamuṣkakau / kramukaḥ paṭṭikākhyaḥ syātkumbhī kaiṭaryakaṭphale //
column2: Kākatindu and kāka pīluka are synonyms. Kramuka and paṭṭikākhya would denote lohitalodhra. Kumbhī is also known as kaiḍarya and kaṭphala.

column1: vīravṛkṣo 'ruṣkaro 'gnimukhī bhallātakīṃ triṣu /
column2: Vīravṛkṣa, aruṣkara and agnimukhī are the synonyms of bhallātakī in all the three genders.

column1: savarjakāsanajīvāś ca pītasāle 'tha mālake //
column2: Sarjaka, pītasāraka and asana are synonyms of jīva jīvaka.

column1: sarjāśvakarṇau vīrendrau indradruḥ kakubho 'rjunaḥ /
column2: Sarja and aśvakarṇa are synonyms of sāla. Arjuna tree is also called vīrataru, indradruḥ , and kakubhaḥ .

column1: iṅgudī tāpasatarurmocā śālmalireva ca //
column2: Iṅgudī is also known as tāpasataru. Śālmali is also known as mocā.

column1: ciravilvo naktamālaḥ karajaś ca karañjake / prakīryaḥ pūtikarajo markaṭyaṅgāravallarī //
column2: Cirabilva , naktamāla and karaja are the other names of karañjaka. Pūtika is also known as prakīrya and pūtikaraja. Markaṭī and aṅgāravallarī are varieties of karañja.

column1: rohī rohitakaḥ plīhaśatrurdāḍimapuṣpakaḥ /
column2: Rohī, plīhaśatru and dāḍimapuṣpaka are synonyms of rohitaka.

column1: gāyatrī bālatanayaḥ khadiro dantadhāvanaḥ //
column2: Khadira is also known as gāyatrī, bālatanaya and dantadhāvana.

column1: arimedo viṭkhadire kadaraḥ khadire site /
column2: Arimeda and viṭkhadira denote varieties of bad smelling khadira. Kadara denotes the white khadira.

column1: pañcāṅgulo vardhamānaś cañcurgandharvahastakaḥ //
column2: Eraṇḍa is also called pañcāṅgula, vardhamāna, cañcu and gandharvahastaka,

column1: piṇḍītako maruvakaḥ pītadāru ca dāru ca /
column2: Piṇḍītaka and maruvaka are synonyms of madana.

column1: devadāruḥ pūtikāṣṭhaṃ śyāmā tu mahilāhvayā //
column2: Devadāru is also called pītadāru, dāru and pūtikāṣṭham .

column1: latā govandanī gundā priyaṅguḥ phalinī phalī /
column2: Priyaṅgu is also known as śyāmā, mahilāhvayā, latā, govandanī, gundrā, phalinī and phalī.

column1: maṇḍūkaparṇapatrorṇanaṭakaṭvaṅgaṭuṇṭukāḥ // śyonākaśukanāsarkṣadīrghavṛntakuṭannaṭāḥ /
column2: Śoṇaka is also known as maṇḍūkaparṇa, patrorṇa, naṭa, kaṭvaṅga, ṭuṇṭuka, śyonāka, śukanāsa, ṛkṣa, dīrghavṛnta and kuṭannaṭa.

column1: pītadruḥ saralaścātha niculo 'mbuja ijjalaḥ //
column2: Pītadru and sarala are synonyms. Nicula, ambuja and hijjala are the synonyms of a kind of reed.

column1: kākoḍumbarikā phalgurariṣṭaḥ picumardakaḥ /
column2: Kākodumbarikā and phalguḥ are the synonyms of malayū.

column1: sarvatobhadrako nimbe śirīṣastu kapītanaḥ //
column2: Ariṣṭa, picumardaka, sarvatobhadra are synonyms of nimba. Śirīṣa is also known as kapītana.

column1: vakulo vañjulaḥ proktaḥ picchilāguruśiṃśapāḥ /
column2: Vakula bakula is said to be vañjula. Kapilā is also called as picchilā and aguruśiṃśapā.

column1: jayā jayantī tarkārī kaṇikā gaṇikārikā // āparṇamagnamanthaḥ syādvatsako girimallikā /
column2: Jayā, jayantī and tarkārī are synonyms of vaijayantikā. Kaṇikā is also known as gaṇikārikā, śrīparṇam and agnimantha. Vatsaka and girimallikā are synonyms of kuṭaja.

column1: kālaskandhastamālaḥ syāt taṇḍulīyo 'lpamāriṣaḥ //
column2: Kālaskandha is a synonym of tamāla. Taṇḍulīya is known as alpamāriṣa.

column1: sindhuvārastu nirguṇḍī saivāsphotā vanodbhavā /
column2: Sinduvāra is also known as nirguṇḍī.

column1: gaṇikā yūthikāmbaṣṭhā saptalā navamālikā //
column2: Yūthikā is also known as gaṇikā and ambaṣṭhā. Navamālikā is also known as saptalā.

column1: atimuktaḥ puṇḍrakaḥ syātkumārī taraṇiḥ sahā /
column2: Atimukta and puṇḍraka are different varieties of kunda. Kumārī is also known as sahā and taraṇi.

column1: tatra śoṇe kuruvakastatra pīte kuruṇṭakaḥ //
column2: Therein, the red variety is kurabaka and the yellow variety is kuruṇṭaka.

column1: nīlā jhiṇṭī dvayorvāṇā bhiṇṭī sairīyakas tathā /
column2: The blue jhiṇṭī is also known as bāṇā. It is also known as dāsī and artagala. Jhiṇṭī in general is known as saireyaka.

column1: tasminrakte kuruvakaḥ pīte sahacarī dvayoḥ //
column2: If it is red, it is known as kurabaka. If it is yellow, it is known as sahacarī and also as sahacara.

column1: dhustūraḥ kitavo dhūrto rucako mātulaṅgake /
column2: Kitava and dhūrta are the other names of dhattūra. Rucaka is the other name of mātuluṅgaka.

column1: samīraṇo maruvakaḥ prasthapuṣpaḥ phaṇijjhakaḥ //
column2: Samīraṇa, maruvaka, prasthapuṣpa and phaṇijjaka are the synonyms of jambīra.

column1: kuṭherakastu parṇāse 'thāsphoto vasukārkake /
column2: Kuṭheraka is the other name of parṇāsa.

column1: śivamallī pāśupato vṛndā vṛkṣādanī tathā //
column2: Vasuka and āsphoṭa are the synonyms of arka. Śivamallī and pāśupata are synonyms.

column1: jīvantikā vṛkṣaruhā guḍūcī tantrikāmṛtā /
column2: Vṛndā, vṛkṣādanī, jīvantikā and vṛkṣaruhā are the synonyms of the plant that clings to a tree and grows.

column1: somavallī madhurṇī mūrvā tu moraṭī tathā // madhulikā madhuśreṇī gokarṇī pīluparṇyapi /
column2: Guḍūcī has the other names tantrikā, amṛtā, somavallī and madhuparṇī. Mūrvā is also called moraṭā, madhūlikā, madhuśreṇī, gokarṇī and pīluparṇī.

column1: pāṭhāmbaṣṭhā viddhakarṇī prācīnā vanatiktikā //
column2: Pāṭhā is also known as āmbaṣṭhā, viddhakarṇī, pracinā and vanatiktikā.

column1: kaṭuḥ kaṭumbharā cātha cakrāṅgī śakulādanī /
column2: Kaṭuḥ , kaṭumbharā, cakrāṅgī and śakulādanī are the names of kaṭurohiṇī.

column1: ātmaguptā prāvṛṣāyī kapikacchuś ca markaṭī //
column2: Ātmaguptā, prāvṛṣāyī and kapikacchu are the other names of markaṭī.

column1: apāmārgaḥ śaikharikaḥ pratyakparṇī mayūrakaḥ /
column2: Apāmārga is also known as śaikharika, pratyakparṇī and mayūraka.

column1: phañjikā brāhmaṇī bhārgī dravanti śambarī vṛṣā //
column2: Phañjikā and brāhmaṇī are the other names of bhārgī. Dravantī, śambarī and vṛṣā are synonyms.

column1: maṇḍūkaparṇī bhaṇḍīrī samaṅgā kālameṣikā /
column2: Maṇḍūkaparṇī, bhaṇḍīrī, samaṅgā and kālameṣikā are synonyms of mañjiṣṭhā.

column1: rodanī kacchurānantā samudrāntā durālabhā //
column2: Rodanī, kacchurā, anantā, samudrāntā and durālabhā are synonyms of dhanvayāsa.

column1: pṛśniparṇī pṛthakparṇī kalaśirdhāvanirguhā /
column2: Pṛśniparṇī, pṛthakparṇī, kalaśi, dhāvani and guhā are synonyms.

column1: nidigdhikā spṛśī vyāghrī kṣudrā dusparśayā saha //
column2: Nidigdhikā, spṛśī, vyāghrī, kṣudrā and dussparśā are synonyms.

column1: avalgujaḥ somarājī suvalliḥ somavallikā / kālameṣī kṛṣṇaphalā vakucī pūtiphaly api //
column2: Avalguja, somarājī, suvalli, somavallikā, kālameśī, kṛṣṇaphallā and pūtiphalī are synonyms of vākucī. Kaṇā, uṣaṇā and upakulyā are synonyms.

column1: kaṇoṣaṇopakulyā syācchreyasī gajapippalī /
column2: Śreyasī and gajapippalī are synonyms.

column1: cavyantu cavikā kākaciñcī guñje tu kṛṣṇalā //
column2: Cavyam and cavikā are synonyms. Kākaciñcī, guñja and kṛṣṇalā are synonyms.

column1: viśvā viṣā prativiṣā vanaśṛṅgāṭagokṣurau /
column2: Viśvā, viṣā and prativiṣā are synonyms. Vanaśṛṅgāṭa and gokṣura are synonyms.

column1: nārāyaṇī śatamūlī kāleyakaharidravaḥ //
column2: Nārāyaṇī and śatamūlī are synonyms.

column1: dārvī pacampacā dāru śuklā haimavatī vacā /
column2: Kālīyaka, haridruḥ , dārvī, pacampacā, dāruśuklā and haimavatī are synonyms of parjanī.

column1: vacogragandhā ṣaḍgranthā golomī śataparvikā //
column2: Ugragandhā, ṣaḍgranthā, golomī and śataparvikā are the synonyms of vacā.

column1: āsphotā girikarṇī syāt siṃhāsyo vāsako vṛṣaḥ /
column2: Āsphoṭā and girikarṇī are synonyms. Siṃhāsya, vāsaka and vṛṣa are synonyms.

column1: miśī madhurikācchatrā kokilākṣekṣurakṣurā //
column2: Madhurikā is also called misi and chatrā. Kokilākṣa is also known as ikṣura and kṣura.

column1: viḍaṅgo 'strī kṛmighnaḥ syāt vajradrusnuksnuhī sudhā / mṛdvīkā gostanī drākṣā valā vāṭyālakas tathā //
column2: Viḍaṅga is known as kṛmighna and is used in the masculine and neuter. Vajradru is also known as snuk, snuhī and sudhā. Mṛdvīkā and gostanī are the other names of drākṣā. Balā and vāṭyālakā are synonyms.

column1: kālā masūravidalā tripuṭā trivṛtā trivṛt /
column2: Kālā and masūravidalā are synonyms of black trivṛt. Trivṛt is also known as tripuṭā and trivṛtā.

column1: madhukaṃ klītakaṃ yaṣṭimadhukā madhuyaṣṭikā //
column2: Madhukam , klītakam , yaṣṭimadhukam and madhuyaṣṭikā are synonyms.

column1: vidārī kṣīraśuklekṣugandhā kroṣṭrī ca yā sitā /
column2: Ikṣugandhā is also known as vidārī, kṣīraśukla and kroṣṭrī.

column1: gopī śyāmā śārivā syādanantotpalaśārivā //
column2: Gopī, śyāmā, śārivā and anantā are the other names of utpalaśārivā.

column1: mocā rambhā ca kadalī bhaṇṭākī duṣpradharṣiṇī /
column2: Mocā and rambhā are synonyms of kadali. Bhaṇṭākī and duṣpradharṣiṇī are synonyms .

column1: sthirā dhruvā sālaparṇī śṛṅgī tu vṛṣabho vṛṣaḥ //
column2: Sālaparṇī is also called sthirā and dhruvā. Śṛṅgī and vṛṣa are the synonyms of the herb vṛṣabha.

column1: gāṅgerukī nāgabalā muṣalī tālamūlikā /
column2: Gāṅgerukī is also called nāgabalā. Muṣalī Musalī and tālamūlikā are synonyms.

column1: jyotsnī paṭolikā jālī ajaśṛṅgī viṣāṇikā //
column2: Paṭolikā is also known as jyotsnī and jāla. Ajaśṛṅgī and viṣāṇikā are synonyms.

column1: syāllāṅgalikyagniśikhā tāmbūlī nāgavallyapi /
column2: Lāṅgalī is also known as agniśikhā. Tāmbūlī and nāgavallī are synonyms.

column1: hareṇū reṇukā kauntī hrīvero divyanāgaraṃ //
column2: The fragrant reṇukā is also called hareṇu and kauntī. Hrībera is also known as divyanāgaram .

column1: kālānusāryavṛddhāśmapuṣpaśītaśivāni tu /
column2: The other names of śaileya are kālānusārī, vṛddhā, aśmapāṣpam and śītaśivam .

column1: śaileyaṃ tālaparṇī tu daityā gandhakuṭī murā // granthiparṇaṃ śukaṃ varhi valā tu tripuṭā truṭiḥ /
column2: Murā is also known as tālaparṇī, daitya and gandhakuṭī. Śukam and barham are other names of granthiparṇam as well as balā. Tripuṭā and truṭi are the synonyms of sūkṣmailā.

column1: śivā tāmalakī cātha hanurhaṭṭavilāsinī //
column2: Śivā and tāmalakī are synonyms of bhūmyāmalakī. Hanu and haṭṭavilāsinī are synonyms.

column1: kuṭaṃ naṭaṃ daśapuraṃ vāneyaṃ paripelavam /
column2: Kuṭannaṭam , dāśapuram , vāneyam and paripelavam are synonyms.

column1: tapasvanī jaṭāmāṃsī pṛkkā devī latā laśūḥ //
column2: Jaṭāmāṃsī is also known as tapasvinī. Spṛkkā is also called devi, latā and laghu.

column1: karcurako drāviḍako gandhamūlī śaṭhī smṛtā / syaddṛkṣagandhā chagalāntrā vegī vṛddhadārakaḥ //
column2: Karcūraka and drāviḍaka are synonyms. Gandhamūlī is also known as śaṭhī. Vṛddhadāraka is also known as ṛkṣagandhā, chagalāntrā and vegī.

column1: tuṇḍikerī raktaphalā vimbikā pīluparṇy api /
column2: Raktaphalā, bimbikā and pīluparṇī are the other names of tuṇḍikerī.

column1: cāṅgerī cukrikāmbaṣṭā svarṇakṣīrī himāvatī //
column2: Cāṅgerī, cakrikā and ambaṣṭhā are synonyms. Svarṇakṣirī is also known as himāvatī.

column1: sahasravedhī cukro 'mlavetasaḥ śatavedhyapi /
column2: Sahasravedhī, cukra and śatavedhī are the other names of amlavetas.

column1: jīvantī jīvanī jīvā bhūminimvaḥ kirātakaḥ //
column2: Jīvantī is also known as jīvanī and jīvā. Bhūnimba Bhūminimba is also called kirātaka.

column1: kūrcaśīrṣo madhukaraś candraḥ kapivṛkas tathā /
column2: Kūrcaśīrṣa and madhuraka are synonyms. Candra, kapivṛka, dadrughna and eḍagaja are synonyms.

column1: dadrughnaḥ syādeḍagajo varṣābhūḥ śīthahāniṇī //
column2: Probably varṣābhū and sobahāriṇī are also synonyms ?.

column1: kunandatī nikumbhastrā yamānī vārṣikā tathā / laśunaṅgṛñcanāriṣṭamahākandarasonakāḥ //
column2: Kunandatī, nikumbhastrā, yamānī and vārṣikā are synonyms. Laśunam is also known as gṛñjanam , ariṣṭa, mahākanda and rasonaka.

column1: vārāhī vadarā gṛṣṭiḥ kākamācī tu vāyasī /
column2: Badarā and gṛṣṭi are synonyms of vārāhī. Vāyasī is also known as kākamācī.

column1: śatapuṣpā sitacchatrāticchatrā madhurā misiḥ //
column2: Madhurā is also known as śatapuṣpā, sitacchatrā, aticchatrā, misi, avākpuṣpī and kāravī.

column1: kaṭambharā bhadravalā karvūraś ca śaṭī hy atha //
column2: Saraṇā, prasāraṇī, kaṭambharā and bhadrabalā are synonyms. Karcūra and śaṭī are synonyms.

column1: paṭolaḥ kulakastiktaḥ kāravellaḥ kaṭillakaḥ /
column2: Paṭola is also known as kulaka and tiktaka. Kāravella is also known as kaṭhillaka.

column1: kuṣmāṇḍakastu karkārurirvāruḥ karkaṭī striyau // ikṣvākuḥ kaṭutumbī syādviśālā tvindravāruṇī /
column2: Kūṣmāṇḍaka is otherwise called karkāru. Karkaṭī is known as urvāruḥ and used in the feminine. Kaṭutumbī is also called ikṣvāku. Indravāruṇī is also known as viśālā.

column1: arśeghnaḥ śūraṇaḥ kando mustakaḥ kuruvindakaḥ //
column2: The other names of sūraṇa are arśoghna and kanda. Mustaka and kuruvindaka are synonyms.

column1: vaṃśe tvaksārakarmāraveṇumaskaratejanāḥ /
column2: Veṇu is also called vaṃśa, tvaksāra, karmāra, maskara and tejana.

column1: chatrāticchatrapālaghnau mālātṛṇakabhūstṛṇe // tṛṇarājāhvayastālo ghoṇṭā kramukapugakau /
column2: Chatra, aticchatra, pālaghna, mālātṛṇaka and bhūstṛṇa denote different kinds of jalatṛṇa. Tāla is also called tṛṇarāja. Pūga is also called ghoṇṭā and kramuka.

column1: śārdūladvīpinau vyaghre haryakṣaḥ keśarī hariḥ //
column2: Śārdūla and dvīpī are synonyms of vyāghra tiger. Haryakṣa, kesarī and hari denote a lion.

column1: kolaḥ pautrī varāhaḥ syāt koka īhāmṛgo vṛkaḥ /
column2: The words kola, potrī and varāha would denote a boar. The words koka, īhāmṛga and vṛka denote a wolf.

column1: lūtorṇanābhau tu samau tantuvāyaś ca markaṭe //
column2: Lūtā, ūrṇanābha, tantuvāya and markaṭa denote a spider.

column1: vṛścikaḥ śūkakīṭaḥ syātsāraṅgastokakau samau / kṛkavākustāmracūḍaḥ pikaḥ kokila ity api //
column2: Vṛścika and śūkakīṭa scorpion are synonyms. Sāraṅga and tokaka are synonyms denoting a cātaka bird. Kṛkavāku and tāmracūḍa are synonyms denoting a cock. Pika and kokila are synonyms denoting a cuckoo.

column1: kokaś cakraś cakravāko kādambaḥ kalahaṃsakaḥ //
column2: Cakravāka is also known as koka and cakra. Kādamba and kalahaṃsaka are synonyms.

column1: pataṅgikā puttikā syātsaraghā madhumakṣikā /
column2: Pataṅgikā and puttikā are synonyms denoting different kinds of honeybees.

column1: dvirephapuṣpaliḍbhṛṅgaṣaṭpadabhramarā.alayaḥ //
column2: Dvirepha, puṣpaliṭ, bhṛṅga, ṣaṭpada, bhramara and ali denote a bee.

column1: kekī śikhyasya vākkekā śakuntiśakunidvijāḥ /
column2: Kekā denotes the sound made by a peacock. The words śakunti, śakuni and dvija denote a bird.

column1: strī pakṣatiḥ pakṣamūlañcañcustoṭirubhe striyau //
column2: Pakṣati is the base of the wing. It is in the feminine. Cañcu and troṭi denote the beak.

column1: gatiruḍḍinasaṇḍīnau kulāyo nīḍamastriyāṃ /
column2: The words uṇḍīnam and saṇḍīnam denote the gait of birds.

column1: peśī koṣo dvihīne 'ṇḍaṃ pṛthukaḥ śāvakaḥ śiśuḥ // potaḥ pāko 'rbhako ḍimbhaḥ sandohavyūhako gaṇaḥ /
column2: Peśī, koṣa and aṇḍa denote an egg. If less than two, aṇḍa is used in the neuter. The young one of a bird is denoted by the words pṛthuka, śāvaka, śisu, pota, pāka, arbhaka and ḍimbha.

column1: saṅghātasañcayau vṛndaṃ puñjarāśī tu kūṭakaṃ //
column2: Puñja, rāśi and kūṭakam are used to denote heap of grains. Cf. Amara paṅkti . Cf. ibid.

column1: nṛbrahmakṣatraviṭśūdravargānvakṣye 'tha nāmataḥ /
column2: Cf. Amara paṅkti . The purāṇic reading is wrong. Cf Amara paṅkti . Cf.

column1: naraḥ pañcajanā martya yadyoṣāvaṃlā vadhūḥ //
column2: From here begins the listing of synonyms of birds. shall describe the class of men , brahmins , kṣatriyas , vaiśyas and śūdras. The words naraḥ , pañcajanāḥ , martyāḥ denote men.

column1: kāntārthinī tu yā yāti saṅketaṃ sābhisārikā /
column2: A person seeking a lover, going to the place indicated by the lover is called abhisārikā.

column1: kulaṭā puṃś calyasatī nagnikā strī ca koṭavī //
column2: The words kulaṭā, puṃścalī and asatī mean a wanton woman. A nude woman is called koṭavī.

column1: kātyāyanyardhavṛddhā yā sairindhrī paraveśmagā / asikrī syādavṛddhā yā malinī tu rajasvalā //
column2: She is independent and proficient in hair dressing etc.. Asiknī is not old and serves the harem. Mālinī is a woman in her monthly course.

column1: vārastrī gaṇikā veśyā bhrātṛjāyāstu yātaraḥ /
column2: Vārastrī, gaṇikā and veśyā mean a courtezan. Brothers’ wives are mutually known as yātaras.

column1: nanāndā tu svasā patyuḥ sapiṇḍāstu sanābhayaḥ //
column2: Husband’s sister is known as nanānda. The descendants for seven generations are known as sapiṇḍas and sanābhis

column1: samānodaryasodaryasagarbhasahajāssamāḥ /
column2: Sisters born of the same womb are called samānodaryaḥ , sodaryaḥ , sagarbhyaḥ and sahajāḥ .

column1: sagotrabāndhavajñātibandhusvasvajanāḥ samāḥ //
column2: The words sagotra, bāndhava, jñāti, bandhu, svaḥ and svajana are synonyms denoting relatives belonging to the same clan.

column1: dampatī jampatī bhāryāpatī jāyāpatī ca tau /
column2: The words dampatī, jampatī, bhāryāpatī and jāyāpatī denote the husband and wife.

column1: garbhāśayo jarāyuḥ syādulvañca kalalo 'striyāṃ // garbho bhruṇa imau tulyau klīvaṃ śaṇḍo napuṃsakam /
column2: The outer skin of the embryo is known as garbhāśaya, jarāyu and ulbam . The foetus is called kalala, in the neuter. The words garbha and bhrūṇa are synonyms denoting the young one in the womb.

column1: syāduttānaśayā ḍimbhā bālo māṇavakaḥ smṛtaḥ // piciṇḍilo vṛhatkukṣiravabhraṭo natanāsike /
column2: The words klība, śaṇḍha are used to denote a eunuch. Uttānaśayā and ḍimbā would mean a child that sucks milk from the mother’s breasts. Bāla boy is known to be māṇavaka

column1: vikalāṅgastu pogaṇḍa ārogyaṃ syādanāmayam // syādeḍe vadhiraḥ kubje gaḍulaḥ kukare kuniḥ /
column2: A deaf person is denoted by the words eḍa and badhira. The word gaḍula is used to denote a hunchback. The word kuni is used to denote a person having a maimed hand.

column1: kṣayaḥ śoṣaś ca yakṣmā ca pratiśyāyustu pīnasaḥ //
column2: The words kṣaya, śoṣa and yakṣmā mean consumption. Pratiśyāya and pīnasa catarrh are synonyms.

column1: strī kṣutkṣutaṃ kṣayaṃ puṃsi kāsastu kṣavathuḥ pumān /
column2: Kṣut, kṣutam and kṣava sneezing are synonyms. The word kṣut is feminine. The words kāsa and kṣavathu meaning cough are both masculine.

column1: śothastu śvayathuḥ śophaḥ pādasphoṭo vipādikā //
column2: Śotha swelling is also known as śvayathu and śopha. Pādasphoṭa sore on the foot is also known as vipādikā.

column1: kilāsaṃ sidhnakacchāntu pāma pāmā vicarcikā /
column2: Pāma, pāmā and vicarcikā are used to mean kacchū scab.

column1: koṭho maṇḍalakaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ śvitre drur nāmakārśasī //
column2: The words koṭha, maṇḍalakam , kuṣṭham and śvitram white leprosy are synonyms. Arśas piles is also known as durnāmakam .

column1: anāhastu vibandhaḥ syādgrahaṇī rukpravāhikā /
column2: The words ānāha and nibandha denote suppression of urine and feces.

column1: vījavīryendrayaṃ śukraṃ palalaṃ kravyamāmiṣaṃ //
column2: The words bījam , vīryam , indriyam and śuklam mean semen. The words palalam , kravyam and āmiṣam denote flesh.

column1: vukkāgramāṃsaṃ hṛdayaṃ hanmedastu vapā vasā / paścādgrīvā śirā manyā nāḍī tu dhamaniḥ śirā //
column2: Hṛdayam and hṛt heart are synonyms. Vapā and vasā denote the marrow of the flesh. The artery on the back of the neck is known as manyā. The words nāḍī, dhamani and śirā artery are synonyms.

column1: tilakaṃ ktoma mastiṣkaṃ drūṣikā netrayormalam /
column2: Tilakam and kloma denote lump of flesh. Mastiṣkam is the fluid on the forehead.

column1: antraṃ purī tadgulmastu plīhā puṃsy atha vasnasā //
column2: Antra intestine is also known as purītat. Plīhā and gulma spleen are synonyms.

column1: snāyuḥ striyāṃ kālakhaṇḍayakṛtī tu same ime / syāt karpūraḥ kapālo 'strī kīkasaṅkulyamasthi ca //
column2: Kālakhaṇḍam and yakṛt are synonyms denoting liver. Karpara and kapāla denote skull, kapālam in the neuter. Bones are in general denoted by the words kīkasam , kulyam and asthi.

column1: syāccharīrāsthni kaṅkālaḥ pṛṣṭhāsthni tu kaśerukā / śiro 'sthani karoṭiḥ strī pārśvāsthani tu parśukā //
column2: The word kaṅkāla denotes skeleton in the body. The word kaśeruka denotes backbone. The skullbone is called karoṭi, in the feminine. The word parśukā denotes the bones on the sides of the body.

column1: aṅgaṃ pratīko 'vayavaḥ śarīraṃ varṣma vigrahaḥ /
column2: The limbs of the body are denoted by the words aṅgam , pratīka and avayava. The words śarīram , varṣma and vigraha denote a body.

column1: kaṭo nā śroṇiphalakaṃ kaṭiḥ śroṇiḥ kakudmatī //
column2: Śroṇiphalakam buttocks is also called kaṭa and that word is masculine. Kaṭi, śroṇi and kakudmatī hip are synonyms.

column1: paścānnitambaḥ strīkaṭyāḥ klīve tu jaghanaṃ puraḥ /
column2: The hinder part of the waist of women is known as nitamba, in the neuter. The frontal part is jaghanam .

column1: kūpakau tu nitambasthau dvayahīne kakundare //
column2: The kūpakas hollows below the loins are in the nitamba.

column1: striyāṃ sphicau kaṭiprothāvupastho vakṣyamāṇayoḥ /
column2: The fleshy portions in the hip are called sphicau sphic and kaṭiprothau .

column1: bhagaṃ yonirdvayoḥ śiśno meḍhro mehanaśephasī //
column2: In the case of women it is called bhagam and yoni. Śiśna, medhra, mehanam and śepha denote penis.

column1: piciṇḍakukṣī jaṭharodaraṃ tundaṃ kucau stanau / cūcukantu kucāgraṃ syānna nā kroḍaṃ bhujāntaram //
column2: The words picaṇḍa, kukṣi, jaṭharam , udaram and tundam denote belly. Stana and kuca mean breast. Cūcuka is the tip of breast. The words kroḍam and bhujāntaram denote chest.

column1: skandho bhujaśiro 'ṃśo 'strī sandhī tasyaiva jatruṇī /
column2: Skandha, bhujaśiras and aṃsa denote shoulder. The junction of shoulder is known as jatru.

column1: punarbhavaḥ kararuho nakho 'strī nakharo 'striyāṃ //
column2: Nail is denoted by the words punarbhava, kararuha, nakhara and nakha used not in feminine.

column1: pradeśatālagokarṇāstarjanyādiyute tate / aṅguṣṭhe sakaniṣṭhe syādvitastirdvādaśāṅgulaḥ //
column2: Tālā is the span of the thumb and the middle finger. Gokarṇa is the span of the thumb and the ring finger. The span of the thumb and the little finger is vitasti measuring twelve finger breadths.

column1: pāṇau ca peṭapratalaprahastā vistṛtāṅgulau / baddhamuṣṭikaro ratniraratniḥ sa kaniṣṭhavān //
column2: The open hand with the fingers extended is called capeṭa, pratala and prahasta. Ratni is the distance from elbow to the end of closed fist.

column1: kambugrīvā trirekhā sāvaṭurghāṭā kṛkāṭikā / adhaḥ syāccivukañcauṣṭhādatha gaṇḍau galo hanuḥ //
column2: Neck with three lines is called kambugrīvā. The words avaṭu, ghāṭā and vṛkāṭikā denote the backside of the union of head and neck. Cibuka chin is below the lips, then the two gaṇḍas cheeks, the throat and chin.

column1: apāṅgau netrayorantau kaṭākṣo 'pāṅgadarśane /
column2: The outer ends of eyes are called apāṅgas. Kaṭākṣa is used to denote the look with apāṅga.

column1: cikuraḥ kuntalo bālaḥ pratikarma prasādhanam // ākālpaveśau nepathyaṃ pratyakṣaṃ khelayogajam /
column2: The words cikura, kuntala and vāla denote hair. The words pratikarma, prasādhanam , ākalya, veṣa and nepothyam denote beautification. It is perceivable and is produced by union with a play.

column1: cūḍāmaṇiḥ śiroratnaṃ taralo hāramadhyagaḥ // karṇikā tālapatraṃ syāllambanaṃ syāllalantikā /
column2: Cūḍāmaṇi is the crestjewel. The central gem in a necklace is called tarala. The earornament is called karṇikā and tālapatra. Lambanam or lalantīkā denote a long necklace.

column1: mañjīro nūpuraṃ pāde kiṅkiṇī kṣudraghaṇṭikā //
column2: The words mañjīra and nūpura denote the anklet on the foot. Kiṅkiṇī and kṣudraghaṇṭikā denote a small bell.

column1: dairghyamāyāma ārohaḥ pariṇāho viśālatā / paṭaccaraṃ jīrṇavastraṃ saṃvyānañcottarīyakam //
column2: The words dairghyam , āyāma and āroha are used to denote the length of a cloth etc.. The words pariṇāha and viśālatā denote the width. Paṭaccaram denotesa rag. Saṃvyānam is the cloth worn on the shoulder.

column1: racanā syāt parispanda ābhogaḥ paripūrṇatā /
column2: The words ābhoga and paripūrṇatā denote the fulfilling of all services.

column1: samudgakaḥ sampuṭakaḥ pratigrāhaḥ patadgrahaḥ //
column2: Samudgaka and sampuṭaka mean a casket. The words pratigraha and patadgraha mean a spitoon.

column1: vaṃśo 'nvavāyo gotraṃ syāt kulānyabhijanānvayau /
column2: Words denoting genealogy are vaṃśa, anvavāya, gotram , kulam , abhijana and anvaya.

column1: mantravyākhyākṛdācārya ādeṣṭā tvadhvare vratī // yaṣṭā ca yajamānaḥ syāt jñātvārambha upakramaḥ /
column2: Ācārya is that person who expounds the scriptures. The person who instructs the priests in the sacrifice is called vratī, yaṣṭa and yajamāna. Upakrama denotes the beginning after having known the course of action.

column1: satīrthyāś caikaguravaḥ sabhyāḥ sāmājikās tathā // sabhāsadaḥ sabhāstārā ṛtvijo yājakāś ca te /
column2: Those having the same preceptors are called satīrthyāḥ . The members of an assembly are called sabhyas, sāmājikas, sabhāsada and sabhāstāras.

column1: adhvaryūdgātṛhotāro yajuḥsāmargvidaḥ kramāt //
column2: The priests who officiate in a sacrifices are known as ṛtvijas and yājakas. Adhvaryu is the priest associated with the Yajurveda.

column1: caṣālo yūpakaṭakaḥ same sthaṇḍilacatvare /
column2: Caṣāla is the wooden ring on the top of a sacrificial post. Sthaṇḍilam and catvaram are synonyms denoting the ground made ready for a sacrifice.

column1: āmikṣā sā śṛtoṣṇe yā kṣīre syāddadhiyogataḥ //
column2: The transformation that occurs in milk by the addition of curd is known as āmikṣā.

column1: pṛṣadājyaṃ sadadhyājye paramānnantu pāyasam / upākṛtaḥ paśurasau yo 'bhimantrya kratau hataḥ //
column2: Ghee together with curd is called pṛṣadājya. The words paramānnam and pāyasam denote cooked rice mixed with milk. The animal that is killed in a sacrifice after being sanctified with formulae is called upākṛta.

column1: paramparākaṃ samanaṃ prokṣaṇañca badhārthakam /
column2: The words paramparākam , śamanam and prokṣaṇam convey the sense of killing.

column1: pūjā namasyāpicitiḥ saparyārcārhaṇāḥ samāḥ //
column2: The words pūjā, namasyā, apaciti , saparyā, arcā and arhaṇā are synonyms denoting worship.

column1: varivasyā tu śuśrūṣā paricaryāpyupāsanam /
column2: Varivasyā, śuśrūṣā, paricaryā and upāsanā are synonyms meaning mode of worship.

column1: niyamo bratamastrī taccopavāsādi puṇyakam //
column2: It consists of the meritorious deeds such as fasting and the like.

column1: mukhyaḥ syāt prathamaḥ kalpo 'nukalpastu tato 'dhamaḥ /
column2: The first injunction is called mukhya. That which in inferior subordinate to that is known as anukalpa.

column1: kalpe vidhikramau jñeyau vivekaḥ pṛthagātmatā //
column2: Kalpa the texts laying down injunctions is known as vidhi and krama. Viveka is the power to distinguish between the world and the spirit.

column1: saṃskārapūrvaṃ grahaṇaṃ syādupākaraṇaṃ śruteḥ /
column2: The receiving of instruction in the scriptures after purification is known as upākaraṇam .

column1: bhikṣuḥ parivrāṭ karmandī pārāśaryapi maskarī //
column2: An ascetic is denoted by the words bhikṣu, parivrāṭ, karmandī, pārāśarī and maskarī.

column1: ṛṣayaḥ satyavacasaḥsnātakaścāplutavratī /
column2: The sages are in general denoted by the words ṛṣi and satyavacāḥ .

column1: ye nirjitendriyagrāmā yatino yatayaś ca te //
column2: Those who have conquered the senseorgans are known as yatinaḥ and yatayaḥ.

column1: śarīrasādhanāpekṣaṃ nityaṃ yat karma tadyamaḥ /
column2: The daily rite which depends on the body as means is known as yama.

column1: niyamastu sa yat karmānityamāgantusādhanam /
column2: But niyama is that which depends on external conditions and is voluntary.

column1: syād brahmabhūyaṃ brahmatvaṃ brahmasāyujyamityapi //
column2: The state of brahman is denoted by the words brahmabhūuam , brahmatvam and brahmasāyujyam .

column1: mūrdhābhiśikto rājanyo bāhujaḥ kṣatriyo virāṭ /
column2: The words denoting the warrior caste are mūrdhābhiṣikta, rājanya, bāhuja, kṣatriya and virāṭ.

column1: rājā tu praṇatāśeṣasāmantaḥ syādadhīśvaraḥ // cakravartī sārvabhaumo nṛpo 'nyo maṇḍaleśvaraḥ /
column2: A king who is respected by the vassals is known as adhīśvara. A king who holds way over the entire earth is known as cakravartī and sārvabhauma. A king who is different from the above is a maṇḍaleśvara.

column1: mantrī dhīsacivo 'mātyo mahāmātrāḥ pradhānakāḥ //
column2: Minister or counsel is known as mantrī , dhīsaciva and amātya. The chief counsel is known as mahāmātra and pradhānaka.

column1: draṣṭari vyavahārāṇāṃ prāḍvivākākṣadarśakau /
column2: A person who attends to disputes is called prāḍvivāka and akṣadarśaka.

column1: bhaurikaḥ kanakādhyakṣo 'thādhyakṣādhikṛtau samau //
column2: The man in charge of gold in a royal treasury is called bhaurika. The words adhyakṣa and adhikṛta are synonyms denoting a superintendent.

column1: antaḥpure tvadhikṛtaḥ syādantarvaṃśiko janaḥ /
column2: The person invested with the charge of the harem is called antarvaṃśika.

column1: sauvidallāḥ kañcukinaḥ sthāpatyāḥ sauvidāś ca te //
column2: The words sauvidalla, kañcukin, sthāpatya and sauvida also denote the same.

column1: ṣaṇḍo varṣavarastulyāḥ sevakārthyanujīvinaḥ /
column2: The words ṣaṇḍa saṇḍa and varṣavara denote the servants in the harem, who are eunuchs.

column1: viṣayānantaro rājā śatrurmitramataḥ paraṃ // udāsīnaḥ parataraḥ pārṣṇigrāhastu pṛṣṭhataḥ /
column2: A ruler of the region other than one’s own is a śatru enemy. One who is beyond that region is a mitram friend. A person beyond that is udāsīna neutral. A king who is in the rear of a kingdom is pārṣṇigrāha.

column1: caraḥ sparśaḥ syātpraṇidhiruttaraḥ kāla āyatiḥ //
column2: A spy is denoted by the words cara, spaśa and praṇidhi. The time that is to come is āyati.

column1: tatkālastu tadātvaṃ syādudarkaḥ phalamuttaraṃ /
column2: The present time is known as tatkāla and tadātvam . The fruit accruing in future is called udarka.

column1: adṛṣṭaṃ vahnitoyādi dṛṣṭaṃ svaparacakrajam //
column2: The fear that is caused by one’s own kingdom or other is dṛṣṭam .

column1: bhadrakumbhaḥ pūrṇakumbho bhṛṅgāraḥ kanakālukā / prabhinno garjito māto vamathuḥ karaśīkaraḥ //
column2: The words bhadrakumbha and pūrṇakumbha are synonyms meaning a pitcher that is full. A vessel made of gold is called bhṛṅgāra and kanakālukā. A rutting elephant is called prabhinna, garjita and matta.

column1: striyāṃ śṛṇistvaṅkuśo 'strī paristomaḥ kutho dvayoḥ / karṇīrathaḥ pravahaṇaṃ dolā preṅkhādikā striyāṃ //
column2: A goad is known as sṛṇi, in the feminine and aṅkuśa, in the masculine. The words paristoma and kutha denote the carpet on the back of an elephant in both the genders. A vehicle used by ladies for transport is called karṇīratha and pravahaṇam .

column1: ādhoraṇā hastipakā hastyārohā niṣādinaḥ /
column2: The words ādhoraṇāḥ , hastipakāḥ , hastyārohāḥ and niṣādinaḥ denote mahouts.

column1: bhaṭā yodhāś ca yoddhāraḥ kañcuko vāraṇo 'striyāṃ //
column2: Warriors are denoted by the words bhāṭāḥ , yodhāḥ and yoddhāraḥ The words kañcuka and vāraṇa mean armour.

column1: śīrṣaṇyañca śirastre 'tha tanutraṃ varma daṃśanaṃ /
column2: Śirṣaṇya is used to denote śirastra helmet. The words tanutram , varma and daṃśanam are used to mean armour.

column1: āmuktaḥ pratimuktaś ca pinaddhaścāpinaddhavat //
column2: The words āmukta, pratimukta, pinaddha and apinaddha are used to mean a person covered by armour.

column1: vyūhastu balavinyāsaś cakrañcānīkamastriyāṃ /
column2: An arrangement of army for the sake of battle is vyūha. The words cakram and anīkam denote an army.

column1: ekebhaikarathā tryaśvāḥ pattiḥ pañcapadātikāḥ //
column2: The patti consists of an elephant, a chariot, three cavalrymen and five infantry.

column1: pattyaṅgaistriguṇaiḥ sarvaiḥ kramādākhyā yathottaraṃ / senāmukhaṃ gulmagaṇau vāhinī pṛtanā camūḥ // anīkinī daśānīkinyo 'kṣohiṇyo gajādibhiḥ /
column2: Three times the constituents of a patti and subsequently in the same way in order would be senāmukham , gulma, gaṇa, vāhinī, pṛtanā, camūḥ anīkinī, daśānikinī and akṣauhiṇi.

column1: dhanuḥ kodaṇḍa+iṣvāsau koṭirasyāṭanī smṛtā //
column2: A bow is also known as kodaṇḍa, and iṣvāsa. The tip koṭi of a bow is known as aṭanī.

column1: nastakastu dhanurmadhyaṃ maurvī jyā śiñjinī guṇaḥ /
column2: The middle of a bow is called lastaka. The bowstring is called maurvī, jyā, śiñjinī and guṇa.

column1: pṛṣatkavāṇaviśikhā ajihmagakhagāśugāḥ // tūṇopāsaṅgatūṇīraniṣaṅgā iṣudhirdvayoḥ /
column2: The words pṛṣatka, bāṇa, viśikha, ajihmaga, khaga and āśuga denote an arrow. The words tūṇa, upāsaṅga, tūṇīra and niṣaṅga denote a quiver both in the masculine and feminine.

column1: asirṛṣṭiś ca nistriṃśaḥ karavālaḥ kṛpālaḥ kṛpāṇavat //
column2: The words asi, riṣṭi, nistriṃśa, karavāla and kṛpāṇa mean a sword.

column1: saruḥ khaḍgasya suṣṭau syādīlī tu karapālikā / dvayoḥ kuṭhāraḥ sudhitiḥ churikā cāsiputrikā //
column2: Tsaru is the handle of a sword. Īlī and karavālikā denote a short sword. The words kuṭhāra and svadhiti denote an axe. The word kuṭhāra is used in both masculine and feminine.

column1: prāsastu kunto vijñeyaḥ sarvalā tomaro 'striyāṃ /
column2: Prāsa is known to be kunta meaning a spear. Sarvalā and tomara mean an iron club used in the masculine and neuter.

column1: vaitālikā bodhakarā māgadhā vandinastutau //
column2: Bards who sing praises and wake up in the morning are called vaitālika and bodhakara.

column1: saṃśaptakāstu samayātsaṅgrāmādanivartinaḥ / patākā vaijayantī syātketanaṃ dhajamistriyāṃ //
column2: Saṃśaptaka are those who do not turn back from battle. The words patākā, vaijayantī, ketanam and dhvajam denote a banner. The word dhvajam is used in the masculine and neuter.

column1: ahaṃ pūrvamahaṃ pūrvamityahaṃpūrvikā striyāṃ /
column2: A fight with enthusiasm first, first, is known as ahaṃpūrvikā, in the feminine.

column1: ahamahamikā sāsyādyo 'haṅkāraḥ parasparam //
column2: Where mutual ego is shown am capable it is known as ahamahamikā.

column1: śaktiḥ parākramaḥ prāṇaḥ śauryaṃ sthānasahobalaṃ /
column2: The words śakti, parākrama, prāṇa, śauryaṃ , sthāma, saha and balam denote valour.

column1: mūrchā tu kaśmalaṃ moho 'pyavarmaddastu pīḍanaṃ //
column2: Mūrcchā, kaśmalam and moha denote stupefaction. Avamardana and piḍanam mean devastation of grains etc.

column1: abhyavaskandanantvabhyāsādanaṃ vijayo jayaḥ /
column2: The words abhyavaskandanam and abhyāsādanam mean encountering an enemy by trick, Vijaya and jaya are synonyms meaning conquest.

column1: nirvāsanaṃ saṃjñapanaṃ sāraṇaṃ pratighātanaṃ //
column2: The words nirvāsanam , saṃjñapanam , māraṇam and pratighātanam mean killing.

column1: syātpañcatā kāladharmo diṣṭāntaḥ pralayo 'tyayaḥ /
column2: The words pañcatā, kāladhama, diṣṭānta, pralaya and aryaya would mean death.

column1: viśo bhūmispṛṣo vaiśyā vṛttirvartanajīvane //
column2: The words viṭ, bhūmispṛk and vaiśya denote a tradesman and agriculturist. The words vṛtti, vartanam and jīvanam mean livelihood in general.

column1: kṛṣyādivṛttayo jñeyāḥ kusīdaṃ vṛddhijīvikā / uddharo 'rthaprayogaḥ syātkaṇiśaṃ sasyamañjarī //
column2: Kṛṣi agriculture etc. are to be known as the means of livelihood of a vaiśya. The words kusīdam and vṛddhijīvikā mean existing on interest by lending money. Uddhāra means debt.

column1: kiṃśāruḥ sasyaśūkaṃ syāt stambo gutsastṛṇādinaḥ /
column2: Kiṃśāru denotes the beard of a corn. Stamba means a bunch of grass etc.

column1: dhāmyaṃ vrīhiḥ stambakariḥ kaḍaṅgaro vupaṃ smṛtaṃ // māṣādayaḥ śamīdhānye śukadhānye yavādayaḥ /
column2: are denoted by the words dhānyam , vrīhi and stambakari. The minute particles of straw are known as kaḍaṅgara and busam . Blackgram etc. are grains in the form of pods.

column1: tṛṇadhānyāni nīvārāḥ śūrpaṃ prasphoṭanaṃ smṛtaṃ //
column2: Grains such as nīvāra are wild grains tṛṇadhānya. A winnowing basket is also known prasphoṭanam .

column1: syūtaprasevau kaṇḍolapiṭau kaṭakiniñjakau /
column2: Kaṇḍola and piṭa denote a cotainer made of bamboo etc. Kaṭa and kiliñjaka relate to different varieties of reeds.

column1: samānau rasavatyāntu pākasthānamahānase //
column2: These are similar. Rasavatī, pākasthānam and mahānasa denote a kitchen.

column1: paurogavastadadhyakṣaḥ sūpakārāstu vallavāḥ / ārālikā āndhasikāḥ sūdā audanikā guṇāḥ //
column2: The kitchen superintendent is called paurogava. Cooks are denoted by the words sūpakāra, vallava, ārālika, āndhasika, sūda, audanika and guṇa.

column1: klīve 'mbarīṣaṃ bhrāṣṭo nā karkaryālurgalantikā /
column2: A frying pan is denoted by the word ambarīṣam , in the neuter and bhrāṣṭra, in the masculine.

column1: āliñjaraḥ syānmaṇikaṃ suṣavī kṛṣajīrake //
column2: A big pitcher is called aliñjara and maṇika. Suṣavī is the name of black cumin seed.

column1: āranālastu kulmāṣaṃ vāhlīkaṃ hiṅgu rāmaṭhaṃ /
column2: The words āranāla and kulmāṣam denote a kind of gruel. The words vāhlīka, hiṅgu and rāmaṭham denote asafoetida.

column1: niśā haridrā pītā strī khaṇḍe matsyaṇḍiphāṇite // kūrcikā kṣiravikṛtiḥ snigdhaṃ masṛṇacikkaṇaṃ /
column2: The words niśā, haridrā and pītā, feminine denote turmeric. The words matsyaṇḍī and phāṇitam mean molasses. Transformed milk is called kūrcikā. The words cikkaṇam , masṛṇam and snigdham denote bland.

column1: jemanaṃ lepa āhāro māheyī saurabhī ca gauḥ /
column2: The words jemanam , leha and āhāra denote food. The words māheyī and saurabhī denote a cow.

column1: yugādīnāñca boḍhāro yugyaprasāṅgyaśāṭakāḥ //
column2: Those which are yoked are called yugyaḥ , prāsaṅgyaḥ and śākaṭaḥ .

column1: cirasūtā vaṣkayaṇī dhenuḥ syānnavasūtikā / sandhinī vṛṣabhākrāntā vehadgarbhopaghātinī //
column2: A cow that has delivered a calf long time back is called vaṣkayaṇī, and one that has delivered recently is called dhenu. The cow that is attacked by a bull for mating is called sandhinī. A barren cow is called vehat.

column1: paṇyājīvo hy āpaṇiko nyāsaścopanidhiḥ pumān /
column2: A person sustaining himself by buying and selling is called paṇyājīva and āpaṇika.

column1: vipaṇo vikrayaḥ saṅkhyā saṅkhyeye hy ādaśa triṣu // viṃśatyādyāḥ sadaikatve sarvāḥ saṃkhyeyasaṃkhyayoḥ /
column2: The words vipaṇa and vikraya mean sale. The numerals one to eighteen are to be used in all the three genders and the numerals twenty onwards take only singular always.

column1: saṃkhyārthe dvibahutve stastāsu cānavateḥ striyaḥ //
column2: While counting number two takes the plural. Among them the numerals upto ninety are feminine.

column1: paṅkteḥ śatasahasrādi kramāddaśaguṇottaraṃ /
column2: A unit measuring ten is called a paṅkti. Successive multiples of a paṅkti would be hundred, thousand etc.

column1: mānantu lāṅguliprasthair guñjāḥ pañcādyamāṣakaḥ //
column2: They are measured by tulāṅguliprastha . Five guñjas make one ādyamāṣaka.

column1: te ṣoḍaśākṣaḥ karṣo 'strī palaṃ karṣacatuṣṭayam /
column2: Sixteen māṣas make one akṣa otherwise called karṣa. The word is not feminine. Four karṣas would make one palam .

column1: suvarṇavistau hemno 'kṣe kuruvistastu tatpale //
column2: An akṣa measure of gold is known as suvarṇa and bista . A pala measure of the same is called kuruvista.

column1: tulā striyāṃ palaśataṃ bhāraḥ syādviṃśatistulāḥ /
column2: One hundred palas make one tulā That word is feminine. Twenty tulās would make one bhāra.

column1: kārṣāpaṇaḥ kārṣikaḥ syāt kārṣike tāmrike paṇaḥ //
column2: A karṣa measure of silver is called kārṣāpaṇa or kārṣika. A karṣa measure of copper is known as paṇa.

column1: dravyaṃ vittaṃ svāpateyaṃ rikthamṛthakthaṃ dhanaṃ vasu /
column2: The words dravyam , vittam , svāpateyam , riktham , ṛktham , dhanam and vasu denote wealth.

column1: rītiḥ striyāmārakūṭo na striyāmatha tāmrakam //
column2: The words rīti and ārakūṭa denote brass. It is not in the feminine.

column1: śulvamaudumbaraṃ lauhe tīkṣṇaṃ kālāṃyasāyasī / kṣāraḥ kāco 'tha capalo rasaḥ sūtaś ca pārade //
column2: The words śulbam and audumbaram are synonyms of tāmrakam brass. Kālāyasam and aya are synonyms of loha iron. The words kṣāra and kāca alkali are synonyms. The words capala, rasa, sūta and pārada are synonyms denoting mercury.

column1: garalaṃ māhiṣaṃ śṛṅgaṃ trapusīsakapiccaṭaṃ / hiṇḍīro 'bdhikaphaḥ pheṇo madhūcchiṣṭantu sikthakam //
column2: The words hiṇḍīra, abdhikapha seafoam and phena are synonyms. The words madhūcchiṣṭam and sikthakam beewax are synonyms. The words raṅgam and vaṅgam denote tin. The words picu and tūla mean cotton.

column1: raṅgavaṅge picusthūlo kūlaṭī tu manaḥśilā /
column2: Kunaṭī denotes manaḥśilā arsenic especially the Nepalese variety.

column1: yavakṣāraś ca pākyaḥ syāt tvakkṣīrā vaṃśalocanāḥ // vṛṣalā jadhanyajāḥ śūdrāścāṇḍālāntyāś ca śaṅkarāḥ /
column2: Yavakṣāra nitre would be known as pākya. The words tvakkṣīrī and vaṃśalocanā denote a medicinal substance got from the bamboo. Vṛṣalāḥ , jaghanyajāḥ and śūdrāḥ are synonyms denoting the fourth class of men.

column1: kāruḥ śilpī saṃhataistair dvayoḥ śreṇiḥ sajātibhiḥ //
column2: Kāru and śilpī denote the artisan. Their union with those of their own caste is called śreṇi, both in the feminine and masculine.

column1: raṅgājīvaścitrakarastvaṣṭā takṣā ca vardhakiḥ /
column2: A painter is denoted by the words raṅgājīva and citrakāra. A carpenter is denoted by the words takṣā, vardhaki and tvaṣṭā.

column1: nāḍindhamaḥ svarṇakāro nāpitāntāvasāyinaḥ //
column2: The words nāḍindama and svarṇakāra denote a goldsmith. The words nāpita and antāvasāyī denote a barber.

column1: jāvālaḥ syādajājīvo devājīvastu devalaḥ / jāyājīvastu śailūṣā bhṛtako bhṛtibhuktathā //
column2: A shepherd is denoted by the words jābāla and ajājīva. A person living by serving the god is called devājīva and devala. Actors are denoted by the words jāyājīva and śailūṣa.

column1: vivarṇaḥ pāmaro nīcaḥ prākṛtaś ca pṛthagjanaḥ / vihīnopasado jālmo bhṛtye dāseraceṭakāḥ //
column2: A low person is denoted by the words vivarṇa, pāmara, nīca, prākṛta, pṛthagjana, nihīna, apasada and jālma. The words dāsera and ceṭaka are used to denote a servant.

column1: paṭustu peśalo dakṣo mṛgayurlubdhakaḥ smṛtaḥ /
column2: The words paṭu, peśala and dakṣa mean a clever person. Mṛgayu is known to be lubdhaka hunter.

column1: cāṇḍālastu divākīrtiḥ pustaṃ lepyādikarmaṇi // pañcālikā putrikā syādvarkarastaruṇaḥ paśuḥ /
column2: Cāṇḍāla low class man is also known as divākīrti. The word pustam is used in the sense of plastering. A puppet made of cloth etc. is pāñcālikā. Any young animal is known as varkara.

column1: mañjūṣā peṭakaḥ peḍā tulyasādhāraṇau samau /
column2: The words mañjūṣā, peṭaka and peṭā denote a box. The words turya, sādhāraṇa and sama mean equal or similar.

column1: pratimā syāt pratikṛtirvargā brahmādayaḥ smṛtāḥ //
column2: The word pratimā would mean pratikṛti an image or statue. The brahma and other classes have been described so far.

column1: sāmānyāny atha vakṣyāmi nāmaliṅgāni tacchṛṇu /
column2: Listen to me! shall describe the genders of the substantives in general.

column1: sukṛtī puṇyavān dhnayo mahecchastu mahāśayaḥ //
column2: The words sukṛtī, puṇyavān and dhanya denote a fortunate person. A generous person is denoted by the words maheccha and mahāśaya.

column1: pravīṇanipuṇābhijñavijñaniṣṇātaśikṣitāḥ /
column2: The words pravīṇa, nipuṇa, abhijña, vijña, niṣṇāta and śikṣita a proficient person are synonyms.

column1: syurvadānyasthūlalakṣadānaśauṇḍā bahuprade //
column2: A very liberal person is denoted by the words vadānya, sthūlalakṣya, dānaśauṇḍa and bahuprada.

column1: kṛtī kṛtajñaḥ kuśala āsaktodyukta utsukaḥ /
column2: The words kṛtī, kṛtajña and kuśala mean a clever person.

column1: ibhya āḍhyaḥ parivṛḍho hy adhibhūrnāyako 'dhipaḥ // lakṣmīvān lakṣmaṇaḥ śrīlaḥ svatantraḥ svairy apāvṛtaḥ /
column2: Adhibhūḥ , nāyaka and adhipa mean a master. A person endowed with fortune is denoted by the words lakṣmīvān, lakṣmaṇa and śrīla. The words svatantra, apāvṛta and svairī denote an independent person.

column1: khalapūḥ syādvahukaro dīrghasūtraścirakriyaḥ //
column2: Khalapū would mean bahukara a sweeper. The words dīrghasūtra and cirakriya denote a lazy person.

column1: jālmo 'samīkṣyakārī syāt kuṇṭho mandaḥ kriyāsu yaḥ / karmaśūraḥ karmaṭhaḥ syādbhakṣako ghasmaro 'dmaraḥ //
column2: Jālma and asamīkṣyakārī mean a person acting without discriminating good and bad. One who is slow in doing things is known as kuṇṭha. One who is proficient in doing things is karmaśūra or kamaṭha.

column1: lolupo gardhalo gṛdhrurvinītapraśritau tathā / dhṛṣṭe dhṛṣṇurviyātaś ca nibhṛtaḥ pratibhānvite //
column2: The words bhakṣaka, ghasmara and admara denote a gluttonous person. Lolupa denotes a person having ardent desire. The words gardhana and gṛdhnuḥ denote a greedy person.

column1: pragalbho bhīruko bhīrurvandārurabhivādake /
column2: A cowardly or timid person is denoted by the words bhīruka and bhīru.

column1: bhūṣṇurbhaviṣṇurbhavitā jñātā vidurabindukau //
column2: The words bhūṣṇu, bhaviṣṇu and bhavitā mean a person desiring to become rich. A knower is denoted by the words vidura and vinduka.

column1: mattaśauṇḍotkaṭakṣīvāś caṇḍastvatyantakopanaḥ /
column2: The words matta, śauṇḍa, utkaṭa and kṣība denote an intoxicated person.

column1: devānañcati devadryaṅviśvadryaṅviśvagañcati //
column2: Devadrayaṅ is a person adoring a deity. A person serving the world is viśvadrayaṅ .

column1: yaḥ sahāñcati sa sadhryaṅ sa tiryaṅ yastiro 'ñcati /
column2: A companion, especially the husband is denoted by the word sadhryaṅ . A person serving crookedly is called tiryaṅ .

column1: vācoyuktiḥ paṭurvāgmī vāvadūkaś ca vaktari // syājjalpakastu vācālo vācāṭo bahugarhyavāk /
column2: A garrulous person is denoted by the word vāvadūka. A person indulging in unrefined talks is denoted by the words jalpāka, vācāla, vācāṭa and bahugarhyavāk.

column1: apadhvasto dhikkṛtaḥ syādbaddhe kīlitasaṃyatau //
column2: One who is censured is called apadhvasta and dhikkṛta.

column1: varaṇaḥ śabdano nāndīvādī nānvīkaraḥ samāḥ /
column2: The words ravaṇa and śabdana denote a person making sound. The words nāndivādī and nāndīkara are synonyms denoting laudatory singer.

column1: vyasanārtoparakrau dvau baddhe kīlitasaṃyatau //
column2: The words vyasanārta and uparakta denote a person afflicted by misfortune.

column1: vihistavyākulau tulyau nṛśaṃsakrūraghātukāḥ / pāpo dhūrto vañcakaḥ syānmūrkhe vaidehavāliśau //
column2: The words nṛśaṃsa, krūra, ghātuka and pāpa mean a person bent on harming others. Dhūrta and vañcaka mean a cheat. The words mūrkha, vaidheya and vāliśa denote a fool.

column1: kadarye kṛpaṇakṣudrau mārgaṇo yācakārthinau /
column2: A miser is denoted by the words kadarya, kṛpaṇa and kṣudra. The words mārgaṇa, yācaka and arthī mean a beggar.

column1: ahaṅkāravānahaṃyuḥ syācchubhaṃyustu śubhānvitaḥ //
column2: The word ahaṃyu means an egoistic person. A person endowed with good fortune is called śubhaṃyuḥ .

column1: kāntaṃ manoramaṃ rucyaṃ hṛdyābhīṣṭe hy abhīpsite /
column2: The words kāntam , manoramam and rucyam are used in the sense of a beautiful thing.

column1: asāraṃ phalgu śūnyaṃ vai mukhyavaryavareṇyakāḥ //
column2: The words asāram and phalgu mean a worthless thing. The word śūnyam means void.

column1: śreyān śreṣṭhaḥ puṣkalaḥ syātprāgryāgryagrīyamagrimaṃ /
column2: An important thing or person is denoted by the words mukhya, varya and vareṇya. The words śreyān, śreṣṭha and puṣkala would mean the outstanding. The words prāgrya, agrya, agrīya and agriya also mean an important person.

column1: vaḍroru vipulaṃ pīnapīvnī tu sthūlapīvare // stokālpakṣullakāḥ sūkṣmaṃ ślakṣṇaṃ dabhraṃ kṛśantanu /
column2: lb. The words vaḍram , uru and vipulam mean wide. The words pīnam , pīva, sthūlam and pīvaram mean stout. The words stoka, alpa and kṣullaka are used in the sense of a little.

column1: mātrākuṭīlavakaṇā bhūyiṣṭhaṃ puruhaṃ puru //
column2: The words mātrā and kuṭī in the feminine and lava and kaṇa in the masculine have the same sense.

column1: akhaṇḍaṃ pūrṇasakalamupakaṇṭhāntikābhitaḥ / samīpe sannidhābhyāsau nediṣṭaṃ susamīpakaṃ //
column2: . The words akhaṇḍam , pūrṇam and sakalam denote the whole. The words upakaṇṭha, antika, abhita, samīpa, savidha and abhyāsa mean near. The word nediṣṭham means very near.

column1: sudūre tu daviṣṭhaṃ syādvṛttaṃ nistalavartule /
column2: The word daviṣṭham would mean very far. The words nistala and vartula would mean circular.

column1: uccaprāṃśūnnatodagrā dhruvo nityaḥ sanātanaḥ //
column2: An eternal thing is denoted by the words dhruva, nitya and sanātana.

column1: āviddhaṃ kuṭilaṃ bhugnaṃ vellitaṃ vakramityapi /
column2: The words āviddham , kuṭilam , bhugnam , vellitam and vakram denote the crooked.

column1: cañcalaṃ taralañcaiva kaṭhoraṃ jaṭharaṃ dṛḍhaṃ //
column2: An unsteady thing is denoted by the words cañcalam and taralam . The words kaṭhoram , jaṭharam and dṛḍham mean hard.

column1: pratyagro 'bhinavo navyo navīno nūtano navaḥ /
column2: The words pratyagra, abhinava, navya, navīna, nūtana and nava mean fresh or new.

column1: ekatāno 'nanyavṛttiruccaṇḍamavilambitaṃ //
column2: The word ekatāna means concentrated on a single object. The word uccaṇḍam means quickly.

column1: uccāvacaṃ naikabhedaṃ sambādhakalilaṃ tathā /
column2: The words uccāvacam and naikabhedam mean manifold ways.

column1: timitaṃ stimitaṃ klinnamabhiyogatvabhigrahaḥ //
column2: The words timitam , stimitam and klinnam mean wet. The word abhiyoga means abhigraha an attack.

column1: sphātirvṛddhau prathā khyātau samāhāraḥ samuccayaḥ /
column2: The word prathā is used to denote fame. The word samāhāra means a collection.

column1: apahārastvapacayo vihārastu parikramaḥ //
column2: The word apahāra means apacaya removal. The words vihāra and parikrama mean movement on foot.

column1: pratyāhāra upādānaṃ nirhāro 'bhyavakarṣaṇaṃ / vighno 'ntarāyaḥ pratyūhaḥ syādāsyātvāsanā sthitiḥ //
column2: The extraction of extraneous objects from the body is denoted by the words nirhāra and abhyavakarṣaṇam . The words vighna, antarāya and pratyūha would mean an obstacle. The words āsyā, āsyanā and sthiti are used in the sense of a seat.

column1: sannidhiḥ sannikarṣaḥ syātmaṃkramo durgasañcaraḥ /
column2: The words sannidhi and sannikarṣa would mean proximity. A difcult path is indicated by the words saṅkrama and durgasañcara.

column1: upalambhastvanubhavaḥ pratyādeśo nirākṛtiḥ //
column2: The words pratyādeśa and nirākṛti are used in the sense of rejection.

column1: parirambhaḥpariṣvaṅgaḥ saṃśleṣa upagūhanaṃ /
column2: The words parirambha, pariṣvaṅga, saṃśleṣa and upagūhanam denote embrace.

column1: anumā pakṣahetvādyair ḍimbe bhramaraviplavau //
column2: The words ḍamara and viplava are used in the sense of frightening an enemy by shouts.

column1: asannikṛṣtārthajñānaṃ śabdāddhi śābdamīritaṃ / sādṛśyadarśanāttulye buddhiḥ syādupamānakaṃ //
column2: The knowledge about an object, that is not perceived, arising from the statement is said to be śābdam . Upamāna Upamānaka comparison would be the cognition arising from seeing the resemblance in a similar object.

column1: kāryaṃ dṛṣṭvā vinā nasyādarthāpattiḥ parārthadhīḥ / pratiyoginyāgṛhīte bhuvi nāstītyabhāvakaḥ /
column2: Arthāpatti presumption would be the knowledge about a different thing which would not exist without the thing seen Abhāva nonexistence is the cognition it is not there when the countercorrelative is not apprehended on the ground.

column1: ityādināmaliṅgo hi harirukto nṛbuddhaye //
column2: Thus ends the genders of substantives told by Hari Viṣṇu for the sake of knowledge of men.

column1: caturvidhastu pralayo nityo yaḥ prāṇināṃ layaḥ / sadā vināśo jātānāṃ brāhmo naimittiko layaḥ // caturyugasahasrānte prākṛtaḥ prākṛto layaḥ / laya ātyantiko jñānādātmanaḥ paramātmani //
column2: The dissolution of beings is of four kinds, such as constant dissolution of all beings that takes place daily, the dissolution known as Brāhma, otherwise known as naimittika pralaya, the prākṛta pralaya, occurring at the end of a thousand of four yuga periods and the absolute dissolution of all beings by the union of all souls in the supreme soul by means of knowledge.

column1: naimittikasya kalpānte vakṣye rūpaṃ layasya te /
column2: shall describe to you the nature of the naimittika dissolution that occurs at the end of a kalpa period.

column1: caturyugasahasrānte kṣīṇaprāye mahītale // anāvṛṣṭiratīvogrā jāyate śatavārṣikī /
column2: When the earth has become almost depleted at the end of a thousand of four yuga cycles, there would be a severe drought for hundred years.

column1: tataḥ sattvakṣayaḥ syācca tato viṣṇurjagatpatiḥ // sthito jalāni pivati bhānoḥ saptasu raśmiṣu /
column2: Then all the beings would perish. Then lord Viṣṇu, the lord of the universe, remaining in the seven rays of the Sun, drinks the waters.

column1: bhūpātālasamudrāditoyaṃ nayati saṃkṣayaṃ //
column2: The water in the oceans, the earth and the nether world and the like gets dried up.

column1: tatastasyānubhāvena toyāhāropavṛṃhitāḥ / ta eva raśmayaḥ sapta jāyante sapta bhāskarāḥ //
column2: Then by the divine power of lord Viṣṇu, the very same seven rays of the Sun, nourished by the water, become seven Suns.

column1: dahanty aśeṣaṃ trailokyaṃ sapātālatalaṃ dvija /
column2: O Twiceborn! They burn the three worlds completely together with the nether world.

column1: kūrmapṛṣṭhasamā bhūḥ syāttataḥ kālāgnirudrakaḥ //
column2: The surface of the earth would appear like the back of a tortoise.

column1: śeṣāhiśvāsasampātāt pātālāni dahatyadhaḥ / pātālebhyo bhuvaṃ viṣṇurbhuvaḥ svargaṃ dahatyataḥ //
column2: Then the terrible fire of dissolution, a manifestation of lord Rudra, burns the nether worlds below in association with the breath of the serpent Śeṣa. Then the allpervading fire burns the region from the nether worlds to the surface of the earth and from there to the heaven.

column1: ambarīṣamivābhāti trailokyamakhilaṃ tathā /
column2: Then all the three worlds appear like one blazing mass.

column1: tatastāparītāstu lokadvayanivāsinaḥ // gācanti te maharlokaṃ maharlokājjanaṃ tataḥ /
column2: Then the inhabitants of the two worlds, oppressed by the terrible heat, ascend to the Maharloka and to the Janaloka from Maharloka.

column1: rudrarūpī jagaddagdhvā mukhaniśvāsato hareḥ // uttiṣṭanti tato medhā nānārūpāḥ savidyutaḥ /
column2: After the world is burnt by the God assuming the form of Rudra, there arise clouds of different shapes together with lightning from the breath of lord Hari Viṣṇu.

column1: śataṃ varṣāṇi varṣantaḥ śamayantyagnimutthitam //
column2: They rain for a hundred years and put down the fire that has arisen.

column1: saptarṣisthānamākramya sthite 'mbhasi śataṃ marut / mukhaniśvāsato viṣṇornāśaṃ nayati tānghanān //
column2: When the water rises upto the region of the seven sages Great Bear, a hundred storms issue from the breath ofthe lord Viṣṇu and disperse those clouds.

column1: vāyuṃ pītvā hariḥ śeṣe śete caikārṇave prabhuḥ / brahmarūpadharaḥ siddhair jalagair munibhistutaḥ //
column2: Then after having drunk the wind lord Hari lies down on that mass of water, having assumed the form of Brahmā, extolled by seadwelling persons who have gained supernatural powers and by sages.

column1: ātmamāyāmayīṃ divyāṃ yoganidrāṃ samāsthitaḥ / ātmānaṃ vasidevākhyaṃ cintayanmadhusūdanaḥ //
column2: Lord Madhusūdana slayer of demon Madhu i.e. Viṣṇu lies down on that mass of water resting in the yogic sleep, which is his divine illusory form, contemplating His own form known as Vāsudeva.

column1: kalpaṃ śete prabuddho 'tha brahmarūpī sṛjaty asau / dviparārdhantato vyaktaṃ prakṛtau līyate dvija //
column2: He then lies down in sleep for a kalpa period and after waking up, in the form of Brahmā, He creates. O Twiceborn! Then the universe lies in an unmanifest state in the Prakṛti for two parārdhas.

column1: sthānāt sthānaṃ daśaguṇamekasmādguṇyate sthale /
column2: One place is ten times the other place when expansion is made from one place.

column1: tato 'ṣṭādaśame bhāge parārdhamabhidhīyate //
column2: Then the eighteenth place would be said to be parārdha.

column1: parārdhaṃ dviguṇaṃ yattu prākṛtaḥ pralayaḥ smṛtaḥ /
column2: The prākṛta dissolution is known to be twice the parārdha.

column1: anāvṛṣṭyāgnisamparkāt kṛte saṃjvalane dvija //
column2: O Twiceborn! When everything is burnt by contact with fire and on account of drought, it is priikṛta dissolution.

column1: mahadādervikārasya viśeṣāntasya saṃkṣaye / kṛṣṇecchākārite tasmin samprāpte pratisañcare //
column2: The modifications of mahat one of the principles, get merged into one losing their separate existence, and get reabsorbed into prakṛti on account of the will of lord Kṛṣṇa.

column1: āpo grasanti vai pūrvaṃ bhūmirgandhādikaṃ guṇaṃ /
column2: Water first swallows the qualities of earth such as smell and the like.

column1: ātmagandhāttato bhūmiḥ pralayatvāya kalpate //
column2: Then earth divested of its characteristic of smell tends towards dissolution.

column1: rasātmikāś ca tiṣṭhanti hy āpastāsāṃ raso guṇaḥ /
column2: Then water having the characteristic of taste remains.

column1: pīyate jyotiṣā tāsu naṣṭāsvagniś ca dīpyate //
column2: It is drunk by light. When it is lost, fire glows on.

column1: jyotiṣo 'pi guṇaṃ rūpaṃ vāyurgrasati bhāskaraṃ /
column2: Then wind swallows light together with its characteristic of colour and form.

column1: naṣṭe jyotiṣi vāyuś cabalī dodhūyate mahān //
column2: When fire is lost, strong wind blows on.

column1: vāyorapi guṇaṃ sparśamākāśaṃ grasate tataḥ /
column2: The characteristic of wind, namely touch, is then consumed by ether.

column1: vāyau naṣṭe tu cākāśannīravaṃ tiṣṭhati dvija //
column2: O Twiceborn! When wind is also lost, ether remains without any sound.

column1: ākāśasyātha vai śabdaṃ bhūtādirgrasate ca khaṃ /
column2: The characteristic of ether is sound. Ether together with its characteristic is swallowed by Bhūtādi i.e.

column1: abhimānātmakaṃ khañca bhūtādiṃ grasate mahān // bhūmiryāti layañcāpsu āpo jyotiṣi tadbrajet /
