column2: Ahaṅkāra or Ego Principle in which the element of Tamas dominates. Ether born of Ego and Bhūtādi are swallowed by Mahat i.e.

column1: vāyau vāyuś ca khe khañca ahaṅkāre layaṃ sa ca //
column2: Earth gets merged in water, water in light, light in wind, wind in ether and ether in ego.

column1: mahāttatve mahāntañca prakṛtirgrasate dvija / vyaktāvyaktā ca prakṛtirvyaktasyāvyaktake layaḥ //
column2: O Twiceborn! that ego gets merged in the principle of mahat and the principle of mahat is swallowed by prakṛti nature. The prakṛti consists of two parts such as manifest and unmanifest.

column1: pumāne kākṣaraḥ śuddhaḥ so 'pyaṃśaḥ paramātmanaḥ /
column2: The puruṣa primordial being is pure and is one undecaying entity. He is also a part of the Supreme Soul.

column1: prakṛtiḥ puruṣaś caitau līyete paramātmani //
column2: These prakṛti and puruṣa get merged in the Supreme Soul.

column1: na santi yatra sarveśe nāmajātyādikalpanāḥ /
column2: There is no determination such as name, species and the like in that lord of all.

column1: sattāmātrātmake jñeye jñānātmanyātmahaḥ pare //
column2: He is to be known and is of the form of knowledge. All other souls are merged in such Supreme Soul.

column1: ātyantikaṃ layaṃ vakṣye jñānādātyantiko layaḥ /
column2: fn. above. Equal to 00,000,000,000,000,000 years. l. shall describe absolute dissolution .

column1: ādhyātmikādisantāpaṃ jñātvā svasya virāgataḥ //
column2: Absolute dissolution arises from knowledge after having known the sufferings caused by the mind etc.

column1: ādhyātmikastu santāpaḥśārīro mānaso dvidhā /
column2: from one’s disinclination. The sufferings are of two kinds physical and mental.

column1: śārīro bahubhirbhedaistāpo 'sau śrūyatāṃ dvija //
column2: The physical sufferings are manifold. O Twiceborn! Listen to me! shall describe them.

column1: tyaktvā jīvo bhogadehaṃ garbhamāproti karmabhiḥ /
column2: The individual soul after having discarded the sensual body enters the womb as a result of the past deeds.

column1: ātivāhikasaṃjñastu deho bhavati vai dvija //
column2: Twiceborn! this body known as ātivāhika that is carried forward is peculiar to men alone.

column1: kevalaṃ sa manuṣyāṇāṃ mṛtyukāla upasthite / yāmyaiḥ puṃbhirmanuṣyāṇāṃ taccharīraṃ dvijottamāḥ // nīyate yāmyamārgeṇa prāṇināṃ mune /
column2: O Twiceborn! when the time for death comes the bodies of men are carried away by the servants of Varna God of Death along the path of Varna. O Sage! this is not the case with the other beings.

column1: tataḥ svaryāti narakaṃ sa bhramedghaṭayantravat //
column2: Such a person would wander in heaven and hell like the ghaṭayantra.

column1: karmabhūmiriyaṃ brahman phalabhūmirasau smṛtā /
column2: O Brahmin! This is a land of deeds and is known to bear fruits of one’s actions.

column1: yamo yonīś ca narakaṃ nirūpayati karmaṇā // pūraṇīyāś ca tenaiva yamañcaivānupaśyatāṃ /
column2: He determines the hell to which one has to go on account of the deed. Being awaited by them men, Varna, makes them get their befitting places dependent on their deeds.

column1: vāyubhūtāḥ prāṇinaś ca garbhante prāpnuvanti hi //
column2: The beings which have got ethereal bodies reach the befitting wombs.

column1: yamadūtair manuṣyastu nīyate tañca paśyati /
column2: A man is led by the messengers of Varna and he sees him Varna.

column1: dharmī ca pūjyate tena pāpiṣṭhastāḍyate gṛhe //
column2: A pious man is honoured by him and a sinner is beaten.

column1: śubhāśubhaṃ karma tasya citragupto nirūpayet /
column2: Citragupta informs him the good or bad deed done in every house.

column1: bāndhavānāmaśauce tu dehe khalvātivāhike // tiṣṭhannayati dharmajña dattapiṇḍāśanantataḥ / tanyaktvā pretadehantu prāpyānyaṃ pretalokataḥ //
column2: The departed soul dwells in the Ātivāhika provisional body and partakes the funeraloblations offered by the relatives. O Knower of virtue! After the funeral is over the soul rejects that preta body attained after death and ascends to another region from that of the pretas.

column1: vaset kṣudhā tṛṣā yukta āmaśrāddhānnabhuṅnaraḥ /
column2: It dwells there experiencing hunger and thirst and partakes the raw offerings made to it by the relatives.

column1: ātivāhikedehāttu pretapiṇḍair vinā naraḥ // na hi mokṣamavāpnoti piṇḍāṃstatraiva so 'śrute /
column2: A person does not get release from this newly acquired body without eating the funeral oblations.

column1: kṛte sapiṇḍīkaraṇe naraḥ saṃvatsarātparaṃ // pretadehaṃ samutamṛjya bhogadehaṃ prapadyate /
column2: He partakes the ballofferings there itself. When the sapiṇḍīkaraṇa has been done, a dead man discards the preta body and gets a sensuous body after one year.

column1: bhogadehāvubhau proktāvaśubhaśubhasaṃjñitau //
column2: Both the bodies are said to be sensuous and designated as inauspicious and auspicious.

column1: bhuktvā tu bhogadehena karmabandhānnipātyate /
column2: After having enjoyed by means of the sensuous body, one gets released from the bondage of deeds.

column1: taṃ dehaṃ paratastasmādbhakṣayanti niśācarāḥ //
column2: Demons devour that body after that.

column1: pāpe tiṣṭhati cet svargaṃ tena bhuktaṃ tadā dvija / tadā dvitīyaṃ gṛhṇāti bhogadehantu pāpināṃ //
column2: O Twiceborn! A person who does sinful deeds, would enjoy the fruits of good deeds at first in the heaven. Then he takes a second body of sinners to experience the fruits of sin.

column1: śucīnāṃ śrīmatāṃ gehe svargabhraṣṭo 'bhijāyate // puṇye tiṣṭhati cetpāpantena bhuktaṃ tadā bhavet / tasmin sambhakṣite dehe śubhaṃ gṛhṇāti vigraham //
column2: After experiencing the fruits of sin one that has enjoyed heaven, is thereafter born in a pure and prosperous family. A person doing pious deeds having a little of sin would first experience the fruits of the sin and when that body is dissolved would attain a beautiful body.

column1: karmaṇyalpāvaśeṣe tu narakādapi mucyate /
column2: A person gets freed from hell even if a little of past deed still remains.

column1: muktastu narakādyāti tiryagyoniṃ na saṃśayaḥ //
column2: There is no doubt that he would be born as an animal after getting liberated from hell.

column1: jīvaḥ praviṣṭo garbhantu kalale 'pyatra tiṣṭhati /
column2: The soul after having entered the womb dwells in the foetus.

column1: ghanībhūtaṃ dvitīye tu tṛtīye 'vayavāstataḥ //
column2: It gets hard in the second month. The limbs grow in the third month.

column1: caturthe 'sthīni tvaṅmāṃsampañcame romasambhavaḥ /
column2: Bones, skin and flesh are formed in the fourth month.

column1: ṣaṣṭhe ceto 'tha jīvasya duḥkhaṃ vindati saptame // jarāyuveṣṭite dehe mūrdhni baddhāñjalis tathā /
column2: Heart is formed in the sixth. The soul feels pain in the seventh. Thus the child remains in the womb being covered with the placenta and having hands folded above the head.

column1: madhye klīvastu vāme strī dakṣiṇe puruṣasthitiḥ // tiṣṭhatyudarabhāge tu pṛṣṭhasyābhimukhas tathā /
column2: A eunuch stays in the middle of the abdomen, a female child on the left side and a male child on the right side. The child stays in the womb facing the back of the mother.

column1: yasyāṃ tiṣṭhatyasau yonau tāṃ sa vetti na saṃśayaḥ //
column2: There is no doubt that it the child recognises the person in whose womb it stays.

column1: sarvañca vetti vṛttāntamārabhya narajammanaḥ /
column2: It knows fully all the incidents of previous life from birth onwards.

column1: andhakārañca mahatīṃ pīḍāṃ vindati mānavaḥ //
column2: A person finds a great darkness and experiences suffering.

column1: māturāhārapītantu saptame māsyupāśnute /
column2: In the seventh month it partakes the food eaten by the mother.

column1: aṣṭame navame māsi bhṛśamudvijata tathā //
column2: It becomes extremely restive in the eighth and ninth months.

column1: vyavāye pīḍāmāpnoti māturvyāyāmake tathā / vyādhiś ca vyādhitāyāṃ syānmuhūrtaṃ śatavarṣavat //
column2: It suffers when there is coition and physical exercise on the part of the mother. It becomes sick when the mother is sick, a moment of agony appearing as if lasting for a hundred years.

column1: santapyate karmabhistu kurute 'tha manorathān / garbhādvinirgato brahman mokṣajñānaṃ kariṣyati //
column2: It is tormented by the past deeds and makes resolutions “O Brahman! After getting out from the womb will gain knowledge relating to liberation from this bondage”.

column1: sūtivātair adhībhūto niḥsaredyoniyantrataḥ /
column2: Being pressed down by the wind inside mother’s womb, it gets out through the vagina.

column1: pīḍyamāno māsamātraṃ karasparśena duḥkhitaḥ //
column2: It gets afflicted in the first month after birth and feels pain when touched with the hand.

column1: khaśabdāt kṣudraśrotāṃsi dehe śrotraṃ viviktatā / śvāsocchāsau gatirvāyorvakrasaṃsparśanaṃ tathā //
column2: The auditory organs, minor organs and the state of being separate are produced in the body from the ether with its attribute of sound. The process of breathing, movement and the feeling of touch are due to the wind.

column1: agnerūpaṃ darśanaṃ syādūṣmā paṅktiś ca pittakaṃ / medhā varṇaṃ balaṃ chāyā tejaḥ śauryaṃ śarīrake // jalātsvedaś ca rasanandehe vai saṃprajāyate /
column2: Personality, sense of seeing, heat, celebrity, biles, intellect, colour, strength, shade, splendour and valour arise in the body from fire. Sweat, the organ of taste, moisture, marrow, taste, blood, semen, urine and phlegm and the like are produced in the body from water.

column1: kledo vasā rasā takraṃ śukramūtrakaphādikaṃ // bhūmerdhrāṇaṃ keśanakhaṃ gauravaṃ sthirato 'sthitaḥ / mātṛjāni mṛdūnyatra tvaṅmāṃsahṛdayāni ca //
column2: The sense of smell, hair, nail, weight and firmness of the bones are from earth. The delicate organs, skin, flesh, heart, navel, marrow, ordure, fat, moisture and the upper part of the belly are got from the mother.

column1: pitṛjāni śirāsnāyuśukrañcaivātmajāni tu //
column2: Veins, arteries and semen are got from the father.

column1: kāmakrodhau bhayaṃ harṣo dharmādharmātmatā tathā / ākṛtiḥ svaravarṇau tu mehanādyaṃ tathā ca yat //
column2: Lust, anger, fear, joy, the states of being pious and not pious, form, voice, colour and the discharge of urine and the like are due to one’s own state.

column1: ??? / ??? // tāmasāni tathājñānaṃ pramādālasyatṛṭkṣudhāḥ / mohamātsaryavaiguṇyaśokāyāsabhayāni ca //
column2: Ignorance, negligence, idleness, thirst, hunger, infatuation, jealousy, defectiveness, grief, weariness and fear are qualities of tamas temperament.

column1: kāmakrodhau tathā śauryaṃ yajñepsā bahubhāṣitā / ahaṅkāraḥ parāvajñā rājasāni mahāmune //
column2: O Great sage! Lust, anger, valour, desire to do sacrifice, garrulousness, ego and contempt for others are qualities of rājasa temperament.

column1: dharmepsā mokṣakāmitvaṃ parā bhaktiś ca keśave / dākṣiṇyaṃ vyavasāyitvaṃ sātvikāni vinirdiśet //
column2: Desire to be righteous, desire for emancipation, extreme devotion to lord Keśava Viṣṇu, compassion and diligence should be termed as arising from sāttvika temperament.

column1: capalaḥ krodhano bhīrurbahubhāṣo kalipriyaḥ / svapne gaganagaś caiva bahuvāto naro bhavet //
column2: A person in whom wind predominates would be fickle, irritable, cowardly, garrulous, yielding to vices of kali yuga and dreams of flying in the air.

column1: akālapalitaḥ krordho mahāprājño raṇapriyaḥ / svapne ca dīptimatprekṣī bahupitto naro bhavet //
column2: A person in whom bile predominates would be prematurely greyhaired, irritable, very learned, fond of battle and one who sees conflagrations in dream.

column1: sthiramitraḥ sthirotsāhaḥ sthirāṅgo draviṇānvitaḥ / svapne jalasitālokī bahuśle ṣmā naro bhavet //
column2: A person in whom phlegm abounds would be a steadfast friend, constantly enthusiastic, having firm limbs, endowed with wealth and one who perceives water and white colour in dream.

column1: rasastu prāṇināṃ dehe jīvanaṃ rudhiraṃ tathā /
column2: Serum is the life force in the body of beings. Blood serves as the anointment.

column1: lepanañca tathā māṃsamedhasnehakarantu tat //
column2: Flesh causes urination and perspiration.

column1: dhāraṇantv asthi majjā syātpūraṇaṃ vīryavardhanaṃ / śukravīryakaraṃ hy ojaḥ prāṇakṛjjīvasaṃsthitiḥ //
column2: Bones make the body firm. Marrow would fill up and increase potency. Semen gives potency. Ojas virility is the sustainer of life.

column1: ojaḥ śukrāt sārataramāpītaṃ hṛdayopagaṃ /
column2: Virility is subtler and lesser yellow than semen and flows in the vicinity of heart.

column1: ṣaḍaṅgaśakthinī bāhurmūrdhā jaṭharamīritaṃ //
column2: There are six parts of the body, viz, two thighs legs, two hands, head and belly.

column1: ṣaṭtvacā vāhyato yadvadanyā rudhiradhārikā / vilāsadhāriṇī cānyā caturthī kuṇḍadhāriṇī // pañcamī vidradhisthānaṃ ṣaṣṭhī prāṇadharā matā /
column2: The six external layers of skin are the epidermis, the layer that contains blood, the next one that contains features of grace, the fourth one that bears the sacs storing fluids, the fifth one that is the seat of abscesses and the sixth one that supports life.

column1: kalāsaptamau māṃsadharā dvitīyā raktadhāriṇī // yakṛtplīhāśrayā cānyā medodharāsthidhāriṇī /
column2: There are seven sheaths namely that which supports flesh, the second one, blood, that which is the prop for liver and spleen, the next one that holds fat and that which supports bone, that which holds marrow, phlegm and feces, situated in the abdomen.

column1: ṣaṣṭhī pittadharā śukradharā śukrāśayāparā //
column2: The sixth is that which holds bile and the next one that holds semen in the region of that sac.

column1: śrotraṃ tvak cakṣuṣī jihvā ghrāṇaṃ dhīḥ khuñca bhūtagaṃ / śabdasparśarūparamagandhāḥ khādiṣu tadguṇāḥ //
column2: The auditory organ, skin, the two eyes, tongue, nose, intellect, the five elements and their qualities such as sound, touch, colour, taste and smell, the anus, the organ of generation, the two hands, the two feet are the embodiments of sky.

column1: utsargānandakādānagativāgādi karma tat //
column2: Their functions are emission, exhilaration, taking, movement and speech and the like.

column1: pañcakarmendriyānyatra pañcabuddhīndriyāṇi ca /
column2: Five among these are organs of action, five are organs of sense.

column1: indriyārthāś ca pañcaiva mahābhūtā mano 'dhipāḥ //
column2: The five great elements are objects of senses having the mind as that which governs.

column1: ātmāvyaktaś caturviṃśatattvāni puruṣaḥ paraḥ /
column2: The soul is unmanifest. The principles are twentyfour. The puruṣa is the supreme.

column1: saṃyuktaś ca viyuktaś ca yathā matsyodake ubhe //
column2: The soul exists just like the fish in the water attached and detached.

column1: avyaktamāsritānīha rajaḥsattvatamāṃsi ca /
column2: The qualities sattva, rajas and tamas dwell in the unmanifest Prakṛti.

column1: āntaraḥ puruṣo jīvaḥ sa paraṃ brahma kāraṇaṃ //
column2: The inner being is the puruṣa. It is the Supreme brahman, the cause.

column1: sa yāti paramaṃ sthānaṃ yo vetti puruṣaṃ paraṃ /
column2: One who knows this Supreme puruṣa, attains the supreme position.

column1: saptāśayāḥ smṛtā dehe rudhirasyaika āśayaḥ //
column2: There are seven sacs in the body. The first one is the sac of blood.

column1: śleṣmaṇaścāmapittābhyāṃ pakvāśayastu pañcamaḥ /
column2: The other sacs are those of phlegm, of undigested food and of bile. The fifth one is that of digestion.

column1: vāyumūtrāśayaḥ saptaḥ strīṇāṃ garbhāśayo 'ṣṭamaḥ //
column2: The receptacles for wind and urine are the sixth and seventh. The uterus is the eighth one in women.

column1: pittātpakvāśayo 'gneḥ syādyonirvikaśitā dyutau / padmavadgarbhāśayaḥ syāttatra ghatte saraktakaṃ //
column2: The sac of digestion gets dilated by bile and the vagina by internal fire. The uterus would resemble lotus and expand during the menstrual period.

column1: śukraṃ svaśukrataścāṅgaṃ kuntalānyatra kālataḥ / nyastaṃ śukramato yonau neti garbhāśayaṃ mune //
column2: O Sage! semen deposited in the vagina is led to the uterus in course of time. Even during the menstruous period, the vagina would be surrounded by wind, bile and phlegm.

column1: bhavettadā vikāśitvaṃ naiva tasyāṃ prajāyate //
column2: It would not get dilated then.

column1: bukkātpukkasakaplīhakṛtakoṣṭhāṅgahṛdvraṇāḥ /
column2: O Fortunate one! heart, lungs, liver and spleen are formed in due succession.

column1: rasasya pacyamānasya sārādbhavati dehināṃ / plīhā yakṛcca dharmajña raktapheṇācca pukkasaḥ //
column2: O Knower of virtue! spleen and liver of men are formed from the essence of the serum that gets condensed. Lungs are formed from the froth of blood.

column1: raktaṃ pittañca bhavati tathā taṇḍakasaṃjñakaḥ / medoraktaprasārācca vukkāyāḥ sambhavaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: Blood is then converted into bile and it is then known as taṇḍaka. Heart is formed from the spreading of fat and blood.

column1: raktamāṃsaprasārācca bhavantyantrāṇi dehināṃ /
column2: Intestines of mortals are formed from the spreading of blood and flesh.

column1: yaṃ yaṃ bhāvaṃ smarannante tyajeddehantamāpnuyāt /
column2: A man would attain the same state which he thinks of at the end after discarding the body.

column1: prāṇaṃ nyasya bhruvormadhye ante prāpnoti matparam // omityekākṣaraṃ brahmavadan dehaṃ tyajantathā / brahmādistambhaparyantāḥ sarve mama vibhūtayaḥ //
column2: Fixing the lifeenergy in the middle of the eyebrows a person reaches me uttering the onesyllabled ‘Oṃ’, the Brahman, and then discarding the life, and knowing that the things beginning with Brahmā and ending with a tuft of grass are all my magnificence.

column1: śrīmantaścorjitāḥ sarve mamāṃśāḥ prāṇinaḥ smṛtāḥ /
column2: All glorious and noble beings are known to be a part of Myself.

column1: ahameko viśvarūpa iti jñātvā vimucyate //
column2: One who knows that the universe is a manifestation of me, gets released.

column1: kṣetraṃ śarīraṃ yo vetti kṣetrajñaḥ sa prakortitaḥ /
column2: One who knows the body as the field is said to be kṣetrajña knower of the field.

column1: kṣetrakṣetrajñayorjñānaṃ yattajjñānaṃ mataṃ mama //
column2: The knowledge about the field and the knower of the field is deemed by Me lord as knowledge.

column1: indrayāṇi deśaikañca pañca cendriyagocarāḥ // icchā dveṣaḥ sukhaṃ duḥkhaṃ saṅghātaścetanā dhṛtiḥ / etatkṣetraṃ samāsena savikāramudāhṛtaṃ //
column2: The great elements, egoism, intellect, unmanifest principle, the ten organs of senses, one mind and the five objects of senses, desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, the aggregate, consciousness and firmnessall these have been described briefly as the kṣetra field with its modifications.

column1: ācāryopāsanaṃ śaucaṃ sthairyamātmavinigrahaḥ // indriyārtheṣu vairāgyamanahaṅkāra eva ca / janmamṛtyujarāvyādhiduḥkhadoṣānudarśanaṃ // āsaktiranabhiṣvaṅgaḥ putradāragṛhādiṣu / nityañca samacittattvamiṣṭāniṣṭopapattiṣu //
column2: Humility, modesty, noninjury, forbearance, uprightness, serving the preceptor, purity, steadfastness, selfcontrol, not having desire for the objects of senses, absence of egoism, cognizing the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness and pain, nonattachment, nonidentification of the self with son, wife, home and the like, constant equanimity towards desirable and undesirable happenings, exclusive unswerving devotion to Me god, resorting to solitary places, distaste for an assembly of men, constancy in knowledge about self, viewing things in accordance with the knowledge of truththese are declared as knowledge.

column1: etajjñānamiti proktamajñānaṃ yadato 'nyathā //
column2: Ignorance is the opposite of these.

column1: jñeyaṃ yattat pravakṣyāmi yaṃ jñātvāmṛtamaśnute /
column2: shall describe that which has to be known, by knowing which one enjoys immortality.

column1: anādi paramaṃ brahma sattvaṃ nāma taducyate //
column2: The Supreme Brahman is without a beginning. It is said to be neither existence, nor nonexistence.

column1: sarvataḥ pāṇipādāntaṃ sarvato 'kṣiśiromukham / sarvataḥ śrutimalloke sarvamāvṛtya tiṣṭhati //
column2: With hands and feet everywhere, with eyes, heads and mouths everywhere and with ears everywhereHe remains enveloping all.

column1: sarvendriyaguṇābhāsaṃ sarvendriyavivarjitam / asaktaṃ sarvabhṛccaiva nirguṇaṃ guṇabhoktṛ ca //
column2: Shining by the functions of all the senses, He is without all the senses. Although unattached, He is the supporter of all beings. Although devoid of qualities, He is the person experiencing them.

column1: vahirantaś ca bhūtānāmacarañcarameva ca /
column2: He is outside and within all the beings. He is movable as well as immovable.

column1: sūkṣmatvāttadavijñeyaṃ dūrasthañcāntike 'pi yat //
column2: He is incomprehensible because of his subtlety. He is far and near.

column1: avibhaktañca bhūteṣu vibhaktamiva ca sthitam /
column2: He is undivided and yet He seems to be existing in beings as divided.

column1: bhūtabhartṛ ca vijñeyaṃ grasiṣṇu prabhaviṣṇu ca //
column2: He should be known as the supporter of beings. He devours and is mighty generator.

column1: jyotiṣāmapi tajjyotistamasaḥ paramucyate /
column2: The light of all lights, He is said to be beyond darkness.

column1: jñānaṃ jñeyaṃ jñānagamyaṃ hṛdi sarvasya dhiṣṭhitaṃ //
column2: He is the knowledge, the knowable and the goal of knowledge, remaining in the hearts of all the beings.

column1: dhyānenātmani paśyanti kecidātmānamātmanā /
column2: By means of meditation some behold the self in the self by the self.

column1: anye sāṅkhyena yogena karmayogena cāpare //
column2: Others see the self by sāṅkhyayoga deliberation and yet others by karmayoga action.

column1: anye tvevamajānanto śrutvānyebhya upāsate /
column2: Still others, not knowing thus, worship Him as they have heard from others.

column1: tepi cāśu tarantyeva mṛtyuṃ śrutiparāyaṇāḥ //
column2: They too cross death quickly by their devotion to what they have heard.

column1: sattvātsañjāyate jñānaṃ rajaso lobha eva ca / pramādamohau tamaso bhavato jñānameva ca //
column2: Knowledge arises from sattva goodness, greed from rajas and error, delusion and ignorance from tamas.

column1: guṇā vartanta ity eva yo 'vatiṣṭhati neṅgate / mānāvamānamitrāritulyastyāgī sa nirguṇaḥ //
column2: One who simply stands composed thinking that the guṇas exist in him and is not shaken by them and remains equanimous towards respect and insult, friend and foe, is said to be free from guṇas.

column1: ūrdhvamūlamadhaḥśākhamaśvatthaṃ prāhuravyayaṃ /
column2: The imperishable aśvattha holy fig tree is said to be having its roots above and branches below.

column1: chandāṃsi yasya parṇāni yastaṃ veda sa vedavit //
column2: Its leaves are the Vedas. One who knows it is the knower of the Vedas.

column1: dvau bhūtasargau loke 'smin daiva āsura eva ca /
column2: There are two types of beings in this world, the divine and the demoniacal.

column1: ahiṃsādiḥ kṣamā caiva daivīsampattito nṛṇāṃ //
column2: Noninjury etc. and forbearance belong to one born for a divine state.

column1: na śaucaṃ nāpi vācāro hy āsurīsampadoddhavaḥ /
column2: Neither purity, nor right conduct belong to one born for a demoniacal state.

column1: narakatvāt krodhalobhakāmastasmāttrayaṃ tyajet //
column2: As anger, greed and sex lead to hell, one should reject the three.

column1: yajñastapas tathā dānaṃ sattvādyaistrividhaṃ smṛtam /
column2: Sacrificial rites, penance and charity are known to be of three varieties due to the three qualities, sattva etc.

column1: āyuḥ sattvaṃ balārogyasukhāyānnantu sāttvikaṃ //
column2: The food that augments life, purity, strength, health and pleasure is known to be sāttvika.

column1: duḥkhaśokāmayāyānnaṃ tīkṣṇarūkṣantu rājasaṃ /
column2: The food that is pungent and dry and productive of pain, grief and disease is rājasa.

column1: amedhyocchiṣṭapūtyannaṃ tāmasaṃ nīrasādikaṃ //
column2: The food that is impure, rejected, putrid and tasteless is said to be tāmasa.

column1: yaṣṭavyo vidhinā yajño niṣkāmāya sa sāttvikaḥ /
column2: The sacrificial rite is said to be sāttvika if it is performed as laid down without desiring reward.

column1: yajñaḥ phalāya dambhātmī rājasastāmasaḥ kratuḥ //
column2: A sacrifice is rajasa, if it is done for the sake of gaining a fruit. If it is for vanity it is tāmasa.

column1: śraddhāmantrādividhyuktaṃ tapaḥ śārīramucyate /
column2: Physical penance is said to be that which is accompanied by faith, sacred formula and the like.

column1: devādipūjāhiṃsādi vāṅmayaṃ tapa ucyate //
column2: Worship of the gods etc. and noninjury etc. are said to be verbal penance.

column1: anudvegakaraṃ vākyaṃ satyaṃ svādhyāyasajjapaḥ /
column2: A speech that does not cause excitement, truthfulness, practice of the study of the scriptures of one’s own school and sacred repetition are said to be austerity of speech.

column1: mānasaṃ cittasaṃśuddhersaunamātsavinigrahaḥ //
column2: Mental austerity consists of purity of disposition, silence and selfcontrol.

column1: sāttvikañca tapo 'kāmaṃ phalādyarthantu rājasaṃ / tāmasaṃ parapīḍāyai sāttvikaṃ dānamucyate //
column2: The sāttvik austerity is done with no desire for any fruit, the rājasa, with the intention of gaining an object and the tāmasa for harming others. The sāttvika charity is that which is performed at the right place etc.

column1: deśādau caiva dātavyamupakārāya rājasaṃ / ādeśādāvavajñātaṃ tāmasaṃ dānamīritaṃ //
column2: with a sense of duty. Rājasa charity is that performed with a view to receive in return. It is said to be tāmasa when performed at a wrong place and insultingly.

column1: oṃtatsaditi nirdeśo brahmaṇastrividhaḥ smṛtaḥ /
column2: “Oṃ tat sat Oṃ, that and real” has been declared to be the triple designation of Brahman.

column1: yajñadānādika karma buktimuktipradaṃ nṛṇāṃ //
column2: Sacrificial rites, charity and such other deeds confer enjoyment and emancipation to men.

column1: aniṣṭamiṣṭaṃ miśrañca trividhaṃ karmaṇaḥ phalaṃ / bhavatyatyāgināṃ pretya na tu sannyāsināṃ kvacit //
column2: The threefold fruit of actiondisagreeable, agreeable and mixedaccrues after death to a person who does not relinquish karma but never to those who renounce.

column1: tāmasaḥ karmasaṃyogāt mohātkleśabhayādikāt / rājasaḥ sāttviko 'kāmāt pañcaite karmahetavaḥ //
column2: The tāmasika action arises from an action associated with delusion, the rājasa action from pain, fear etc., and the sāttvika from nondesire.

column1: adhiṣṭhānaṃ tathā kartā karaṇañca pṛthagvidham / trividhāś ca pṛthak ceṣṭā daivañcaivātra pañcamaṃ //
column2: These following five are the five causes of an actionthe body, the agent, the various instruments such as the senses, the different functions of various sorts and the presiding deity, the fifth.

column1: ekaṃ jñānaṃ sāttvikaṃ syāt pṛthag jñānantu rājasaṃ /
column2: The knowledge that everything is one is sāttvika. The knowledge that it is separate is rājasa.

column1: atattvārthantāmasaṃ syāt karmākāmāya sāttvikaṃ //
column2: That which is contrary to reality is tāmasa. The Sāttvika action is without any desire.

column1: kāmāya rājasaṃ karma mohāt karma tu tāmasaṃ /
column2: The rājasa action is with desire. The tāmasa action is from igno rance.

column1: sīdhyasiddhyoḥ samaḥ kartā sāttviko rājaso 'tyapi //
column2: A Sāttvika agent would be equanimous towards success and failure. A rājasa doer would be deceitful.

column1: śaṭho 'lasastāmasaḥ syāt kāryādidhīś ca sāttvikī /
column2: A tāmasa doer would be languid. The understanding at the beginning of an action is sāttvikī.

column1: kāryārthaṃ sā rājasī syādviparītā tu tāmasī //
column2: That which is only at the time of an action would be rājasī. The contrary would be tāmasī.

column1: manodhṛtiḥ sāttvikī syāt prītikāmeti rājasī /
column2: The firmness of mind towards pleasure and pain etc. would be sāttvikī. The desire of the mind for satisfaction is rājasī.

column1: tāmasī tu praśokādau mukhaṃ sattvāttadantagaṃ //
column2: is tāmasī. There would be pleasure at the beginning from sattva.

column1: sukhaṃ tadrājasañcāgre ante duḥkhantu tāmasaṃ /
column2: The pleasure that comes at the end is rājasa. Pain at the beginning and end is tāmasa.

column1: ataḥ pravṛttirbhūtānāṃ yena sarvamidantataṃ //
column2: All the beings had their origin from that by which this universe has been pervaded.

column1: svakarmaṇā tamabhyarcya viṣṇuṃ siddhiñca vindati /
column2: One finds success by worshipping lord Viṣṇu by one’s action.

column1: karmaṇā manasā vācā sarvāvasthāsu sarvadā // brahmādistambhaparyantaṃ jagadviṣṇuñca vetti yaḥ /
column2: A person who knows the world from Brahmā to a tuft of grass as lord Viṣṇu by means of his action, mind and speech in all the states gains success always.

column1: siddhimāpnoti bhagavadbhakto bhāgavato dhruvaṃ //
column2: The devotee of the lord would certainly be a bhāgavata.

column1: yamagītāṃ pravakṣyāmi uktā yā nāciketase /
column2: Cf. BG .. shall describe to you the Yamagītā expounded to Naciketas.

column1: paṭhatāṃ śṛṇvatāṃ bhuktyai muktyai mokṣārthināṃ satāṃ //
column2: It would confer enjoyment and emancipation to the pious desiring emancipation who read and listen to this.

column1: āsanaṃ śayanaṃ yānaparidhānagṛhādikam / vāñchatyaho 'timohena susthiraṃ svayamasthiraḥ //
column2: Alas! man himself being noneternal, desires for eternal seats, beds, vehicles, clothes, houses etc.

column1: bhogeṣu śaktiḥ satataṃ tathaivātmāvalokanaṃ / śreyaḥ paraṃ manuṣyānāṃ kapilodgītameva hi //
column2: It has been said by the sage Kapila in olden days that always having nonattachment for pleasures and viewing one’s own self critically are most excellent for men.

column1: sarvatra samadarśitvaṃ nirmasatvamasaṅgatā / śreyaḥ param manuṣyānāṃ gītaṃ pañcaśikhena hi //
column2: The sage Pañcaśikha has said that impartiality to wards all, attitude of nonpossession, not being attached to worldly pleasures are most excellent for men.

column1: āgarbhajanmabālyādivayo 'vasthādivedanaṃ / śreyaḥ paraṃ manuṣyāṇām gaṅgāviṣṇupragītakaṃ //
column2: Gaṅgāviṣṇu has declared that a true knowledge of the miseries of the stages of life beginning with that of embryo and including birth, childhood and old age etc. is most excellent for men.

column1: ādhyātmikādiduḥkhānāmādyantādipratikriyā / śreyaḥ paraṃ manṣyāṇāṃ janakodgītameva ca //
column2: Janaka has stated that remedying the pains such as the ādhyātmika bodily and mental and the like from the beginning to the end is most excellent for men.

column1: abhinnayorbhedakaraḥ pratyayo yaḥ parātmanaḥ / tacchāntiparamaṃ śreyo brahmodgītamudāhṛtaṃ //
column2: Brahmā holds that the most excellent thing for men is to perceive the oneness of the Supreme Being appearing as different in different beings.

column1: kartavyamiti yatkarma ṛgyajuḥsāmasaṃjñitaṃ / kurute śreyase saṅgān jaigīṣavyeṇa gīyate //
column2: Jaigīṣavya has said that the highest good lies in discharging one’s duties as laid down in the Ṛg, Yajur or Sāma veda without attachment and with a sense that they have to be done.

column1: hāniḥ sarvavidhitsānāmātmanaḥ sukhahaitukī / śreyaḥ paraṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ devalodgītamīritaṃ //
column2: Devala is said to hold the view that the most excellent thing for men would be to abandon all actions for the sake of the happiness of the self.

column1: kāmatyāgāttu vijñānaṃ sukhaṃ brahma paraṃ padaṃ / kāmināṃ na hi vijñānaṃ sanakodgītameva tat //
column2: Sage Sanaka has declared that the knowledge gained from renunciation of desires leads one to Brahman, the supreme place, and that those who entertain desires do not get this knowledge.

column1: pravṛttañca nivṛttañca kāryaṃ karmaparo 'bravīt / śreyasāṃ śreya etaddhi naiṣkarmyaṃ brahma taddhariḥ //
column2: Lord Hari has said that the foremost among the excellent is to transform the actions done with attachment into those of nonattachment. This is verily nonaction, the Brahman.

column1: pumāṃścādhigatajñāno bhedaṃ nāpnoti sattamaḥ / brahmaṇā viṣṇusaṃjñena parameṇāvyayena ca //
column2: The elevated person who has gained knowledge does not become different from Brahman, known as lord Viṣṇu, the supreme and indestructible.

column1: jñānaṃ vijñānamāstikyaṃ saubhāgyaṃ rūpamuttamam / tapasā labhyate sarvaṃ manasā yadyadicchati //
column2: A person would gain by doing austerities whatever he mentally desires such as knowledge of Brahman, knowledge of worldly existence, faith in god, good fortune and a beautiful form.

column1: nāsti viṣṇusamandhyeyaṃ tapo nānaśanātparaṃ /
column2: There is nothing to be contemplated equal to lord Viṣṇu. There is no austerity superior to fasting.

column1: nāstyārogyasamaṃ dhanyaṃ nāsti gaṅgāsamā sarit //
column2: There is no fortune equal to health. There is no river equal to the river Gaṅgā.

column1: na so 'sti bāndhavaḥ kaścidviṣṇuṃ muktvā jagadguruṃ /
column2: There is no kinsman other than lord Viṣṇu, the lord of the universe.

column1: adhaścordhaṃ hariścāgre dehendriyamanomukhe // ityevaṃ saṃsmaran prāṇān yastyajetsa harirbhavet /
column2: A person who meditates on lord Hari as existing below, above, in front and in the body, senses, mind etc. and passes away would become lord Hari.

column1: yattad brahma yataḥ sarvaṃ yatsarvaṃ tasya saṃsthitam //
column2: That which is the Brahman, from that all the things have emanated and in that all the things exist.

column1: parāparasvarūpeṇa viṣṇuḥ sarvahṛdi sthitaḥ //
column2: Lord Viṣṇu dwells in the hearts of all in the form of higher and lower, as ununderstandable, indefinable and wellestablished.

column1: yajñeśaṃ yajñapuruṣaṃ kecidicchanti tatparaṃ / kecidviṣṇuṃ haraṃ kecit kecid brahmāṇamīśvaraṃ //
column2: Some people invoke that lord Viṣṇu as the lord of sacrifices. Some invoke Him as lord Hari, some as lord Hara Śiva and some others as Brahmā.

column1: indrādināmabhiḥ kecit sūryaṃ somañca kālakam /
column2: Some invoke Him by the names of Indra etc. and others as Sun, Moon and as the eternal time.

column1: brahmādistambhaparyantaṃ jagadviṣṇuṃ vadanti ca //
column2: People state that the whole earth, from Brahmā to a tuft of grass, is Viṣṇu.

column1: sa viṣṇuḥ paramaṃ brahma yato nāvartate punaḥ /
column2: A person who has attained lord Viṣṇu, the Supreme Brahman, never returns to worldly existence.

column1: suvarṇādimahādānapuṇyatīrthāvagāhanaiḥ // dhyānair vrataiḥ pūjayā ca dharmaśrutyā tadāpnuyāt /
column2: A man may acquire such a state by making great gifts such as gold, bathing in sacred waters, meditation, austerities, worship, wealth and listening to sacred texts.

column1: ātmānaṃ rathinaṃ viddhi śarīraṃ rathameva tu // buddhintu sārathiṃ viddhi manaḥ pragrahameva ca /
column2: Know the soul as traveller, the body as chariot, intellect as charioteer and mind as reins.

column1: indrayāṇi hayānāhurviṣayāṃśceṣugocarān //
column2: The senses are said to be horses and the objects the pasture ground for them.

column1: ātmendriyamanoyuktaṃ bhoktetyāhurmanīṣiṇaḥ / yastvavijñānavān bhavatyayuktena manasā sadā // na satpadamavāpnoti saṃsārañcādhigacchati /
column2: People name the soul united with the mind and senses as the enjoyer. He who is not wise and whose mind is not always associated with the soul, does not reach the Supreme Brahman and is born in the world.

column1: yastu vijñānavān bhavati yuktena manasā sadā // sa tatpadamavāpnoti yasmādbhūyo na jāyate /
column2: He who is wise and whose mind is united with the soul always, attains the place of Brahman and is not born in this world again.

column1: vijñānasārathiryastu manaḥpragrahavānnaraḥ // so 'dhvānaṃ paramāpnoti tadviṣṇoḥ paramaṃ padam /
column2: A person who has knowledge as the charioteer and mind as the reins, reaches the end of his journey and gets the highest region of lord Viṣṇu.

column1: indriyebhyaḥ parā hy arthā arthebhyaś ca paraṃ manaḥ // manasastu parā buddhiḥ buddherātmā mahān paraḥ /
column2: The objects of senses are higher than the respective organs the mind is higher than the objects the intellect is higher than the mind the self is higher than the intellect and the principle of mahat is higher than the self.

column1: mahataḥ paramavyaktamavyaktātpuruṣaḥ paraḥ // puruṣānna paraṃ kiñcit sā kāṣṭhā sā parā gatiḥ /
column2: The unmanifest is higher than the mahat. The Puruṣa the spirit is higher than the unmanifest. There is nothing higher than the Supreme Spirit. It is the ultimate end and course.

column1: eṣu sarveṣu bhūteṣu gūḍhātmā na prakāśate //
column2: This self hidden in all the bodies does not reveal itself.

column1: dṛśyate tvagryayā budhyā sūkṣmayā sūkṣmadarśibhiḥ /
column2: The subtle one is perceived by men having sharp intellect and subtle vision.

column1: yacchedvāṅmanasī prājñaḥ tadyacchejjñānamātmani // jñānamātmani mahati niyacchecchānta ātmani /
column2: A wiseman should restrain his speech in the mind, that knowledge in the self, that knowledge in the great self and place it at the end in the self.

column1: jñātvā brahmātmanoryogaṃ yamādyair brahma sadbhavet //
column2: After having known the union of Brahman and the self by means of moral duties etc., one would become Brahman.

column1: ahiṃsā satyamasteyaṃ brahmacaryāparigrahau /
column2: Noninjury, truthfulness.

column1: yamāś ca niyamāḥ pañca śaucaṃ santoṣasattapaḥ // svādhyāyeśvarapūjā ca āsanaṃ padmakādikaṃ /
column2: Tḥe niyamas abservances are fivepurity, happiness, austerity, study of the Veda of one’s school and worship of God. The physical postures are such as the padmaka etc.

column1: prāṇāyāmo vāyujayaḥ pratyāhāraḥ svanigrahaḥ //
column2: Prāṇāyāma is conquest of wind. Pratyāhāra is the restraining of the mind in the self.

column1: śubhe hy ekatra viṣaye cetaso yat pradhāraṇaṃ /
column2: Dhāraṇā consists of fixing of the mind on an auspicious object.

column1: niś calatvāttu dhīmadbhirdhāraṇā dvija kathyate //
column2: O Twiceborn! It is said to be the dhāraṇā by the wise because the mind is steady.

column1: dhyānaṃ smṛtaṃ samādhistu ahaṃ brahmātmasaṃsthitiḥ //
column2: The continuous fixingup of the mind in the same place is known as dhyāna contemplation. Samādhi is the state of having the attitude “ am Brahman”.

column1: ghaṭadhvaṃsādyathākāśamabhinnaṃ nabhasā bhavet / mukto jīvo brahmaṇaivaṃ sadbrahma brahma vai bhavet //
column2: Just as the space enclosed by a pitcher becomes one with the sky when the pitcher is destroyed, in the same way the liberated soul becomes Brahman.

column1: ātmānaṃ manyate brahma jīvo jñānena nānyathā /
column2: The individual soul deems itself as Brahman by means of knowledge alone and not by any other means.

column1: jīvo hy ajñānatatkāryamuktaḥ syādajarāmaraḥ //
column2: The individual soul gets released from ignorance and its effect and becomes undecaying and immortal.
